column2: To the Sports Editor: Clinton Portis of the Washington Redskins apologized after saying in a radio interview that when female reporters enter N.F.L. locker rooms, both sides have wandering eyes.

SUMBERG--Tania Kleid, beloved wife of the late Lewis Kleid and the late Mike Sumberg. Loving mother of Roger, Lynne, Kerry, adoring grandmother of Chris, Jessica, and Lewis, great-grandmother of Tegan, sister of Linda and stepmother to John, Andy and Daniel. Pianist, painter and generous loving friend to many. We will miss her warm presence in our lives.

OnStar is officially joining the ''there's an app for that'' generation. Until now, the hallmark of OnStar's connected car services was that there was a person at the other end of the voice connection. But on Wednesday, the company revealed more details about its coming MyLink interface that will run popular smartphone apps, like Facebook and Pandora, on a computer system in cars.

BECAUSE buying a camel coat and a shearling jacket this season just wasn't an option, we chose the latter, inspired mainly by the photograph at right. Something about the warmth and tossed-on ease appealed to us, and apparently everyone else: Acne's oversize aviator -- a big bearhug of a jacket -- flew out of both the New York shop and Net-a-porter the week it arrived. As of now, neither store plans to restock it, but both are selling similar styles, like an Arctic cream version at Acnestudio.com. Pair it with jeans and a T-shirt and shiny red lips, and as far as we're concerned, you're set for fall. Acne Velocite oversize shearling, $2,250; similar styles available at net-a-porter.com and acnestudios.com. Chanel Rouge Allure lip gloss, $32 at Chanel .com.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Open and CBS Ponder Their Losses During Interminable Wait for Winner,'' Sept. 14: Rafael Nadal, garnering a career Grand Slam at 24 with his victory at the United States Open on Monday night, deserved a great deal more respect from CBS and ESPN2 than he received during the broadcast of his delayed final against Novak Djokovic.

HUDSON--William Hoffman, a resident of Dallas, Texas died in Dallas on Sunday, September 5th, 2010, age 80 of complications of prostate cancer. His passions were quail hunting and his love for the game of polo. Mr. Hudson was born in Oklahoma City on October 24, 1929 into a family with deep American roots. The family of his paternal grandmother founded Hartford Colony. His maternal grandmother's family, the Elder John Strong, arrived in America in 1630 on the "Mary and John." His grandfather was Major General Roy Hoffman, an aide to General Pershing in the First World War. General Hoffman received the Legion of Honor from Marshall Foch, the highest honor given to a soldier who is not in the French army. His father, Hubert R. Hudson, had owned the Oklahoma Ada & Atoka Railroad; a friend of Mr. Hudson's, Steven Bechtel saved the railroad from bankruptcy when his construction company rebuilt the two major railroad bridges that had been wiped out by the ravages from flooding. Subsequently, Mr. Hudson sold the railroad prior to the crash of 1929 to the Ingersoll brothers of Philadelphia. William Hudson attended Culver Military Academy in Indiana and Williams College, Massachusetts. His freshman year, he arrived at college with four feisty and agile polo ponies, which necessitated finding like-minded students who also wanted to have a polo team. Mr. Hudson's ponies were not his; he had played polo at the Broadmoor in Colorado Springs, Colorado, where his family had summered for two years. There he was taught to play polo by Lawrence Phipps, of Littleton, Colorado, who gave him four of his ponies to have for his years at Williams. Upon graduating from Williams (where he only started studying in his fourth year when he discovered "with surprise, how much his professors had to teach him"), Mr. Hudson decided to enlist in the army because of the Korean War. He was sent to the camp at De Ridder, Louisiana along with thousands of soldiers in preparation for going to Korea. Because he ranked first in the camps evaluation test, he was sent to OCS (Officers Candidate School). After returning from Korea with the rank of Captain, he resumed his interest in polo, spending the next ten years playing polo in America and Europe; in Italy, with Harry Cushing who was captain of the American team and then onto Madrid, Spain where he became close friends with Perico Domecq, and in Deauville, France with Baron Elie de Rothschild, whose team featured the three famous Gracida brothers from Mexico. As each spring turned to summer, Mr. Hudson would move on to England, where the captain of the American team, George Sherman, and his friend Allan Corey, a ten goal player from Westbury, LI invited him to join their team. In England the matches were with Prince Philip, who was captain of the British team. On his return to the United States, in Dallas Mr. Hudson founded the Lone Oak Polo Club, which hosted the first high goal polo tournaments in Dallas where Mr. Hudson was a driving force in Dallas polo; he knew only one speed, and that was faster. Bill Hudson was a veteran of the oil and gas business for over 50 years. He began his career at Tri-State Natural Gas Company, eventually becoming president, where he developed a significant portion of the San Juan field in New Mexico. His wildcatting spirit led to the discovery of the Rocanville field in Saskatchewan. He was also chairman of the American Stock Exchange - listed GNC Energy Corporation and president of TJ Service Company, a contract drilling company with a fleet of 27 rigs. He was Director of the Colorado Rocky Mountain School, Director and President of the Dallas Opera, and member of the Brook Hollow Golf Club, the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, and Doubles. An enthusiastic and avid tennis player where he excelled. Despite his difficult last year, Mr. Hudson exhibited grace, dignity and his inimitable sense of humor while comforted by his family and friends. Mr. Hudson was predeceased by his parents Dorothy and Hubert R. Hudson and his brother Hubert R. Hudson, Jr. He is survived by his beloved wife Cathy, his children Andrew Hudson, Chris Hudson, Eugenia King and her husband Frank Paul, Courtney Nyhuis, his step children Callie Kincaid, Maggie Kincaid, and Sam Kincaid, Lindsay Ganz and her husband Jason. He is also survived by his former wife, Betty Hudson, his sister in NYC Caroline Hudson Firestone, and five grandchildren. A memorial service was held in Dallas, Texas, and a private memorial service will be held in New York City in October.

BABCOCK--John Bodine, of Amenia, NY and Jupiter Island, FL, died on September 17, 2010, after a long illness. He was 85 years old. Mr. Babcock had a long successful career in the magazine business. Beginning in the early 1950's at McGraw Hill, Inc. and ending in the 1990's as a publishing consultant. He spent over 20 years at the American Business Press, Inc., where, as president, he was the force behind the merger of the controlled (freely) circulated magazine association with the paid circulated ABP group. Later, Mr. Babcock co-founded Kobak Business Models, Inc., a provider of software solutions to magazine publishers, and he consulted on many magazine start-ups during his career. He also owned Industrial Design magazine in the 1980's. And he served on the boards of the Ad Council and the Killdonan School. Born in Schenectady, NY and raised in New York City, Mr. Babcock attended The Hotchkiss School and Yale College. He received his B.A. from Columbia University. He was a veteran of World War II and the Battle of the Bulge. Mr. Babcock is survived by his wife of 64 years, Mary Lois Scheerer Babcock, sons, John Babcock, Jr. and Frederick Babcock, daughter Joanne Wilmerding. Daughter, Linda Wilson predeceased him. He is also survived by 10 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. The Babcocks lived for many years in West Orange, NJ; in the mid 1960's they moved to Sharon, CT, eventually settled on a farm in Stanfordville, NY. In lieu of flowers, Maplebrook School, Amenia, NY. Service at St. Peters Church, Lithgow, NY September 25th at 11am.
Cambridge, Mass. IMAGINE you are a venture capitalist. One day a man comes to you and says, ''I want to build the game layer on top of the world.''

INSPIRE magazine, an English-language journal published by Al Qaeda, included in its summer edition what amounted to a ''Friends and Foes'' list. There, on Page 4, following the letter from the editor (''We survive through jihad and perish without it''), were pictures of, and quotations from, kindred spirits like Faisal Shahzad, who pleaded guilty in a plot to detonate a car bomb in Times Square, and, perhaps surprisingly, David Letterman, who was praised for recent criticism of former President George W. Bush. Among the magazine's ''foes'' were Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates; Nicolas Sarkozy, the president of France; and King Abdullah II of Jordan. Then there was Mitchell D. Silber, a studious and mild-mannered former financier who grew up in Atlantic Beach, N.Y.

GILBERT--Clifford S.,passed away on September 17, 2010 in Phoenix, Arizona. He was forty-five years of age. Born November 17, 1964, he was the son of Thomas and Rosann Gilbert of Manhattan. Clifford made many people laugh, he had a big heart and was a gentle soul. Trained as a mechanic, he repaired all types of engines and was a master of his trade. Moreover, he had a deep appreciation for the magic of music. Clifford will be missed by all of the friends he made in Hollywood and elsewhere. Clifford is survived by his father and stepmother, Marjorie Gilbert, of Purchase, NY; a step-brother Douglas Gorlin of Hollywood, CA; a step-brother Bill Gorlin and his wife Natalie of Briarcliff, NY; a step-sister Wendy Tayer and her husband Marc of Del Mar, CA; by his five nieces and nephews, Madeleine, Melanie and Jason Tayer and Richard and Michael Gorlin. He was predeceased by his mother and his brother, Evan Gilbert. The family is having a private funeral service at Kensico Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. The Gilberts are receiving visitors at their home in Purchase, NY on Thursday, September 23, from 5-7 pm.

In the late 19th century, it wasknown as the Chicago Butter an dEgg Board. Now, as the CME Group, it has fast become one o fthe largest futures exchanges inthe world. In 2007, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange merged with the Chicago Board of Trade, taking the CME Group name.The next year, CME absorbed the New York Mercantile Exchange.The combined entities trade in agricultural crops, dairy products,lumber, cocoa, coffee, oil, weather futures, foreign currency, credit default swaps, gold, silver, equity indexes and long bonds to name a few. Today most trading is done via the exchange's Globex electronic trading system. But 15 percent is still conducted ina pit where traders shout and gesticulate. Electronic trading maybe sleeker and faster, but the openoutcry system with its face-to-face drama and longstanding traditions definitely hasmore visual appeal.

An article on Sept. 5 about the Manhattan nightspot Max's Kansas City misstated the professional background of Danny Fields, who used to frequent the club and take photographs there. He was a music executive, not a music producer, from the 1960s to the 1980s.
GERSON--Ivan. Dad is with you in heaven. Rest in peace. We love and miss you. Mom and Adrienne

T: MEN'S FASHION Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the singer Harry Nilsson misstated his connection to the song ''Without You.'' While he covered the song, he did not write it. (Pete Ham and Tom Evans of the band Badfinger were the writers.) (Go to Article)

METROPOLITAN An article in some editions last Sunday about the Fall Festival at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, scheduled to open on Friday in Katonah, N.Y., misstated the nature of a benefit for Caramoor's historic Rosen House. It is a dinner, not a performance. (Go to Article)

The New York spring fashion shows of more than 300 designers, which ended on Thursday, were about the possibilities of dressing. Fashion, per se, is definitely not art; it is an elegant hybrid of craft and commerce to beautify the human body. But on rare occasions, the work of designers can be classified as a minor art form, especially when put together artfully by a wearer. Top row, guests at the shows who created tasteful and refined looks through their use of color and proportion. Bottom row, wearable art: a man wore a different suit om each day of the shows. He'd had them tailored from painter's canvas and then had an artist paint them after posters from the Belle Époque. In between these two extremes were many suggestions of fashion to come: full skirts, hot pants and the futuristic prints of the late Alexander McQueen. For many of the guests, the shows are a time to dress up; two were resplendent in their Native American turquoise and silver jewelry. The move of a third of the shows to Lincoln Center from Bryant Park proved a huge success with its luxury of space. Nearly 200 designers showed in other locations throughout the city.
A roundup of the week's laugh lines last Sunday misattributed a joke about Sarah Palin's use of the words ''insensitive'' and ''provocation.'' It was by David Letterman, not Jay Leno.

PARKER--Rolland S.,PhD, neuropsychologist, 81, died on September 9, 2010 of cancer. Founder and former President of the New York Academy of Traumatic Brain Injury, Adjunct Professor of Clinical Neurology at the NYU School of Medicine and a scholar, the author of many professional books and articles, photographer and music lover. He is mourned by Irmgard, his wife of many years, his family and friends.

THE $10 million Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize, the competition to create fuel-efficient vehicles that ended last week with three winners, would have appeared to favor all the technology and finesse that goes with electric vehicles. But Oliver Kuttner succeeded by using the same nitty-gritty approach that once led him to rebuild a Corvette engine in his college dorm room.

Some of the top trends from Saturday's games: 500 FOR PATERNOPenn State's victory over Kent State was the 500th for the Nittany Lions since Joe Paterno, left, joined the staff as an assistant in 1950. It was Paterno's 396th victory as a head coach.

I HAVE been fond of apples and apple trees for as long as I can remember. I grew up with a crab apple tree in front of our apartment in Flushing, Queens, which my Manhattan-born mother misidentified as a cherry blossom tree. At the start of every spring and autumn, I was beguiled by the dense cluster of flowers and fruit I saw through our living room window. Trees in the Malus genus, including crab apple and wild apple, produce abundant fruit, and this time of year even a short stroll through the city is an exercise in falling fruit. I was recently standing under a gorgeous specimen on Staten Island, admiring its sizable apples, when I was hit on the head by one, like some textbook lesson in gravity.

c. 1650 Horn-book Wooden paddles with printed lessons were popular through the colonial era. c. 1890 School slate Widely used throughout the 19th century, it was praised by a Boston school superintendent in 1870 this way: ''If the result of the work should, at any time, be found infelicitous, a sponge will readily banish from the slate all disheartening recollections, and leave it free for new attempts.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Chasing Federer, or Pulling Away?'' Sept. 13: Some of Harvey Araton's comments about Roger Federer strike me as condescending, if not cruel: ''probably spared a deflating and defining beatdown''; ''we can wait another year before writing off Federer as a serious contender at the Slams''; ''a healthy Nadal has the goods to restore the rivalry to full historical bloom by the time Federer is gone from the sport, playing family doubles with his wife and twin girls.''

A Memorial Service will be held Saturday September 25, 2010 at 5pm, St. Andrew's Dune Church with a reception to follow at The Meadow Club. Memorial gifts in his honor to Southampton Hospital, 240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968.

At least six people were killed on Saturday when the driver of a church van with 13 adult passengers lost control and crashed in the northbound lanes of the New York State Thruway near Woodbury, N.Y., the authorities said. The crash occurred shortly before 3 p.m., at Mile Marker 50.9, between Exits 16 and 17, said State Trooper Jeffrey Salatel, in the agency's communications unit.

The five most e-mailed articles from nytimes.com/sports for Sept. 11 to 17. 1. SUICIDE REVEALS SIGNS OF A DISEASE SEEN IN N.F.L. A brain autopsy of a University of Pennsylvania football player who killed himself discovered early stages of chronic traumatic encephalopathy.

PORTLAND, Me. -- Apparently it is not so easy to find a permanent home for a resident that weighs tens of thousands of tons and is more than 1,000 feet long. The John F. Kennedy, an aircraft carrier christened by a 9-year-old Caroline Kennedy in 1967 and decommissioned three years ago, needs a place to retire. The Navy wants to donate it. If no viable host can be found, the carrier that aided United States military operations in Beirut and Operation Desert Storm will be turned into scrap.

SOBELMAN--George, Rehovot, Israel-Jewish scholar, passionate lover of the Hebrew language and state of Israel, and Judaic scholarship. Assistant Rabbi at Cornell's Hillel Foundation 1965-69, Rabbi at Wesleyan University, Connecticut 1969-73. Nina's husband, loving, energetic grandfather of eight. Our Georgie was 67.

TAFFNER--Eleanor. Our entire Lenox Hill Hospital family deeply mourns the loss of our beloved Trustee, Eleanor Taffner. Eleanor and her loving husband, Donald, were dedicated and generous supporters, for many years, of our Hospital and mission. Eleanor was a woman of considerable strength and abilities and her great dignity, keen intelligence and warm grace were apparent to all who were privileged to know her. We celebrate Eleanor's life and honor her memory. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband Donald, her children and grandchildren. William O. Hiltz, Chairman, Executive Committee Gladys George, President Lenox Hill Hospital

An envelope containing the N.B.A.'s referee schedule arrived in Steve Javie's mailbox the other day, as it has every September for the last 25 years. This one felt different. ''It felt like Christmas Eve,'' Javie said gleefully. ''I didn't know if I would get one again.''
GAUGER--Ruth C. Age 82, loving wife of Daniel, mother of Ann and Daniel Jr. Memorial service in Virginia, Tuesday, 16 November. Full obituary and on-line guest book at www.Flintofts.com

The Streetscapes column on Aug. 22 about Terminal City, a development around Grand Central Terminal, misstated the location of the old Hotel Chatham. It was on Vanderbilt Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets -- not on Park Avenue.

ELKIND--Charlotte Woods, died on September 14, 2010 at the age of 84. Adored wife for 59 years of Morton Digby Elkind who died last month, she was a devoted mother to Elisabeth, Sam and Margaret, and a loving grandmother to Cordelia and Miranda Alquist, Eric and Will Van Gelder and Alexandra Elkind. Born in Evanston, IL, she graduated from the University of Rochester in 1947 and received MAs from Columbia and NYU. She worked at the Institute for International Education where she organized a union and helped negotiate the first contract, taught history at Packer and was an associate graduate dean at Long Island University, Brooklyn for 28 years. Memorial service: Friday, October 29th, 1pm, Green-Wood Cemetery Chapel, Brooklyn.

Q.I'm planning a trip to Machu Picchu in late September and early October. I'm interested in making this a safe but adventurous trip. I will be traveling to Peru with my adult son. Neither of us speaks Spanish. Linda Fletcher, Lansing, Mich.A.First, it's important to note that Machu Picchu has imposed a daily limit on the number of trekkers to the site. This means it's essential to plan well ahead. That said, the famous Inca ruins can be reached in several ways. The easiest and most common route, but still adventurous, is by train from Cuzco (a 20-minute taxi ride to Poroy station) to Aguas Calientes (allow a day or two in Cuzco to acclimatize to the altitude).

SEGAL--Marvin B.,84, passed away peacefully in Manhattan on July 4, 2010. He leaves behind his wife of 27 years Eleanor and his son Lukas Horn. Born in 1926 in Philadelphia, a graduate of Haverford College and Yale Law School, he served in the Army Air Corps during World War II, and as an Assistant United States Attorney in Washington, D.C. After going into private practice, Marv represented a long and varied group of clients at his firm Segal & Hundley. His most famous case was as the attorney defending former Attorney General John Mitchell during his Watergate trail in 1974-75. Marv was a gentleman of the highest order, a loving husband and father, a man of diverse interests and insightful viewpoints, and a generous, faithful friend. He will be missed greatly by all who knew him. Memorial service to follow.

Toyota has reached an out-of-court settlement with relatives of a family killed when the Lexus sedan they were driving sped out of control and crashed, an accident that put a national spotlight on the sudden acceleration problems that later prompted the automaker to recall millions of vehicles. Toyota confirmed the settlement Saturday in a statement but did not provide the amount of the settlement or any other details.

KLINGON--Judith M. Born February 28, 1931 in Cowansville, Quebec, Canada. Died September 7, 2010, peacefully and at home in New York City following a brief illness. Beloved wife for 55 years of Gerald H. Klingon, M.D. and mother of Karen L. Klingon (Jerry Middleton) and Robert M. Klingon. Cherished long-time friend to many. Judy was a people person who loved family get-togethers and dates with friends. She was an ardent fan of theater, museums, architecture, music, and design. Upbeat, generous, and fun, she had a great sense of humor and enjoyed making others happy. She will be sorely missed. There will be a gathering to celebrate Judy's life in October. Please consult the family on donations to charity.

WAY--Alva O. International business leader and beloved husband of Eleonore Way and father of Cynthia, Karin, and Peter, died on September 15 at the age of 81. A native of Schenectady, New York, Al Way served two years in the army and graduated from Brown University with a B.A. in economics in 1951. Al Way's career took him to the pinnacle of some of America's major corporations. He began his career at General Electric Corporation, working in various financial positions in the U.S., Latin America, and Europe. In 1970, he became Vice President of Honeywell Information Systems. Three years later, he rejoined General Electric as Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, serving also on G.E.'s Corporate Policy Committee. He was pivotal in establishing GE Capital. In 1979, he accepted the position of Vice Chairman of the American Express Company and in 1981 was named President of American Express, serving also as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of American Express International Banking Corporation. He went on to become President, Director, and Chairman of the Travelers Corporation in 1983 and also served as Chairman of its Investment Committee. In 1985, he was named Chairman of the Board of IBJ Schroder Bank & Trust Company in New York and was also a consultant to and director of Schroders plc in London. Well-known for his sound judgment and insight, he served as Director of Dayton Hudson, Eli Lilly, Gould, The Guidant Corporation, the Fireman's Fund, McGraw Hill, Ryder System, and Warner Amex Cable Communications. He was a Trustee of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, the Committee for Economic Development, and the Conference Board. Al Way was especially passionate about education and deeply grateful for the opportunities that his education at Brown University provided him. He expressed his deep commitment to Brown by serving for 31 years on Brown's corporation--as Chancellor for nine years, Fellow for 11 years, and Trustee for 11 years. As Chancellor, he presided over the Campaign for the Rising Generation, which raised over $527 million, at the time the largest fundraising effort in the university's history. In 1991, he received an Honorary Doctorate in Law from Brown and in 1992 the Independent Award, which acknowledged his self-reliance, integrity, and vision. In 1997, the university established the Alva Way Professorship in his honor. He generously supported numerous charities in education, medicine, and the arts. He is survived by his wife Eleonore; sister Ruth Senior (widow of Bruce Senior); brother Paul Way (husband of Terri Way); former sister-in-law Carol Way; his children Peter Way (husband of Frances Way), Karin LaPann (wife of David LaPann), and Cynthia Way; and his grandchildren Brian LaPann, Kathryn LaPann, Monica Way, Daniel Way, and Julia Way. Swan Funeral Home in Old Saybrook, CT will be handling the service. A memorial will be held at Brown University. In lieu of flowers, donations may be offered to the Margaret S. Way Scholarship at Brown University (Box 1877, Providence, RI, 02912) or Middlesex Hospital and Weiss Hospice Unit (28 Crescent St, Middletown, CT, 06457 Attn: Office of Philanthropy).

In an experiment published last month, researchers recruited schoolchildren, ages 9 and 10, who lived near the Champaign-Urbana campus of the University of Illinois and asked them to run on a treadmill. The researchers were hoping to learn more about how fitness affects the immature human brain. Animal studies had already established that, when given access to running wheels, baby rodents bulked up their brains, enlarging certain areas and subsequently outperforming sedentary pups on rodent intelligence tests. But studies of the effect of exercise on the actual shape and function of children's brains had not yet been tried. So the researchers sorted the children, based on their treadmill runs, into highest-, lowest- and median-fit categories. Only the most- and least-fit groups continued in the study (to provide the greatest contrast). Both groups completed a series of cognitive challenges involving watching directional arrows on a computer screen and pushing certain keys in order to test how well the children filter out unnecessary information and attend to relevant cues. Finally, the children's brains were scanned, using magnetic resonance imaging technology to measure the volume of specific areas.

The Kansas City Royals used two pitchers against the Oakland Athletics on Monday. The starter was Luke Hochevar, and the reliever was Bryan Bullington. They each began their professional careers as the No. 1 overall pick in the draft. The A's started Bobby Cramer, 30, a former substitute math teacher and utility worker making his major league debut. Naturally, Cramer tossed five and a third strong innings for a well-earned victory. What a game.

DASHEFSKY--Joseph H.,of Highland Beach, FL and Massapequa Park, NY died September 11, 2010. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Dedicated orthopedic surgeon, pioneer in arthroscopy, creative inventor, ardent Zionist. Zichrono L'vracho.

BONCHICK--Robert Ellis 10/36-9/18/05 You are gone five years now. But you will forever be in my heart. I walk and talk with you every day. You are a part of my soul. I miss my best friend. Annise

PARROT--David Gray, of Fort Lauderdale, FL, sailed the final voyage during the early morning hours of September 15, 2010 in Bangor, Maine. David was born April 16th, 1945 in Boston, MA, to Donald Gray Parrot and Margot Howell Parrot of Scarborough ME. In 1981 David founded one of the world's most respected maritime salvage firms, Titan Salvage, a worldwide salvage and wreck removal company headquartered in Pompano Beach, FL. Prior to that, he was a highly respected and well accomplished yacht broker. David was a member of the Cruising Club of America, New York Yacht Club, and International Salvors Union. In addition to his parents Don and Margot, David is survived by his wife Penny Parrot, brother Steven Parrot, sons Robert Hunter Parrot, Christopher Gage Parrot and Jody O'brien, daughter Laurie Beckmann, granddaughters Keeli and Elle O'Brien and grandsons David, Chris and Jason Beckmann and Jeffrey Parrot. There will be a private remembrance held in Hancock, ME, on Saturday September 18th and a memorial service held in Fort Lauderdale at a later date. In lieu of flowers, David's family asks that donations be made to Kids in Distress, 819 NE 26th St, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33305.

While BP plans to permanently abandon its stricken well in the Gulf of Mexico, with little but a plug left at the top, it may yet make use of the reservoir of oil and gas that the well tapped into. Experts say that there are no technical or commercial reasons why BP -- or another company if BP is wary of the political or public-relations repercussions -- could not eventually produce oil from the formation, which BP once estimated contained about 50 million barrels of oil. The well spewed only about one-tenth of that amount, according to government estimates.

BURSON--Bette, 85 years of age, a 56-year Edgemont section of Scarsdale resident and life member of Scarsdale Woman's Club, died September 16, six months after being diagnosed with an inoperable brain tumor. She was married almost 63 years to Harold Burson, founder of the Burson-Marsteller global public relations firm, and mother of two sons, Scott (Wendy Liebow), of Lexington, MA and Mark (Ellen Jones), of Westlake Village, CA. Her grandchildren are Allison and Esther Burson of Lexington and Wynn, Holly and Kelly Burson of Westlake Village. The Scarsdale Woman's Club named its library the Bette Burson Library this past April. She was the club's longtime representative to the Westchester Federation of Woman's Clubs. Earlier, she was a board member of the Center for Preventive Psychiatry, the Edgemont Community Council and a Cub Scout den mother. She travelled extensively with her husband visiting Burson-Marsteller offices and clients on five continents including 30-plus trips to Europe, a dozen to Asia, and several to Australia and Latin America. Born on Manhattan Island, she graduated from Horace Mann School for Girls in 1943 and attended University of North Carolina Woman's College at Greensboro, and Katherine Gibbs School in New York. She was office manager for the predecessor firm to Burson-Marsteller for five years following her marriage on October 30, 1947. For more than 30 years she was a dedicated bowler at the Scarsdale Golf Club and in Westchester County leagues. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Scarsdale Woman's Club, 37 Drake Road, Scarsdale, NY 10583 or Edgemont Scholarship Fund, c/o Edgemont High School, 300 White Oak Lane, Scarsdale, NY 10583.
KOFF--William, 83. Died September 4, 2010. Husband to Susan, father to Zoe and Rebecca. An engineer, a craftsman, and a thinker whose sweet soul and kindness will never be forgotten.

MEXICO CITY -- Two of nine police officers on their way to investigate a killing in southwestern Mexico were found dead on Saturday and the others were missing, the authorities said. The officers, from the Guerrero State Investigative Police, were dispatched Friday to investigate the death and recover a body near El Revelado, a small town more than 300 miles from Acapulco, which is in Guerrero State.

CORPER--Philip Lewis of Stamford, CT, 84, formerly Chappaqua, NY and Wilmette, IL, died on September 3, 2010, at home of natural causes. Predeceased by his wife, Anne Hollingbery Corper, Philip is survived by their children, Debby Corper of Barcelona, Spain; Doug Corper of Wilton, CT; Tom Corper of New York City; Cathy Sullivan of Darien, CT; and 14 grandchildren. Services will be held 11am, Saturday, October 2, Noroton Presbyterian Church, Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent to Boys and Girls Clubs of Northern Westchester.

H AVING created iconic ad campaigns for Balenciaga and Stella McCartney, and imagery for French Vogue, Arena Homme Plus and Interview, Michael Amzalag and Mathias Augustyniak, the graphic design duo known simply as M/M (Paris), are well-known forces in the fashion world. But these days you ain't nobody until you have your own fragrance. As such, their latest project is a bottle of perfume, created in collaboration with the Swedish fragrance house Byredo. Called M/Mink, it is inspired by Japanese calligraphy and contains notes of patchouli, honey, amber and adoxal, an ingredient used in detergents. It is, as M/M (Paris) put it, ''a truly unusual and unique composition.'' Of course, given Mr. Amzalag and Mr. Augustyniak's day jobs, the perfume also has a series of striking ads, composed of photos by Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, smeared with ink.

"There will come a time," Frank Zappa sang, "when everybody who is lonely will be free to sing and dance and love." And there will come a time, he vowed, "when you can even take your clothes off when you dance." Until then, the city of Baltimore has found a more traditional way to honor Zappa, the genre-bending avant-garde rock musician who was born in Baltimore and died in 1993, with a bust in his likeness that was dedicated there on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. In a ceremony timed to the 25th anniversary of Zappa's Senate testimony, at which he compared the labeling of explicit records to censorship, and attended by Zappa's widow, Gail, his sons, Dweezil and Ahmet, and daughter Diva, as well as Baltimore's mayor, Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, a bust of the mustachioed, pony-tailed Zappa was unveiled atop a 12-foot pole outside the Southeast Anchor Branch of the Enoch Pratt Free Library. It isn't very large, but the bust is a replica of a similar sculpture in Vilnius, Lithuania. The duplicate was donated to Baltimore by the Lithuanian nonprofit organization ZAPPART. "He'd be wildly amused by this," Gail Zappa told The A.P., "because of the absurdity of these guys in Lithuania coming up with this phenomenal sculptor who normally does busts of Stalin."

In an article in the Week in Review section this weekend, I look at the sobering story of Owen Thomas, a junior lineman on the University of Pennsylvania football team. After a sharp and sudden emotional collapse, he committed suicide last spring, and last week researchers at Boston University revealed that a brain autopsy found evidence of chronic traumatic encephalopathy. It's a syndrome seen most often in professional boxers and N.F.L. players - athletes whose brains have been slammed around inside their skulls for decades, leading to a pattern of damage that is linked to depression, loss of impulse control and often suicide.

Let me recommend, once again, Brad DeLong's superb discussion of how it is that people at the 99th percentile, despite making twice what their counterparts made in 1980, feel poorer now than they did then. On reflection, however (and discussion with Robin), it seems to me that there's something Brad didn't say that's worth mentioning -- the change in social norms.

The Toronto International Film Festival's People's Choice Award, a prize that has sometimes served as a bellwether for future success at the Academy Awards, was given on Sunday to "The King's Speech," a feature directed by Tom Hooper, Reuters reported. The film stars Colin Firth as King George VI of Britain, who overcame a nervous stammer to deliver a crucial address on the eve of that country's entrance into World War II, and will be released in the United States by the Weinstein Company later this year. Previous winners of the award, which comes with a prize of about $30,000, have included "Slumdog Millionaire," "Crash" and "American Beauty," all winners of the Oscar for best picture; last year's winner, "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' By Sapphire," was a best picture nominee.

In an epic display of ruthless but necessary judgment, the Guggenheim Museum has announced that it had winnowed the entries for its "YouTube Play, A Biennial of Creative Video" contest to a mere 125 from more than 23,000 online submissions. We're not art critics and we're not even going to pretend that we've watched the 125 selections (which will be reduced to a maximum of 20 top choices on Oct. 21). But there are some very cool films to be found through random wanderings of the competition's official Web site, at youtube.com/play, including, above, Tiffany Shlain's "Yelp," a 21st-century update of Allen Ginsberg's "Howl." New York may need a better health care system, but the infinite expansion of Medicaid is not the answer, Lt. Gov. Richard Ravitch says. In a report to be released today, Mr. Ravitch calls for reining in the program, which now serves one in four state residents and consumes about a third of all the money the state spends - roughly $20 billion a year. Mr. Ravitch, writes Anemona Hartocolis, who covers health issues for The Times, wants to take control of the rate-setting process away from the Legislature and make it harder for middle-class families to qualify, among many other things.

Last week, Twitter began rolling out a big redesign of its Web interface. The company's goal is to keep users from having to click through to other sites to see photos and videos tweeted by members, as well as to encourage more searching of its content. It's also intended to make it easier to follow back-and-forth conversations between others. But even for heavy Twitter users, it can be hard to figure out some of the new design's basic functions.

BABCOCK--John Bodine, of Amenia, NY and Jupiter Island, FL, died on September 17, 2010, after a long illness. He was 85 years old. Mr. Babcock had a long successful career in the magazine business. Beginning in the early 1950's at McGraw Hill, Inc. and ending in the 1990's as a publishing consultant. He spent over 20 years at the American Business Press, Inc., where, as president, he was the force behind the merger of the controlled (freely) circulated magazine association with the paid circulated ABP group. Later, Mr. Babcock co-founded Kobak Business Models, Inc., a provider of software solutions to magazine publishers, and he consulted on many magazine start-ups during his career. He also owned Industrial Design magazine in the 1980's. And he served on the boards of the Ad Council and the Killdonan School. Born in Schenectady, NY and raised in New York City, Mr. Babcock attended The Hotchkiss School and Yale College. He received his B.A. from Columbia University. He was a veteran of World War II and the Battle of the Bulge. Mr. Babcock is survived by his wife of 64 years, Mary Lois Scheerer Babcock, sons, John Babcock, Jr. and Frederick Babcock, daughter Joanne Wilmerding. Daughter, Linda Wilson predeceased him. He is also survived by 10 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. The Babcocks lived for many years in West Orange, NJ; in the mid 1960's they moved to Sharon, CT, eventually settled on a farm in Stanfordville, NY. In lieu of flowers, Maplebrook School, Amenia, NY. Service at St. Peters Church, Lithgow, NY September 25th at 11am.

Mother of Alice Hines of Oakland, CA, Dorothy McCartney of Chappaqua, Margaret Hines of Boston, William Hines of Hingham, MA, Elizabeth Battison of Flintridge, CA and Robert Hines of South Hamilton, MA also survived by nine grandchildren. Funeral Services were private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to East End Hospice.

the Dolphins' defense had three interceptions of Brett Favre -- including one by Vontae Davis, left -- and stopped Adrian Peterson on fourth-and-goal to preserve a 14-10 victory over the Vikings. HAMILTON--David Denslow Ryus III, husband of Mary Louise, with whom he shared 54 years of marriage, publishing executive, died on September 17 at a hospice facility near his home in So. Hamilton, MA. He was 92 years old. He was a Lieutenant Commander in the United States Navy and served for over six years on active duty during World War II, in the Atlantic, Mediterranean and Pacific theaters. Mr. Ryus spent 23 years with Time Incorporated where he traveled extensively and served as Managing Director for off-shore operations of Time-Life International. He also served as Vice President of the American Museum of Natural History in New York City for 10 years, which included the position of Publisher of Natural History magazine. Son of the late David Denslow Ryus Jr. and Sophie Shannon Ryus; Father of Mimi Shannon, Peter Rand Ryus and Michael Denslow Ryus; Step father of David B.H. Martin and Susan B. Martin; Grandfather of eight grandchildren and Great -grandfather of four greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on October 1, 2010 at St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale St., Beverly Farms, MA. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that contributions be made in Mr. Ryus's memory to Hospice of the North Shore or The Trustees of Reservations.

A picture caption last Monday with an obituary about the actor Kevin McCarthy carried an incorrect credit. The photograph, of Mr. McCarthy and Dana Wynter in the 1956 movie ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers,'' was from Allied Artists, not United Artists. (The photograph was also erroneously credited on Aug. 12, 2007, and on Nov. 19, 2000.)

Is Zillow, the real estate Web site, getting ready to go public? On Tuesday, Zillow announced that its co-founder and chief executive, Rich Barton, would step down as chief executive and become executive chairman. Spencer Rascoff, Zillow's current chief operating officer and co-founder of Hotwire, will take his place.

JARETZKI--Paul, 89, died in New York on September 16, 2010. A devotee of opera from the age of ten, after graduating from Harvard in 1942 and serving in the Army, he was hired as Executive Assistant at City Opera. This led to a happy twenty-one year career at the Metropolitan Opera as Assistant Artistic Administrator under Rudolf Bing. In addition, Paul wrote for and coordinated the intermission programming for the Saturday afternoon radio broadcasts. He is survived by his siblings, Josie Lipman, Alfred Jaretzki III and Dotsy Eisner, and ten nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Monday, September 20 at 3:00pm. Contributions in Paul's memory can be made to the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

LEVENSON--Kathe Tanous. A freer spirit was never on this earth, nor ever left it. Kathe died on September 17, with Bob holding her toes. She leaves behind, all in tears, her step-sons Keith and Seth, her brother Ron and sister-in-law Patty, her sister Dorothy and her shattered husband, Bob. She brought light into every room just by being in it. Her paintings and drawings and sketches (and even her Christmas cards) will always bring light into countless rooms the world over. Her last years were very hard, but now she is freer than ever.

MONTGOMERY--Samuel John. Died suddenly early Friday morning, September 17th, 2010 following a solo car crash during inclement weather. Beloved son of Stamford residents Claude and Diane Montgomery, he left behind his two older brothers and a sister-in-law: Doug of New Haven CT, Nick and Hillary of Chicago, IL. He is also survived by his grandparents David and Martel Montgomery of Kennett Square, PA and Marilyn Rogers of Hyannis, MA, and numerous relatives and friends. He was pre-deceased by his grandfather John W. Rogers. He was a graduate of King & Low Heywood Thomas High School in Stamford, Ct, The Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park NY and University of Nevada Las Vegas, School of Hospitality Management. In his short 23 years, Sam traveled to China and Italy studying culinary and vintner arts and had achieved his twin goals of mastering the kitchen and the front of the house in the restaurant business. His infectious laugh, his delight in new culinary experiences, and his extreme loyalty to family and friends will be sorely missed by many. His family will be receiving visitors on September 21, 2010 at The Nicholas F. Cognetta Funeral Home & Crematory, 104 Myrtle Avenue, Stamford, Ct. Funeral services will be held on September 22, 2010 at the Unitarian Universalist Society in Stamford, 20 Forest Street, Stamford, Ct . at 10:00am. All are welcome. To leave online condolences, please visit www.cognetta.com

PARROT--David Gray, of Fort Lauderdale, FL, sailed the final voyage during the early morning hours of September 15, 2010 in Bangor, Maine. David was born April 16th, 1945 in Boston, MA, to Donald Gray Parrot and Margot Howell Parrot of Scarborough ME. In 1981 David founded one of the world's most respected maritime salvage firms, Titan Salvage, a worldwide salvage and wreck removal company headquartered in Pompano Beach, FL. Prior to that, he was a highly respected and well accomplished yacht broker. David was a member of the Cruising Club of America, New York Yacht Club, and International Salvors Union. In addition to his parents Don and Margot, David is survived by his wife Penny Parrot, brother Steven Parrot, sons Robert Hunter Parrot, Christopher Gage Parrot and Jody O'brien, daughter Laurie Beckmann, granddaughters Keeli and Elle O'Brien and grandsons David, Chris and Jason Beckmann and Jeffrey Parrot. There will be a private remembrance held in Hancock, ME, on Saturday September 18th and a memorial service held in Fort Lauderdale at a later date. In lieu of flowers, David's family asks that donations be made to Kids in Distress, 819 NE 26th St, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33305.

FISCH--Solomon, M.D.,Ph.D., 84. See yesterday's obituary at nytimes.com/deathnotices. Funeral services on Monday, September 20, 2010, 12:30pm, Temple Sinai, 1 Engle Street, Tenafly, NJ, (201) 568-3035. For futher information, contact Gutterman Musicant Funeral Home (201) 489-3800.

HAMMELBACHER--Hella. A warm and caring person who for more than 65 years was married to Hans Hammelbacher. She was a wonderful mom to Ralph and Frank; grandma to Jill; mother-in-law to Faith Halter and Janet Ingber; brother to the late Herbert Tuchmann; and aunt to Tom and Eric Tuchmann, Karen Tuchmann Gray and the late Nicole Tuchmann. At 96 she was still living an independent life. Among her many interests were painting, which she continued to pursue late in life, music and the opera. She was active in and dedicated to Congregation Habonim and The Blue Card. She will be missed by her far-flung network of friends and family. Services Tuesday, September 21 at 11:30 at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (at 76th Rd), Forest Hills.

The Books of The Times review on Aug. 31 about ''The Warmth of Other Suns: The Epic Story of America's Great Migration,'' by Isabel Wilkerson, misidentified the writer of a song about Dr. Robert Foster, whose story is told in the book. While the song, ''Hide Nor Hair,'' was recorded by Ray Charles, who also commissioned it and suggested its subject matter, it was written by Percy Mayfield, not Mr. Charles. (The error was repeated on Sept. 9 in an article about Ms. Wilkerson and the writing of the book.)

Who better to tell the story of Michael Rockefeller's disappearance than the people among whom he disappeared? That's the simple but smart narrative idea behind Jeff Cohen's play ''The Man Who Ate Michael Rockefeller,'' a Dog Run Rep production that has a light, sure touch even when it treads on weighty cultural ground. Some background: In 1961 Michael Rockefeller, an anthropologist and a son of Nelson Rockefeller, then the governor of New York, disappeared off the western coast of the island of New Guinea. Michael probably drowned after his canoe collapsed; he tried to swim to shore but his body was never found. But because the Asmat people he was studying practiced cannibalism and headhunting, there was plenty of speculation about how he met his end.

A picture caption in the special Retirement section on Thursday, with an article about some financial risks in continuing-care communities, misstated the target of a lawsuit by residents of one such community, Concordia of the South Hills, in Mount Lebanon, Pa. A suit seeking to recover entrance fees was filed against the community's previous owner, B'nai B'rith Housing, and its parent, B'nai B'rith International; it does not name the community itself, which is now owned by Concordia Lutheran Ministries of Pittsburgh.

Lately, stories about Google often seem to be stories about conflict -- Google knocking heads with China or the Justice Department or Facebook. For Eric E. ''If we were losing, we would not have these problems.''

Regular readers of New York magazine are familiar with its Approval Matrix, which is really more of a graph than a matrix. But that's beside the point. The matrix plots on X and Y axes pop culture happenings of the previous week, ranking them neatly into one of four quadrants: highbrow/brilliant; highbrow/despicable; lowbrow/despicable; or lowbrow/brilliant. It's all on how much they offend or stimulate accepted standards of cultural decency.

Left, Yucaipa, via Bloomberg; right, Alex Brandon/Associated Press Ronald W. Burkle, left, and Stephen Riggio, the vice chairman of Barnes & Noble, are locked in a proxy struggle over the direction of the company. Leonard S. Riggio, the pugnacious Barnes & Noble chairman, may be in the fight of his career, but he says he doesn't relish it. ''I find it almost repulsive I have to be put in a position to defend myself,'' Mr. Riggio said last week in Barnes & Noble's corporate offices, leaning forward to press his point. ''I don't want to consume myself with not liking people.'' Just over a week before Barnes & Noble shareholders convene for their annual meeting, Mr. Riggio remains locked in battle with the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle over three board seats, including Mr. Riggio's. And Barnes & Noble has begun seeking potential buyers for the entire 1,350-store chain. Mr. Riggio, 69, lights up when talking about walking into physical bookstores or building up his company's digital one. It is his vision for the company that is at the center of the increasingly fierce proxy fight, one that began last month and in which both sides have recently dredged through the other's corporate history for purported instances of self-dealing and incompetence. This week Barnes & Noble is hoping to win the backing of Institutional Shareholder Services, an influential company whose advice on proxy fights is closely followed by corporate investors. Barnes & Noble has already won the qualified support of a smaller adviser, Glass Lewis & Company. The fight over Barnes & Noble may seem disproportionate to what is at stake. The company's market value has shrunk to less than $1 billion, and bookselling has been squeezed by Amazon.com on one end and Wal-Mart Stores on the other. But as Mr. Riggio says, the battle touches on deep reservoirs of sentiment about an empire he fashioned starting with a small bookstore 39 years ago. ''Lots of people have an emotional stake in books,'' he said. ''It's not like what they have with their haberdashers.'' For his part, Mr. Burkle has praised Mr. Riggio's accomplishments in building up Barnes & Noble and professes a desire for peace with his longtime acquaintance. But he also described Mr. Riggio as intolerant of questions about his strategy and management. ''With Len, you're either a white hat or a black hat,'' Mr. Burkle said in an interview by phone from his plane. Mr. Burkle said he was not seeking control of the company through the proxy fight, but wanted to have independent directors on the board. ''I want someone in there who doesn't say, 'That's the most amazing thing I ever heard' every time Len opens his mouth,'' he said. Mr. Riggio's biggest challenge remains grappling with the Internet, and he argues that digital bookselling is the biggest opportunity since the paperback revolution. Barnes & Noble's e-reader, the Nook, has been making headway in sales, he said. (The company says it controls about 20 percent of the e-book market, based on information from publishers.) He also pointed to growth at the company, which reported net income of $36.7 million on a 31 percent gain in revenue, to $5.8 billion, for the year ended May 1. For its most recent quarter, Barnes & Noble reported a 21 percent jump in overall revenue, to $1.4 billion, though it posted a $63 million net loss as a result of the legal fight with Mr. Burkle and weakening sales of print books. Many analysts and industry executives do not share Mr. Riggio's optimism. Shares in the company have tumbled 28.9 percent in the last year. An analyst at Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch downgraded Barnes & Noble to ''underperform'' last week, arguing that the company's digital strategy faced major challenges from wealthier rivals like Amazon and Apple. Mr. Burkle, who amassed his fortune in supermarket chains, alarmed Barnes & Noble when his investment company, Yucaipa, began buying up shares last year, acquiring a nearly 20 percent stake. He described Mr. Riggio's strategy as too little, too late. Adding to Mr. Riggio's anxiety were the near-simultaneous share purchases made by Aletheia Research and Management, an investment firm based in California that has often followed in Mr. Burkle's footsteps. To the company's management, Yucaipa and Aletheia's moves represented a potential stealth takeover of Barnes & Noble without a premium for shareholders. Mr. Burkle has denied working in concert with Aletheia. Glass Lewis and Mr. Riggio have questioned Mr. Burkle's lack of an alternative vision for Barnes & Noble. When pressed, Mr. Burkle says he has ideas for the company, but adds that because he is not seeking outright control of Barnes & Noble he sees no need to share them publicly. In the last two weeks, the clashes have become more personal, with Barnes & Noble and Yucaipa trading blows over past business decisions. Barnes & Noble published a 26-page compendium last week of what it described as examples of Mr. Burkle's having gained control of companies without paying a premium or making disastrous business decisions. One involved a series of transactions by Source Interlink, a media and distribution company created from Yucaipa-instigated deals, and in which Mr. Riggio was an investor; the company filed for bankruptcy in 2008. Another involved the merger of Pathmark and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, a union that Barnes & Noble said resulted in gains for Yucaipa far beyond those realized by other shareholders. Mr. Burkle called the 26-page document misleading or inaccurate and pointed to several deals made by Barnes & Noble for companies in which the Riggio family had ownership interests. Chief among those, Mr. Burkle said, was the $514 million deal last year for a college bookstore business owned by Mr. Riggio and his wife. (Excluding cash held by the college unit, the deal amounted to $439 million, or about 3.8 times its profits.) The acquisition led to a spate of investor lawsuits, which are still pending. Glass Lewis has questioned Barnes & Noble's past pay practices, arguing that the company drastically overpaid its executives in light of its stock performance. Barnes & Noble's new chief executive, William Lynch, is paid $900,000 in salary, while his predecessor, Stephen Riggio, who was also vice chairman, was paid $800,000. Stephen, Mr. Riggio's younger brother, remains vice chairman and now earns $400,000. Mr. Riggio - who reduced his salary this year to $100,000 from $300,000 - made no apologies for what he said were necessary costs for hiring good executives. ''I'm significantly undercompensated,'' he said. ''Steve is undercompensated.'' Mr. Burkle has raised questions about whether Barnes & Noble's plan to sell itself will be fair and open to any bidder besides Mr. Riggio, who has indicated that he may make an offer. About 20 parties, including private equity firms, have either signed nondisclosure agreements with Barnes & Noble or are close to doing so, people with direct knowledge of the process said, adding that preliminary offers could be due as soon as next month. Yucaipa has not signed an agreement, Mr. Burkle said, arguing that such documents typically contain onerous restrictions for potential bidders. Dismissing concerns that the sale process was being handled improperly, Mr. Riggio said, ''If there's any stink to the process, it'd be all over the Street.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

If you rely on Microsoft's Internet Explorer's privacy settings to control cookies on your computer, you may want to rethink that strategy. Large numbers of Web sites, including giants like Facebook, appear to be using a loophole that circumvents I.E.'s ability to block cookies, according to researchers at CyLab at the Carnegie Mellon University School of Engineering.

After months of heated speculation, two prominent Wall Street bankers have raised money for a new private equity fund focused on media deals. They are the latest in a long line of financiers who have left large banks to start boutiques that provide strategic advice and make principal investments. According to a letter recently sent to its investors, the firm, called the Raine Group, had raised more than $300 million and hopes to close at $500 million. It is being run by Joseph Ravitch, a former partner at Goldman Sachs, and Jeffrey A. Sine, a former senior banker at UBS. Mr. Ravitch and Mr. Sine have made names for themselves in the media and entertainment business, advising companies on some of the sector's highest-profile deals. Mr. Ravitch, 48, has worked on transactions including the creation of NBA China and the sale of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer movie studio. Mr. Sine, 54, advised the Sundance Channel on its sale to Rainbow Media, part of Cablevision, and advised Time Warner on its merger with AOL. The two financiers formed Raine about a year ago and have since spanned the globe to secure backing. Among Raine's closest ties are to William Morris Endeavor, the influential Hollywood talent agency, which owns a stake in the Raine parent company and has an investment in the private equity vehicle, according to people familiar with the firm. Mr. Ravitch advises the agency and is close friends with Ariel Z. Emanuel, William Morris's chief executive. Raine's investors, according to the letter, are a mix of large sovereign wealth funds, including those run by the Abu Dhabi and Singapore governments. Investors who are also on Raine's advisory board include moguls like Ted Forstmann, owner of the sports marketing giant IMG Worldwide; Raymond G. Chambers, the private equity pioneer and an owner of the New Jersey Devils hockey team; and Masayoshi Son, founder of SoftBank, the large Japanese media company. Other advisers are Thomas E. Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, and Marc Andreessen, a founder of Netscape and a board member of Facebook, eBay and Hewlett-Packard. William Morris will not have a day-to-day role in Raine's operations, say people familiar with the firm who requested anonymity because the plans were confidential. But Raine's Los Angeles office will be at the William Morris Endeavor's Beverly Hills headquarters, in a separate space. (The Raine name is an amalgamation of the founders' surnames; people close to the firm have suggested that the E stands for Emanuel.) Raine has already worked on a number of advisory assignments, including counseling Flash Entertainment, owned by Abu Dhabi, on its purchase of a stake in the Ultimate Fighting Championship league. This month, Playboy Enterprises announced that it had retained Raine to review a bid by its founder, Hugh Hefner, to take the company private. Like many other private equity shops, Raine has focused on the fast-growing Asia region. The firm counts among its advisory board members Li Ruigang, president of the Shanghai Media Group and chairman of the media-focused investment fund sponsored by the Chinese government. Raine has also advised IMG Worldwide on a venture with the Indian conglomerate Reliance Industries to build a professional sports business in India. The idea behind firms like Raine, which is modeled, in part, on the boutique investment bank Allen & Company, is that their deal-making contacts will give them exclusive access to prospective investments, which could include global comic book brands and new sports leagues. Byron Trott, another former Goldman Sachs partner, recently set up a similar business in Chicago focused on family-owned and industrial companies. The Raine fund's media industry focus is similar to the early formation of the Quadrangle Group a decade ago when Steven Rattner, a leading media banker at Lazard Frères, left the firm with three colleagues to form a private equity operation. Other boutique firms founded by well-known bankers to provide advice and make investments include Greenhill & Company and Evercore Partners. Both of those firms, now publicly traded, have either been spun off or are winding down their in-house private equity arms to avoid potential conflicts and decrease earnings volatility. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

POST--Pamela Peyton, died peacefully with family and friends on September 13, 2010 at her home in New Canaan, CT. Born in New York City on October 30, 1953 she was the daughter of Joan Paton Tilney now of Yarmouth, Me. and the late Bernard Peyton Jr. In 1978 she married her cherished husband William Stanton Post. Pammie led a courageous life choosing to turn the adversities of Cystic Fibrosis into the gift of appreciating every moment of every day. Her love and joy had an indelible effect on us all. A celebration of her life will be held at 11am on Saturday, October 2, 2010 at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, please live your life as Pammie did, smiling out loud.

Add crazy scheduling to the many reasons it's so hard for Super Bowl champions to repeat. The Saints opened the season as one of the performers in the Taylor Swift-Dave Matthews Band-Brett Favre Tinsel and Stubble Music Festival on Sept. 9, and they looked rusty (as did the Vikings) in a 14-9 victory. Then they got what amounted to a second bye week by playing a Monday night game in Week 2. ''That Minnesota week almost felt like the Super Bowl week because of the media hype and blitz and everything,'' Drew Brees told The Times-Picayune of New Orleans. ''But just also because your routine gets totally thrown off.'' The good news: after this game, the Saints have a string of old fashioned Sunday afternoon games. Pick: Saints. MIKE TANIER

An article on Aug. 13 about the area around Upper St. Regis Lake, N.Y., where many of New York City's richest and most powerful families used to gather in the summer, including Frederick Vanderbilt and his family, misidentified the nearby mountain that reminded Vanderbilt and his wife of Mount Fuji in Japan. It was Whiteface Mountain, not St. Regis Mountain. This correction was delayed for research.

Mobile devices work on different operating platforms, and market share has been shifting in the last year. Research In Motion's share has dropped, but it still leads the pack with its BlackBerrys, carried along by ardent business fans. Equally enthusiastic iPhone users made Apple one of only two platforms to gain. Google developed its opeating system, Android, as open-source software, and it comes on smartphones like the Ally, above, from LG and Verizon, and the Evo 4G, made by HTC for Sprint. Android-based devices have shown the biggest gain. Wireless companies are constantly looking for that sweet spot to entice customers: the right texting plan, the perfect price point for the latest smartphone, and a mix of cool new apps. SHELLY FREIERMAN

For omnivores who want to take it to the next level, Tom Turpin, a professor of entomology at Purdue University, offers information on three common bugs you can easily buy, prepare and cook.

CARPET BAGGINGIt's easy to be taken on a magic carpet ride when you're buying rugs - hawkers will wave you into their stalls, ply you with mint tea and take you through stacks of fake antique rugs. However, La Porte d'Or, in the thick of the souks, is the real deal. Marc Jacobs, Tom Cruise and Edgar Kauffman, who picked up carpets for his Fallingwater house, have all shopped here. The staff will guide you through a vast selection - kilims from the Glowa tribe, carpets made from 400-year-old silk - and pass on valuable tips. (Lamb's-wool rugs won't shrink; a double-knotted weave lets you restore holes.) The shop also ships. 115 Souk Semmarine; 011-212-524-44-54-54.

In the last couple of posts on our House forecasts, I've noted that the generic Congressional ballot tends to show worse results for Democrats than other indicators like polls of individual House races. The generic ballot, as of last week, pointed toward a Republican lead of 7 or 8 percentage points among likely voters, according to our estimates. Local polls are a little bit less straightforward to read because you have to make a lot of adjustments for polls that are (i) partisan, (ii) bad, or (iii) both. But in general -- while there is a lot of variance from district to district -- the local polls seem to point toward a House vote that would be about evenly divided.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Some British newspapers this morning picked up on the extreme shoes worn by guests to the memorial to Alexander McQueen. The Daily Express featured a photo on its cover, next to the headline: "A shoebiz tribute to McQueen." Against the backdrop of the London shows, one impression that stuck was seeing Plum Sykes in her perfectly fitted black McQueen day dress. I saw Ms. Sykes from a distance in the cathedral, but you would know from the line of her outfit that it was a McQueen. That sort of authority and fashion imprint hasn't been seen here - and I didn't expect to see it. That's one reason Mr. McQueen was so rare.

City firefighters worked to extinguish the blaze under the bridge, which crosses the Harlem River, and commuters waited at Grand Central Terminal. There were no injuries, a Metro- North spokeswoman said, and service was restored within a few hours.

A new exploration of how evolution works at the genomic level may have a significant impact on drug development and other areas of medicine. The report, published in Nature last week, offers new evidence in a longstanding debate about how organisms evolve. One well-known path to change is a heavily favorable mutation in a single gene. But it may be well known only because it is easy to study. Another path is exploitation of mildly favorable differences that already exist in many genes.

The wandering albatross has the largest known wingspan of any living bird, at times reaching nearly 12 feet. But millions of years ago, there was a bird with wings that dwarfed those of the albatross, researchers now report. The newly named species, Pelagornis chilensis, which lived about 5 million to 10 million years ago, had a wingspan of at least 17 feet.

Lisa Rickard, executive vice president of the Chamber, signaled in a statement that Mr. Manchin grasped the economic challenges the country faces and had created a climate in West Virginia conducive to creating jobs.

''There will come a time,'' Frank Zappa sang, ''when everybody who is lonely will be free to sing and dance and love.'' And there will come a time, he vowed, ''when you can even take your clothes off when you dance.'' Until then, the city of Baltimore has found a more traditional way to honor Zappa, the genre-bending avant-garde rock musician who was born in Baltimore and died in 1993, with a bust in his likeness that was dedicated there on Sunday, The Associated Press reported. In a ceremony timed to the 25th anniversary of Zappa's Senate testimony, at which he compared the labeling of explicit records to censorship, and attended by Zappa's widow, Gail, his sons, Dweezil and Ahmet, and daughter Diva, as well as Baltimore's mayor, Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, a bust of the mustachioed, pony-tailed Zappa was unveiled atop a 12-foot pole outside the Southeast Anchor Branch of the Enoch Pratt Free Library. It isn't very large, but the bust is a replica of a similar sculpture in Vilnius, Lithuania. The duplicate was donated to Baltimore by the Lithuanian nonprofit organization ZAPPART. ''He'd be wildly amused by this,'' Gail Zappa told The A.P., ''because of the absurdity of these guys in Lithuania coming up with this phenomenal sculptor who normally does busts of Stalin.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Christie's, the auction house based in London, announced to its staff on Monday morning that Edward Dolman, its chief executive for nearly 11 years, had been replaced by an outsider, Steven Pleshette Murphy. Mr. Dolman was promoted to the post of chairman of the company worldwide. Mr. Murphy, 56, most recently was president and chief executive of Rodale Inc., a publishing company perhaps best known for producing hits like ''The South Beach Diet'' and ''An Inconvenient Truth.'' Mr. Dolman, 50, who will be based in New York, plans to concentrate on attracting business while Mr. Murphy will move to London and be responsible for the house's day-to-day operations.

SUNDELL--Michael G.,of New York, NY, on September 7, 2010, age 74. The Members and Directors of Yaddo are deeply saddened by the death of their former President, Michael G. Sundell, and hereby express their profound sympathy to Nina and their children, and their gratitude to Michael for his inspired leadership of Yaddo over eight years. He has earned his place in a veritable Pantheon of Yaddo Saints, joining Spencer, Katrina, Elizabeth, and others who nurtured and supported the creative process and stimulated - in the words of the Trasks - "the Sacred Fire" within Yaddo's artist guests. The more than 1,500 artists who had the privilege of being guests during Michael's tenure, as well as the roughly equivalent number who have been guests since his retirement, are all the beneficiaries of his extraordinary legacy of leadership. He had a deep understanding of Yaddo's mission and the importance of assuring an atmosphere of security, peace, freedom and protection for the artist guests, he skillfully took Yaddo in some new directions, he loved Yaddo, derived joy from the experience of running Yaddo, and conveyed such joy and enthusiasm to others, leaving Yaddo better for his presence and stronger than he found it. The Members and Directors note with pride that in his retirement Michael pursued his passion in archeology, art history, and the history of religion researching mosaics in Rome and publishing Mosaics in the Eternal City. When ultimately confronted with a life threatening illness, he never lost his interest in serious scholarship, his zest for life, his love of family and friends, his passion for travel, and his love of the creative process and the work that goes on at Yaddo.

An article on Wednesday about the use of antibiotics in livestock may have left the incorrect impression about the effect of a proposal under consideration by the Food and Drug Administration. While the guidelines that the agency is expected to issue, seeking to end the use of antibiotics to promote growth in healthy animals, are indeed its strongest yet, they are voluntary and will not have the binding force of regulations. And an accompanying picture caption referred imprecisely to an injectable antibiotic, Excenel RTU. Excenel is used in the treatment of swine disease, but it is not used to prevent disease or promote faster growth in pigs and thus would not fall under the F.D.A.'s proposed guidelines.

The Toronto International Film Festival's People's Choice Award, a prize that has sometimes served as a bellwether for future success at the Academy Awards, was given on Sunday to ''The King's Speech,'' a feature directed by Tom Hooper, Reuters reported. The film stars Colin Firth as King George VI of Britain, who overcame a nervous stammer to deliver a crucial address on the eve of that country's entrance into World War II, and will be released in the United States by the Weinstein Company later this year. Previous winners of the award, which comes with a prize of about $30,000, have included ''Slumdog Millionaire,'' ''Crash'' and ''American Beauty,'' all winners of the Oscar for best picture; last year's winner, ''Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' By Sapphire,'' was a best picture nominee. The People's Choice award for a documentary went to ''Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie,'' a feature by Sturla Gunnarsson about that Canadian environmentalist. Among the films that were acquired for distribution at the end of Toronto festival, Variety reported (subscription required) were Werner Herzog's ''Cave of Forgotten Dreams,'' a 3-D film about the paintings in the Chauvet Cave of southern France.

Senator Jim DeMint, the conservative South Carolina Republican, is putting his political action committee's money where his mouth is, releasing on Monday a new television ad in Delaware that attacks the Democratic senate candidate, Chris Coons, for his close ties to Washington. Mr. Coons is running against Republican Christine O'Donnell, one of the handful of Tea Party candidates with Mr. DeMint's support. Considered a long-shot, she won the Republican primary for Delaware's open Senate seat less than a week ago.

KAHN-ROSENKRANZ--Susan, 86, died suddenly on September 20, 2010 at home. She was the loving and beloved wife of both Richard Rosenkranz and the late Joseph Kahn. The rape was at 2:30 a.m. on the Lower East Side: a man attacked a 16-year-old girl as she was entering her building on Eldridge Street, just north of Grand Street. The victim was treated at a hospital; statements were taken but no arrest was made. Now, 17 years later, a suspect is in custody. The suspect, Alberto Barriera, 46, was arraigned on Monday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges that he robbed and raped the teen-ager on Dec. 18, 1993.''The assailant took money and jewelry from her and sexually assaulted her,'' Martha Bashford, an assistant district attorney, said at the arraignment. DNA was collected from the victim at the hospital, Ms. Bashford said, and was preserved. In 2002 it was examined as part of the New York Police Department's Backlog Testing Program. The next year, a DNA profile of the unidentified rapist was indicted under the name John Doe.

The $200,000 Steinberg award for playwriting, the most lucrative prize in theater, will go to Lynn Nottage for her body of work that most recently includes the 2009 Pulitzer Prize recipient ''Ruined,'' the Harold and Mimi Steinberg Charitable Trust announced on Monday. The distinguished playwright award is presented every other year; the first winner, in 2008, was Tony Kushner (''Angels in America,'' ''Caroline, or Change''). In alternating years the trust gives awards to playwrights at earlier stages of their careers - a category that generated some debate in 2009 among the award's judges, who had different views on the definition of an emerging writer. That year Bruce Norris (''Clybourne Park'') received a $50,000 award, and David Adjmi (''Stunning'') and Tarell Alvin McCraney (''The Brother/Sister Plays'') received $25,000 apiece.

The music on ''Silver and Ash,'' a new album from the songwriter Clare Burson, started with silence. There was the silence that descended in 1941, when letters from her maternal great-grandparents, German Jews who had fled to Latvia, abruptly stopped arriving in Memphis, where Ms. Burson's grandmother settled in 1938. Then there was the second silence: the silence in Ms. Burson's family about the first silence. Ms. Burson, now a 34-year-old songwriter who lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, started asking about her family's history in Europe when she was 8, and learned about the Holocaust at religious school. Her mother's response: ''Don't ask Grandma about it.''

The new musical ''Catch Me If You Can,'' created by several of the forces behind the Broadway hit ''Hairspray,'' will arrive in New York in the spring, with preview performances starting on March 7, 2011, and an opening night of April 10, the producers announced on Monday. The addition of ''Catch Me'' to Broadway's 2010-11 schedule is also the clearest sign yet that another new musical, Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Love Never Dies,'' will not come to New York next spring as planned. The ''Catch Me'' director is Jack O'Brien and the choreographer is Jerry Mitchell; they mounted the London debut production of ''Love Never Dies'' last spring and were expected to bring it to Broadway, but people close to both men said recently that the two had left the Lloyd Webber production, his sequel to ''The Phantom of the Opera.''

RYUS--David Denslow III, husband of Mary Louise, with whom he shared 54 years of marriage, publishing executive, died on September 17 at a hospice facility near his home in So. Hamilton, MA. He was 92 years old. He was a Lieutenant Commander in the United States Navy and served for over six years on active duty during World War II, in the Atlantic, Mediterranean and Pacific theaters. Mr. Ryus spent 23 years with Time Incorporated where he traveled extensively and served as Managing Director for off-shore operations of Time-Life International. He also served as Vice President of the American Museum of Natural History in New York City for 10 years, which included the position of Publisher of Natural History magazine. Son of the late David Denslow Ryus Jr. and Sophie Shannon Ryus; Father of Mimi Shannon, Peter Rand Ryus and Michael Denslow Ryus; Step father of David B.H. Martin and Susan B. Martin; Grandfather of eight grandchildren and Great-grandfather of four greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am on October 1, 2010 at St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale St., Beverly Farms, MA. In lieu of flowers, the family has asked that contributions be made in Mr. Ryus's memory to Hospice of the North Shore or The Trustees of Reservations.

As Donald H. Rumsfeld liked to say, there are known knowns, known unknowns and unknown knowns. A truncated version of that famous Rummyism has been turned into the title of his coming memoir, ''Known and Unknown,'' Mr. Rumsfeld's publisher said on Monday.

My husband found the bike race, but then he refused to train seriously for it. He was ambivalent, not sure he wanted to compete. But I signed us up anyway. I like having goals, and we had never raced on our bikes before. I wanted to see how we'd do. It was not what we expected -- in fact, that race was quite a shock. But it certainly taught us some lessons. Our experience turned out to be a perfect illustration of the power of one sort of mental strategy in racing and a perfect example of what motivates some people to stay with a sport.

Are you worried about high-fructose corn syrup in your diet? If you answered yes, you're not alone. Today, about 55 percent of Americans list the infamous corn sweetener among their food-safety worries, right behind mad cow disease and mercury in seafood, according to the consumer research firm NPD Group.
