Gov. David A. Paterson vetoed a bill over the weekend that would have significantly increased the legal penalties for assaults against cabbies, overturning a nearly unanimous vote in the Legislature. A product of months of lobbying by drivers' groups, the Taxi Driver Protection Act would have required yellow cabs and livery cars to post a sticker notifying passengers that an assault on a driver ''is punishable by up to 25 years in prison,'' a warning similar to those found on the region's subways and commuter trains.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about the proxy fight at Barnes & Noble misidentified an executive from Barnes & Noble in some editions. He is Stephen Riggio, the vice chairman of the company -- not Leonard S. Riggio, the chairman, and brother of Stephen.

House Republicans on Thursday intend to unveil their long-awaited legislative blueprint for the next Congress if they win a majority in the November elections, aides said Monday. To illustrate their commitment to focusing on the concerns of Americans outside the Washington Beltway, Republican leaders will venture 30 miles west to Sterling, Va., where the platform will be released at a hardware and lumber business.

McELNEA--William H. Jr.,88, died in his Colorado home on September 10th. A WWII hero, Dartmouth/Tuck grad and admired business leader, he took the gaming industry into the public markets and later co-founded Regent Air. PORTLAND, Me. -- There were no strobe lights, no outlandish costumes and only a mediocre sound system. ''There she is,'' a girl shrieked. Not the typical reception for someone who is on hand to deal with a Congressional filibuster.

Are you being followed online? If you've ever used the Flash program from Adobe to watch videos - and odds are you have - you may have code on your computer that tracks your Web browsing, sending that information to companies that may sell it or use it for tailored advertising. On this week's Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter, about so-called Flash cookies, which have raised privacy concerns and prompted lawsuits from consumers against companies involved in this form of tracking.

In a case study we've just published, Kermit Pattison writes about Firehouse Subs, a fast-food sandwich chain based in Florida. When the recession hit, the chain's sales took a dive. At first, Firehouse responded by rescinding the 2 percent marketing fee it had been collecting from its franchisees and encouraging them to spend that money on local marketing. When that failed, the chain took a very different approach: it asked its franchisees to increase the amount of money they were spending on marketing and it unleashed an $8 million advertising campaign -- right into the teeth of the recession. It also chose Zimmerman Advertising to handle its corporate account.

In this lesson, students analyze the information included on labels of popular dish detergents. Merely as an exercise, I was trying to think this evening of a tweet-size summary of the Alberta Ferretti show, because I was pretty sure that if I wrote down peasant blouses, faded floral tiered skirts, long-sleeved linen dresses with white crochet trim, and floppy hats and rope sandals, you might get the wrong idea - that it was corny or something. But I guess I kept coming back to Nantucket in the summer of 1974 or '75 (I had my driver's license). Days after "30 Rock" broadcasts its live episode on Oct. 14 Jack McBrayer will once again be flying without a net. Mr. McBrayer, who on "30 Rock" plays the NBC page and lovable rube Kenneth, will make his Broadway debut in a staged reading of Larry Kramer's "The Normal Heart" at the Walter Kerr Theater on Oct. 18, the production's publicists said on Wednesday. The reading, to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Mr. Kramer's play about the early years of the AIDS crisis, will be directed by Joel Grey; its previously announced cast will include Patrick Wilson, Victor Garber, Joe Mantello, Michael Stuhlbarg, Jason Butler Harner and John Benjamin Hickey. The reading, which is produced by Daryl Roth, is a benefit for the Actors Fund and the organization Friends in Deed, which provides services for people with life-threatening illnesses.

"Sultry, sexy and fresh" was how Burberry's head makeup consultant Wendy Rowe described the look she put together for the label's show yesterday afternoon. Brightly colored makeup has popped up on more than a few runways this season, but Rowe kept her palette cool, leaving the spotlight to the accessories (think canary-yellow belts and turquoise clutches). "This season's Burberry girl climbs off the back of her boyfriend's bike and shakes her hair out, still looking beautiful," Rowe says. "She has a vaguely feline face, and we did a slightly disappearing lip, with a touch of lip gloss, to make it more modern. The look isn't too considered." Naturally, this look was achieved using Burberry's recently introduced makeup collection, which she helped develop with Christopher Bailey, Burberry's creative director.

Beginning Thursday, Bryn Mawr, the women's college in Pennsylvania, will convene a conference to explore the role of women's colleges in improving the lives of women worldwide. Jane Dammen McAuliffe, the college's president, spoke to me during a recent visit to The Times about the conference, which is pegged to Bryn Mawr's 125th anniversary. We have since exchanged a few questions and answers by e-mail, and I thought our discussion -- which you'll find below -- might spark some conversation on The Choice, particularly among young women and their families. So please use the comment box below to weigh in on the state of women's colleges -- not just Bryn Mawr -- and their future. Questions and answers have been edited. -- Jacques Steinberg

Empty out your vintage shopping bags from Love Saves the Day, unroll your fishnet stockings and dust off that pyramid jacket you claim belonged to Jimi Hendrix, because "Desperately Seeking Susan" is a quarter-century old. This 1985 comedy-drama, which starred Rosanna Arquette as a New Jersey housewife masquerading as a bohemian Manhattanite - and, by the way, provided Madonna with her first lead role in a movie - was for a generation of viewers an introduction to New York's downtown counterculture and its motley fashion sensibility. Now the film plays like a cinematic time capsule, filled with endearingly grimy places, authentic and imagined, and distinctive personalities that have vanished from the city.

New York City has long been home to many squatters, people who want to stay even when the fickle but often expensive real estate market makes it all but impossible. Most of them, whether holed up in a converted Brooklyn factory, decrepit Lower East Side tenement or the man-made cavern of an abandoned subway station, cannot imagine the luxury Daniel K. Perlman enjoyed. Manny Fernandez reports in today's About New York column that Mr. Perlman, a family law and criminal defense lawyer, was the sole occupant of a six-room suite on the 40th floor of the Empire State Building for seven months after a mortgage broker who rented him space in the suite for little or no rent went under.

KOURY--Frederick, J. Co-founder of City-As-School High School, passed away on July 7, 2010 at age 87. He was principal of CAS for 17 years and respected as a leader in experiential learning. He taught English at Wingate and at Dewey High School in New York. Fred was a founding member of the United Federation of Teachers and served on the Executive Board. During WWII, he was a lead navigator with the 100th Bomb Group. He will be missed by the many students, colleagues, friends, and family whose lives he touched and influenced. A tribute will be held at 5:30pm on Friday, September 24 at City-As-School, 16 Clarkson St., New York City. Donations may be made to the Fred Koury Memorial Scholarship Fund at City-As-School, 16 Clarkson St., New York, NY 10014.

COCCARO--Nicholas F.,94 of Bayside, NY. Pre-deceased 19 years by his cherished wife Romilda Forno ("Roey"), Nick passed on September 20, 2010. Survived by five loving children and spouses, nine grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. A proud decorated WWII Veteran who served in the US Army's 52nd Signal Battalion for 34 months in the South Pacific, Nick is gratefully remembered as a caring, selfless, steadfast provider whose example imparted a fair and strong work ethic. His artistic accomplishments are admired for beauty, craftsmanship, wry humor and gentle wit. The life and achievements of this quiet, humble man will continue to inspire his loving family as a paragon of the greatest generation. Donations to Calvary Fund Inc, PO Box 5173, Toms River NJ 08754-9944. Reposing Sept. 22 at Lloyd Funeral Home, 214-43 39th Ave., Bayside NY. Mass September 23, 10:45am at St. Robert Bellarmine Church 213th St at 58th Ave., Bayside NY.

FENIGER--Jerome Roland "Jerry", Jr.,83, died September 21, 2010. Happily married for 59 years to Marian Schwartz. Survived also by his loving children Robin, Bruce (Bonnie) and adored grandchildren Leah Nicole and William Jerome. He had a broadcasting career spanning 60 years pioneering the birth of television. In 1970, Feniger founded and became president of Horizon Communications, Inc., which owned and operated eight radio and television stations throughout the country. He was managing director of the Station Representatives Association, Inc., past president of the International Radio and Television Society, past chair of the International Radio and Television Foundation, and a member of the founding group of the Museum of Television and Radio (The Paley Center). Throughout these numerous leadership roles, Feniger continued to use his communication skills to connect with others. He served as the senior director of the Advertising Council and has been deeply involved in assisting various philanthropic organizations with their public service advertising campaigns. He also had been instrumental in helping Iowa alumni find professional success on the East Coast. Though Feniger did graduate work at Columbia University and New York University, and eventually earned an honorary doctorate from St. John University, his Iowa affinity remains strong. He received the Distinguished Alumni Service Award. In addition, Feniger provided generous financial resources for the UI, particularly through the endowed Jerome and Marian Feniger Fellowship in Communication Studies, which offers financial aid to needy and deserving majors who plan to pursue careers in broadcasting. Funeral services will be Friday 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to Lilian and Benjamin Herzberg Palliative Care Institute, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1020, New York 10029 and the University of Iowa Jerome and Marian Feniger Fellowship in Communications, University of Iowa Foundation, PO Box 4550, Iowa City, IA 52244-4550.

KULUKUNDIS--M. Michael, a much respected and loved member of the Greek shipping community and Director of Rethymnis and Kulukundis Ltd., passed away at his home in New York City on Sunday, September 19th. He was 76. Upon graduation from Harvard University in 1956, Mr. Kulukundis joined his father, shipping magnate Manuel E. Kulukundis, in the long running Kulukundis family ship owning interests established in 1832. In addition to his success in the shipping industry, Mr. M. Michael Kulukundis was also a pioneer in the technology industry through his company Ram Broadcasting Corporation in the radio paging and mobile telephone sectors throughout the 1970s and 80s. In 1988, Mr. Kulukundis formed and headed Ram Mobile Data which was the U.S. Operator of the Mobitex network and worked alongside RIM in devising the mobile data networks that today run devices such as the Blackberry. RAM Mobile Data was sold and renamed BellSouth Wireless Data in 1995 and later became Cingular Interactive when BellSouth and SBC Communications formed Cingular Wireless. Mr. Kulukundis is survived by his widow Tara, children Eric, Manuel, Cassandra, and Christopher and grandchildren, Alexandra, Michael, and Isabella. The family will receive the condolences of relatives and friends, wishing to attend in person on Wednesday, September 22nd, between the hours of 6:00 and 9:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. The funeral will take place at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street, New York, NY 10021, on Thursday, September 23rd at 12 noon.

TAFFNER--Eleanor. The St. John's University family mourns the passing of Eleanor Taffner, extraordinarily generous benefactor, esteemed trustee emerita, and loyal, cherished friend. For more than a decade, she shared her vision, leadership skills, and infectious optimism as a member of the Board of Trustees, Chair of its Athletics subcommittee, and member of its Executive Committee. We who were privileged to work with her have been immeasurably enriched by her insights, her grace, and her remarkable ability to call forth the best in each of us. Our University has been strengthened by her service. We shall remember her with great affection always. Our thoughts and prayers go to her cherished husband, Donald, and her beloved children and grandchildren in this time of sorrow. Thomas E. McInerney, Chair, Board of Trustees Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

A picture on Tuesday with the Personal Best column, about a time trial bike race, was published in error. It showed a group of cyclists riding track bikes, not racers in a time trial race. (As the column noted, time trial racers start at certain intervals and are alone on the course.)

Get your ''Thriller'' avatar and moonwalk keystrokes ready: Planet Michael will soon be ready for virtual exploration. The Michael Jackson estate will announce on Tuesday that it has made a deal with the company SEE Virtual Worlds to release Planet Michael, a 3D computer environment that will be part of the Entropia Universe game platform. In the game, which is expected to be released late next year, fans can dance in a recreation of the ''Billie Jean'' video, visit Neverland and explore continents drawn from themes in Jackson's music and life, as well as ''the global issues that concerned him,'' the estate and SEE Virtual Worlds, the game's publisher, said in a joint statement. As a massively multiplayer online computer game, Planet Michael will allow huge numbers of users to interact at the same time; it's free to download and play but users can convert their real dollars into play money in the game for virtual transactions. There will also be virtual advertising.

KAHN-ROSENKRANZ--Susan, 86, died suddenly on September 20, 2010 at home. She was the loving and beloved wife of both Richard Rosenkranz and the late Joseph Kahn. She is survived by loving nieces, nephews, grandnieces and one great-grandniece. All of whom she loved and kept in close contact with. To know her as a friend was unforgettable. Susan was a world-class Artist who had numerous one - woman shows and whose work is exhibited in museums and private collections throughout the world. There is not enough that can be said about this very classy lady who will always be remembered. Services will be 12:30pm, Wednesday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st).

Placido Domingo has signed on for two more seasons as general director of the Los Angeles Opera, the company said on Monday. Mr. Domingo's term was to last through this season, but he will now continue until mid-2013, with the contract renewing automatically as long as both sides agree, officials said. Mr. Domingo also runs the Washington National Opera and maintains a busy singing schedule, giving rise to periodic concerns that he is overextended. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

9 P.M. (13, 49) NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC: OPENING NIGHT CONCERT 2010 ''Live From Lincoln Center'' inaugurates its 35th season with this gala performance from the New York Philharmonic, under the baton of Alan Gilbert, right, now in his second year as music director. The program spans the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries -- from ''Don Juan,'' the first published tone poem of Richard Strauss, and Hindemith's ''Symphonic Metamorphosis on Themes of Carl Maria von Weber,'' to the American premiere of the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis's ''Swing'' Symphony No. 3. Commissioned jointly by the New York Philharmonic, the Berlin Philharmonic, the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Barbican Center in London, ''Swing'' will feature performances by Mr. Marsalis and his Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLYKelly Ripa, Kristin Chenoweth and AnnaLynne McCord will don stilettos -- only those with heels three inches or higher need apply -- to make a mad 150-yard dash in Central Park for the annual ''High Heel-a-thon'' to benefit the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health. The first 300 contestants to complete the race will receive a pair of shoes from Zappos.com. The woman who makes it across the finish line first will win a 2011 Volkswagen Jetta, the better to zoom home and soak her feet. Tim Gunn will report from the sideline. (Yes, men can test their agility in women's heels in their own race, to be held earlier in the morning.)

Less than an hour after promoting the strong ratings for Episode 1, HBO announced on Tuesday a second season order for the sprawling gangster drama ''Boardwalk Empire.'' The first episode was watched by 7.1 million viewers on Sunday night, a standout rating for HBO, which has been in need of big new dramas since ''The Sopranos'' ended in 2007. Some critics have already compared that mob tale to ''Boardwalk Empire,'' and the high ratings and the almost-instant renewal are likely to generate more of that talk.

GABORIAULT--Andrew L.,a retired petroleum industry executive, died on September 17 in Redding, Connecticut. He was 87 years old and had resided in Wilton, Connecticut. The cause of death was congestive heart failure. Mr. Gaboriault was born in Cleveland, Ohio on May 19, 1923, the son of Aloysius and Agnes Gaboriault. He graduated from St. Ignatius High School in Cleveland and Catholic University in Washington, D.C. from which he graduated as class valedictorian in 1945 with a Bachelor of Chemical Engineering Degree. He joined Mobil Oil Corporation in 1946 and remained with the company until his retirement in 1988. After several years of petroleum research and a year in the U.S. Army where he worked on guided missile research, he transferred to the Patent and Licensing Division of Mobil's Legal Department in 1950. He graduated first in his class from the New York University School of Law in 1954 with a Juris Doctor degree and became a member of the New York bar. He was also a member of the Connecticut bar. In 1967 he completed the Advanced Management Program at Harvard Business School. He progressed through positions of increasing responsibility in Mobil's legal function and in 1968 he was appointed General Patent Counsel. In 1974 he was promoted to General Counsel for Mobil's North American Division and in 1979 became General Counsel of the Worldwide Marketing and Refining Division, one of Mobil's two major operating divisions. Subsequently he became Associate General Counsel of the Corporation and in 1985 he was elected Vice President. He was also the President of Mobil Foundation the Corporation's principal gift giving entity and he was a Director of Montgomery Ward. He is survived by his daughter Diane Gaboriault of Redding, a son Peter Gaboriault of Wilton, two grandchildren, Jessica and Thomas Gaboriault of Wilton, Connecticut and a brother Paul of Ann Arbor, Michigan. A Memorial to celebrate Andrew's life will be held on October 2, 2010, please contact Peter for details. Contributions in memory of Mr. Gaboriault may be made to Visiting Nurse & Hospice of Fairfield County or to the New York University School of Law.

BECKER--John T.,international entrepreneur, dies at 90. John Thomas Becker, 90, of Greenwich, died on September 17 2010 after a short illness. He was born in May 1920 in Pontiac, Michigan. A graduate of Michigan State University he enlisted in WWII and attended Navy Officer training school at Notre Dame University. During the war, he distinguished himself as a commander of subchaser crafts from the Caribbean to the North Pacific. In 1951, John established Eurpac Service Inc. a global sales, marketing and distribution services company. From a Paris-based two-person operation the company expanded to four continents and staff numbering in the thousands. Among markets served, Eurpac became a leader in consumer product distribution to military commissaries and exchanges worldwide. Becker and his wife, Sheila moved to Greenwich in 1958, and John quickly became an active and involved citizen. A man of opinion, dedication and action, he owned and operated the local AM station, WGCH. Additionally, he served as Chairman of the Board of Greenwich YMCA, was on the board of the Greenwich Historical Society, and was Chairman of a United Way annual giving campaign. He actively and generously contributed to the growth and well-being of many Greenwich institutions including Parsonage Cottage, Greenwich Hospital and The Bruce Museum. Active in and dedicated to the political process, he was committed to the Republican party throughout his life. He participated in the Greenwich RTM and acted two terms as Chairman. He served several terms on the Republican State Central Committee. In 1982 he ran for Connecticut State Treasurer on the Republican party ticket and later ran for the US Congressional seat vacated by Senator McKinney. Among his many activities outside the local community, he was a founding member of the Armed Forces Marketing Council and served on the Board of the USO in Washington D.C. His interests were varied from building a stable of race horses to catching fish in the waters off of his residence in the Bahamas. Above all, Becker will be remembered as a valuable contributor and a focused leader, dedicated to his family, friends and community. His knowledge on almost any topic combined with his accurate, matter-of-fact analysis of the world made him an inspiration to all who encountered him[MMB1]. He was predeceased by his wife Sheila in 2001 and is survived by his four daughters, Jamee Becker of Greenwich, Lisa Edmundson of Greenwich, Virginia "Gigi" Becker of Lyme and Margaret McDonough Becker of Redwood City; a son Frank "Jed" Becker of Darien; eleven grandchildren and three great-grandchildren; and a sister Margaret Miller of Virginia Beach. A funeral service will be held on Friday September 24, 2010 at 11am at Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Avenue in Greenwich. Private Burial will follow in Putnam Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, his memory may be honored by contributions to the Greenwich Historical Society 39 Strickland Road Cos Cob, CT 06807 or The Greenwich United Way 1 Lafayette Court Greenwich, Ct. 06830.

For receiver Braylon Edwards, his arrest on a misdemeanor drunken driving charge in Manhattan at 4:45 a.m. -- his blood-alcohol level was measured at twice the legal limit -- marked his latest run-in with the police. For the Jets, Edwards's latest misstep highlighted an organization criticized often lately, fairly or unfairly, for a lack of control.

2:44 p.m. | Updated Talk about your beginner's luck: in his first crack as a stage director Jerry Seinfeld is headed all the way to Broadway, and Colin Quinn - you know, the guy who has to get on stage and perform the show eight times a week -- is coming along, too. ''Colin Quinn Long Story Short,'' the one-man show starring Mr. Quinn, the comedian and ''Saturday Night Live'' alumnus, will transfer to the Helen Hayes Theater for an 11-week run, its producers said on Tuesday. The show, in which Mr. Quinn humorously condenses about 2,000 years of human history into about 75 minutes, was originally presented at the Bleecker Street Theater over the summer, where it was directed by Mr. Seinfeld.

Lindsay Lohan continues to keep the nation's legal system busy on two coasts. According to a filing made Monday in a Manhattan court reported by The Associated Press, Ms. Lohan, the 24-year-old ''Mean Girls'' star, withdrew her lawsuit against E-Trade over a Super Bowl commercial for that online brokerage that she believed was taking aim at her. In the advertisement, a baby with an adult's voice asks another infant whether he's been visited by ''that milkaholic Lindsay.'' A lawyer for Ms. Lohan wrote in an earlier filing that the babies ''were actually portraying'' Ms. Lohan ''and her grown-up friends,'' but a lawyer for E-Trade responded, ''No reasonable person would connect'' the actress with the commercial. Ms. Lohan may instead be marshaling her resources for her legal woes in California, where a Beverly Hills judge on Monday revoked her probation and issued a warrant for her arrest after she failed a drug test, The A.P. reported. Over the summer, Ms. Lohan served less than two weeks of a 90-day jail sentence and spent 22 days in a rehabilitation facility after missing a probation hearing in May stemming from her 2007 arrests on charges of drunken driving and drug possession. The warrant has been stayed until a Friday hearing to determine if Ms. Lohan's latest actions violated her probation.

WASHINGTON -- Some of the critical players in President Obama's national security team doubt his strategy in Afghanistan will succeed and have spent much of the last 20 months quarreling with one another over policy, personalities and turf, according to a new book. The book, ''Obama's Wars,'' by the journalist Bob Woodward, depicts an administration deeply torn over the war in Afghanistan even as the president agreed to triple troop levels there amid suspicion that he was being boxed in by the military. Mr. Obama's top White House adviser on Afghanistan and his special envoy for the region are described as believing the strategy will not work.

A cat strolled the courtyard of an apartment building at Park Avenue and 184th Street in the Bronx where a man was shot on Sept. 2. A woman was overheard talking about the amount of blood she saw between the first and second floors, and officers from the 48th Precinct searched for suspects, described as two men wearing shorts and white T-shirts. Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

HAMPLE--Stuart E.,84, of New York City, died on Sunday September 19, 2010 at home surrounded by family and friends. Stuart was an author, cartoonist and playwright whose works included the international best-seller "Children's Letters to God" and "The Silly Book" and most recently, "Dread and Superficiality: Woody Allen as Comic Strip". He is survived by his wife, Naomi Cohen Hample, of New York City and four children, Joseph, Henry, Martha, and Zack Hample and three grandchildren. A celebration memorial is being planned for the end of October. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to the American Civil Liberties Union.

An article in some editions on Friday about the opening of training camp for the New York Rangers erroneously included one player and omitted another among those who are there on a tryout basis. Besides the defenseman Alexei Semenov and the wing Ruslan Fedotenko, the defenseman Garnet Exebly is also trying out. The center Todd White is not a tryout; he has already signed with the team, having been acquired in a trade.

KATZ--Marilyn. Today we lost our dear friend. She fought a long, hard fight, but the cancer consumed her body and literally ate her alive. Till the very end, she was clear thinking and hopeful, she never gave up the fight until there was nothing left to give. Today we mourn her, with tears and sadness that it almost palpable. We will miss her every day of our lives, but down the road we will remember her strength, graciousness and style; and smile knowing that she was in our lives for over 30 years. So, we look towards the sky and say thank you Marilyn for being a part of our lives. You have been an inspiration to countless people, especially women in the workplace, who balance careers and family, making it seem effortless. Now, forever and then some. Carolyn and Francine. Graveside service at Mt Carmel Cemetery , Glendale NY, today 1pm.

The American International Group is close to a deal to sell two Japanese life insurance units to Prudential Financial for at least $4 billion, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday. If completed, the deal for the two units, the AIG Star Life Insurance Company and the AIG Edison Life Insurance Company, would be the latest by A.I.G. to raise money to help pay back its $130 billion taxpayer-financed bailout.

Michelle Obama will begin appearing on behalf of Democratic candidates starting in mid-October, bringing a softer appeal to voters for a continuation of the policies of her husband's party. Democratic candidates across the country have been agitating for the popular First Lady, who was a valuable asset for President Obama on the campaign trail in 2008. Aides to Mrs. Obama said she has been eager to start stumping. ''From the beginning, she's wanted to hit the campaign trail,'' said Susan Sher, the First Lady's chief of staff. ''It was just a matter of figuring out what would work with her schedule and what would be most useful.'' Advisers said Mrs. Obama has no plans to bring sharp-edged rhetoric to the campaign trail. They said the First Lady will not attack Republicans directly or accuse them of driving the country into a ditch. ''She's campaigning to advocate, to rally voters behind specific candidates based on what we can do together to build a better future,'' said Stephanie Cutter, assistant to the president for special projects. ''She comes to this as a mom, and that's the lens through which she sees the world and that's her test for every issue-what it means for her daughters and all of our kids.'' White House officials have built a schedule for the First Lady that focuses on a handful of candidates for the U.S. Senate and events for the Democratic National Committee's women's leadership forum. She will start in Wisconsin and Illinois, travel to Colorado, Washington state and California. Among the candidates to receive her help: Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado; Senator Russell D. Feingold of Wisconsin; Alexi Giannoulias who is running for the Senate in Illinois, and Senators Barbara Boxer of California and Patty Murray of Washington. Most of the events will be fundraisers - including one for the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi -- though aides said there will likely be some other public events added to the schedule in the coming days. So far, there are no major campaign-style rallies on Mrs. Obama's schedule. An aide explained that Mrs. Obama has chosen not to travel for the campaign on weekends, which makes it more difficult to schedule big public events. But aides said there are likely to be other events added to the First Lady's schedule, especially in the final days of the campaign, when the White House hopes to use her appeal to make a final pitch on behalf of candidates. Robert Gibbs, the White House press secretary, told reporters Tuesday that Mrs. Obama is an ''enormous asset'' for the administration and predicted that she will be an effective advocate for the candidates she campaigns with. ''She is, as you might guess, a popular ask on the campaign trail and I think she will go out and make a forceful and positive case for what this administration has done,'' Mr. Gibbs said. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

ROSENKRANZ--Susan Kahn. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Susan Kahn Rosenkranz and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

Lily Rabe will reprise her acclaimed Central Park performance as Portia in this fall's Broadway transfer of ''The Merchant of Venice,'' as will Byron Jennings in the title role, Antonio, and Heather Lind as Jessica, the daughter of Shylock (Al Pacino), the producers announced on Tuesday. But the play is also losing several actors who drew wide praise in the original production in the Park this summer. Jesse Tyler Ferguson, who played the clown Launcelot Gobbo, has returned to his ABC series, ''Modern Family''; he will be replaced by Christopher Fitzgerald, whose work as the leprechaun in the 2009 revival of ''Finian's Rainbow'' earned him a Tony Award nomination last spring. Hamish Linklater, who played Bassanio, is filming a movie; David Harbour (Nick in the 2005 Broadway revival of ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'') will play the role on Broadway.

Senate Republicans are not happy with their colleague, Senator Lisa Murkowski, for running as a write-in candidate in Alaska's Senate race, and they intend to show it. Not content with Ms. Murkowski's resignation from her position as vice chairwoman of the Senate Republican Conference, Republicans intend to meet on Wednesday and vote to strip her of her position as the senior Republican on the Energy and Natural Resources Committee.

KLEIN--Joan. We mourn the passing of Joan Lee Klein on Friday September 17, 2010 after a lengthy and courageous battle. She is survived by her husband of 51 years, Robert, her sister Norma, daughters Lisa Leffell (Michael) and Wendy Dunn (Brandon) and grandchildren Benjamin, Adam, Lauren, Ari, Sarah and Noah. May her memory be a blessing.

Dr. Murillo-Rohde, the founder of the National Association of Hispanic Nurses, passed away in her native Panama on September 5. Our condolences are extended to her family and friends. John C. KATZ--Ronen. Alchemy Properties Inc. mourns the untimely passing of our dear friend and partner Ronen Katz. Ronen was an extraordinary man whom we are very fortunate to have known. His passion, intelligence, humor and sensitivity will live on in all who were lucky enough to have spent time with him. Ronen was a mensch whose charisma and charm lit up any room he walked into. We absolutely loved him like our brother and will miss him terribly. Our thoughts and prayers go out to Ronen's parents and siblings as they mourn this incomprehensible loss. Kenneth S. Televisions, in the form of 10-inch video screens, made their debut in the New York City subway system on Tuesday, providing a vivid contrast to the usual static advertisements familiar to most commuters.

LANDE--Robert M. Died September 17, 2010. Devoted husband to the late Anita Lande, loving father to children and spouses Laura and Fred Graumann, Barbara Lande, and John Lande and Ann Harrell, loving grandfather to Carol and Billy Graumann. An article on Saturday about election violence in Afghanistan misstated the surname of a deputy interior minister who told a news conference in Kabul that preparations for protecting polling places had been proceeding peacefully. He is Gen. Munir Mohammed Mangal, not Mangar.

KARPE--Henry (April 22, 1925 to September 19, 2010) Loving husband to Charlotte, father of five and grandfather of six. He was compassionate and generous, a consummate host and true friend. Known for his sense of humor and thirst for knowledge, with an expansive, eclectic love of literature. He lived a life of service as a respected hospital executive in New York, Connecticut and the Midwest from 1956-80. From 1980 to the last he had his own health administrative consulting business. A scholar and mentor, he was an Associate Adjunct Professor for over 25 years at Columbia University and Hofstra. Services today at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Rego Park at 12:45. Family will be receiving guests at home through the morning of September 28.

The Hong Kong-based Lane Crawford, Asia's leading purveyor of all things luxury, is celebrating its 160 years of pioneering design by enlisting a small army of the store's style-setting friends from around the globe to create special pieces in honor of the celebration. Customized one-of-a-kind Burberry trenches were created by 23 top fashion folks like Anna Della Russo, Simon Doonan, Milan Vukmirovic and Lane Crawford's own gravity-defying fashion director Sarah Rutson, while eight antique Chinese Ming chairs were redesigned by the likes of Tom Dixon and Fornasetti. For the next 30 days, the Heritage 160 collection, as it is being called, is being sold off in an online auction to benefit Unicef. A store visit is also highly recommended in order to try on limited-edition reissues of iconic shoes from 13 top brands, including Jimmy Choo, Nicholas Kirkwood, Pierre Hardy and Christian Louboutin. It's sure to be a birthday party not to be missed.

Chalk it up to oversaturation, but the days of young bands blowing up overnight on MySpace are long gone. So it's all the more surprising to hear stories like the one of the Band Eclypse. The New York area octet put together an EP, "Ten Past," on their own, and self-published it on iTunes two weeks ago. Within 24 hours it had climbed to No. 9 on the music seller's influential hip-hop charts. The band's style is something of a 2010 update on the 1990s rap-rock formula, which sounds cringe worthy, but these teenagers (ages 14-19) put a spin on it that works. They rap over rock riffs reminiscent of MGMT and Phoenix, and set their rhymes into soft relief with an amazing shoegazer-y female vocalist. On the eve of their record release show on Friday at 7 p.m. at Santos Party House in TriBeCa, The Moment caught up with the band.

Plenty of baseball players have made a splash after being called up in midseason. But for Chris Carter, the A's 23-year-old outfield prospect, this September is one he would just as well forget. Carter (not to be confused with the Mets' Chris Carter or the former N.F.L. receiver Cris Carter) worked his way into the record books by going hitless in his first 10 starts. By the time he collected his first major league hit, on Sept. 20 - a line-drive single off the White Sox' Scott Linebrink - he had been waiting 11 games, 42 days and 34 at-bats.

Richard liked fancy restaurants well enough - or at least he indulged us and pretended that he did - but his favorite dishes were things like roasted and braised meats. Andrew Cuomo released a television advertisement on Thursday in his first direct assault on Carl P. Paladino, his Republican opponent in the New York governor's race.  The advertisements came a day after signs that Mr. Paladino, a novice candidate who won an upset victory in the Republican primary last week, showed unexpected strength, including a poll that showed him surprisingly close to Mr. Cuomo, New York State's attorney general. While a new poll issued Thursday showed a much wider gap, Mr. Cuomo, who had initially held Mr. Paladino at arm's length, appears to have concluded that it was time to confront his opponent more directly. Read more about the race on the City Room blog.

One of the more poetic sights at the London Design festival is "Thin Black Lines," an exhibition of new works by the Japanese design office Nendo at the Saatchi Gallery. Organized by Brent Dzekciorius of the auction house Phillips de Pury, the show (on view until the end of November) consists of pieces in steel that look like delicate, geometric line drawings, but which, when seen from certain angles, suddenly snap into three dimensions. Oki Sato, Nendo's founder, who likens the designs to Japanese calligraphy, says that they "move alternately between the becoming and collapse of form." In an adjoining gallery, the Projectory is a pop-up store (in place until April) that Dzekciorius has stocked with edgy pieces by young designers like Peter Marigold, Oscar Diaz and Leon Ransmeier.

More private military contractors than uniformed service members were killed while serving in Iraq and Afghanistan between January and June of this year, marking the first time that corporations have lost more personnel on America's battlefields than the United States military, according to ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative reporting group. The Austrian artist Franz West has long made art that can picked up or sat down upon without reservation as well as actual furniture that has the presence of sculpture. "If I would give the truthful answer," he says, "I would have to say that I really do not think in such categories between furniture and sculptures." His latest installation, "Roman Room," at Gagosian Gallery in Rome, makes a practical distinction if not a conceptual one. A cluster of sculptures made largely from papier-mâché, foam, gauze and cardboard, perched on low pedestals, intermingle with a pair of linen sheathed sofas and a chair that West created specially for the occasion. "I had the idea while watching my 3-year-old son looking up at the sculptures," the artist says of the arrangement. "The seatings make for alternative positions and viewing platforms throughout the show." The sculptures, which, depending on how you look at them and also maybe how old you are, might bring to mind enormous, melting ice cream treats, are as lumpy and charming as the seating is lean and angular. Both exude comfort in their own way. "When I was younger, I thought it was all right to make the visitor uncomfortable," West says. "But now that I am older it would not be correct because my problems have gone."

Break out the Champagne and the deposit slips. The PEN American Center has announced the 14 winners of its annual literary awards. Don DeLillo won the $25,000 Saul Bellow Award for Achievement in American Fiction, while Paul Harding, who earlier this year received the Pulitzer for his novel "Tinkers," won the $35,000 Robert Bingham Fellowship for Writers. Susan Choi was awarded the W. G. Sebald Award for a Fiction Writer in Mid-Career, worth $10,000, while Michael Scammell received a $5,000 award for his biography "Koestler: The Literary and Political Odyssey of a Twentieth-Century Skeptic." David Mamet took home the top prize for an American dramatist, Theresa Rebeck won the midcareer playwriting honor and Marilyn Hacker was cited for her poetry. They and the other winners will receive their awards at an Oct. 13 ceremony.

Richard Phibbs's black and white photography focuses on the graceful athleticism of man and beast, from sweaty rugby players in postgame repose to a snow-covered pack of horses to Phibbs's beloved dog, Huck, leaping over a sand dune. This refined ideal of beauty has made him the perfect photographer for Giorgio Armani, Polo Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein advertising campaigns. While working for Ralph Lauren, Phibbs formed an inspired partnership with the label's chief creative officer, Alfredo Paredes, whose encouragement and art direction led to "Chasing Beauty" (Powerhouse; $50), the photographer's first monograph, out next week. In his elegant foreword, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Michael Cunningham succinctly describes the images as a "vastly interconnected series of marvels, different in their particulars, but alike in their ravishing, unorthodox perfections."

A music review on Sept. 9 about Barbara Cook and Michael Feinstein, at Feinstein's at Loews Regency, misidentified the arranger of the version of ''I've Got You Under My Skin'' sung by Ms. Cook. It was arranged by Lee Musiker -- not John Oddo, the show's musical director.

An article on Aug. 26 about a new house in Racine, Wis., misidentified the media outlet that published a neighbor's characterization of the house as ''the ice cube.'' The comment appeared on RacinePost.com, a local news Web site, not in a local newspaper.

One of Lance Armstrong's close associates testified Wednesday before a federal grand jury in Los Angeles looking into possible crimes relating to doping in cycling, according to people briefed on the investigation. That associate, Stephanie McIlvain, served as Armstrong's liaison to the Oakley sunglass company and worked closely with Armstrong during the years he won the Tour de France. McIlvain was expected to be questioned about the events that unfolded in a hospital room in 1996, when she and others were visiting a cancer-stricken Armstrong.

FREEMAN--Irving. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Friar "Mickey" Irving Freeman, a member of the Friars Club since January, 1987. His quick wit and enormous talent for making people laugh will be missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. The Friars Club

Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, who has flexed his political muscle by backing victorious Tea Party candidates in Republican primaries across the nation, introduced legislation on Wednesday aimed at restricting the ability of federal agencies to issue new regulations. Mr. DeMint has accused the Obama administration of strangling various sectors of the economy with onerous regulations, and his bill would require Congressional approval of any new ''major rule'' - that is any regulation that ''may result in an annual effect on the economy of $100 million or more.''

FENIGER--Jerome Roland "Jerry", Jr.,83, died September 21, 2010. Happily married for 59 years to Marian Schwartz. Survived also by his loving children Robin, Bruce (Bonnie) and adored grandchildren Leah Nicole and William Jerome. He had a broadcasting career spanning 60 years pioneering the birth of television. In 1970, Feniger founded and became president of Horizon Communications, Inc., which owned and operated eight radio and television stations throughout the country. He was managing director of the Station Representatives Association, Inc., past president of the International Radio and Television Society, past chair of the International Radio and Television Foundation, and a member of the founding group of the Museum of Television and Radio (The Paley Center). Throughout these numerous leadership roles, Feniger continued to use his communication skills to connect with others. He served as the senior director of the Advertising Council and has been deeply involved in assisting various philanthropic organizations with their public service advertising campaigns. He also had been instrumental in helping Iowa alumni find professional success on the East Coast. Though Feniger did graduate work at Columbia University and New York University, and eventually earned an honorary doctorate from St. John University, his Iowa affinity remains strong. He received the Distinguished Alumni Service Award. In addition, Feniger provided generous financial resources for the UI, particularly through the endowed Jerome and Marian Feniger Fellowship in Communication Studies, which offers financial aid to needy and deserving majors who plan to pursue careers in broadcasting. Funeral services will be Friday 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to Lilian and Benjamin Herzberg Palliative Care Institute, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1020, New York 10029 and the University of Iowa Jerome and Marian Feniger Fellowship in Communications, University of Iowa Foundation, PO Box 4550, Iowa City, IA 52244-4550.

An article on Saturday about the Mets' Hispanic Heritage Night and the team's ties to Hispanic culture misspelled the given name of one of the four Latin players on the Mets' opening day roster in 2004. He is Ricky Gutierrez, not Rickey. The article also misstated the year that the catcher Paul Lo Duca and the reliever Billy Wagner joined the Mets. It was 2005, not 2006.

KULUKUNDIS--M. Michael, a much respected and loved member of the Greek shipping community and Director of Rethymnis and Kulukundis Ltd., passed away at his home in New York City on Sunday, September 19th. He was 76. Upon graduation from Harvard University in 1956, Mr. Kulukundis joined his father, shipping magnate Manuel E. Kulukundis, in the long running Kulukundis family ship owning interests established in 1832. In addition to his success in the shipping industry, Mr. M. Michael Kulukundis was also a pioneer in the technology industry through his company Ram Broadcasting Corporation in the radio paging and mobile telephone sectors throughout the 1970s and 80s. In 1988, Mr. Kulukundis formed and headed Ram Mobile Data which was the U.S. Operator of the Mobitex network and worked alongside RIM in devising the mobile data networks that today run devices such as the Blackberry. RAM Mobile Data was sold and renamed BellSouth Wireless Data in 1995 and later became Cingular Interactive when BellSouth and SBC Communications formed Cingular Wireless. Mr. Kulukundis is survived by his widow Tara, children Eric, Manuel, Cassandra, and Christopher and grandchildren, Alexandra, Michael, and Isabella. The family will receive the condolences of relatives and friends, wishing to attend in person on Wednesday, September 22nd, between the hours of 6:00 and 9:00pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. The funeral will take place at the Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74th Street, New York, NY 10021, on Thursday, September 23rd at 12 noon.

DRISCOLL--Brother John G.,CFC, Ph.D. The trustees, administration, faculty, alumni and students of Iona College are deeply saddened by the passing of our past president, Br. John G. Driscoll, CFC, PhD, who served as Iona College's sixth President for nearly 25 years. Br. Driscoll died peacefully on September 21 at St. Joseph's Care Center with Brothers and family members present. A graduate of Iona and long-time resident of New Rochelle, Br. Driscoll was Iona's top administrator from 1971 to 1995. He also served as a professor of mathematics and as a member of Iona's Board of Legal Trustees. Br. Discoll left a rich legacy as an inspired educator, visionary administrator, biblical scholar and a remarkable human being. Under Br. Driscoll's nearly quarter century as President, his leadership established Iona as one of the country's leading private Catholic colleges. In 1994, Br. Driscoll was inducted into Iona's Hall of Fame for his significant contribution in enhancing Iona's athletic department. He had been a driving force in the building of Mulcahy Center and Mazzella Field, expanding women's athletics, developing athletic scholarships in almost all sports and raising the competitive standing of Iona's teams. At his Hall of Fame induction ceremony he was aptly described as Iona's most loved and recognized alumnus, whose vision and stewardship of Iona athletics places him among our all-time greats. Br. Driscoll was born in New York City in 1933 to parents from Ireland. He obtained a Bachelor of Science degree in physics, summa cum laude from Iona. He continued his studies at various universities with high honors in chemistry, higher education administration, and certification in counseling psychology. He also was awarded a PhD in theoretical mathematics from Columbia University. Honorary doctorate degrees had also been conferred on him by the National University of Ireland, Galway; Pace University; St. Thomas Aquinas College; and the College of New Rochelle. Br. Driscoll was a long-time member of an international association of teachers and the Congregation of Christian Brothers. Br. Driscoll taught at all educational levels, including elementary schools in the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood of Manhattan's West Side, through secondary schools in Harlem, Midtown and the West Indies, as well as undergraduate and graduate universities in New York, Massachusetts, Michigan and Wisconsin. He lectured widely on education, psychology and religious life in the United States, the Caribbean and Western Europe. In February 1989, Br. Driscoll was appointed director of the Bat Kol Institute in Jerusalem, Israel. He was a member of the Board of Governors of the Marino Institute of Education, Dublin, Ireland. In addition, he served on many boards of governors of banks, corporations, hospitals and universities in the U.S. Since spring 1995 until recently, Br. Driscoll was a Scholar in Residence at Hebrew University in Israel. There, and at various other venues in Jerusalem, he studied Midrash, Talmud, the Hebrew language and biblical studies, with particular emphasis on the Jewish sources and tradition. He lectured on these topics in Jerusalem at the Ecce Home Institute in the Old City, Ein Kerem, and the Ratisbonne Pontifical Institute. He presented lectures on biblical studies taught through the Jewish traditions to Christian seminary groups and in religious education study centers in the US, India, South Africa, Italy, Zambia, Canada, the Philippines and Australia, among others. Br. Driscoll is survived by his brothers Michael P. Driscoll, CFC '56 and Kevin J. Driscoll, '75, '77 MBA, and his wife Peggy, and a sister Geraldine (Geri) M. Cryan and her husband Andrew. Br. Driscoll is predeceased by his parents John and Mary Kennedy Driscoll. Visitation will be held on Sunday, September 26, 1pm to 8pm, at Iona College, Burke Lounge in Spellman Hall. A funeral Mass will be held on Monday September 27, at 9:30am, Holy Family Church, 83 Clove Road, New Rochelle, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: The Br. John G. Driscoll Fund, Iona College 715 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10801 or St. Joseph's Care Center, 30 Montgomery Circle New Rochelle, NY 10805

Linkin Park and the R&B singer Trey Songz lead a wave of new releases on the latest Billboard album chart as the music industry gears up for its all-important fall sales season. Linkin Park notches its fourth No. 1 with ''A Thousand Suns'' (Warner Brothers). It sold 241,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan, just a hair more than the 240,000 copies Trey Songz had for his new ''Passion, Pain & Pleasure'' (Songbook/Atlantic). It was the best sales week of Trey Songz's four-album career but far from Linkin Park's best; its last record, ''Minutes to Midnight,'' had 623,000 in its first week out in 2007.

Joaquin Phoenix returned to the scene of his most famous television appearance - and acting performance - Wednesday night when he sat down for an interview with David Letterman. And unlike his previous trip to the Letterman couch, when he came on as a bearded, disoriented former actor turned rap artist, Mr. Phoenix was back to his former self, acknowledging - as his director Casey Affleck had last week - that he had never been that other guy anyway. It was all an elaborate extended bit of performance art, part of a fake documentary, ''I'm Still Here,'' cooked up by Mr. Affleck.

Taylor Phinney, the United States time trial champion, announced on Wednesday that he would not renew his contract with Lance Armstrong's RadioShack team, opting to join the BMC Racing team instead. Phinney said RadioShack had offered him only a one-year contract, while BMC offered a multiyear deal.

The Big City column on Wednesday, about Clare Burson, a songwriter who has recorded an album about her family's history and the Holocaust, misidentified the nationality of Geddy Lee of the band Rush, who also recorded a song about the Holocaust. He is Canadian, not American.

DILLON--Dorothy Hardin of Gladstone, NJ, died peacefully on September 16th, 2010 after a brief illness. She is survived by Sidney G. Dillon, her husband of 62 years; five children: Dorothy D. Raymond of Potomac, MD; Thomas H. Dillon of Oldwick, NJ; Lucy S. Dillon of Nantucket; Mary D. Bird of Bethesda, MD; Charles H. Dillon of Oldwick; nine grandchildren and a brother William D. Hardin. Mrs. Dillon graduated from Vassar College as President of her class in 1944-45 ("the Class with the Dash"). She received a Masters Degree in Education from Rutgers University. She put her education to work at Kent Place School in Summit, NJ, where she taught constitutional law, acted as the college advisor and served as Head of School. In more recent years she was the Development Director of the Somerset Hills YMCA and a founding trustee of The Willow School near Gladstone. Dorothy Dillon was an active at St. Luke's Church in Gladstone, where she was married in 1948. She was head of the Sunday School, a member of the Vestry, became Senior Warden, and chaired the successful Capital Campaign. Mrs. Dillon was also active in local politics, serving on the Peapack Gladstone Borough Council. For almost 50 years, Dorothy and her family summered on Nantucket. She was a member of the Sconset Chapel, the Sankaty Golf Club, and the Sconset Casino. She also served on the Board of Trustees of the Maria Mitchell Association. Always an athlete, Mrs. Dillon enjoyed many sports, both in college and later in life. She was a member for many years of the Somerset Lake & Game Club and the Somerset Hills Country Club. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church, Gladstone, at 11:00am on Monday, September 27th.

GREENBERG--Paul, died September 20, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Lenore. Devoted father of the late Jill and Gwen. Dear brother of Lenore. Adoring grandfather of Lauren, Amanda, Jake and Will. Funeral Friday, 11:30am at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale, NY 10583. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery Hasting-on Hudson, NY.

They claim it's democracy. I claim it's an abuse of democracy. You can find 3 percent against the Constitution of the United States, 3 percent against democracy, against the Bible. DONALD L. PLUSQUELLIC, mayor of Akron, Ohio, who survived a recall election after opponents gained the required 3,200 signatures in a city of more than 200,000. [A1]

MOREY--Alison, daughter of the late Elizabeth (King) and Lee Bogart Morey, died September 13th in Leesburg, Virginia. She was 75. She had been Chief of Litigation in the Consumer Protection Division at the Washington State Office of the Attorney General, and was a former counsel at Cahill, Gordon, & Reindell, specializing in antitrust and litigation. Alison was a graduate of the Brearley School, Wellesley College, and Columbia University School of Law, where she was editor of the Law Review. She is survived by her sisters, Mary Lee Rowen and Grace McKenzie; children, Melissa Barden Dowling, Scott Morey Barden, and Elizabeth Barden Ackerman; and grandchildren, Katherine Dowling, Maxfield Barden, Emma Kirkpatrick, James Ackerman, and Kepler Ackerman. A memorial service will be held at Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY, Saturday, September 25th at 11am. Contributions may be sent to the Harry L. King Trust for faculty development at Wellesley College.

A news analysis article on Aug. 12 about policy choices confronting the Federal Reserve misstated the year that William Poole, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, retired. It was 2008, not 2007. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Wednesday.

It's lights, camera, action for Lawrence H. Summers this week. Mr. Summers, the chief architect of President Obama's economic policy, has been dominating headlines since he announced Tuesday that he was leaving his White House post before the end of the year to return to Harvard.

COHN--Lucille S.,passed away in her home on September 22. Lucille was an artistic person and, other than her closeness to her family, devoted most of her life to various forms of art, including piano playing, singing, painting, tapestries, and writing poetry and prose. At the end of World War II, Lucille played piano and sang at various V.A. hospitals. She also did volunteer work for the New York Foundling Home. Her oil paintings were exhibited in a one-woman show in New York City, and at the Berkshire Museum where she had another showing of her creative tapestries. For the past 20 years she was very active at the Great Neck Senior Center where she taught painting, creative writing, and singing. Lucille was married for 65 years to Milton S. Cohn. Her daughter is Bonnie L. Winters, the mother of Lisa D. Barnacle, who gave her three beautiful great-grandchildren, James, Rachel, and Lindsay. The services will be held at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck on Sunday, September 26, at 10:00am. Donations in her memory can be made to the Great Neck Senior Center.

After the wave of entry-level D.S.L.R. cameras of the past two years, many of us are itching to move up to something a bit more capable - and the coming Nikon D7000 looks like a very solid midrange choice. Priced at $1,200 (body only) the D7000 sits above the $900 D90 and below the $1,700 D300S. (The D90 and D300S will remain available.) In features, the D7000 is much nearer the higher-end D300S, however, at a price that's $500 less.
Interactive feature detailing a designer's inexpensive makeover of the Jersey City home of a recent transplant from the West Coast. nytimes.com/home

The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced Wednesday that its chairman, David M. Rubenstein, is making a $10 million donation over five years. The gift includes $5 million for the National Symphony Orchestra, $2.5 million for other artistic programming, $1.5 million for education, and $1 million to support events like the Kennedy Center Honors and the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor. Mr. Rubenstein, a co-founder and managing director of the Carlyle Group, became chairman of the Kennedy Center in May. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

8 P.M. (NBC) COMMUNITY School's back in session at Greendale Community College, and -- who else? -- Betty White, above, shows up in a guest role as an esteemed but batty anthropology professor in this Season 2 premiere. Meanwhile Señor Chang (Ken Jeong) decides to enroll as a student so he can join the study group. The fifth-season premiere of ''30 Rock,'' at 8:30, finds Jack (Alec Baldwin) determined to help Liz (Tina Fey) hold on to a man for once by meddling in her relationship with Carol (Matt Damon). Elsewhere, Tracy (Tracy Morgan) agonizes over the termination of Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) as a page. And Jenna (Jane Krakowski) becomes the newest TGS producer. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Steve Carell begins his seventh and final season as Michael, who incites outrage when he refuses to fire the surly new assistant (Evan Peters). Meanwhile, Andy (Ed Helms) acts as if he doesn't mind that Erin (Ellie Kemper) has expressed interest in another man. And Pam (Jenna Fischer) thinks she'll impress Jim (John Krasinski) with a prank of her own. She could be wrong. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Johnny Weir swaps his figure skates for a pair of stilettos to run in the men's division of the ''High Heel-a-thon,'' a 150-yard dash in Central Park held on Tuesday -- in heels three inches or more -- to support the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health.

They are obviously expecting to have something to celebrate. One of the top lobbying firms in Washington is seeking partners for an exclusive election night soiree to be held downtown in the nation's capital. Those who help cover the costs of the party, being organized by Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld, will be able to spend a special night with top Congressional Republicans who hope to be toasting their rise to power. Democrats said the party seemed a tad cozy as well as presumptuous.

An obituary on Sept. 10 about Thomas Guinzburg, a former president of Viking Press, using information from the company, misstated the name of the man with whom his father, Harold K. Guinzburg, founded Viking in 1925. He was George S. Oppenheimer, not George S. Oppenheim.

KAMISHER--Martin, D.D.S. June 7, 1920 - September 21, 2010. Dearest friend of Irene Schultz for 15 years. Devoted husband to Annette. Loving father to Marcia and Stephen Falk, Diane and Hank Green, and Eric and Amy Kamisher and grandpa to Ben, Elizabeth, Elon, Rachel, Olivia and Alex. Exceptional dentist to his many patients. Founder and First President, B'nai B'rith No. Woodmere Lodge. Avid sailor and gardener. His smile and warmth lit up many rooms. For those who wish to contribute in his honor: Martin Kamisher Scholarship fund, www.surpriselake.org. Service Friday 11:30am Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck Plaza, NY 11021.

SCHINE--Joan Goldwasser, 87, on September 18 in her home in Westport, CT after a long illness. Mrs. Schine was the daughter of Edith and Israel Edwin Goldwasser. She was married to the late Harold L. Schine, and is survived by her children Judith Seltz of Alexandria, VA, James D. Schine of Yardley, PA, Robert S. Schine of Middlebury, VT, and Beth R. Schine of Framingham, MA, and by her eleven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, September 26, 2pm at Westport Town Hall, 110 Myrtle Avenue, Westport, CT.

AHEARN--John Joseph, passed away in his sleep at home in Plano, TX on Sunday, September 19, 2010. He was born September 9, 1926 in New York City, NY to John and Catherine Ahearn. An alumnus of Fordham University and its Law School, he served as a First Lieutenant in the Army in the Judge Advocate General's Office during the Korean conflict. Mr. Ahearn, a member of the New York State Bar, served over 25 years as a procurement attorney with the Department of Defense. He also enjoyed teaching as an adjunct professor at the University of Dallas. He shared over 39 years with his loving wife Kathleen Theresa O'Connor and together they raised four sons and one daughter. He is survived by his children Kevin Ahearn of Plano, TX, Brian Ahearn of Amarillo, TX, Christopher Ahearn of Allen, TX, Erin Ahearn of Plano, TX and his four granddaughters - Megan, Kristen, Kathleen and Lauren. Mr. Ahearn is preceded in death by his wife Kathleen, his son, John Joseph Ahearn Jr., his parents and two sisters, Peggy Slagg and Kathleen Ahearn. He loved life and his family. Visitation will be held from 7 to 9pm on Thursday, September 23, 2010 at Sparkman Hillcrest Funeral Home in Dallas, TX with the funeral Mass the following morning at 10am at Christ the King Catholic Church and Christian burial at Sparkman Hillcrest. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of your choice.

On Wednesday, Microsoft officially released a beta version of Internet Explorer 9, the latest remake of the company's nearly-ubiquitous Web browser. A few months from now, it will become the built-in browser on all new PCs. Most techies think of Internet Explorer as the first piece of software they replace on a new computer. Firefox, Chrome, Safari and Opera are the preferred browser brands among self-styled geeks. But IE9, as everyone calls it, has some features of its own that make it worth a test drive.

BURKE--Muriel Mary Sheehan, died peacefully on September 21, 2010 at age 93. Graduate of Holy Cross Academy and Drake Business School. Worked for the FBI and a Legal Secretary to Harry J. Burke, Esq. Survived by daughter Ann Loretta, granddaughter Jillian and son-in-law Craig. Donations to: Notre Dame School, 327 West 13th St. New York, NY 10014

The health care reform legislation, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, turns six months old today. And while the main features of the act won't go into effect until 2014, the government has begun laying the foundation for the law's major pillars. This report -- the first in a series -- grades progress in three main areas: ''Rollout'' (Are critical milestones being met?); ''Reactions'' (Are key health care and political players cooperating?); and ''Results'' (Is health care reform actually reining in insurance premiums and insuring more Americans?).

Mandi Schwartz, the Yale player whose battle with leukemia has drawn widespread attention, underwent a stem-cell transplant that her doctors hope will save her life. Schwartz, 22, was infused with umbilical cord blood from two donors in the procedure, which took place at the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance's adult inpatient transplant unit at the University of Washington Medical Center. Schwartz's case has been widely documented, thanks to efforts to find a stem-cell donor by her family, friends and teammates as well as Tedd Collins IV, who founded two leukemia-related charities after his daughter died a year ago after having the disease. Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, started an investigation into Collins's charities after The New York Times reported in July that Collins had a tangled legal history.

Most iPod docks make an effort at speaker separation for true stereo sound but, truth is, you're not going to get much physical separation of speakers in a 12-inch-wide chassis. Audyssey doesn't even try.

FENIGER--Jerome. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Friar, Jerome Feniger Jr. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Services will be held on Friday, September 24th at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The Friars Club

BLAUNER--Patricia, on September 21, 2010, at age 57. Beloved wife of Richard. Loving mother of Patrick and Christopher. Devoted sister of William and Robert McCabe, Joan Dodaro, Carol Aguirre and Kathleen McCabe. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass on Saturday at St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89th St. at 10am.

TAYLOR--Daniel Edward, who died after a short illness on August 26, was a lover of music and dance, peerless raconteur, Southern gentleman, athlete, aesthete, and mentor. Missed by his wide network of friends and family, his life will be celebrated on Tuesday, September 28, 7:15pm, at St. Luke of the Fields, 487 Hudson Street, New York City.

An article on Wednesday about the quarrels among President Obama's national security advisers described in a new book by Bob Woodward referred incompletely to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s reported assessment of Richard C. Holbrooke, the president's special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan. While Mr. Biden is indeed quoted as calling Mr. Holbrooke ''the most egotistical bastard I've ever met,'' he also is quoted saying that Mr. Holbrooke ''may be the right guy for the job.''

SHERIDAN--Msgr John Virgilius, beloved pastor emeritus of Our Lady of Malibu Church, Malibu, CA died September 17 at 4:30am of heart failure at UCLA Medical Center following injuries sustained in a single-car accident August 25. In a September 17 email announcement to parishes, Cardinal Roger Mahony wrote, "Ever since his serious automobile accident, his injuries and his age of 94 years have been huge challenges for his recovery. But his long and grace-filled journey on this earth has come to its conclusion, and he now enjoys the fullness of God's life as he believed and preached over these many decades. Please keep him and the people of Our Lady of Malibu Parish in your prayers." Msgr. Sheridan was injured in a single-car accident that claimed the life of Sister of St. Louis Mary Campbell, 75, a former teacher at Our Lady of Malibu School. Msgr. Sheridan, Sister Campbell and the driver of the car, U.S. Ambassador to Malta, Douglas Kmiec, were returning from a 60th anniversary celebration of the Sisters of St. Louis at Louisville Convent and High School in Woodland Hills. Born in County Longford, Ireland, Msgr. Sheridan completed his seminary studies at St. John's Seminary, Camarillo, and was ordained April 27, 1943 in St. Vibiana's Cathedral. After serving as an associate pastor at several parishes, including Holy Cross, St. Elizabeth (Altadena), St. Basil, and St. Vibiana Cathedral, he was appointed director of Our Lady Chapel and Catholic Information Center on Flower St. in downtown Los Angeles, where he served for 14 years. In 1965, he was appointed pastor of Our Lady of Malibu, retiring as pastor emeritus in 1990. A former columnist for The Tidings, the archdiocesan newspaper, Sheridan was a prolific writer and poet. "We have lost a grand priest and a true patriarch of our Catholic Community," said Cardinal Mahony. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on the grounds of Our Lady of Malibu Church on Friday, Sepember 24, at 11am, Cardinal Roger Mahony presiding.

An article last Thursday about tenkara, a form of traditional Japanese fly-fishing that has begun to attract anglers in the United States, misidentified the parts of the fly rod that hold the fishing line. They are guides -- not ferrules, which are joints that connect sections of a fishing rod.

A month after signing up Rosie O'Donnell for a daytime talk show, Oprah Winfrey's coming cable channel is adding a second chat-fest, this one centered around a panel of hosts. Ms. Winfrey's channel, called OWN, confirmed a New York Post report that it had hired the super-producer Mark Burnett to create the daytime show. The as-yet-untitled show will have its debut in January, the same month that the channel will start up. The hosts have not been named, but because it is a panel format it will inevitably draw comparisons to ''The View,'' the popular ABC show that briefly featured Ms. O'Donnell.

An article on Saturday about benefits in the new health care law for small businesses misstated the effect of rising insurance costs on a bookstore in Utah. Health care costs have grown to account for a third of the store's payroll expenses, not its revenue. The article also misidentified the source of the comment that small-business employees had been particularly vulnerable to certain lapses in insurance coverage. The observation was made by several people who were interviewed; the comment was not by John Arensmeyer, chief executive of Small Business Majority.

GALLANT--Edward. Born March 23, 1921, in NYC; died September 22, 2010, at his home in Stony Creek, CT. The youngest child of Louis and Fay Gallant, he grew up in Brooklyn. He left college to join the US Army Air Corps and served with great bravery (Distinguished Flying Cross with Oak Leaf Cluster, Purple Heart, Air Medal with four Oak Leaf Clusters, Bronze Star, etc) in World War II and Korea, attaining the rank of Captain in the USAF and acquiring a lifelong love of flying. He married Claire Bradoc on November 13, 1944. She survives him, as do their daughter Anne and grandson Ricky Song of Cornwall, CT; their son Brad, daughter-in-law Joanna Waley-Cohen, grandson Kit and granddaughter Isabel of New Haven, CT; two sisters, Marjorie Ginsburg and Sylvia Golomb; and nine nephews and nieces. A practicing lawyer for over 50 years, he served as Executive Director and General Counsel of the Connecticut State Employees Association from the 1950's until the 1970's and taught administrative law at Bridgeport (now Quinnipiac) Law School in the 1980's. He continued to advise local charities pro bono until shortly before his death. Unfailingly modest about his own achievements, he was intensely proud of those of his family. His innate respect for others, his moral dignity, his many kindnesses, and not least his sense of humor, will not be forgotten. A memorial service at the Unitarian Society of New Haven will be announced. A graveside service will be held at 2pm on September 25th in Stony Creek Cemetery. Contributions may be made to the Edward Gallant Financial Aid Fund (which was named in his honor earlier this year) c/o Vista Vocational and Life Skills Center, 1356 Old Clinton Road, Westbrook, CT 06498. May peace dwell in our hearts and understanding in our minds. May courage strengthen our will and the love of truth forever guide us. Amen.

No matter what James Stewart thought he saw from his wheelchair perched perilously close to the window overlooking his Greenwich Village courtyard in ''Rear Window,'' a federal judge said she did not see enough similarities between that 1954 Alfred Hitchcock thriller and the 2007 film ''Disturbia'' to rule that it infringed on the copyright of the earlier movie. In 2008 the Sheldon Abend Revocable Trust, which owns the rights to the 1942 Cornell Woolrich short story ''It Had to Be Murder,'' from which ''Rear Window'' was adapted, filed suit against DreamWorks and Paramount Pictures, which distributed ''Disturbia,'' as well as Steven Spielberg, a Dreamworks founder. The suit said ''Disturbia,'' which also chronicles a young man (played by Shia LaBeouf) who thinks he sees a murder while he is spying on a neighbor, had used the short story's plot without obtaining the trust's permission.

FENIGER--Jerry. West End Synagogue A Reconstructionist Congregation mourns the loss of the booming resonant voice so resolutely raised in enthusiastic ambition for our community. Our warm sympathies go to his beloved wife, Marian, and their children.

A couple of weeks ago, H.P. invited me to a preview of 11 new printers, enough to populate a very large boardroom table. I don't normally find printers totally mesmerizing-and I hope you don't either-but two were definitely worthy of a little rubbernecking. For starters, I've never seen a printer like the $249 H.P. Envy 100 e-All-in-One. It looks nothing like a printer: There's no unsightly paper trays or feeders, no awkward pop-up LCDs or even the slightest glimpse of a drive roller. Instead, the Envy 100 looks like a handsomely designed stereo component; all its printer-like mechanisms are tucked inside until you need them. That's a remarkable feat, considering that the printer is only 4 inches tall.
