''Kuk nisht af der vant!'' warned Shane Baker, who was giving a tour of the Hebrew Actors Union building to a group of Irish actors on Tuesday. ''Don't look at the wall.'' His Yiddish warning harked back to an old traditional superstition not to look upon the deceased stars of the Yiddish theater, whose portraits line the walls of the second-story banquet hall building, at 31 East Seventh Street in the East Village. ''They're all dead,'' he said, ''and there's only one way you get on the wall.''
GOLDBERG--Rena, 92. In memory of our beloved Mom, Grandma and Great- Grandma. Dearly loved and always remembered.

REITZ--Peter N.,on September 19, 2010 after a short battle with cancer. Born in David, Panama, April 21 1955, Peter graduated from Balboa High School (CZ) and was a Local 1 Stage Hand in NYC. He is survived by his mother, Mildred Lyness Reitz who resides in Panama, three brothers and sisters-in-law: Paul and Trudy, Philip and Beverly, and Perry "Sam" and Sherry; four nieces and a nephew: Nicole, Megan and husband Ray, Leah, Melissa and Lucas. A memorial service will be held at 10:00am on Saturday, September 25, Huguenot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Ave., Pelham, NY, 10803. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Church in support of the "Youth Mission Ministries". Peter shall be fondly remembered and missed by his many friends and family.

DRISCOLL--Brother John G.,C.F.C., Ph.D., Passed away on September 21, 2010. Former President of Iona College. Brother Driscoll was born on April 17, 1933 in New York City, the son of John and Mary Driscoll. Jack is survived by his brother Michael, also a Christian Brother, his sister Geri Driscoll Cryan and her husband Joe, his brother Kevin, (Iona 1975 and 1977) and his wife Peggy. Also, Jack is the loving uncle of six nieces and nephews, Kevin, Iona (1998), Sean, Iona (2000), Conor Cryan, Iona (2000), Siobhan Driscoll Fenton, Iona (2004), Eireann Cryan Iona (2007) and Brendan Iona (2011). Jack also has four grandnephews Jack, Colin and Ronan Driscoll and Michael Fenton. The Driscoll Cryan and Fenton families love him and will miss him very much. Bro. Driscoll was a member of the Edmund Rice Christian Brothers for over 60 years. He served in schools in New York, Antigua West Indies and Jerusalem. Bro. Driscoll served as President of Iona College form 1971 to 1995. A wake will be held at Spellman Hall at Iona College on Sunday, September 26 from 1pm to 8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Holy Family Church, 85 Mayflower Ave, New Rochelle, NY at 9:30am Monday, September 27, 2010. Interment to follow at Christian Brothers Cemetery, West Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to St. Joseph's Residence, 30 Montgomery Circle, New Rochelle, NY 10804 or the Driscoll Fund at Iona College.

COHN--Lucille. Lucille and Milton have been vice chairs of the Beth Israel Second Century Ball and generous to a number of hospital programs, most notably support for the Division of Digestive Diseases and the Department of Psychiatry. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Milton and the entire Cohn family over their loss. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman, Continuum and Beth Israel Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO, Continuum Harris M. Nagler, MD President Beth Israel Medical Center

RANCHO CUCAMONGA. Now there's an answer. The city was originally a land grant when California was under Mexican control, became home to the state's first winery and gained fame on The Jack Benny Program from Mel Blanc's train depot character's announcing, "Train now leaving on track five for Anaheim, Azusa and Cuc ... amonga." The name comes from the American Indian word "kukamonga," meaning "sandy place."

MILAN -- The models at the Versace show tonight looked wetted down; their shoulders and chests glistened, their red lips were heavily glossed and their hair was pulled into tight buns and covered with a snood of black vinyl or patent leather. Donatella Versace used all the top girls, naturally, and I can't remember when they looked that good. They could certainly walk, and that hasn't been true for a lot of the models this week in Milan. They seem to waver rather than walk.
In Udon Thani, a poor farming area in northeastern Thailand, marriages between Western men and Thai women are so common that they have become a local business.

General Motors, Ford Motor and Kia each have three contenders for the North American Car and Truck of the Year Awards, to be announced in January at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, plays hardball on the deepwater drilling moratorium: she threatens to block President Obama's pick to run the Office of Management and Budget unless the ban, set to expire at the end of November, is immediately lifted. Charles Isherwood, a theater critic for The New York Times, initially traveled to Zurich to hear the opera star Renée Fleming sing. In an unexpected twist, Sunday's cover story details how he also discovered the city's charms and even (gasp!) a few things he could afford.

The spirit of John Hughes seems to be making a resurgence this fall. Last week, the Film Society of Lincoln Center paid its respects to the director, who died last year, with a 25th-Anniversary screening of his teen comedy "The Breakfast Club." Now, Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden, the filmmakers behind the dramas "Half Nelson" and "Sugar," make their third directorial outing with a comedy inspired in part by Mr. Hughes's work. "It's Kind of a Funny Story," which opens October 8, is based on the young adult novel by Ned Vizzini and, much in the Hughesian tradition, features a teenage protagonist (Keir Gilchrist). Mr. Fleck and Ms. Boden discussed Mr. Hughes's impact in an interview for Arts & Leisure. While they didn't aim to copy the director's style, they did make a direct homage to "The Breakfast Club" in one scene. Below is a look at the scene from "Funny Story."
Mark Bittman adds cheese, herbs and spices to biscotti, which need not be sweet.

Yale University said on Friday that its endowment, which has sizable assets in real estate, had an investment gain of 8.9 percent last year, an underwhelming performance in a year when many big endowments are reporting gains of 9 percent to 14 percent.

On a day of rapid transitions and abrupt departures in the television industry, could the late-night landscape at least be spared? Apparently not: Max Weinberg, the drummer and longtime band leader for Conan O'Brien, will not be following the host to his new show at TBS, according to a report in The Riverfront Times of St. Louis.

Jay Carroll, the man behind the style site onetrippass.com, and who was recently featured in our men's fall fashion issue, has spent the last week driving from Portland, Oregon to Los Angeles with Jou-Yie Chou, the curator of the Ace Hotel and photographer Nate Bressler. Travelling in a vintage Airstream, they've picked up a couple of stylish friends -Cassie McGettigan, co-owner of San Francisco's Gravel & Gold,  Andrea Westerlind, the brand manager for outerwear company Fjallraven- along the way. The mission was simple: to collect all things California-from interesting artwork to vintage crafts. "Who doesn't want to cruise around the West Coast cultivating a cross section of California culture in an Airstream with good friends," says Carroll. "Stopping to camp every night, drink PBR and blast a daily dose of vitamin Neil?"

Reinhard Krause has spent much of his photojournalism career in some of the most tumultuous and critical places on the planet - including North Korea, Kosovo, Tibet and, most recently, the flooded regions of Pakistan. Beginning in November, all the hot spots in the world will constitute his beat, as the global pictures editor of Reuters, leading 400 staff and freelance photographers.
With the Yankees close to securing a playoff berth, Joe Girardi announced on Friday the first of a few changes intended to align the rotation heading in the division series opener on Oct. 6.

Consumers are getting used to seeing pitches for electric cars, thanks to the big ad campaign from Nissan Motor for its coming Leaf as well as efforts by Chevrolet to familiarize the public with the coming Volt.

The recession pushed nearly 100,000 additional New York City residents into poverty last year, according to an analysis by the Fiscal Policy Institute to be published on Monday.

This morning, Jasper Morrison held a press preview at his London studio and shop. He was showing the final prototypes of three designs: the country Trainer, a redesign of Camper's 1975 Camaleon shoe; the r5.5 platinum chronograph for the Swiss watchmaker Rado; and the DP01 phone for Punkt, a new Swiss company. I liked them all, but I loved the phone. It sits keyboard side up on a hammock-like base, so you can read the screen and dial the number without picking it up, and the handset is magnetized, so the phone can sit horizontally or vertically (and be mounted on a wall). That it's simple and beautiful goes without saying. The only bad thing about this phone is that it will not be available in the United States.

Slap Shot's blogger Stu Hackel is now also blogging for The Montreal Gazette's Habs Inside/Out blog and the sports departments of The Times and Gazette have agreed to cross-link Stu's posts. These Habs Inside/Out posts will, like The Morning Skate, generally focus on league-wide issues and news. Today's post concerns some familiar names, like Stanley Cup playoff hero Jaroslav Halak, Alex Kovalev, Nikolai Khabibulin, as well as items on the Rangers hopeful Ryan McDonagh and the Anaheim Ducks owners.

Thomas Doheny, spokesman for the Delaware Republican Party, was pretty tough on the opposition in the state's recent Senate primary. As it turned out, the opposition, Christine O'Donnell, won an upset victory, putting her on the campaign trail as the Republican Senate nominee while Mr. Doheny is hitting the road.

The list of intriguing games this Saturday starts right at the top, with No. 1 Alabama traveling to Arkansas to take on the Razorbacks and their Heisman hopeful, quarterback Ryan Mallett. The Tide has been dominant so far, and the return of Mark Ingram last week gives them even more firepower. This is the kind of game that makes coming out of the Southeastern Conference unscathed such a feat, as is South Carolina's matchup with Auburn. Notre Dame has hit some bumps already in Brian Kelly's first season as coach and it doesn't get any easier this weekend, with No. 16 Stanford coming to South Bend. Andrew Luck has been spectacular for the Cardinal so far, and a big game against the Irish could give him a lot of confidence heading into the rest of the Pac-10 schedule. West Virginia and Louisiana State are both undefeated, but have still managed to seem somewhat suspect. Will the Mountaineers be able to overcome the hostile environment they are sure to be greeted with in Baton Rouge? But perhaps the weekend's most intriguing game is Oregon State traveling to Boise State, where it will face the Broncos on the Smurf Turf. Boise State needs a convincing win to answer some of the critics now downplaying its victory over Virginia Tech. Of course, the Beavers have knocked off top teams before (just ask U.S.C.). Will the Broncos see their national championship hopes dashed or will they get through their final non-conference test without a blemish? We have our thoughts. Feel free to share yours.

When General Electric announced the WattStation electric car charger last July, it seemed likely that it would need a charging company partner to make sure its E.V. station, styled with a designer touch by Yves Behar, would reach a wider world. It's one thing to produce a nice piece of hardware, but quite another to actively engage with automakers, governments, businesses and interest groups to make sure they get installed, both in public and in home garages.
All the fashion news of the week that's fit to reprint.

Rabbi Moshe Steinberg recites a blessing in the sukkah outside his home on 41st Street in Borough Park, Brooklyn. Sukkahs, which symbolize the transient homes the Israelites built during their 40 years in the desert, are built yearly to celebrate the holiday Sukkot. Today is the second day of the weeklong Jewish holiday.

3:18 p.m. | Updated Michael Crawford is set to play the Wizard in Andrew Lloyd Webber's new production of "The Wizard of Oz," which will begin previews at the London Palladium on Feb. 7, 2011, according to Mr. Lloyd Webber's Web site. "We will be going a lot further than simply presenting the movie on stage," Mr. Lloyd Webber said in a comment posted on the site. "We have revisited the original novel and re-conceived our 'Oz' as a piece of new musical theater using the wonderful Arlen/Harburg songs and adding a few new ones where there are gaps." Mr. Crawford starred in Mr. Lloyd Webber's production of "The Phantom of the Opera" in the West End in 1986 and on Broadway in 1988, where he won a Tony Award for best actor in a musical. Danielle Hope, the winner of the BBC television reality show "Over the Rainbow," will play Dorothy. The production of L. Frank Baum's classic tale will be directed by Jeremy Sams, choreographed by Arlene Phillips, with music and lyrics by Harold Arlen and E.Y. Harburg, with additional music and lyrics by Mr. Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice.
Bristol builds expensive cars by hand in England and despite the global downturn, its sales are up.

Now that Subaru's engine is old enough to drink, the automaker has taken steps to make it less thirsty. Subaru announced on Thursday that it has redesigned the horizontally opposed 4-cylinder boxer engine that has been a key component of its vehicles for many years. This reworking marks the first substantial change to the engine since the current version was introduced in 1989.

It's a good weekend to be a beer drinker in New York. Today is the kick off of Craft Beer Week (It's actually a 10-day event that ends Oct. 3), when nearly 100 bars and 30 restaurants across all five boroughs will offer specials on beers (and some food pairings). A $10 pass gets you 3 beers.

Good food and good mattresses are a classic combination, but this season three inns are breathing new life into the restaurant-with-rooms trend. In London, the St. John chef Fergus Henderson (above left), known for his nose-to-tail fare, is teaming with Trevor Gulliver (above right) to bring his humble yet decadent principles to the St. John Hotel (1 Leicester Street; 011-44-207-251-0848; doubles from about $310). It will offer 15 whitewashed and wainscoted rooms (''mini grand urban hut'' is the theme) above the restaurant and bar. At Chicago's Longman & Eagle gastropub (2657 North Kedzie Avenue; 773-276-7110; doubles from $75), you'll soon be able to retire upstairs to one of six retro-modern rooms should that flight of small-batch bourbons prove too much. And why stay in a chateau when you can stay in a revolving dome? The Dôme de Montmiral (011-33-5-63-57-26-78; double room and board from about $193), near Castelnau de Montmiral, France, combines organic vegetarian food and cooking classes with a U.F.O.-worthy design.

The N.B.A. announced a crackdown on players complaining about calls at its annual referee camp on Thursday and a marginal increase in instant replay to include its use in clear-path fouls and all of overtime.
Shoes, handbags and glasses form the Gucci, Prada, Fendi and Verace spring 2011 shows.
Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekend's Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete articles.)

In this weekend's Your Money column, I take a deep dive into the world of what bankers like to call "mobile remote deposit capture." In English, that is a system that allows you to take a photograph of a check using a smartphone and then push a button to deposit it instantly into your checking account.

At World Maker Faire, you might see a robot solving a Rubik's Cube. Or you might watch visitors making full 360-degree circles in a swing while, in another pavilion, people dressed as mice tap dance around a life-size version of the game "Mouse Trap."

The Forbes Galleries on lower Fifth Avenue will be emptying out their darkened maze of toys in dioramas, The Associated Press reported. Sotheby's will organize about 7,500 pieces, including metal marching bands, submarines, motorcycles and a box of Titanic brand soap ("Guaranteed to Sink"), into about 250 lots for an auction on Dec. 17.

This summer Tarikh Korula and a friend set out into New York City's Lower East Side to a find a beer garden they had visited once before. There was one problem: neither of them remembered the name of the bar, let alone the street address. So they split up and began wandering down blocks, planning to call each other when they finally found their destination.
Sometimes, the past catches up to you.

In her review of "Enter the Void," Manohla Dargis writes that "the camera soars above the world like a bird, like a kite, like a ghost." With an exploration of the afterlife at its center, "Enter the Void" takes viewers on an extended, sometimes frantic, visual journey. Above, its director Gaspar Noé discusses a scene shot from overhead with a roving crane and featuring the film's two leads, Paz de la Huerta and Nathaniel Brown.

Style-setters like Margherita Missoni, Queen Rania of Jordan and Giovanna Battaglia of L'Uomo Vogue are wearing elegant but playful pieces by Ca & Lou, a new Milan-based label designed by the fashion insiders Carolina Neri and Bérengère Lux. Inspired by Art Deco geometric shapes with a touch of 1980s glamour, this Snake bracelet, of gold-dipped bronze and Swarovski crystals, is $565 at saksfifthavenue.com.

Overview | If the economic recession officially ended 15 months ago, why is the poverty rate still rising? In this lesson, students learn about the correlation between job growth and poverty. They investigate how national trends in economics, labor and commerce are playing out in their area and then go into the community to photograph and compile evidence. They present their findings in a class-wide project.

In June, as thousands of barrels of oil gushed hourly into the Gulf of Mexico from its blown-out deepwater well, BP was stripped from the Dow Jones Sustainability Index. The index, which tracks "sustainability leaders" in industry worldwide, determined that the oil spill was an "extraordinary event" that merited BP's removal.

Any iPhone owner knows that there are a lot of gadgets and objects the iPhone has replaced. Among its Web and communications abilities phone owners do not need maps, notepads, music players and a litany of other single-serving devices.

When it comes to checks to the head, the N.H.L. is trying something new this season. Earlier this week, the league released a video outlining its new rules on checks to the head delivered from the blindside or laterally, which mandates an automatic game misconduct and either a major or match penalty. The player also faces the possibility of supplementary discipline.

The comedian Stephen Colbert appeared in character before Congress on Friday to testify about an immigration bill that he acknowledged he had not read, "like most members of Congress." His credentials: a day spent picking beans in a segment for his satirical news show on Comedy Central. "I believe that one day of me studying anything makes me an expert," Mr. Colbert said. Read more on The Caucus...
Ridley Scott, known for directing movies like "Blade Runner" and "Gladiator," has chosen the winner of a contest to create short films that was sponsored by Philips.

I wanted so badly to hate this man. He's extremely handsome, with soft eyes, thick, curling lashes, and a nervous glance. It doesn't fit with the dirty green uniform and rickety gun hanging from his shoulder.

General Motors is recalling about 20,000 of its 2009-10 Cadillac CTS all-wheel-drive and CTS-V models. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said that in a frontal crash the CTS would not adequately protect an unbelted passenger under 5 feet tall sitting in the front seat.

In a television interview to be broadcast to Iran by the BBC's Persian-language satellite channel, President Obama said remarks made by Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, suggesting that the American government was responsible for the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, were "inexcusable." Watch the video, or read an excerpt of his comments, at The Lede blog.

Nelson D. Schwartz, a DealBook colleague, reports:

A Taiwan museum plans for the first time to lend a major painting for exhibition in China, Agence France-Presse reported. The National Taiwan Museum plans to lend a 17th-century portrait of a Chinese general, along with other artworks, to the Hubei Provincial Museum in central China and another museum in Fujian Province for exhibitions next year. In exchange, the museum in Hubei will lend more than 100 objects to the National Taiwan Museum for an exhibition in November.

It's another huge weekend in college football. The Southeastern Conference schedule gets started for real and gives us a couple of potential great games. Boise State needs a big win over Oregon State in its last non-conference test of the season. Notre Dame needs to avoid losing its third in a row. West Virginia hopes to boost the Big East's Q rating a little bit. Stay with me. There's a lot going on here.

In T's new fall travel issue, the spotlight is on Mexico City's movers and shakers - an illustrious bunch that includes architects, artists and actors photographed for a cover story in some of the capital's iconic spots. For a look at other cities on the rise, we survey the design scene in Valencia, Spain; check in on politically minded filmmakers in Sarajevo; and take the pulse in Seoul, where tradition gets cozy with 21st-century ambition. Then we head for the hills - that is, the mysterious peaks and untrammeled valleys of Roussillon, one of France's last frontiers. The pioneer spirit continues with a profile of the trailblazing hotelier and hitmaker Chris Blackwell, as well as a romp through the Canadian wilderness with one of the world's foremost food foragers. And for some unabashed sybaritism, we offer a top-to-toe guide to Marrakesh, a playground so swanky it will knock your caftan off.

One of the moody pleasures of this week's Book Review is Chester Higgins Jr.'s tender-tough black-and-white portrait of the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza, who are noted playwrights and the co-authors of the generational family novel "Some Sing, Some Cry." Our reviewer, Kaiama L. Glover, writes that the novel is "a rich mix of storytelling and African-American history" following "seven generations of black women who, largely through music, are able to survive the violence of their national and personal histories."

The Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe has won the $300,000 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, which recognizes artists who have had an extraordinary impact in their field. The award, named after the silent film stars, will be delivered at a ceremony on Oct. 27 in New York. Past winners include Robert Redford, Ornette Coleman, Merce Cunningham and Frank Gehry. Mr. Achebe's books are among the most widely read in African literature. His 1958 novel, "Things Fall Apart," has sold more than 10 million copies, and he has also won the Man Booker International Prize for Fiction and the Nigerian National Merit Award.

Stephen Colbert testified in Congress on Friday about an immigration bill that he said -- in all truthiness -- he had not read, "like most members of Congress."

Calling it "one of the most important discoveries for many years,'' curators at the Prado Museum in Madrid have uncovered what they say is the largest surviving canvas painted by the 16th-century Flemish master Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
Everyone has projects.
Mikhail Baryshnikov, Laurie Anderson and other artists describe working with Trisha Brown from the 1960s on.

Most museum fashion shows are relegated to a dark basement, reflecting not just the status of fashion vis-à-vis fine art but also the vulnerability of, say, a 150-year-old silk gown, to the effects of sunlight. When the Los Angeles County Museum of Art shows off its newly acquired, and reportedly groundbreaking, trove of European clothing on Saturday, it will do so in a new light-filled pavilion designed by Renzo Piano. "Fashioning Fashion: European Dress in Detail, 1700-1915," which runs through April 3, ends well before the invention of ready-to-wear. In this stunning context, even a man's vest from the 18th century (it is embroidered with symbolism relevant to the French Revolution and it predates the message T-shirt by at least 200 years) somehow seems modern and alive.
This weekend, Schott's Vocab is soliciting frozen words and phrases - those terms that are still in use, despite their archaic references.
A photographer's view of the allied offensive in Southern Afghanistan and a house so well insulated it doesn't need a furnace.

Major League Soccer's media machine has been operating at full power all week ahead of Friday night's match between the Red Bulls and Los Angeles Galaxy at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. The match will be televised live nationally by ESPN2 at 11 p.m. Eastern.

This week: Alexandra Jacobs on the novelist James Ellroy's new memoir, "The Hilliker Curse: My Pursuit of Women"; Kaiama Glover discusses "Some Sing, Some Cry," a novel by the sisters Ntozake Shange and Ifa Bayeza; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive)

Robert L. Nardelli has taken the helm of yet another portfolio company of Cerberus Capital Management, assuming on Friday the role of head of the gun maker Freedom Group's newly created office of the chief executive.

The hairstylist Guido Palau seems to have been hitting the history books since February - the look he created for the Marc Jacobs show was all '70s scene queens, and now for Prada he said he channeled the '30s icon Josephine Baker and her signature hairstyle, a helmet of Marcel waves. The hair was slicked down with Redken Hardwear 16 Super-Strong Sculpting Gel, and in the back it was coiled into two buns, which Palau intended to look "playful." Perhaps to shake up the historical reference, the makeup artist Pat McGrath created a futuristic look she said she meant to look a bit androgynous: a strong brow, clean skin and a shiny slick of silver across the eyelids. The metallic shadow offset the bright colors and Carmen Miranda prints in the "minimal baroque" collection, and the graphic shape of the hair on the forehead meshed perfectly with Prada's wacky eyewear.
If choosing the law firm that you could spend much of your professional life at was not already a frenetic and stressful enough process, the system became even a little bit more fast paced this year.
The Nissan Leaf is a go. In fact, until next year, it's gone.
For Op-Ed's 40th anniversary, author and professor Camille Paglia recounts the story behind her 1990 Op-Ed about feminism, Madonna, and the music video “Justify My Love.”

Lindsay Lohan was sent back to jail on Friday morning by a California judge after the actress failed a recent drug test, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, the "Mean Girls" star, was ordered by Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court to be held without bail until Oct. 22, when a formal probation hearing will be held.

A bipartisan bill introduced in the Senate this week that would require utilities nationwide to generate at least 15 percent of their electricity from renewable sources like wind, solar and biomass by 2021 continues to garner Republican support, with Charles E. Grassley of Iowa signing on as a co-sponsor. His support brings the number of Republican co-sponsors to four; 25 senators in all have signed on to the bill.
Last night the old masters up for auction at Sotheby's on York Avenue were heirloom vegetables. And they brought in more than $100,000 to support local farming programs.
SmartyPig, the online savings bank known for its competitive interest rates, recently became a little less generous.

Amgen's anemia drugs have been embroiled in controversy about their safety for several years as evidence has mounted that their overuse can cause heart attacks or strokes or make cancer worse. Now comes yet another problem, though presumably a temporary one.

Walt Frazier, the N.B.A Hall of Fame player who was known as "Clyde" in his heyday as a point guard for the Knicks, closed on three Harlem penthouses Thursday, for $2.4 million, according to the developer of the new condominium building, known as the Lenox Grand. Mr. Frazier bought the entire seventh and eighth floors of the building, with a total of 4,600 square feet and another 2,500 square feet of terraces. Our colleagues in the Real Estate section have the full story.

College educators - or at least those involved enough in political campaigns to donate - are indeed generally liberal. That is the implication of a new analysis of federal political contributions conducted by the Center for Responsive Politics, which tracks public data on campaign donations. Read more about the analysis, and view a chart at the Economix blog.

In Ristretto, Oliver Strand, the author of The Filter, a guide to New York coffee from The New York Times, explores the world of coffee gadgets, coffee beans and why it's never been easier to get a cortado.

When LeNell Smothers's landlord would not renew her lease and she reluctantly closed her beloved liquor store in Red Hook, taking her Alabama chandelier and little-boy-urinating fountain with her, her predictions for the future, however cryptic, proved prescient.

A series of commercials for six big Unilever brands, which appeared during - and were inspired by - the AMC series "Mad Men" were successful, according to the results of a study.

To get ready for this weekend's Le Grand Fooding 2010: New York vs. San Francisco at P.S.1, we asked David Chang to respond to Daniel Patterson's post about what West Coast cuisine really means. Gentlemen.

Mae Bishop, a proud Barbadian immigrant who raised two daughters and worked in the New York hotel industry, retiring in 1976 as an assistant housekeeper in the linen room at the Delmonico Hotel on Park Avenue, died on Wednesday. She was 102 - or, as she put it, just past the 72nd anniversary of her 30th birthday.

SINGAPORE - During a press meeting at the Mercedes motor home Thursday in Singapore, someone asked Michael Schumacher if we going to see him again next year. There had been rumors that he would not finish his contract at Mercedes and retire again in the off-season.

For young Americans with no health insurance, Thursday was an important day: those younger than 26 were able to join their parents' plans under the recently enacted health care overhaul. (Previously, children were dropped from their parents' policies at 19, or 23 if they were full-time students.) Young people make up the largest group of uninsured Americans, although they are healthier and cheaper to insure. And they are much less likely to vote. Still, in many states with high rates of uninsured young adults, providing health coverage is not at the forefront of political campaigns. Below, the areas of the country with high rates of uninsured, and how health care is playing out as an issue in those areas:

In a series of skits and "Weekend Update" segments over the last two years, the cast of "Saturday Night Live" has mercilessly mocked Gov. David A. Paterson's impaired vision and presented him as an improbably clumsy figure who walks into cameras, holds charts upside down, and hates New Jersey. The genial Mr. Paterson, in turn, has made it clear that he finds the parodies to be in poor taste, even for a comedy show.

In circumstances George Stephanopoulos probably never imagined when he gave up a hands-on role in politics to become a broadcaster, two fuzzy, nonhuman members of the "Sesame Street" cast joined him Friday morning on "Good Morning America," along with that PBS children's show's executive producer, Carol-Lynn Parente, to discuss the recent decision at "Sesame Street" to pull a music video featuring the pop singer Katy Perry.

Lisa Murkowski, who has decided to run a write-in campaign for the Senate, may soon have some company. Representative Mike Castle, the moderate Delaware Republican who was upended by Christine O'Donnell in the primary, is also said to be considering a write-in bid. Although both Mr. Castle and his advisers have characterized a bid as unlikely, his interest is serious enough that he's commissioned a poll, according to reporting by Politico.

During my recent interview with Martha Rose Shulman about her new Recipes for Health cookbook, she mentioned that she had just finished cooking up some new quinoa dishes. Although she has written about the grain before, she realized there was more to say -- and eat.

Jeff Zucker, the chief executive of NBC Universal, told the company's employees in an e-mail Friday morning that he would step down from his position upon the completion of the takeover of NBC by Comcast.

The Internet has been a great boon for wine lovers, not least for offering the opportunity to scan wine lists online in advance, relieving us of the awkward social withdrawal at the table for the task of wine selection. But Internet wine lists can also come back to bite you.

Protesters took to the streets of cities across Pakistan on Friday, calling on their government to intervene in the case of Aafia Siddiqui, an American-educated Pakistani scientist who was sentenced to 86 years in jail on Thursday in New York.

Norway's central bank has sued Citigroup over $835 million in losses on Citi shares and bonds.

Elisabeth Moss has certainly been a topic of conversation lately, possibly because of her acting work, which earned her a second consecutive Emmy Award-nomination for her performance on "Mad Men," or possibly because of articles like this one. This particular interview is going to address only one of those two topics; before a recent conversation with ArtsBeat, Ms. Moss let us know she would not discuss her personal life. But hey, why let 15 minutes of telephone time go to waste? Ms. Moss was still game to talk about her recent role in the comedy "Get Him to the Greek," in which she played the long-suffering girlfriend of a hapless record-label flunky played by Jonah Hill (and which will receive a DVD release on Tuesday). And of course she was open to discussing Peggy Olson, her "Mad Men" alter ego, who in just four seasons has gone from a timid new hire to an ambitious, pot-smoking, clothes-shedding, lesbian-befriending, dead-executive-secretary-poking young copywriter.

In an essay in the New York Times Magazine this weekend, my colleague Peggy Orenstein notes a change in the message that some marketers are aiming at girls. Or, more likely, at the mothers of girls. From the Target spot that paints back-to-school clothes as empowering with music from "Free to Be, You and Me" to the Verizon ad that shows bright-eyed, young women announcing, "I can lead the army that will follow," advertisers are selling girls as strong and powerful.
Hertz Global Holdings is standing by its deal to acquire the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, even after the Avis Budget Group unveiled on Thursday what it described as a significantly higher offer.
How sensitive is the White House to charges that President Obama has not done enough to push for an end to the military's "don't ask, don't tell" ban on gays serving openly in the armed forces?
Jonathan Klein, the president of the beleaguered CNN/U.S. cable channel, is being replaced by Ken Jautz, the head of the tabloid-oriented sister channel HLN, the company said Friday.

Henry Olsen at National Review Online has a smart critique up on my observation that the generic Congressional ballot may underestimate Democrats' standing in House races this year. Let me warn you up front: this post is going to get into some fairly technical issues.

Whether it's connecting a photographer with a stylist or finding the right location or editor, Laura Holmes puts all the fashion pieces together. Since leaving the London creative production company Gainsbury and Whiting, where she worked with Alexander McQueen, to set up her namesake company, Holmes has made a niche for herself in the worlds of photography and film production and has become the go-to girl for creatives like Sharif Hamza, who shot the most recent cover of Dazed & Confused. ¶ The family of Bob Probert, the Red Wings and Blackhawks enforcer who died last June at 45, have agreed to donate Probert's brain to Boston University researchers studying the health effects of repeated head trauma in athletes. "I know Dani and Bob had spoken about it prior to his passing," Daniel Parkinson, whose daughter Dani was married to Probert, tells AOL FanHouse. "I know he wanted to advance the research." Last year B.U.'s Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy released results of its study of the brain of Reggie Fleming, which showed the same kind of damage as that experienced by boxers and football players. Probert died of an apparent heart attack while boating on Lake St. Clair.
After a busy Thursday at the United Nations, President Obama's last day on his trip to New York is to include a working lunch with Southeast Asian leaders and a meeting dealing with Sudan.

Steamy AffairThere's no better way to end a day of dodging mopeds and vendors in the souks than a long steam at a hammam. The smell of roses emanating from the spa at Amanjena resort is so intoxicating that you'll quickly find yourself supine in the steam room. Choose from services that include a four-handed massage and a scrub-down with local products like black Moroccan soap and sesame seeds. Route de Ouarzazate; 011-212-524-39-90-00.

The financial system is still at risk even after an overhaul of financial regulation in the United States and new capital requirements for international banks, says Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve and an adviser to President Obama.

At the end of the 2009-2010 television season we said farewell to NBC's Thursday-night comedy lineup by noting how eerily similar the season finales of the network's sitcoms were. But what looked like mere coincidence in May is now starting to look like the guiding hand of some larger instrument, as "Community," "30 Rock" and "The Office" returned on Thursday night with similar jokes that can only point toward their convergence into one identical show.

Raj Rajaratnam is "a man of Falstaffian appetites and a craving for power," Forbes writes, in a profile of the former billionaire Galleon hedge fund manager arrested last October and charged with running the largest insider-trading ring busted since the 1980s.

Thursday was a rackety day of dissent at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, a leafy oasis opposite the United Nations, as this group or that group had its permissible moment to decry one of the world leaders appearing at the annual General Assembly session. Visiting the Vatican Museums after hours used to be a rare privilege enjoyed at great expense - think 275 euros (about $350) a person for a two-hour group tour. Strolling the galleries at twilight and basking in the glory of the Sistine Chapel without all the tour groups and daytime hordes is an extraordinary experience, even for the veteran traveler. Last fall, such experiences became a  lot more accessible when the Vatican Museums began organizing Friday night visits from 7 to 11  at the affordable price of 19 euros (about $24.30) per person.

Petroleo Brasileiro, the Brazilian oil and gas giant, on Thursday raised 120.36 billion reais in the largest share issue ever, arming it with the cash needed to realize an ambitious offshore development plan.
Oracle's chief executive, Larry Ellison, says his company won't follow one of the technology world's hottest trends: buying services companies.
Is Olam International, the Singapore-based commodity trader, heading for a merger with French rival Louis Dreyfus Commodities?
Investors who fell victim to Bernard L. Madoff's $65 billion Ponzi scheme should not be forced to return profits they believed they had legitimately made, U.S. lawmakers said on Thursday.
A senior Credit Suisse commodity executive and a team of traders have left the bank to set up a hedge fund backed by the Blackstone Group, the latest shake-up resulting from tough financial reform.

Europe's commercial real estate owners, saddled with 1.9 trillion euros ($2.5 trillion) of debt, may be forced to make billions of euros in cash payments under planned laws that would treat them like hedge funds, Bloomberg News reports.

Shares of CoreSite Realty, backed by founders of The Carlyle Group, remained relatively flat in their market debut, after the data center owner and manager raised about $270.4 million in its initial public offering.

Banks are sitting out the busiest September for corporate bond sales in a sign they may refrain from lending while the Federal Reserve considers how to jolt the economic recovery, Bloomberg News reports.
Stricter capital rules for banks could benefit distressed debt investors hoping to buy loans at a discount as lenders try to lighten their books, Reuters said, citing industry insiders.
A Democratic plan to aid small businesses was approved by the House on Thursday and sent to President Obama for his signature.
From Nick Bilton at Bits:

When David Lynch and Frank Gehry made headlines last year for their involvement in two multimillion-dollar cultural centers in the economically downtrodden city of Lodz, Poland, confusion ran high. What could they possibly see in the so-called Manchester of Poland? In fact, Lodz is undergoing something of a creative rebirth. The city has begun turning its 19th-century textile buildings into new-economy hubs - a case in point is the Manufaktura complex (Ogrodowa Street), home to a museum and the city's first upscale design hotel, Andel's. Lodz is also financing cultural festivals and programs aimed at retaining local art school grads, and once a planned high-speed rail slashes the Warsaw commute to 35 minutes, they'll have one more reason to stay put.

MIDDLETON--Thomas H. Loving husband of Jean C. Middleton. Beloved step-father of Tom Javits and Linda Tallant and their families. Screen and television actor. Columnist in the Los Angeles Times and Saturday Review. Author of Double-Crostic puzzles in the New York Times.

Tensions over the cheap renminbi are running high amid Chinese Prime Minister Wen Jiabao's visit to New York. Japan's deliberate weakening of the yen further aggravates China. The irony is that America, too, might be said to be pursuing a weak currency policy. And there are other, quieter, victims in the currency wars. Currency strains are proliferating because global growth is scarce. The United States is not recovering fast. Many American businesses and politicians accuse China of taking away American jobs. A Congressional committee may vote for trade sanctions on China on Friday. Quarrels could get nasty and lead to reprisals.

An article last Friday about issues involving an oil pipeline that carries oil from Canada to the Midwest referred imprecisely to how much of the Midwest's oil comes from Canada: 87 percent of its imported oil comes from Canada, not 87 percent of its total consumption. Also, because of an editing error, the article had the incorrect date for the start of the spill. It was Sept. 9, not Sept. 10.
SCHNITZLER--Dr. Irving. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Services Sunday, September 26, 9:30am at Shermans' Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn. (Avenue J).

KAMISHER--Martin, D.D.S. June 7, 1920 - September 21, 2010. Dearest friend of Irene Schultz for 15 years. Devoted husband to Annette. Loving father to Marcia and Stephen Falk, Diane and Hank Green, and Eric and Amy Kamisher and grandpa to Ben, Elizabeth, Elon, Rachel, Olivia and Alex. Exceptional dentist to his many patients. Founder and First President, B'nai B'rith No. Woodmere Lodge. Avid sailor and gardener. His smile and warmth lit up many rooms. For those who wish to contribute in his honor: Martin Kamisher Scholarship fund, www.surpriselake.org. Service Friday 11:30am Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck Plaza, NY 11021.

DRISCOLL--Jack. To my dear friend, Brother Jack Driscoll. I will never forget the times we have shared, our travels, our talks and your wise council. You have been my brother in spirit, who died too young trying to build understanding and peace among all religious groups. Your commitment to teaching interfaith relations has been the guiding light for so many. You will always have my deepest admiration and respect, and be part of my heart forever. Susan and I will miss you. Love from your "other brother" Jack

REITZ--Peter N.,on September 19, 2010 after a short battle with cancer. Born in David, Panama, April 21 1955, Peter graduated from Balboa High School (CZ) and was a Local 1 Stage Hand in NYC. He is survived by his mother, Mildred Lyness Reitz who resides in Panama, three brothers and sisters-in-law: Paul and Trudy, Philip and Beverly, and Perry "Sam" and Sherry; four nieces and a nephew: Nicole, Megan and husband Ray, Leah, Melissa and Lucas. A memorial service will be held at 10:00am on Saturday, September 25, Huguenot Memorial Church, 901 Pelhamdale Ave., Pelham, NY, 10803. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Church in support of the "Youth Mission Ministries". Peter shall be fondly remembered and missed by his many friends and family.
A listing of credits on Thursday with a theater review of ''The Divine Sister,'' at the SoHo Playhouse, misstated the surname of the composer of the show's music. He is Lewis Flinn, not Finn.

A critic's notebook on Saturday about an exhibition on Mark Twain at the Morgan Library & Museum, and the Mark Twain House & Museum in Hartford, misidentified the home in ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'' where Huck felt discomfort. It was Widow Douglas's -- not Aunt Polly's, where Tom Sawyer lived.

THE ARTS An article on Wednesday about an Afghan-American film director's efforts to shoot a feature film in Afghanistan reported that the director, Sonia Nassery Cole, said she took the leading role in her film after the actress she had cast had her feet cut off by militants. The local casting director and Latif Ahmadi, head of the Afghan Film Organization, corroborated Ms. Cole's account for the article. After the article appeared, questions were raised about the assertion, and in a followup article today on Page A10, Mr. Ahmadi contradicts his support of Ms. Cole's assertion, characterizing it as ''just propaganda for the film.''

8 P.M. (CBS) MEDIUM Freaky Friday: Mayhem ensues in this Season 7 opener after Allison (Patricia Arquette) and her daughter Bridgette (Maria Lark, above left, with Jake Weber and Ms. Arquette) have the same dream about a dead con man (Tony Sirico) and wind up swapping personalities. At 9, ''CSI: NY'' introduces Jo Danville (Sela Ward), a former F.B.I. agent, who gets an unusual welcome when she stumbles over the body of a young woman who has been murdered in the building that houses the N.Y.P.D. crime lab. 7 A.M. CALNAN--Steven R.,age 54, of New York City and Bridgehampton, died suddenly September 19th. Steve's beautiful life brought much joy and happiness to his wife Carol Finocchio, parents Beryl and Richard Calnan (deceased), and brothers Bob and Ron. Born in Waltham, MA he moved to New York to become a retoucher and artist. He was an avid fisherman and skier, and loved nature and animals, especially his cats Taffy and Boots. We will love him eternally and miss him immensely.

SCHWARTZ--Stephen H. Beloved brother, brother-in-law, uncle, grand-uncle, cousin and friend, was killed in a tragic car accident on September 22, 2010. If ever the words "He did it his way" were apt, they applied to Stephen. A true citizen of the world, he visited every corner of the globe, lived in many of them, had friends everywhere. Passionate in his commitment to ideas, political debate and cultural criticism, he lived and died a free man. He was only 66 and he will be deeply missed. Interment will be private. Shivah will be observed at the home of his brother and sister-in-law, Ellen and Michael Schwartz, New York City, Sunday-Tuesday, from 6-9pm, and Wednesday morning from 10-12. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

A television review on Thursday about ''Outsourced,'' a new NBC show about an American sent to run a call center in India, misidentified the job held by the Eastern European character played by Andy Kaufman on ''Taxi'' in citing earlier shows that portrayed cultural clashes. The character, Latka, was a mechanic, not a cabdriver.

A theater review on Monday about ''The Man Who Ate Michael Rockefeller,'' at the West End Theater, misidentified the area where Rockefeller disappeared in 1961. It was off the western coast of the island of New Guinea; not in the eastern part that is now the country of Papua New Guinea.
Audio clips of Europeans who are affected by the debt crisis on the Continent. They discuss their feelings on Europe's future and who's at fault. Nytimes.com/world

BOWRING--Shirley F.,formerly of Cold Spring Harbor NY. Died September 18, 2010 at her residence in Hilton Head Island, SC. Survived by daughters Sally Andersson, Lisa Bowring, grandchildren Nathaniel Sargent, Benjamin Sargent, Raina Hodgson, April Jakubisin and nine great-grandchildren. Memorial service 10am Tuesday, October 12, 2010 at The Cypress, Hilton Head Island.

Old favorites led the ratings on Wednesday night, but some new shows put up promising numbers. According to Nielsen's estimates, the new CBS legal drama ''The Defenders'' (12.1 million viewers) delivered the largest audience of any new show on the night, trouncing ABC's rival series ''The Whole Truth'' (4.9 million) and the second half of NBC's ''Law & Order: SVU'' (which averaged 10 million viewers in a two-hour premiere). Earlier on NBC, ''Undercovers'' (8.6 million), a new espionage thriller created by J. J. Abrams, made a solid if more modest debut. CBS's ''Criminal Minds'' (14.1 million) earned the night's largest audience, while ABC's Emmy-winning comedy ''Modern Family''(12.6 million) finished close behind for the premiere of its second season.

An article on Monday about the disappointing ratings for the ''Martha Stewart Show'' as it begins its sixth season misidentified, in some editions, the channel that is broadcasting the show. It is the Hallmark Channel, not NBC. (The show was on NBC stations in syndication for five seasons.)

Twenty years ago Stockard Channing transfixed audiences at Lincoln Center Theater as the conflicted wife of an Upper East Side art dealer in John Guare's play ''Six Degrees of Separation.'' This winter she'll return to the theater as another wife, this time a former member of Ronald Reagan's inner circle living in Palm Springs, in Jon Robin Baitz's new play ''Other Desert Cities.'' Ms. Channing and Stacy Keach will play the parents of a once-promising novelist, played by Elizabeth Marvel (now in Off Broadway's ''The Little Foxes''), who returns home after a six-year absence to celebrate Christmas - and who discloses plans to publish a memoir about her family. The Tony Award winner Linda Lavin (''Broadway Bound,'' last season's ''Collected Stories'') will play an aunt of Ms. Marvel's character. The role of the son in the family has yet to be cast.

RALSKE--Norman N.,M.D., 83, of Acton and Billerica Crossing, MA., formerly of NYC and Cambridge, MA., September 21, 2010. Husband of Eileen F. (O'Malley) Ralske. Father of Alycia Ogawa and husband Akira of Manhattan, Jan Ralske of Berlin, Germany, Erik Ralske of Tenafly, NJ., and Kurt Ralske and wife Gillian of Manhattan. Granfather of Kira, Elsa and Evan Ralske. Brother of the late Robert Ralske. Fond cousin of Rita Rogers of Newport, RI. A memorial service will be held Sun. Baz Luhrmann, the film auteur behind ''William Shakespeare's Romeo + Juliet'' and ''Moulin Rouge!,'' is moving forward on a long-intended stage musical adaptation of his first movie, ''Strictly Ballroom,'' with hopes of bringing it to Broadway someday, Mr. Luhrmann said in a phone interview this week. A 1992 romantic comedy inspired by Mr. Luhrmann's ballroom dance classes while growing up in Australia, ''Strictly Ballroom'' emerged as an award-winning audience favorite at the Cannes Film Festival and went on to achieve cult status in the United States and Europe. The movie itself was based on a 20-minute play that Mr. Luhrmann wrote in drama school.

COHN--Lucille S.,passed away in her home on September 22. Lucille was an artistic person and, other than her closeness to her family, devoted most of her life to various forms of art, including piano playing, singing, painting, tapestries, and writing poetry and prose. At the end of World War II, Lucille played piano and sang at various V.A. hospitals. She also did volunteer work for the New York Foundling Home. Her oil paintings were exhibited in a one-woman show in New York City, and at the Berkshire Museum where she had another showing of her creative tapestries. For the past 20 years she was very active at the Great Neck Senior Center where she taught painting, creative writing, and singing. Lucille was married for 65 years to Milton S. Cohn. Her daughter is Bonnie L. Winters, the mother of Lisa D. Barnacle, who gave her three beautiful great-grandchildren, James, Rachel, and Lindsay. The services will be held at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck on Sunday, September 26, at 10:00am. Donations in her memory can be made to the Great Neck Senior Center.

Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, said Thursday that she would block confirmation of President Obama's new budget director until the administration lifts the moratorium on deep-water oil drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. Ms. Landrieu, a steadfast supporter of the oil and gas industry, said that although she believes that Jack Lew is qualified to lead the White House Office of Management and Budget, she will place a hold on the nomination as long as the drilling pause is in place. The moratorium is set to expire on Nov. 30, although Department of Interior officials have hinted that it may be lifted sooner.

Phish's New Year's Eve concerts, although not quite as celebrated as its costumed Halloween shows, are still the stuff of jam-band legend. Rolling Stone called the show on Dec. 31, 1995, one of the best concerts of the 1990s, and the band's year-end shows are responsible for at least one marriage. But this year, dude, they're taking it to a whole other level, playing not only on New Year's Eve but also, the first time, on New Year's *Day*. As part of a string of year-end shows that begin at the DCU Center in Worcester, Mass., on Dec. 27 and 28, Phish will play three nights at Madison Square Garden, from Dec. 30 to Jan. 1. You can totally sign up right now for an early ticket lottery, and remaining tickets for the shows will go on sale on Oct. 9. Your ticket price includes access to an MP3 download of the entire show, although the guy four seats over is probably taping it anyway.

Break out the Champagne and the deposit slips. The PEN American Center has announced the 14 winners of its annual literary awards. Don DeLillo won the $25,000 Saul Bellow Award for Achievement in American Fiction, while Paul Harding, who earlier this year received the Pulitzer for his novel ''Tinkers,'' won the $35,000 Robert Bingham Fellowship for Writers. Susan Choi was awarded the W. G. Sebald Award for a Fiction Writer in Mid-Career, worth $10,000, while Michael Scammell received a $5,000 award for his biography ''Koestler: The Literary and Political Odyssey of a Twentieth-Century Skeptic.'' David Mamet took home the top prize for an American dramatist, Theresa Rebeck won the midcareer playwriting honor and Marilyn Hacker was cited for her poetry. They and the other winners will receive their awards at an Oct. 13 ceremony. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

COMBE--Mary Elizabeth Deming of Greenwich, Connecticut, died peacefully at home on September 20th. She was 94. Mary Elizabeth Deming was born on New Year's Eve in Ada, OH, on December 31, 1915, to Major Cliffe Deming and Okla Riley. She graduated from Ohio State University majoring in Fine Arts in 1938, the year she married the late Ivan D. Combe. In 1949 they started Combe Incorporated and built it into one of the largest privately owned health and beauty care companies in America. An inseparable team, they created such well-known brands as Clearasil, Just For Men Hair Color, Odor Eaters and more. An artist since her youth, Mary Elizabeth Combe expressed her particular love for flowers in the paintings that she did throughout her life. Her love for art extended to helping others find the art in themselves. Her philanthropy helped support Vermont's Manchester Music Festival and the Long Trail School Arts Program as well as music and arts programs in Greenwich and New York City. In 2000 Ivan and Mary Elizabeth Combe funded Camp Combe, a YMCA camp for children in Westchester and Putnam Counties, New York. She also served on the Round Hill Community Church Board, the Ohio Northern University Board and was Past President of Kappa Alpha Theta Sorority of Westchester. Mary Elizabeth Combe is survived by her three children, Diana Bickford, Juliette Larson and Christopher Combe, six grandchildren, eight great- grandchildren as well as her wonderful friends and caregivers - Stephanie Davenport and Angelica Maldonado. A memorial service will be held at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT 06831 on Tuesday, September 28, at 4pm. Donations in memory of Mary Elizabeth Combe may be sent to Heart Care International, 139 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06830 which funds U.S. doctor directed pediatric heart surgery in Central America.

FEHLHABER--William (Bill), age 98, of Scarsdale, NY passed away on Wednesday September 22, 2010. Beloved husband of the late Virginia (Ginny) S. Fehlhaber with whom he shared 64 years of marriage. William was born to William and Anna Fehlhaber on July 21, 1912 in Bronx, NY. He was a First Lieutenant in the United States Army and served over five years on active duty during WWII. A graduate of New York University School of Business formerly known as the School of Commerce with a Bachelor's and Master's Degrees in Business Administration. Mr. Fehlhaber during his professional career held many positions in accounting with various New York firms. Mr. Fehlhaber spent over 25 years with Shell Oil Company. He also served the Westchester County's Public Administrator's office as an investigator for over 10 years. William was a very loving, caring and supportive father. Throughout William's life he provided not only encouragement but tremendous fortitude to his family. A very caring and nurturing man who devoted his life to his family. His kind and giving heart touched many and will be greatly missed. Mr. Fehlhaber was involved in local community activities for many years. He was a member of the Village Lutheran Church in Bronxville, NY serving as an usher. He is survived by his only son, Craig and daughter-in-law, Kelly and cherished granddaughter Hallie all of Utica, NY. He leaves a very special nephew Frank (Skipper) Shaw III and his family of Illinois. William played an instrumental role in Skipper's younger years developing a very caring and loving relationship. William was pre-deceased by his parents William and Anna, a beloved sister Edna, his mother and father-in-law Anna and Frank Shaw and his two brother-in-laws Clarence Frank Shaw, Jr. and Herbert A. Shaw. The family wishes to express their sincere appreciation to Drs. Santry and Buttari, along with the staff at Lawrence Hospital in the Critical Care Unit (CCU) and the sixth floor nursing staff for providing such diligent and compassionate care. A special thank you to all the staff at Sunrise Senior Living in Fleetwood, Bill's second home for their care and compassion which was so comforting. Visitation will be held on Friday (today) from 11am to 12:30pm at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, 20 Cedar St., Bronxville, NY. William's funeral service will commence immediately following the visitation at 12:30pm. Interment will follow at The Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY.

What better way to open an orchestra's new season than with a new piece? That was Alan Gilbert's reasoning last September, when he inaugurated his tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic with the premiere of ''EXPO,'' an exciting work by Magnus Lindberg, the Philharmonic's composer in residence. On Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, Mr. Gilbert began his second season at the helm of the Philharmonic. Again the program, broadcast on PBS's ''Live From Lincoln Center,'' began with a premiere, this time of an ambitious new score by Wynton Marsalis, ''Swing Symphony'' (Symphony No. 3), written for and performed by the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra and the Philharmonic.

STRASSBURGER John R. - The Board of Trustees, faculty and staff, students and alumni of Ursinus College deeply mourn the loss of President Emeritus John R. Strassburger, an extraordinary leader who devoted his life to advancing liberal education and who transformed the lives of so many. An American historian, President Strassburger, 68, earned his undergraduate degree from Bates College, his master's degree from Cambridge University and Ph.D. from Princeton University. He was inaugurated as the 12th president of Ursinus College in January 1995, and retired June 30. Dr. Strassburger's focus was on student achievement, undergraduate research, and a nationally hailed "Common Intellectual Experience" first-year course. He also oversaw many campus improvements in the sciences and the arts. A Memorial Service will be held 4:30pm Sunday, Bomberger Hall, Ursinus College, Collegeville, PA. In lieu of flowers the family asks that gifts be made either to the John and Trudy Strassburger Faculty Development Fund or to the Annual Fund Challenge, at Ursinus College, 601 E. Main St., Collegeville, PA 19426. Attn: Advancement Office. We extend heartfelt condolences to his wife, daughters and family.

For young Americans with no health insurance, Thursday was an important day: those younger than 26 were able to join their parents' plans under the recently enacted health care overhaul. (Previously, children were dropped from their parents' policies at 19, or 23 if they were full-time students.) Young people make up the largest group of uninsured Americans, although they are healthier and cheaper to insure. And they are much less likely to vote.Still, in many states with high rates of uninsured young adults, providing health coverage is not at the forefront of political campaigns. An article on Saturday about Pope Benedict XVI's visit to Britain, aimed partly at improving relations between the Roman Catholic Church and the Church of England, referred incorrectly to the significance of Westminster Abbey. While it is one of Britain's most visited religious sites, it is not the seat of the Church of England. (That is Canterbury Cathedral.) The article also misinterpreted a prayer offered during an ecumenical service attended by the pope at Westminster Abbey. When the woman offering the prayer used ''she'' twice, the references were to the church; she did not refer to God as a woman.

It is an enduring image from last Thursday's storm: the car, innocently parked along a sidewalk or resting in a driveway, suddenly crushed into near-oblivion by a tree. True, cars are a luxury in many city neighborhoods - even, some would argue, an unnecessary assault on the environment. Still, city car owners have their reasons, and they suffer enough already: The jolting realization that it's 11 p.m., you're already in your pajamas, and you need to move the car to comply with alternate-side parking regulations. The tickets that come when that realization comes just a minute too late. Those shaming window stickers. The road-hogging garbage trucks. No right turn on red.

DRISCOLL--Brother John G.,CFC, Ph.D. The trustees, administration, faculty, alumni and students of Iona College are deeply saddened by the passing of our past president, Br. John G. Driscoll, CFC, PhD, who served as Iona College's sixth President for nearly 25 years. Br. Driscoll died peacefully on September 21 at St. Joseph's Care Center with Brothers and family members present. A graduate of Iona and long-time resident of New Rochelle, Br. Driscoll was Iona's top administrator from 1971 to 1995. He also served as a professor of mathematics and as a member of Iona's Board of Legal Trustees. Br. Discoll left a rich legacy as an inspired educator, visionary administrator, biblical scholar and a remarkable human being. Under Br. Driscoll's nearly quarter century as President, his leadership established Iona as one of the country's leading private Catholic colleges. In 1994, Br. Driscoll was inducted into Iona's Hall of Fame for his significant contribution in enhancing Iona's athletic department. He had been a driving force in the building of Mulcahy Center and Mazzella Field, expanding women's athletics, developing athletic scholarships in almost all sports and raising the competitive standing of Iona's teams. At his Hall of Fame induction ceremony he was aptly described as Iona's most loved and recognized alumnus, whose vision and stewardship of Iona athletics places him among our all-time greats. Br. Driscoll was born in New York City in 1933 to parents from Ireland. He obtained a Bachelor of Science degree in physics, summa cum laude from Iona. He continued his studies at various universities with high honors in chemistry, higher education administration, and certification in counseling psychology. He also was awarded a PhD in theoretical mathematics from Columbia University. Honorary doctorate degrees had also been conferred on him by the National University of Ireland, Galway; Pace University; St. Thomas Aquinas College; and the College of New Rochelle. Br. Driscoll was a long-time member of an international association of teachers and the Congregation of Christian Brothers. Br. Driscoll taught at all educational levels, including elementary schools in the Hell's Kitchen neighborhood of Manhattan's West Side, through secondary schools in Harlem, Midtown and the West Indies, as well as undergraduate and graduate universities in New York, Massachusetts, Michigan and Wisconsin. He lectured widely on education, psychology and religious life in the United States, the Caribbean and Western Europe. In February 1989, Br. Driscoll was appointed director of the Bat Kol Institute in Jerusalem, Israel. He was a member of the Board of Governors of the Marino Institute of Education, Dublin, Ireland. In addition, he served on many boards of governors of banks, corporations, hospitals and universities in the U.S. Since spring 1995 until recently, Br. Driscoll was a Scholar in Residence at Hebrew University in Israel. There, and at various other venues in Jerusalem, he studied Midrash, Talmud, the Hebrew language and biblical studies, with particular emphasis on the Jewish sources and tradition. He lectured on these topics in Jerusalem at the Ecce Home Institute in the Old City, Ein Kerem, and the Ratisbonne Pontifical Institute. He presented lectures on biblical studies taught through the Jewish traditions to Christian seminary groups and in religious education study centers in the US, India, South Africa, Italy, Zambia, Canada, the Philippines and Australia, among others. Br. Driscoll is survived by his brothers Michael P. Driscoll, CFC '56 and Kevin J. Driscoll, '75, '77 MBA, and his wife Peggy, and a sister Geraldine (Geri) M. Cryan and her husband Andrew. Br. Driscoll is predeceased by his parents John and Mary Kennedy Driscoll. Visitation will be held on Sunday, September 26, 1pm to 8pm, at Iona College, Burke Lounge in Spellman Hall. A funeral Mass will be held on Monday September 27, at 9:30am, Holy Family Church, 83 Clove Road, New Rochelle, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: The Br. John G. Driscoll Fund, Iona College 715 North Avenue, New Rochelle, NY 10801 or St. Joseph's Care Center, 30 Montgomery Circle New Rochelle, NY 10805

Mae Bishop, a proud Barbadian immigrant who raised two daughters and worked in the New York hotel industry, retiring in 1976 as an assistant housekeeper in the linen room at the Delmonico Hotel on Park Avenue, died on Wednesday. She was 102 - or, as she put it, just past the 72nd anniversary of her 30th birthday. The cause was pneumonia, said her grandson, Christian Hylton.

NUSSDORF--Dorothy Bunny. Passed away on September 22, 2010 at age 89. Beloved wife of nearly 68 years to Milton, loving mother of Gail Hefler (Elliott) and Steven Nussdorf, adoring grandmother of Scott Hefler and Laurie Krasik (Scott), and great-grandmother of Cooper Krasik and Skylar Krasik. She was a graduate of Hunter College from which she also received her MA and a teacher and guidance counselor in the New York City Public School System for many years. After retirement she wrote and performed dramatic presentations on the lives of movie stars. She was a co-founder of the Manhattan Chapter of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America and a past president of the Manhattan Chapter of Brandeis University's Women's Organization. Her love, special qualities, and unique sense of humor will be missed. Funeral services will be held at 12:30pm on Sunday, September 26th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

FALK--Oscar N.,93, of New Rochelle, NY, died, September 23, after a long illness. Survived by his beloved and devoted wife Ellin, loving children Joan, Jake, Alan, and four grandchildren, he was predeceased by his first wife Florence. Oscar, WWII veteran, was in New York City real estate and devoted to Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, NY, where he was a member for a half century. Funeral services Sunday, September 26, 1:30pm, Zion Memorial Chapel, Mamaroneck, NY. In lieu of flowers, charitable donations to UJA appreciated.

Lindsay Lohan was sent back to jail on Friday morning by a California judge after the actress failed a recent drug test, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, the ''Mean Girls'' star, was ordered by Judge Elden S. Fox of Los Angeles County Superior Court to be held without bail until Oct. 22, when a formal probation hearing will be held. Ms. Lohan this summer served less than two weeks of a 90-day jail sentence and spent 22 days in a rehabilitation facility after she missed a probation hearing in May that stemmed from 2007 arrests on charges of drunken driving and drug possession. Judge Fox on Monday revoked Ms. Lohan's probation and issued a warrant for her arrest after she failed a drug test she had been ordered to take as a condition of her probation. Ms. Lohan acknowledged this in a series of messages on her Twitter account in which she wrote, ''Substance abuse is a disease, which unfortunately doesn't go away over night. I am working hard to overcome it and am taking positive steps.''

Stephen Colbert testified in Congress on Friday about an immigration bill that he said -- in all truthiness -- he had not read, ''like most members of Congress.'' And when the comedian was challenged by one disgruntled lawmaker about his expertise, which was based on a single day spent hamming it up in a bean field for his show on Comedy Central, Mr. Colbert, keeping completely in character, said that was enough time to make him an expert on anything.

TUCKER--Mary R. Our beloved mother, Mary R. Tucker, age 74, died at her home on September 21, 2010. Born on October 29, 1935 in Manhattan, she lived in Armonk, NY. Mary attended Vassar College and received a BA in Early Childhood Education. She was a long time resident in Armonk, NY. Mary was an active member of Congregation B'nai Yisrael in Armonk, and worked as an election inspector for several years there, as well. Survivors include: her son and daughter-in-law, Bill and Barbara Tucker and their sons, Nick, Alex, and Dylan and her daughter and son-in-law, Sally Tucker-Levy and Robert Levy and their children Rebekah and Andrew. Other family members include her brother, Lewis Rose and his family, and Janet Klion and her family. Mary was preceded in death by her husband, Ralph Tucker, Jr. and her mother and father Elaine and Louis Rose. Services will be held at 12pm on Sunday, September 26, 2010 at Congregation B'nai Yisrael located at 2 Banksville Road in Armonk, NY. The burial will be held at the Kensico Cemetery. Relatives and friends of Mary are welcome to join us for a gathering at Congregation B'nai Yisrael on Sunday, September 26, 2010 between the hours of 2-4pm in remembrance of Mary. In lieu of flowers, contributions are welcome to: Congregation B'nai Yisrael at 2 Banksville Road in Armonk, NY 10504 or to The Guilford Art Center at 411 Church Street in Guilford, CT. 06437.
