8 P.M. (HBO) UP IN THE AIR (2009) A sleekly attired, flatteringly lighted George Clooney plays Ryan Bingham, a corporate assassin -- he fires people for a living -- and frequent flier who reaches a crossroads when a young upstart (Anna Kendrick) tries to change the rules of the game. Vera Farmiga, above with Mr. Clooney, is Alex, the fast-moving executive who, for the first time, causes Bingham to rethink his life. Reviewing this film, adapted by Jason Reitman (''Juno'') from the novel by Walter Kirn, in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis wrote, '' 'Up in the Air' is an assertively, and unapologetically, tidy package, from its use of romance to instill some drama into the narrative (the book introduces disease instead) and the mope-rock tunes that Mr. Reitman needlessly overuses.'' Still, she added, one of the film's pleasures is that its actresses ''share the frame with Mr. Clooney as equals, not props.'' In the end, ''however bright Mr. Clooney's smile, there is something terribly off about Bingham's blithe attitude both toward his own existential reality and his profession,'' Ms. Dargis said. ''Instructively, it is how Mr. Reitman circles around the character, showing how Bingham's actions affect not just him, but also those around him -- including the people he fires -- that deepens the movie if not its peripatetic center.'' 8 P.M. (Logo) WRANGLER: ANATOMY OF AN ICON The life and times of the 1970s gay pornography legend Jack Wrangler, from his childhood as a star on the Sunday morning religious television drama ''Faith of Our Children'' and his failed attempts at acting and directing to his crossover success in straight pornography and marriage to the singer Margaret Whiting.

SCHWARTZ--Stephen H. Beloved brother, brother-in-law, uncle, grand-uncle, cousin and friend, was killed in a tragic car accident on September 22, 2010. If ever the words "He did it his way" were apt, they applied to Stephen. A true citizen of the world, he visited every corner of the globe, lived in many of them, had friends everywhere. Passionate in his commitment to ideas, political debate and cultural criticism, he lived and died a free man. He was only 66 and he will be deeply missed. Interment will be private. Shivah will be observed at the home of his brother and sister-in-law, Ellen and Michael Schwartz, New York City, Sunday-Tuesday, from 6-9pm, and Wednesday morning from 10-12. A memorial celebration of his life will be held at a later date.

SHAFIR--Mary, 83, of Bal Harbour, Florida died on September 14, 2010. A native New Yorker, she had a lifelong passion for the city. Beloved mother, she is survived by three sons: Jeremiah Shafir and his wife Lorna of Newton, MA, Mark Shafir of New York City and Robert Shafir and his wife Donna of New York City; two sisters: Joyce Wiestmiller of Surfside, FL and Patricia Miles of St. Petersburg, FL; seven grandchildren: Caroline, Katherine, Allison, Nicholas, Max, Stephanie and Alex; a cousin, Christopher Smith of Whiting, NJ and two nephews: William Schnoor and his wife Roberta of Chestnut Hill, MA and Peter Schnoor and his wife Mary of Norwood, MA. Much devoted sister, she was predeceased by Eleanor (Wiestmiller) Schnoor, with whom she lived for many years. Mary, nee Wiestmiller, grew up in New York City where she graduated from Julia Richmond High School and worked as a hat model and dance instructor. She married Jere Shafir (deceased) in 1948 and raised her family in New York City and Englewood Cliffs, NJ. She sold real estate in northern New Jersey and volunteered at Englewood Hospital before moving to Bal Harbour, FL. For the last twenty four years, Mary lived at The Plaza, where she served on the board. She was an avid golfer and bridge player, pastimes she enjoyed right up to her death. All friends and family are welcome to attend a memorial service to honor Mary on Sunday, October 3 from 4:30pm to 6:30pm at Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue between 103rd and 104th Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in memory of Mary Shafir to Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Greater New York Chapter, 205 E. 42nd Street, Suite 1821, New York, NY 10017.

Fred Bierman handicaps Saturday's best college matchups. All times Eastern. 1 ALABAMA at 10 ARKANSAS 3:30 p.m., CBS The defending champions face a test on the road against an up-and-coming conference foe.

THE ARTS A listing of credits and contact information on Thursday with a theater review of ''The Divine Sister,'' at the SoHo Playhouse, misstated the theater's telephone number. It is (212) 691-1555.

DRUCKER--Terry, 95, September 24. Beloved mother of Dr. Jan Drucker and adored grandmother of Matthew. Lifelong dedicated New Yorker, Barnard Class of '35, Terry had a highly respected career as reporter, researcher and editor at Time and Life Magazines and Time-Life books, followed by free lance research, travel, and devotion to grandparenting. Admired for her intelligence, courage and commitment to her values, Terry was a rare person who retained the interests, social, and political values of her youth and was one of the youngest nonagenarians one could know. Contributions to Manhattan Country School or an organization of your choice. Informal gathering in celebration of her life at 260 WEA, Sunday, September 26, 3-8pm.

DRISCOLL--Brother John G.,C.F.C., Ph.D., Passed away on September 21, 2010. Former President of Iona College. Brother Driscoll was born on April 17, 1933 in New York City, the son of John and Mary Driscoll. Jack is survived by his brother Michael, also a Christian Brother, his sister Geri Driscoll Cryan and her husband Joe, his brother Kevin, (Iona 1975 and 1977) and his wife Peggy. Also, Jack is the loving uncle of six nieces and nephews, Kevin, Iona (1998), Sean, Iona (2000), Conor Cryan, Iona (2000), Siobhan Driscoll Fenton, Iona (2004), Eireann Cryan Iona (2007) and Brendan Iona (2011). Jack also has four grandnephews Jack, Colin and Ronan Driscoll and Michael Fenton. The Driscoll Cryan and Fenton families love him and will miss him very much. Bro. Driscoll was a member of the Edmund Rice Christian Brothers for over 60 years. He served in schools in New York, Antigua West Indies and Jerusalem. Bro. Driscoll served as President of Iona College form 1971 to 1995. A wake will be held at Spellman Hall at Iona College on Sunday, September 26 from 1pm to 8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Holy Family Church, 85 Mayflower Ave, New Rochelle, NY at 9:30am Monday, September 27, 2010. Interment to follow at Christian Brothers Cemetery, West Park, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to St. Joseph's Residence, 30 Montgomery Circle, New Rochelle, NY 10804 or the Driscoll Fund at Iona College.

INTERNATIONAL A headline on Friday with an article about an incendiary speech in the United Nations General Assembly by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran summarized his remarks about the Sept. 11 terror attacks incorrectly. In his speech, Mr. Ahmadinejad asserted various theories about the origin of the attacks, including the possibility that they had been planned by the United States. He did not say that the United States had planned the attacks.
HALITZER--Sidney. Shelter Rock Tennis Club mourns his loss and extends sympathy to his wife Nettie and family.

SCHNEIDER--Lynn Andrea, passed away on Thursday, September 23, at age 45. A free spirit who lived and loved life. Survived by her adored partner, Chris Haydel, devoted father, Donald Schneider, her loving sisters and brother, Lisa Simoncic, Lorin Schneider and Raymond Ennis and nieces Danielle and Alexandra Simoncic and Rebecca and Amanda. Services Sunday, September 26 at 2pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91 Street.

COMBE--Mary Elizabeth Deming of Greenwich, Connecticut, died peacefully at home on September 20th. She was 94. Mary Elizabeth Deming was born on New Year's Eve in Ada, OH, on December 31, 1915, to Major Cliffe Deming and Okla Riley. She graduated from Ohio State University majoring in Fine Arts in 1938, the year she married the late Ivan D. Combe. In 1949 they started Combe Incorporated and built it into one of the largest privately owned health and beauty care companies in America. An inseparable team, they created such well-known brands as Clearasil, Just For Men Hair Color, Odor Eaters and more. An artist since her youth, Mary Elizabeth Combe expressed her particular love for flowers in the paintings that she did throughout her life. Her love for art extended to helping others find the art in themselves. Her philanthropy helped support Vermont's Manchester Music Festival and the Long Trail School Arts Program as well as music and arts programs in Greenwich and New York City. In 2000 Ivan and Mary Elizabeth Combe funded Camp Combe, a YMCA camp for children in Westchester and Putnam Counties, New York. She also served on the Round Hill Community Church Board, the Ohio Northern University Board and was Past President of Kappa Alpha Theta Sorority of Westchester. Mary Elizabeth Combe is survived by her three children, Diana Bickford, Juliette Larson and Christopher Combe, six grandchildren, eight great- grandchildren as well as her wonderful friends and caregivers - Stephanie Davenport and Angelica Maldonado. A memorial service will be held at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT 06831 on Tuesday, September 28, at 4pm. Donations in memory of Mary Elizabeth Combe may be sent to Heart Care International, 139 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT 06830 which funds U.S. doctor directed pediatric heart surgery in Central America.

SPORTS An article on Wednesday about the arrest of Jets receiver Braylon Edwards on a drunken-driving charge misstated the terms of his sentence after an altercation at a Cleveland nightclub last Oct. 5. He pleaded no contest to aggravated disorderly conduct in January and was placed on probation for 18 months; he did not serve jail time and therefore this latest charge could not constitute ''a violation of his parole.''

NEW YORK Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a vote of confidence from Muslim leaders over the proposed Islamic community center in Lower Manhattan may have left the incorrect impression that the Islamic Leadership Council of Metropolitan New York was listed as an unindicted co-conspirator in a case against a charity whose leaders were convicted of funneling money to Hamas. The reference to ''the council'' involved in the case was to the Council on American-Islamic Relations.

HALITZER--Sidney. Loving husband, father, grandfather. Founder, owner/operator of Sid Hall, Inc. Veteran of WWII. Passionate tennis player, member of Shelter Rock Tennis Club. Active fundraiser, supporter and honoree of UJA/FEDERATION for 50 years. October 4, 1919 - September 22, 2010.
In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began. The ''time on the market'' is from the most recent listing to the sales agreement.

Eddie Fisher, whose matinee-idol looks and smooth, romantic voice made him one of the most popular singers of the 1950s, and whose busy love life stole headlines in 1959 when he divorced Debbie Reynolds to marry Elizabeth Taylor, died on Wednesday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 82. The cause was complications of hip surgery, his daughter Tricia Leigh Fisher told The Associated Press.

MASI--Jeanette Watercolor artist. Born July 29, 1915, died peacefully September 21 surrounded by her family. She was 95. Known to many as "Nettie" she was a woman of many talents. A professional artist who excelled in most media including oils, acrylics, pastels, water colors, and mixed media, Jeanette achieved state and national recognition for her artistic talents. She was passionate about art and loved to paint anything she saw. She was a past Co-Chairwoman of the annual juried Sidewalk Show of South Orange and Maplewood and a member of several art associations including the prestigious New Jersey Water Color Society and the American Water Color Society. Jeanette was honored with numerous awards by fine arts organizations in New Jersey and New York and earned a Merit Award from the highly regarded Salmagundi Art Club in New York and the Dagmar H. Tribble Memorial Award from the Garden State Watercolor Society. Her paintings were exhibited in numerous galleries and in many outdoor exhibits including the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit in Greenwich Village, New York and the South Orange Outdoor Art exhibit beginning in the 1960s and continuing throughout the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. She continued to submit paintings in juried shows until 2008 with great success. It is remarkable that her professional art career did not begin until she was in her 50s and had already raised five children. Jeanette is survived by her children, daughters: Sandy and her husband Joe Gigliotti, Bonni Masi Oswald, Susan Masi, Carol Masi and son, Tom Masi and his wife Luby; 10 grandchildren: Greg and his wife Kristine, John and his wife Day and Joe Gigliotti; Peter and his wife Elena Mele; John and his wife Robin, Tucker and his wife Shauna, Kurt and his wife Lindsay and Kirsten Oswald, John and Jenna Masi and eleven great-grandchildren: Annie and Gracie Gigliotti, Griffin and Sydney Gigliotti, Carson, Harrison and Reilly Oswald, Rowan and Reagan Oswald and Nicolas and Alexandra Mele. In addition to her art work, Jeanette's memory will endure as a lively and unique individual who always kept an open door. There were always good spirits, food and an ample supply of manhattans to greet all visitors. Jeanette was a resident of South Orange for more than 60 years. Her home "155" in South Orange was a central gathering point for family, friends and art groups for decades. Holiday parties and special occasions would last throughout the night. Some would go to bed only to find others in the morning still gathered around the table talking and cooking breakfast. Jeanette's spirit, creativity, wit, inspiration and ability to reinvent herself no matter what the challenge, will be with us for generations to come. Visitation will be at Galloway and Crane Funeral Home on South Finley Avenue in Basking Ridge, NJ on Sunday, September 26 from 3 to 7pm. Funeral Mass will be held at Jeanette's home parish of Our Lady of Sorrows in South Orange, NJ on Monday, September 27 at 10:15am. Interment will be at Holy Cross Cemetery on Mt. Airy Road in Bernardsville, NJ at noon. Memorial donations in Jeanette's honor may be made to the Villa Walsh Jeanette Fragasso Masi Memorial Art Award, c/o Villa Walsh Academy, 455 Western Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07960.

TUCKER--Mary. We at Congregation B'nai Yisrael mourn the death of our longtime friend Mary Tucker. We share our sadness with her children and grandchildren. Many will miss her vibrant personality. Lawrence C. Fox, President, Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz, Rabbi Seth M. Limmer, Cantor Hayley Kobilinsky

Calling it ''one of the most important discoveries for many years,'' curators at the Prado Museum in Madrid have uncovered what they say is the largest surviving canvas painted by the 16th-century Flemish master Pieter Bruegel the Elder. While cleaning the work -- ''The Wine of Saint Martin's Day'' -- which was thought to have been painted by the artist's less-talented son, conservators began to see a far more accomplished composition. X-rays then revealed Bruegel the Elder's signature, making it the 41st known signed painting by the artist, and roman numerals dating the work between 1565 and 1568.

The technology industry is being rattled by a quiet and sophisticated malicious software program that has infiltrated factory computers. The malware, known as Stuxnet, was discovered in mid July, at least several months after its creation, by VirusBlokAda, a Belarussian computer security company that was alerted by a customer.

BORGENICHT--Travis. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed Friar Travis Borgenicht. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. TRAVEL The 36 Hours column on Page 10 this weekend, about Chicago, misstates the name of a well-known shopping district along Michigan Avenue. It is the Magnificent Mile, not the Miracle Mile. The column also misstates the distance from the ''L'' to Logan Square. It is about five to six miles, not two. And the column describes the academic calendar of the University of Chicago incorrectly. The school is on a quarterly system, not semesters.

A Taiwan museum plans for the first time to lend a major painting for exhibition in China, Agence France-Presse reported. The National Taiwan Museum plans to lend a 17th-century portrait of a Chinese general, along with other artworks, to the Hubei Provincial Museum in central China and another museum in Fujian Province for exhibitions next year. In exchange, the museum in Hubei will lend more than 100 objects to the National Taiwan Museum for an exhibition in November. Taiwan has been hesitant to send important artworks to China, fearing they would be confiscated. But this painting does not belong to a group of artifacts that is the subject of particular contention between the countries: thousands of Chinese imperial treasures that were shipped to Taiwan in 1949 by the Chinese Nationalists, who were being routed by the Communists. Those objects now form the collection of the National Palace Museum in Taipei. The National Palace Museum maintains that it will not lend objects to China until the Chinese government formally agrees that it will not seize them.

The Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe has won the $300,000 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, which recognizes artists who have had an extraordinary impact in their field. The award, named after the silent film stars, will be delivered at a ceremony on Oct. 27 in New York. Past winners include Robert Redford, Ornette Coleman, Merce Cunningham and Frank Gehry. Mr. Achebe's books are among the most widely read in African literature. His 1958 novel, ''Things Fall Apart,'' has sold more than 10 million copies, and he has also won the Man Booker International Prize for Fiction and the Nigerian National Merit Award. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Tea Party is off. At least, the National Tea Party Unity Convention that was being planned for mid-October in Las Vegas is off. It was supposed to be a repeat of the convention in Nashville last February, which drew 600 ''delegates'' (and almost as many reporters) and an adoring audience for Sarah Palin, the keynote speaker.

In circumstances George Stephanopoulos probably never imagined when he gave up a hands-on role in politics to become a broadcaster, two fuzzy, nonhuman members of the ''Sesame Street'' cast joined him Friday morning on ''Good Morning America,'' along with that PBS children's show's executive producer, Carol-Lynn Parente, to discuss the recent decision at ''Sesame Street'' to pull a music video featuring the pop singer Katy Perry. On Thursday, Sesame Workshop, which produces ''Sesame Street,'' said it would not broadcast a segment planned for the show's coming season in which Ms. Perry performs a version of her song ''Hot 'N Cold'' with Elmo and is seen wearing a low-cut dress.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Patrick Merrell was talking recently about how tough Monday puzzles are to create. We haven't heard from the constructor Janice M. Putney for a while, but she's an early week specialist. Monday puzzles have to be easy enough for beginners, but interesting enough to be engaging. You need three or four, or more commonly, now, five theme answers (like today) that are amusing and fresh. This crossword is a fine example.

The Yankees, mired in a four-game losing streak and struggling to clinch a playoff spot, decided to start Phil Hughes against the Red Sox on Sunday for his regular turn in the rotation. The Yankees had planned to start Dustin Moseley to give Hughes extra rest for the postseason. Starting pitching has been a particular concern over the course of the losing streak after poor appearances by C.C. Sabathia, A.J. Burnett, Andy Pettitte and Ivan Nova.

One thing I should probably make clear in this discussion of structural unemployment is that I have no problem in principle with the idea that shifts in the economy can temporarily lead to a large rise in the "natural" rate of unemployment. Let me offer a case in point: it was quite clear, circa 1990, that Britain was no longer capable of running unemployment rates as low as those of the 1960s and early 1970s.

Since its "discovery" by Western travelers in the late 1960s, Goa, a region 12 hours south of Mumbai by train, has developed a reputation for carefree living, shading into hedonism. The region's unique cuisine, though, has added to its charms. With a large Christian population unrestrained by dietary taboos, Goan cooking features plenty of meat (pork and beef included) and fish, combined with a generous use of spice.

AT World Maker Faire, you might see a robot solving a Rubik's Cube. Or you might watch visitors making 360-degree circles in a swing while, in another pavilion, people dressed as mice tap dance around a life-size version of the game ''Mouse Trap.'' The event, which started five years ago in San Mateo, Calif., captures the intersection of high-tech engineering, arts and crafts, and the carnival culture of the Burning Man festival.

In an age of childhood obesity and children tethered to electronic consoles, playgrounds have rarely been more important. In an age of constrained government budgets, playgrounds have rarely been a harder sell. Fortunately, the cost of play doesn't have to be prohibitive. In creating the Imagination Playground in Lower Manhattan -- a playground with lots of loose parts for children to create their own play spaces -- we realized that many of the elements with the greatest value to children were inexpensive and portable. Although traditional playgrounds can easily cost in the millions to build, boxed imagination playgrounds can be put together for under $10,000. (Land costs not included!) The design below is one that my architecture firm has done in collaboration with the New York City Parks Department and KaBoom, a nonprofit organization. But it needn't be the only one out there. There are a lot of ways to build a playground -- and a lot of communities in need of one. Let a thousand portable playgrounds bloom. -- DAVID ROCKWELL, president of the Rockwell Group

YouTube introduced an online travel channel this month called the YouTube Vacationer. Sponsored by Norwegian Cruise Line, it features short videos on various destinations and activities organized geographically by tabs: Caribbean/Bahamas; Europe; United States and Canada; and Exotic (Latin America, Middle East, Africa). The videos are provided by travel industry heavy hitters like Lonely Planet (Honduras, Costa Rica, Italy) and National Geographic (Egypt, the Northern Lights). There are also practical guides -on how to apply sunscreen, how to not look like a tourist and the like -provided by Howcast and eHow.An additional tab labeled Norwegian Cruise Line toggles to videos about the line's Freestyle Cruising itineraries and about onboard entertainers like the Blue Man Group and CirqueDreams. Norwegian also offers an interactive video component: its ''Vacation You'' function allows users to create their own dream cruise vacation video by choosing images from a video library. The final product can then be shared with friends via social networks or e-mail.

GILBERT--Sanford "Sandy", 88, of Boynton Beach, FL, died suddenly on September 24th. He was predeceased in April by his wife of 65 years, Helen. He is survived by sons Jim and Steve, daughter-in-law Marie and grandsons Justin and Don, brother Bill, as well as nieces, nephews and numerous friends. THE NEWSJennifer Lopez, the singer and actress, and Steven Tyler,the lead singer for Aerosmith, joined the panel of judges on ''American Idol,'' remaking the hit show on Fox. BEHIND THE NEWS The singing-competition show is being retooled for its 10th season after the departures of Ellen DeGeneres, Kara DioGuardi and the longtime house curmudgeon, Simon Cowell. Producers hope that the new judges will pump fresh energy into the show, which begins airing in January. Though ''Idol'' is still America's most-watched entertainment show, its ratings have flagged in recent years.

First came the expansionist decades, in which Hilton and Holiday Inn behaved like the Coke and Pepsi of the hotel business. Then came the boutique-hotel era, which moved lodgings from mass production to couture. But even the creators of one-off properties want to be able to offer their guests a change of scenery. Which explains the rise of the latest hotel hybrids: small-scale chainlets melding boutique DNA with expansionist ambition. FRED A. BERNSTEIN The creators of Lux 11, in Berlin's Mitte neighborhood, have brought high-thread-count linens to Mitte's high-hipster-count streets with the Weinmeister (theweinmeister.com). When you're not in the Schwarz bar, named for the German starlet Jessica Schwarz, hole up in your giant bed, with duvets that, according to the Web site, ''can cover up to six.''
Film Stephen Holden

WORCESTER, Mass. It was not as big a draw as the playground or the hot dog truck, but the drug collection program at a busy downtown park here on Saturday still netted a few hundred bottles of prescription pills as part of a broader one-day effort to clean out the nation's medicine cabinets. From 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., people young and old delivered bag after bag of pills, including the types of powerful painkillers and anti-anxiety drugs that the Drug Enforcement Administration, which coordinated the program nationally, was hoping for. More than anything, the goal was to empty homes of legal but dangerous drugs that the authorities say are driving addiction and crime around the country.

LEMAIRE--Henry, died September 20 at his home at Wake Robin, Shelburne, VT from complications of Alzheimer's disease and heart problems. Henry was born in New York City on January 24, 1921. He attended Riverdale Country School, graduated from Pomfret School, and received a B.S. in chemistry from MIT. On his graduation day in 1942 he also received his commission in the US Army Chemical Corp. and served his country for four years. After his army service he studied at the California Institute of Technology and achieved his Ph.D. in Synthetic Organic Chemistry in 1950. He worked for Wyandotte Chemicals for two years and then took a postdoctoral Fellowship at the University of Wisconsin for further research. He met and married his loving wife, Connie while at Wisconsin and then accepted a position at Lever Brothers Research Lab in New Jersey. While with Lever Brothers he received several patents, and made many lasting friends. In 1966, he took a position as Professor of Chemistry at the University of New Haven and moved to Westport, CT. After retiring in 1978, he and his wife greatly enjoyed traveling in Europe, around the world, and to the Artic and Antarctic. In 1993, they moved to Wake Robin Community in Shelburne, VT, where Henry greatly enjoyed indulging his passion for bridge. Henry is survived by his wife of 57 years, Connie, and two sons: Tom and his wife Elyse of Arlington, MA; and Brian and his wife Debbie of Jersey City, NJ, and three grandchildren Beverly, Eddie and John and one niece Wendy Warne of Arizona. There will be a Memorial Circle of Remembrance held on Sunday, September 26 at Wake Robin. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Southern Poverty Law Center or Planned Parenthood of New England would be appreciated. Ave et vale, dear Henry.

Choose from services that include a four-handed massage and a scrub-down with local products like black Moroccan soap and sesame seeds. Route de Ouarzazate; 011-212-524-39-90-00; amanjena.com.

When a brand ''goes global,'' that usually means the forces behind it will be racking up frequent-flier miles. Carolina Herrera Báez, the daughter of the designer Carolina Herrera, is doing exactly that as the creative adviser for CH Carolina Herrera, a casual lifestyle brand that is rolling out 18 boutiques this year. The first New York City boutique, which sells everything from silk dresses to cashmere travel blankets, opened earlier this month. This 14-karat gold headband is one of the spoils of last spring's excursion, when both Carolinas made their way to Beirut, Lebanon, to celebrate the opening of a new CH shop. Amid all the festivities, Carolina Jr. made time to check out the local shops: ''That's how I get to know a place more than sightseeing.'' She picked up this souvenir, an elegant band embellished with a pair of doves, at a boutique called Orient 499 (499 Omar Daouk Street; 011-961-1-369-499) in the city's Ain-el-Mreisseh neighborhood. ''I've been having kids for the past five years,'' she says, ''so my hair would fall out, grow back in, fall out. Sometimes I just need to put it back.'' Her motivation was only partly practical, though. The Madrid-based mother of three admits to something of a headband habit, owning about 15 for both day and evening. MEENAL MISTRY

Look past the sizzling pans of paella and you'll discover something fresh cooking in Valencia, Spain's third largest city. Over the past decade, Valencia has welcomed a parade of profile-raising buildings by the likes of David Chipperfield, Norman Foster and Santiago Calatrava, a native son who designed the astro-chic City of Arts & Sciences complex. That creative momentum has spurred a range of cultural happenings, including a yearly design fair. And now a new generation of local and expat cross-pollinators has upped the energy in Valencia's grittier redoubts: El Carmen, with its street performers and makeshift art galleries, and Russafa, the once scary, now savory market district. JILL SINGER CULDESAC

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Night of Remembrance,'' Sept. 21: George Steinbrenner's monument should have called him the Bully rather than the Boss. Making his monument so very much larger than Ruth's, Mantle's, Gehrig's and DiMaggio's proves the point better than words.Forrest Murray

BATAMDA, Egypt -- One place to begin to understand why this parched country has nearly ruptured relations with its upstream neighbors on the Nile is ankle-deep in mud in the cotton and maize fields of Mohammed Abdallah Sharkawi. The price he pays for the precious resource flooding his farm? Nothing. ''Thanks be to God,'' Mr. Sharkawi said of the Nile River water. He raised his hands to the sky, then gestured toward a state functionary visiting his farm. ''Everything is from God, and from the ministry.''

It's easy to be taken on a magic carpet ride when you're buying rugs -- hawkers will wave you into their stalls, ply you with mint tea and take you through stacks of fake antique rugs. However, La Porte d'Or, in the thick of the souks, is the real deal. Marc Jacobs, Tom Cruise and Edgar Kauffman, who picked up carpets for his Fallingwater house, have all shopped here. The staff will guide you through a vast selection -- kilims from the Glowa tribe, carpets made from 400-year-old silk -- and pass on valuable tips. (Lamb's-wool rugs won't shrink; a double-knotted weave lets you restore holes.) The shop also ships. 115 Souk Semmarine; 011-212-524-44-54-54.

In 1927, Mies van der Rohe designed the innovative concrete-and-steel Weissenhof apartments in Stuttgart, Germany, which would become a landmark of International-style architecture; that same year, Gerrit Rietveld built the so-called chauffeur's house (below), a little-known but remarkably similar building in his hometown of Utrecht, the Netherlands, which leaked and had to be redone shortly thereafter. Trained as a cabinetmaker, Rietveld -- an early member of the de Stijl movement known for his Red-Blue Chair and Schröder House -- suffered many such disappointments in a career of more than 45 years. But a new retrospective at Utrecht's Centraal Museum illustrates how his groundbreaking ideas had a much broader impact than is generally acknowledged. ''In Holland you have this feeling that maybe he was a genius but he wasn't a good architect,'' says Ida van Zijl, the curator of ''Rietveld's Universe,'' which opens Oct. 20 as part of the Netherlands' Rietveld Year. ''People don't realize how many works he made and how experimental they were.'' The exhibition puts his furniture and architecture on an international scale, comparing it with Marcel Breuer, Le Corbusier and van der Rohe as well as showing its influence on contemporary designers. In a room dedicated to the Red-Blue Chair, the real thing will sit alongside a video of Maarten Baas's charred homage. MONICA KHEMSUROV

Spotted cats have not lost their magnetic power on fashionable women. The wonderful difference from 30 years ago is that what now slinks along the sidewalks is printed, knitted, stenciled, flocked or woven, never the skins of the endangered animals themselves. The cat patterns that arrived with the first blast of fall dressing are often the stuff of accessories. Most popular are the bags. Most noticeable are the exotic shoes, in one case worn with flocked jaguar-pattern stockings. Always striking, cat prints work from morning to night, when they may be spotted on long dresses.

In the first week of November I will travel from Buenos Aires to Cambridge, Mass., for my 20th law school reunion, and my 15-year old son will join me for three days. Can you suggest things to do in Cambridge and Boston that we would both enjoy? Sebastian Soler, Buenos Aires A.Both Boston and Cambridge, its neighbor across the Charles River (above), are small, manageable cities packed with fun, historical sights - you can cover a lot of ground over three days. In fact, it's best to eschew a rental car for good walking shoes and a day pass ($9; mbta.com) for the public transit system, known as the T.

SHORE--Arlene, 84, former director of Residence Life at the Fashion Institute of Technology, died peacefully at home in Manhattan on Sunday, September 19, 2010 surrounded by her beloved family and friends. Born in Buffalo, NY to the late Joseph and Margaret Green. She is survived by daughter Kerry, son Brett, grandchildren Ruby and Conor and mother Enoka.

MASI--Jeanette Watercolor artist. Born July 29, 1915, died peacefully September 21 surrounded by her family. She was 95. Known to many as "Nettie" she was a woman of many talents. A professional artist who excelled in most media including oils, acrylics, pastels, water colors, and mixed media, Jeanette achieved state and national recognition for her artistic talents. She was passionate about art and loved to paint anything she saw. She was a past Co-Chairwoman of the annual juried Sidewalk Show of South Orange and Maplewood and a member of several art associations including the prestigious New Jersey Water Color Society and the American Water Color Society. Jeanette was honored with numerous awards by fine arts organizations in New Jersey and New York and earned a Merit Award from the highly regarded Salmagundi Art Club in New York and the Dagmar H. Tribble Memorial Award from the Garden State Watercolor Society. Her paintings were exhibited in numerous galleries and in many outdoor exhibits including the Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit in Greenwich Village, New York and the South Orange Outdoor Art exhibit beginning in the 1960s and continuing throughout the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s. She continued to submit paintings in juried shows until 2008 with great success. It is remarkable that her professional art career did not begin until she was in her 50s and had already raised five children. Jeanette is survived by her children, daughters: Sandy and her husband Joe Gigliotti, Bonni Masi Oswald, Susan Masi, Carol Masi and son, Tom Masi and his wife Luby; 10 grandchildren: Greg and his wife Kristine, John and his wife Day and Joe Gigliotti; Peter and his wife Elena Mele; John and his wife Robin, Tucker and his wife Shauna, Kurt and his wife Lindsay and Kirsten Oswald, John and Jenna Masi and eleven great-grandchildren: Annie and Gracie Gigliotti, Griffin and Sydney Gigliotti, Carson, Harrison and Reilly Oswald, Rowan and Reagan Oswald and Nicolas and Alexandra Mele. In addition to her art work, Jeanette's memory will endure as a lively and unique individual who always kept an open door. There were always good spirits, food and an ample supply of manhattans to greet all visitors. Jeanette was a resident of South Orange for more than 60 years. Her home "155" in South Orange was a central gathering point for family, friends and art groups for decades. Holiday parties and special occasions would last throughout the night. Some would go to bed only to find others in the morning still gathered around the table talking and cooking breakfast. Jeanette's spirit, creativity, wit, inspiration and ability to reinvent herself no matter what the challenge, will be with us for generations to come. Visitation will be at Galloway and Crane Funeral Home on South Finley Avenue in Basking Ridge, NJ on Sunday, September 26 from 3 to 7pm. Funeral Mass will be held at Jeanette's home parish of Our Lady of Sorrows in South Orange, NJ on Monday, September 27 at 10:15am. Interment will be at Holy Cross Cemetery on Mt. Airy Road in Bernardsville, NJ at noon. Memorial donations in Jeanette's honor may be made to the Villa Walsh Jeanette Fragasso Masi Memorial Art Award, c/o Villa Walsh Academy, 455 Western Avenue, Morristown, NJ 07960.

Andrea Kate Harris and David Richard Smith were married Saturday in New York. Andra M. Miller, the president of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at the Boathouse in Central Park. The bride, 38, will continue to use her name professionally. She is an actress who works in London and Johannesburg. She is a member of the Royal Shakespeare Company and in its 2008-9 season played Titania in ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' and Cornelia (a female version of the courtier Cornelius) in ''Hamlet.'' On television, she had a role in two episodes of the BBC series ''Dr. Who,'' and she appeared in the 2008 film ''Last Chance Harvey.''

Rosenthal--Jeremy S. December 8, 1969 - August 27, 2010. Beloved Husband of Chrissy, beloved father of Nik and Dylan, beloved brother of David and Sara, beloved son of Lois and the late Richard G. Rosenthal. Jeremy was passionate about family and community. Upon graduating from high school he served in the Israeli Army for five years and returned home to finish his schooling. Jeremy attended the University of New Haven's School of Criminal Justice and completed his degree in Criminal Justice at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. He graduated from the New York Police Academy and worked as an investigator for the Manhattan District Attorney's Office before moving his family to Florida. At the time of his death, he worked as a Special Agent for the Florida Department of Law Enforcement in the violent crimes unit, was a member of their Strategic Operations Team and worked on a specific task force for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Jeremy was loved and respected by many and will be missed by those whose lives he touched.

WHAT more can be said in praise of Trisha Brown's career? She has been creating dance -- and changing what we think of as dance -- for half a century, including radical experiments in the 1960s Judson Dance Theater movement, stints with the 1970s improvisational collective Grand Union and a decades-long history of interdisciplinary collaborations with artists like Robert Rauschenberg. The Village Voice cultural critic Jill Johnston, who died on Sept. 18, described her in 1966 as ''one of an almost zero number who can make 'dance' movement unconventional by seeming to exert no effort in letting it come alive.'' On Thursday, the Whitney Museum of American Art will present ''Seven Works by Trisha Brown,'' a program of seminal pieces. Five collaborators and colleagues were asked for their thoughts on Ms. Brown and her work. Here are excerpts.

HITCHENS--Gordon R.,international film journalist and founding editor of Film Comment magazine, died on August 7, 2010 at Carillon Nursing Center, on Long Island. He was 85 years old. Born on March 3, 1925, he served in WWII. He earned a BA and two MA degrees from Columbia University, marrying fellow student Diana Macbeth. Over 30+ years, Mr. Hitchens covered documentary film festivals in Berlin, Moscow, Nyon, and Yamagata, among others. In 1962, he founded Film Comment, a film opinion magazine, of which he was editor until 1970. Film Comment is now published by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. He taught film studies at area colleges until 1990. A long-time stringer for Variety Magazine, he wrote articles for the New York Times, International Documentary, and Film Culture. He is survived by daughter Janine, son Laurence, four grandchildren, and brother Michael. A Memorial Reception honoring Mr. Hitchens is set for October 14th, 8-10pm, at the Furman Gallery, Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center. Colleagues and friends please RSVP to www.gordonhitchens.com by October 7, 2010. Colleagues able to share remarks at the Memorial, RSVP ASAP. Donations in his memory can be made to Human Rights Watch.

An article in some editions on Sept. 12 about a new playground in Bay Ridge, misidentified the role of a New York Parks Department official who helped supervise its planning and construction. The official, Rick Bockowski, was a construction project manager, not a design project manager, for the project.

When David Lynch and Frank Gehry made headlines last year for their involvement in two multimillion-dollar cultural centers in the economically downtrodden city of Lodz, Poland, confusion ran high. What could they possibly see in the so-called Manchester of Poland? In fact, Lodz is undergoing something of a creative rebirth. The city has begun turning its 19th-century textile buildings into new-economy hubs -- a case in point is the Manufaktura complex 1 (Ogrodowa Street; manufaktura.com), home to a museum and the city's first upscale design hotel, Andel's 2 . (andelslodz.com). Lodz is also financing cultural festivals and programs aimed at retaining local art school grads, and once a planned high-speed rail slashes the Warsaw commute to 35 minutes, they'll have one more reason to stay put. ART In 1931, Wladyslaw Strzeminski and his circle of Polish avant-gardists founded the Muzeum Sztuki (Wieckowskiego 36; msl.org.pl) -- the world's second modern-art institution, after MoMA. It now puts on shows of recent work (its permanent collection is at Manufaktura), including next month's survey of the painter Zbigniew Rogalski. The original building includes the Mondrian-inspired Neoplastic Room and the futuristic-looking MS Café, designed in 2008 by the local architects Wunderteam. The Fokus Lodz Biennial (biennalelodz.pl), curated in part by the local art legend Ryszard Wasko, will fill the rest of the city's public art spaces until mid-October. For contemporary Polish art year-round, there's Atlas Sztuki (Piotrkowska 114; atlassztuki.pl), a white-box gallery in a former Jewish meat market.

JACOBSON--Seymour Davis. Dress Designer and avid New Yorker died Wednesday atCooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, MA, ten days before his 101st birthday. The youngest of seven brothers, Seymour was born in Brooklyn on October 2, 1909 and weaned on the New York Times. His first job at age ten was filling penny candy machines in the New York Subway. In the mid 1930's Seymour became a partner in Encore Dresses. This launched his career designing and manufacturing elegant cocktail and party dresses through his various labels that included Seymour Jacobson, Ltd. Donna Paula and Luciana Moda. Grace Kelly, Rita Hayworth and Eleanor Roosevelt were among the many influential women who wore his line. Seymour's interests extended beyond fashion: In Lawnside, New Jersey he financed and built a community for returning black veterans of World War II and built offices for the US Postal Service in Nassau and Fairfield Counties. He married Dorothy Lipton in 1932. She died in 1979. He is survived by his three children Jay Jacobson and his wife Patricia, Clifford Jacobson and Lynn Lewin, his four grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. He was a forty-year resident of The Century at 25 Central Park West and spent the last year in Massachusetts, living closer to family. Contributions in Seymour's memory should be addressed to Doctors Without Boarders for Haiti Earthquake Relief at Doctors Without Borders USA, PO Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741.

An article on Sept. 5 about Maryland vineyards misstated the comparison of Maryland's latitude and that of Bordeaux in France. Maryland is roughly between the 38th and 39th parallel. It is not at the same latitude as Bordeaux, which is just south of the 45th parallel.

TIMOTHY EGAN Travel is good for many things, not the least of which is testing your national values against those of other countries. But perhaps the best way to judge the health of a nation's heart is by how it treats the shunned. Plagued by low poll numbers, France's President Nicolas Sarkozy this summer set out to dismantle Gypsy camps and deport the people to Romania and Bulgaria. It has proven to be a popular move at home, but prompted a stinging rebuke from the European Union's justice commissioner, Viviane Reding: she compared the expulsions to ethnic cleansing by the Nazis. As often happens when the morally indignant let their passions get the best of them, the justice commissioner's comparison was over the top. Sarkozy's deportation is simply a crass political move, and a huge hurdle for poor people who have to gather all their belongings and start anew in another country.

It is now more than 30 years since China forcefully occupied Tibet. In this period, our religion and culture have been destroyed. But never did the Tibetans lose their distinct national identity. That is the threat we face today: the complete absorption of our people by a vast sea of Chinese settlers streaming across our borders.
COLONIAL ON A CANAL $1,500,000

For his latest book, ''A Week at the Airport'' (Vintage, $15), Alain de Botton stranded himself at Heathrow. Here, the Swiss-born essayist lines up for the T: Travel Questionnaire. What's your favorite airport pastime? Spotting signs of feigned or ambivalent joy among reuniting couples at Arrivals. What do you do to fall asleep on an airplane? Read Time magazine.

Most museum fashion shows are relegated to a dark basement, reflecting not just the status of fashion vis-a-vis fine art but also the vulnerability of, say, a 150-year-old silk gown, to the effects of sunlight. When the Los Angeles County Museum of Art shows off its newly acquired, and reportedly groundbreaking, trove of European clothing on Saturday, it will do so in a new light-filled pavilion designed by Renzo Piano. ''Fashioning Fashion: European Dress in Detail, 1700-1915,'' which runs through April 3, ends well before the invention of ready-to-wear. In this stunning context, even a man's vest from the 18th century (it is embroidered with symbolism relevant to the French Revolution and it predates the message T-shirt by at least 200 years) somehow seems modern and alive. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print

Can technology solve the problems it creates? That question came to the forefront again as several companies took the Distracted Driving Summit meeting on Tuesday in Washington as an opportunity to push new technologies to prevent or reduce the dangers of texting and talking on cellphones while driving.

GREENBERG--Alfred N. May 16, 1919 September 12, 2010. An employee of Bache & Co., Playboy Magazine and CBS, Alfred was a music lover, an avid reader, and a contributor to the letters to the editor section of the New York Times. He served with distinction in the U.S. Army and was among those soldiers who were present at the liberation of Dachau. He was a devoted companion to the late Dr. Gertrude Ashur. He is survived by his sister, Miriam Lonsk, his nephew Donald (Marcia) Goodfriend and his niece Lois (Gary) Meyer. His brother "Buddy" Greenberg predeceased him. Services have already been held. Alfred's knowledge, intelligence and integrity will be missed by all who knew him.

An article last Sunday about food collectives and other collaborative organizations in Bushwick, Brooklyn, misspelled the surname of an author of the book ''What's Mine Is Yours: The Rise of Collaborative Consumption.'' She is Rachel Botsman, not Bosman.

The financial world is a mess. Its problems have been leaking into the general economy, and the leaks are now turning into a gusher. In the near term, unemployment will rise, business activity will falter and headlines will continue to be scary. So ... I've been buying American stocks. This is my personal account, in which I previously owned nothing but government bonds. Why?

DAVISON--Daniel Pomeroy of Peacock Point, Locust Valley, NY on August 25, 2010 age 85. Beloved husband of Katusha. Father of Daniel P. Jr., George (Judith Rivkin), and Henry (Kristina Perkin). Grandfather of Daniel P. III, Hallie and Max; Samuel and Alice; Olympia and Henry P. III. Retired Chairman of U.S. Trust Co. of New York, Christie's North America, and The Burlington Northern Santa Fe. To the Sports Editor: Thanks for the grace note on Nancy Faust's career as the Chicago White Sox' organist (''Ballpark Farewell, Played Adagio,'' Sept. 18). I'm 59, so I appreciate her playing much more than the hyperkinetic atmosphere of most ballparks.
Television Neil Genzlinger

DORFSMAN--Ann Hysa, 92, of undetermined cause on September 20, 2010. Born and bred in New York by immigrant parents from the Ukraine, and widow of Louis Dorfsman (see editorial obit of October 26, 2008). Valedictorian of her class at Washington Irving High School; Graduate of Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art ('39) (The art studio at the new building at Cooper Union is named for Ann Hysa Dorfsman and Louis Dorfsman). Ann was a multi-talented artist, as adept at illustration as photography, calligraphy, fashion design and interior design. She was the founder and curator of the Historic Wall Coverings Collection at the Cooper Hewitt Museum of Design, NY, for 20 years until her retirement. As it was her true passion, she was a master weaver of wall hangings, pillow covers, clothing, rugs and the innovator of many weaving styles and techniques. An avid cook and gardener, she experimented with recipes until she perfected them: breads of all sorts, quiche (before it became part of the American lexicon), the ultimate spaghetti sauce and on and on. She was outstanding at everything she set her mind to - the "Martha Stewart" of her day. In lieu of flowers or gift baskets, Ann would prefer a donation of any size to the Alzheimer's Association: Alz.org; then enter your zip code for local chapter; or 1-800-272-3900. She is survived by her daughter, Elissa Delano Dorfsman of Morrisville, PA, her granddaughter, Sophia Indria Dorfsman of Yorktown Heights, NY, and two sons, one in California and the other in New York. Memorial services will be announced at a later date.
Art Karen Rosenberg

MANNY HOWARD Amid a frenzied bull run in Céret, one of the unspoiled Catalan villages in Roussillon, France (''Sauvage Grace,'' Page 92), Manny Howard encountered a man wearing an orange life vest, blowing on a blue whistle, and holding a Hello Kitty boogie board. ''He was using it as a tray to carry glasses of pastis,'' Howard says. ''We managed to become friends.'' A writer, hunter and saltwater fisherman, Howard grew up in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. (His family immigrated there from Britain so that his rocket-scientist dad could take part in the Mercury space program.) ''We were one of the first non-Italian families on Degraw Street,'' says Howard, who is still a Brooklynite. His book, ''My Empire of Dirt'' (Scribner), is about urban farming -- as in a chicken coop behind your brownstone. It's appropriately subtitled ''A Cautionary Tale.''

FADER--Gussie, 97, passed in peace at home on September 24. Beloved aunt, grand-aunt, cousin and friend. Funeral services Monday, September 27 at 11am at Grace Park Memorial Chapel, 352 2nd Avenue, New York, NY.
FOR THE FOODIE Ksar Char-Bagh

Two months after flooding began in the northern reaches of Pakistan, the waters of the Indus River continue to flood low-lying areas of Sindh, the country's southernmost province. The flooding killed about 1,800 people, and more than 20 million people, or around 14 percent of the country's population, have been affected. The United Nations estimates that 12.4 million people are in need of immediate humanitarian assistance, meaning they have no access to clean water and are living in temporary shelters. Millions do not know when they will be able to return home. A majority of the displaced are farmers, and the flooding has destroyed not only their homes but their fields, herds and livelihoods. The complexity of the situation, combined with the instability in the country, makes it the worst natural disaster the United Nations has ever responded to in its 65-year history, according to a recent report by the organization.

Howard Brodie, a noted combat artist during World War II who went on to sketch some of the most famous courtroom dramas of the postwar era, including the trials of the Chicago Seven, Charles Manson and Patty Hearst, died on Sunday at his home near Parkfield, Calif. He was 94. The death was confirmed by his son, Bruce.

MOREY--Alison, daughter of the late Elizabeth (King) and Lee Bogart Morey, died September 13th in Leesburg, Virginia. She was 75. She had been Chief of Litigation in the Consumer Protection Division at the Washington State Office of the Attorney General, and was a former counsel at Cahill, Gordon, & Reindell, specializing in antitrust and litigation. Alison was a graduate of the Brearley School, Wellesley College, and Columbia University School of Law, where she was editor of the Law Review. She is survived by her sisters, Mary Lee Rowen and Grace McKenzie; children, Melissa Barden Dowling, Scott Morey Barden, and Elizabeth Barden Ackerman; and grandchildren, Katherine Dowling, Maxfield Barden, Emma Kirkpatrick, James Ackerman, and Kepler Ackerman. A memorial service will be held at Allen Funeral Home, Millbrook, NY, Saturday, September 25th at 11am. Contributions may be sent to the Harry L. King Trust for faculty development at Wellesley College.

WOOD--Ann Budd, long time New York volunteer, died peacefully at the age of 94 on September 15. She founded the Metropolitan Structures Association (MHSA) in 1976 and was its first President. As part of her work with MHSA and Daughters of the American Revolution, she oversaw the restoration of the Morris Jumel Mansion, oldest surviving Manhattan residence, and hosted a visit there by Queen Elizabeth. In addition to raising five children, Wood was executive officer of many organizations, including the National Lawn Bowling Association, Women's Republican Club, Colonial Dames, NY Bible Society, Junior League, Brick Church and Florida DAR. Wood was married for 50 years to J. Frank Wood of the New York firm, Thacher, Proffitt, Prizer, Crawley, Wood and was a descendant of Thomas A. Hendricks, 21st Vice President of the U.S. under Grover Cleveland. She is survived by 13 grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, and five children. See legacy.com

The upsurge of student activism and the radicalization of large segments of the undergraduate population since 1964 has led to speculation about the future politics of this college cohort. Opinion surveys make clear that the most recent students and graduates are much more left of center and critical than those of the '40s and '50s. Will they retain their present commitments in substantial measure, and thus constitute a major force for social change, as they climb the occupational hierarchies? If American experience is any guide, it is likely that the cohort which experienced the radical and activist campus politics of the late '60s will not continue in the distinctive frame of mind it now shows. Colleges are encapsulated communities in which peer group pressures are especially intense and pervasive. After graduation, however, most -- even today when the absolute number rejecting a ''careerist'' outlook is far greater than ever before -- re-enter the highly differentiated larger society.

WIDELITZ--Irwin H. "The heart benevolent and kind. The most resembles God." Robert Burns. With a kind heart, a generous spirit, and a deep devotion to family, Win lived a life of love, accomplishment, adventure, creativity and joy. As a child prodigy and exceptional pianist, he shared his gift of music as a volunteer for many organizations including Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home for over 25 years. He was an award-winning salesman, successful real estate owner, tournament tennis champion, food connoisseur and faithful practitioner of transcendental meditation for 33 years. He traveled extensively including 80 days around the globe. Above all, he was devoted to his family: daughters Susan and Sarah, son Roger, late wife Maureen, nine grandchildren, one great-grandchild and his devoted companion of 28 years Leslie Gottlieb. Funeral service will be held Monday, September 27, 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.), New York. Donations will be gratefully accepted for music students who are blind or visually impaired: The Irwin H. Widelitz Scholarship Fund, Music School, Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, New York City 10022 www.lighthouse.org

Jack Kershaw, who represented James Earl Ray as he fought to overturn his conviction in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., arguing that Ray was an innocent participant in a conspiracy led by a mysterious figure named Raul, died Sept. 7. in Nashville. He was 96. His death was announced by the League of the South, an organization Mr. Kershaw helped found that tries to keep the spirit of the Confederacy alive.

Richard Phibbs's black and white photography focuses on the graceful athleticism of man and beast, from sweaty rugby players in postgame repose to a snow-covered pack of horses to Phibbs's beloved dog, Huck, leaping over a sand dune. This refined ideal of beauty has made him the perfect photographer for Giorgio Armani, Polo Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein advertising campaigns. While working for Ralph Lauren, Phibbs formed an inspired partnership with the label's chief creative officer, Alfredo Paredes, whose encouragement and art direction led to ''Chasing Beauty'' (Powerhouse; $50), the photographer's first monograph, out next week. In his elegant foreword, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Michael Cunningham succinctly describes the images as a ''vastly interconnected series of marvels, different in their particulars, but alike in their ravishing, unorthodox perfections.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Stem cell research is at an uncertain stage, but the hope it offers is amazing: infinitely adaptable human cells to replace damaged or defective tissue and treat a wide variety of diseases. Yet the ethics of medicine are not infinitely adaptable. There is at least one bright line: we do not end some lives for the medical benefit of others. For me, this is a matter of conviction -- a belief that life, including early life, is biologically human, genetically distinct and valuable.
Because Clarence Thomas has been poor, has been nearly suffocated

MICHELSEN--John A.,75, died September 24, 2010 in Verona, NJ. Services will be held in the First Presbyterian Church of Verona, Fairview Avenue at Bloomfield Avenue, on Tuesday at 11am. Friends will be received in the Prout Funeral Home (www.proutfuneralhome.com) 370 Bloomfield Avenue, Verona on Monday 4 to 7pm. An entry on the ''On the Market'' page last Sunday, for a co-op at 909 East 29th Street in Midwood, Brooklyn, misstated the age of the building. It was built in 1939, not the 1960s.

The hidden ground of American politics is now a simultaneous information environment that extends to the entire planet. This situation is structured and patterned for role-playing rather than for goals or policies. In effect, this means that both political parties and policies have little relevance in a world that expects a total-service environment. This charismatic image has replaced the goals and the parties and the policies.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Donation Will Allow Penn State to Field Division I Hockey Teams,'' Sept. 18: I believe athletics play an important role in the overall collegiate experience. But when an $88 million donation is made to provide a sports team with the resources to compete in Division I, there is something wrong with the values of Penn State and perhaps the country.

Some of the top trends from Saturday's games: WINNING FOR COACH Michigan State, behind three touchdowns by Le'Veon Bell, left, beat Northern Colorado without Coach Mark Dantonio, who suffered a minor heart attack last week.

I feel like saying something about this abortion issue. My credentials as an expert on the subject: None. I am an M.D. and a novelist. I will speak only as a novelist. Any number of doctors have given opinions and who cares about another? As a novelist I can recognize meretricious use of language, disingenuousness and a con job when I hear it. The current con, perpetrated by some jurists, some editorial writers and some doctors, is that since there is no agreement about the beginning of human life, it is therefore a private religious or philosophical decision and therefore the state and the courts can do nothing about it. This is a con. Religion, philosophy and private opinion have nothing to do with this issue.

Charles Salzberg is a co-author of ''On a Clear Day They Could See Seventh Place: Baseball's Worst Teams'' with George Robinson. As September fades into October, the baseball regular season is finally coming to an end. For teams like the Diamondbacks, the Pirates, the Nationals, the Orioles, the Royals and the Mariners, and their fans, it cannot be soon enough. Losing can corrupt the soul, infect the psyche and drain the will to live.Or maybe not.

My husband, two sons (10 and 9) and I are planning a trip to Singapore in December to visit family. Where else nearby would you suggest visiting? I had been thinking of Thailand, but am not sure of the safety given the recent political unrest. Naomi Stein, Morristown, N.J. A.Before deciding to go to Thailand, you should check the State Department's Web site (travel.state.gov; see ''Travel Warnings'' for the latest advisories). The Thailand section warns United States citizens that though ''the level of violence in Bangkok has subsided since the end of the May 2010 protests, the potential for random acts of politically motivated violence remains as demonstrated by the recent bombings on July 25 and July 30.''

SOME artists just can't resist a blank canvas, even when it is a leather motorcycle jacket. Eighteen such art-endowed jackets were on view last Wednesday at the Palazzo Bovara in Milan, in a one-night show that Sisley sponsored to benefit the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh. Rita Ackermann riffed on Warhol's dollarbill paintings. Dan Colen studded the backs of two jackets with the words ''Rama Lama'' and ''Ding Dong.'' Tom Sachs took one look at the jacket Sisley sent him and torched it (left). Six of the jackets will be auctioned Nov. 8 at Christie's. The rest will be available for online bidding through Nov. 10 on Charity Buzz (www.charitybuzz .com/auctions.do). The idea for the fund-raiser belongs to Glenn O'Brien, whose jacket, with a crown painted by his friend Jean- Michel Basquiat, might bring the highest price, but he's not selling.LINDA YABLONSKY

A report last Sunday about the wedding of Ashley Terban and Andrew Lockhart misidentified the affiliation of the Rev. Neely P. Towe. She is a United Church of Christ minister, not Unitarian Universalist.

CAMPBELL--Ernest T. Dr.,86, passed away peacefully July 9, 2010. He was the son of Carolyn and William Campbell. He received his early education in the New York City public school system. He graduated from Bob Jones University and Princeton Theological Seminary. He served Presbyterian churches in Portland and Mt. Bethel, PA, Stroudsburg, PA, York, PA, and Ann Arbor, MI. He became a minister in the United Church of Christ and served as Senior Minister in the Riverside Church, New York City. He was a frequent speaker on The Protestant Hour and The National Radio Pulpit. He authored three books, a quarterly for preachers, and was a visiting lecturer at various seminaries including Garrett Evangelical Seminary. He had long been actively concerned for civil rights, the migrant worker, a humane national budget and fairer treatment for the LGBT community. He is survived by his wife Joan, brother Robert, sons David and Erik and stepsons Glenn and Craig Walsh. He is preceded in death by his parents and stepson Keith Walsh. Memorial contributions may be made in his honor to Habitat for Humanity.
Theater Ben Brantley

Two new photography books cast an eye on the American cultural landscape. Over the last 15 years, the legendary photographer Lee Friedlander has shot in almost all 50 states, employing the windows and mirrors of his rental cars to frame parts of the country that are often sped past -- the churches, motels, bars and bridges. Those black-and-white pictures, collected in ''America by Car'' (D.A.P./Fraenkel; $50), are timeless in their shabby grandeur. And to coincide with this month's survey exhibition at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, ''From Here to There: Alec Soth's America'' (left; Walker Art Center; $60) is an anthology of past and new work that takes us through the country's sad and dreamy subcultures, including ''Broken Manual,'' portraits of men who live off the grid. ''I've had the opportunity to photograph all over the world,'' Soth says, ''but I keep coming back to America. I find it endlessly rich.'' CHRISTINE MUHLKE

The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about Morris Heights, the Bronx, misstated the relationship between New York State and River Park Towers, a residential complex. Although it operates under state supervision, the complex is not owned by the state and thus is not public housing.

Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the wedding of Tracie Jorge Strahan and Zelkadis Rozz Elvi, referred incorrectly to the couple's officiant. The Rev. Violet L. Dease, the assistant pastor at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York, is a woman.

To the Editor: Re the ''Week Ahead'' report on the new season of ''House'' by Ginia Bellafante [Sept. 19]: The House/Cuddy coupling is not what this fan wants to see. Ms. Bellafante is right on one count: It is a ''lame and sappy'' plot twist. It is also disappointing to those of us who savor the misanthropy of Gregory House, which was on glorious display during the show's first five seasons. Unfortunately, the show's sixth season gave off faint whiffs of a producing and writing staff that had run out of ideas, and was capped off by the seemingly outof- nowhere ''cliffhanger'' of Lisa Cuddy professing her love for House. How desperate of them. For the most part, ''House'' has always seemed to be about something: medicine, smart people, mysterious ailments. Give me that show any day over this loveconquers- all silliness that is unworthy of these characters and this series. JOANNE NESTI Haddam, Conn.

FREYER--Carl. The Yeshiva University/RIETS family mourns the loss of its long-time supporter while visiting in Israel. Together with his beloved wife, Sylvia, they established scholarship funds at several YU schools and were YU Guardians. They established the Carl and Sylvia Freyer Professional Training Program in Community Outreach at the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. Heartfelt condolences to Sylvia, their daughters Louisa and Maura and their entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Julius Berman, Chair RIETS Board

MIX--Gregory Hawke. Our beloved Gregory passed away Thursday, September 16th, 2010 in New York, NY following a lengthy illness. He leaves behind a sister, Beverly and many loving friends. Born May 21, 1954 in New Orleans, LA, he relocated to Manhattan in 1991 to further his career in the designer luxury market. Over the span of three decades, Gregory worked for several fashion houses including Emanuel Ungaro, Christian Dior, Gianfranco Ferre and Sonia Rykiel. His expertise was recognized and sought after having regularly been consulted by some of the world's most recognizable women. His sense of style and knowledge of fashion's past and present, along with his passion for architectural and interior design was iconic. We will mourn our loss, cherish his memory and forever celebrate his life.

Activists have different priorities than artists do, but they, too, are forced to acknowledge the prevalence of the atrocious while maintaining faith in the possibility of the desired.

A CD called ''Songs From the East Village'' might make you think of old-school punk or hipster rock. But for a group of children from the East Village Community School, the CD means music from Puerto Rico, Iraq, Tibet, Ireland and elsewhere. ''These are songs the children's grandparents or parents grew up singing,'' said Susan McKeown, a Grammy-winning Irish singer who produced the album, which was released on Monday with a party at the Tenement Museum. ''The music is a part of their culture.''

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Starter or Not, Vick May Already Have Won,'' Sept. 21: Everyone loves a winner, it seems, even when the winner is Michael Vick. I am appalled that Vick's being involved in the running of a dogfighting ring is passed off as an implication.

The Italian owners of the design showroom Ministero del Gusto, a former fashion editor and a furniture designer, built their shop based on the desert houses of the architect Paolo Soleri. The resulting structure looks like the product of Georgia O'Keeffe's and Antoni Gaudí's imaginations. The overarching theme, somehow, is midcentury African eclectic: Murano ashtrays, tribal art pieces, Joe Colombo chairs and zebra-skin stools, as well as a sizable stash of vintage designer clothing, including Chanel gowns, Lucite clutches and Elsa Schiaparelli jewelry. The hours are limited, so call ahead. 22 Derb Azzouz, Mouassine; 011-212-524-42-64-55; ministerodelgusto.com.

Cowboys (0-2) at Texans (2-0)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Texans by 3 You are cordially invited to a coming-out party for the Houston Texans, reluctant debutantes who spent eight years as a gangly little expansion team before finally exhibiting the grace and poise to be presented to the high society of N.F.L. contenders. The Texans have won six straight games since last December, and their comeback victory against the Redskins, close on the heels of an upset of the Colts, proved that there's more to them than receiver Andre Johnson, defensive end Mario Williams and youthful exuberance. The Texans' offense is vintage 1990s Broncos -- cutback runs and rollout passes -- and their run defense has held opponents to 62 rushing yards and 2.3 yards per carry this year. Their pass defense still has some growing up to do, but a win over the faded belle-of-the-ball Cowboys would demonstrate how they have come of age.

ANNUAL shareholder meetings may not be the most efficient occasion for managers to meet with the owners of the companies they run -- they can be hard for shareholders to get to and are sometimes hijacked by gadflies with personal agendas and long-winded, irrelevant questions. Because most, if not all, shareholders cast their votes before the meetings even take place, they can feel ritualistic and not terribly meaningful. Yet, these congregations do give shareholders a rare opportunity to take the measure of the managers and directors who are supposed to work for them. How executives answer questions that shareholders pitch at them can be very revealing.

SUNDELL--Michael G.,of New York, NY, on September 7, 2010, age 74. The Members and Directors of Yaddo are deeply saddened by the death of their former President, Michael G. Sundell, and hereby express their profound sympathy to Nina and their children, and their gratitude to Michael for his inspired leadership of Yaddo over eight years. He has earned his place in a veritable Pantheon of Yaddo Saints, joining Spencer, Katrina, Elizabeth, and others who nurtured and supported the creative process and stimulated - in the words of the Trasks - "the Sacred Fire" within Yaddo's artist guests. The more than 1,500 artists who had the privilege of being guests during Michael's tenure, as well as the roughly equivalent number who have been guests since his retirement, are all the beneficiaries of his extraordinary legacy of leadership. He had a deep understanding of Yaddo's mission and the importance of assuring an atmosphere of security, peace, freedom and protection for the artist guests, he skillfully took Yaddo in some new directions, he loved Yaddo, derived joy from the experience of running Yaddo, and conveyed such joy and enthusiasm to others, leaving Yaddo better for his presence and stronger than he found it. The Members and Directors note with pride that in his retirement Michael pursued his passion in archeology, art history, and the history of religion researching mosaics in Rome and publishing Mosaics in the Eternal City. When ultimately confronted with a life threatening illness, he never lost his interest in serious scholarship, his zest for life, his love of family and friends, his passion for travel, and his love of the creative process and the work that goes on at Yaddo.

In 1919, 30 years before Paul Bowles gave us ''The Sheltering Sky,'' Edith Wharton wrote ''In Morocco,'' about her experiences in this North African country. The Marrakesh chapter is a series of spare impressions about souks and sultans. Born in Marrakesh and now based in New York, Hassan Hakmoun fuses traditional Gnawa music -- a mixture of sub-Saharan African, Berber and Arabic songs -- with jazz and psychedelic sounds.

Art usually presents us with incontrovertible facts. Abstract canvas or marble bust, representational drawing or fanciful relief -- all fix a specific image in a specific way for all time. And then there's M.C. Escher. His paradoxical, mind-twisting prints tell you over and over again that there are no incontrovertible facts, even in art. The negative space around an image suddenly resolves into a positive image of something else -- absence becoming presence, presence disappearing into absence. What you are looking at is not what you see.

''Can I help the next guest?'' It was a straightforward question. One I'd expect to hear from a bartender if I were at a wedding, or from a concierge at a hotel. My mother might even ask that at the table, when cutting slices of her chocolate pudding pie. So when I was shopping for clothes at Daffy's and the girl behind the counter said, ''Can I help the next guest?'' I had no idea she was talking to me. Since when is a guest someone waiting in line for 10 minutes to pay for a crop sweater? If I'm a guest, then who is a customer? I mean, whatever happened to ''Next''?
LEVITT--Stacy. 22 years ago we parted in the dentist's office. Miss you, sweetie. Mommy and Michael

Maggie Peck and Aaron Wolk were married Saturday at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Douglas B. Sagal officiated. The bride and the bridegroom, both 29, met at the University of Michigan, from which they graduated, he cum laude.

NUSSDORF--Dorothy Bunny. Passed away on September 22, 2010 at age 89. Beloved wife of nearly 68 years to Milton, loving mother of Gail Hefler (Elliott) and Steven Nussdorf, adoring grandmother of Scott Hefler and Laurie Krasik (Scott), and great-grandmother of Cooper Krasik and Skylar Krasik. She was a graduate of Hunter College from which she also received her MA and a teacher and guidance counselor in the New York City Public School System for many years. After retirement she wrote and performed dramatic presentations on the lives of movie stars. She was a co-founder of the Manhattan Chapter of the Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America and a past president of the Manhattan Chapter of Brandeis University's Women's Organization. Her love, special qualities, and unique sense of humor will be missed. Funeral services will be held at 12:30pm on Sunday, September 26th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.
