The 36 Hours column on Page 10 this weekend, about Chicago, misstates the name of a well-known shopping district along Michigan Avenue. It is the Magnificent Mile, not the Miracle Mile. The column also misstates the distance from the ''L'' to Logan Square. It is about five to six miles, not two. And the column describes the academic calendar of the University of Chicago incorrectly. The school is on a quarterly system, not semesters.

Christina S. N. Lewis, a daughter of Loida Nicolas Lewis of New York and the late Reginald F. Lewis, was married Saturday to Daniel Halpern, the son of Joan Halpern and Joseph Halpern of Brookline, Mass. David N. Dinkins, the former mayor of New York, officiated in East Hampton, N.Y., at the home of the bride's mother. The bride, 30, is a freelance journalist in New York who was until May a staff writer for The Wall Street Journal, most recently covering commercial real estate. She graduated cum laude from Harvard.

The Cheering Section article last Sunday, about an art exhibit examining the Pittsburgh Steelers and their place in popular culture, misspelled part of the name of a fictional parent of the Black and Golden Calf, an artifact on display at the exhibit. She is the Heinz Heifer, not the Heinz Heffer. The article also erroneously attributed a distinction to the crowd at the exhibit's opening. It was one of the Miller Gallery's largest, but not the largest ever. And the article misidentified the object that President Obama was holding in a model depicting a game at Heinz Field. It was a Terrible Towel, not an American flag.

Good food and good mattresses are a classic combination, but this season three inns are breathing new life into the restaurant-with-rooms trend. In London, the St. John chef Fergus Henderson (near right), known for his nose-to-tail fare, is teaming with Trevor Gulliver (far right) to bring his humble yet decadent principles to the St. John Hotel (1 Leicester Street; 011-44-207-251-0848; stjohnhotellondon.com; doubles from about $310. It will offer 15 whitewashed and wainscoted rooms (''mini grand urban hut'' is the theme) above the restaurant and bar. At Chicago's Longman & Eagle gastropub (2657 North Kedzie Avenue; 773-276-7110; longmanandeagle.com; doubles from $75), you'll soon be able to retire upstairs to one of six retro-modern rooms should that flight of small-batch bourbons prove too much. And why stay in a chateau when you can stay in a revolving dome? The Dôme de Montmiral (011-33-5-63-57-26-78; double room and board from about $193), near Castelnau de Montmiral, France, combines organic vegetarian food and cooking classes with a U.F.O.-worthy design. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

A number of travel companies have cropped up for people looking to have an authentic experience at a destination. ''No longer are travelers looking to collect stamps in their passports or tick countries off their lists, but they want a guarantee that what they are seeing is real and unique,'' said Gregory Sacks, a founder of Trufflepig (trufflepig.com), one such company. It connects travelers with experts in their destinations -- a Peruvian shaman leading a tour of Machu Picchu, for example. Other trips focus on experiences difficult to accomplish, like climbing dunes in Namibia (above).

Last week's Spokes column about conflicts between cyclists and pedestrians drew more than 200 comments from readers. Following are excerpts: A few years ago, when I injured both legs and was hobbling around very unsteadily for several days, I developed an appreciation for how terrifying these bike riders on the sidewalks can be for the elderly or disabled. And yet I've never, in 25 years of living in this city, seen a cyclist get a summons for doing so.

WHILE the name Onassis brings to mind Jackie and the high-stakes world of Greek shipping tycoons, a new shop and men's wear line is out to change that. Located at 71 Greene Street (between Broome and Spring Streets) in SoHo, Onassis (ona-ssis.com) is a one-stop shop for every Tom, Dick or Ari. Here, they can find everything from boxer shorts to button-down shirts and sturdy outerwear. Coffee, served in an atrium out back, is provided to customers who need a midafternoon jolt. When pressed on the meaning behind the label's name, Eric Mancuso, a spokesman, matched Aristotle Onassis for discretion and simply said, ''The answer to that question is quite fascinating, but it's better off kept private.'' MAX BERLINGER

BLAIR--Claude Maclary, retired Chairman of National City Bank, died Monday, September 20, 2010 in Palm Beach, Florida. Mr. Blair was 97 and is survived by his wife, Rose; son, Randall; daughters, Julie and Peggy; six grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his daughter Barbara and his twin brothers Jack and Earl Blair. Blair was born in Columbia, Tennessee on May 5, 1913, and raised in West Palm Beach, Florida. After graduation from high school he went to work for the Long Lines division of American Telephone and Telegraph (AT&T). This began a 30 year career with AT&T that included Assistant Treasurer of AT&T, Vice President of the Telstar Satellite Program which was the world's first commercial communications satellite. He was the operating officer of several bell telephone companies including Mountain States Bell. He was President of Ohio Bell and Chairman of Pacific Northwest Bell. Blair's telephone career was interrupted twice for military duty in World War II and The Korean War. He finished his military career as a Major and Senior Tact Officer of the Signal Corps School at Fort Monmouth, New Jersey. In 1967 Blair became Chairman and CEO of National City Bank in Cleveland. He guided the bank through a period of successful expansion, the creation of the Master Charge credit card system, and the construction of a new bank office tower. He retired from the bank in 1980. Blair was very active in civic affairs including Vice Chairman of Case Western Reserve University and Vice President of The Cleveland Orchestra. He also served on the board of directors for a number of corporations including Gould and J.M. Smucker. He received the Business Statesman of the Year Award in 1976 from the Harvard Business School. Other awards included: Outstanding Chief Executive (Financial World magazine) and Banker of the Year (Finance magazine). A memorial service will be held on Monday, September 27, at 11am at the Bethesda-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach, Florida.
ROTH--Ida. My beloved mother on my shoulder and in my heart forever. Diane
The 36 Hours column on Aug. 22 about Portland, Me., described South Portland, across a bridge from Portland, incorrectly. It is a city, not a suburb, and has one beach, not beaches.

IN the 1920s, when Berlin roared with decadence, revolution and cabaret, the quiet, lush resort island of Hiddensee off the German Baltic coast drew fame as a kind of sun-drenched bohemian retreat, where artists and literati escaped to draw inspiration from nature and dip their feet in the sea. Today, families and sock-and-sandal-clad retirees have replaced the bold young things who once inhabited the century-old thatched-roof Ferienwohnungen, or vacation houses, sprinkled about the island, but Hiddensee still feels a world away from contemporary urban life.

As part of the bargain that kept JetBlue Airways from moving its headquarters from Queens to Orlando, state tourism officials agreed to let the airline mesh the iconic I NY logo with its own. The result, above, which was unveiled on Monday, signifies the first time that a corporation has received permission to link its brand to the symbol that is widely recognized as one of the most valuable assets in the realm of tourism marketing.

Sometimes forces beyond our control -- rock bands, bloggers, fashion people -- anoint a new epicenter of cool. Marfa, Tex., and Reykjavik, Iceland, had their moment, and now it's Lisbon's turn. The Walkmen named their latest album after the city. (J. Crew chimed in too, shooting a catalog there.) Hamilton Leithauser, the frontman, said the band traveled to Portugal while they wrote ''Lisbon'': ''Everything just worked there. The rest of Europe doesn't work as well for us -- our horn players quit in Germany.'' The results are 11 songs that range from explosive anthems (''Angela Surf City'') to lonely dirges (''Stranded''). ''Lisbon'' also marks the Walkmen's debut on Fat Possum Records, based in Oxford, Miss., another drowsy town ripe for aesthetic reclamation any minute now. ETHAN HAUSER

DRISCOLL--Brother Jack. The Rudin Management Company and the entire Rudin family mourn the passing of a wonderful man, our dear, compassionate, true friend, Brother Jack Driscoll. Jack's relationship with our family began in the early 1970's, when he became an outstanding President of Iona College, and that bond has continued to grow in spirit and substance in all the years since. Jack's insatiable love of learning, his ever-present kindness, insight and humility will always be an inspiration to those of us who knew him. We send out heartfelt condolences to the entire Driscoll family. Jack Rudin, Chairman Rudin Management Company

Imagine getting a bit lost in, say, Manchester, England, pointing your cellphone at a nondescript building and learning instantly that you've chanced across a legendary pub that opens 30 minutes from now -- and, by the way, a nearby rare-vinyl shop is offering a 20 percent discount, today only. Oh, and just down the block is a bistro that is never mentioned in guidebooks but is beloved by locals. Welcome to the new, hyper-connected, technology-based travel paradigm. It's the era of the smartphone as ubiquitous tool of navigation, when what matters is not just the here but the now. With smart phones increasingly ubiquitous, a new era of hyper-connected travel is at hand--literally--as so-called location-awareness continues to explode as a cultural/tech meme. Google Maps and Google Street View blanket more and more of the planet. Facebook and Twitter allow users to ''geotag'' their updates with specific geographic coordinates, while Foursquare turns ''checking in'' into a form of entertainment. Users of the photo-sharing site Flickr geotag more than four million photos per month. And augmented reality (AR) technology, which allows travelers to navigate their way to nearby attractions by aiming a smartphone in any direction, weaves together all those geodata points into a miniaturized virtual world coated with zesty little information bubbles.

An epic battle broke out in Fort Greene after the tornado touched down in Brooklyn last Thursday. Soldiers attacked damaged fortifications and raided larders. Rescue efforts failed, and no one made it to the refugee camp. The queen is missing - presumed dead. Human wars are often about money. This war was about honey.

SMITH--Helen. The board of directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the loss of Helen Smith, mother of our esteemed friend, Howard (Thelma) Smith. Helen was a kind and warm woman who made everyone smile. She was very devoted to her family as they were to her. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces and nephews and hope that the entire Smith family will be comforted by fond memories of this very special woman. Daniel Reingold, Pres. & CEO

London's bohemian vanguard has found a new home base in the twin neighborhoods of Kensal Rise and Kensal Green. North of Notting Hill in the former badlands above the Harrow Road, The traditionally Portuguese district of Victorian row houses north of Notting Hill is home to buzzy gastropubs and incognito celebrities -- Sophie Dahl and Jade Jagger live here -- and the rents are still cheap enough that pioneering shop owners are hanging out shingles on Chamberlayne Road. Victoria Brotherson, the florist behind Scarlet and Violet 1 (76 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-969-9446; scarletandviolet.co.uk), worked in Notting Hill Gate for 16 years before coming to Kensal Rise; now she sells vintage cut-crystal vases and chipped enamel pitchers alongside English blooms like cornflower and nigella. ''I thought I was just going to have a little workshop,'' she says. ''I was taken by surprise that we were that busy.'' In her wake, two vintage furniture stores, Howie & Belle 2 (52 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-964-4553; howieandbelle.com) and Circus Antiques (60 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-968-8244; circusantiques.co.uk), have opened among the bookies' offices down the street. And a 10-minute walk away in Kensal Green, Retrouvius 3 (2A Ravensworth Road; 011-44-208-960-6060; retrouvius.com) is the brainchild of the designers Adam Hills and Maria Speake, a space stocked with repurposed architectural salvage. There's quirky drinking and dining, too: besides the Chamberlayne Pub and Steakhouse (83 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-208-960-4311; thechamberlayne.co.uk) and the wine bar Miro's (75 Chamberlayne Road; 011-44-203-235-0003; miros.co.uk), the gastropub Paradise by Way of Kensal Green (19 Kilburn Lane; 011-44-208-969-0098; theparadise.co.uk)serves seasonal and organic dishes and a beloved sticky toffee pudding. It doubles as a lounge and performance space that may hide in its warren of rooms a burlesque show, a wedding or even the singer Lily Allen. VALERIE STIVERS

Stephanie Alison Scott and Bruce Hampton Harbour Jr. were married Saturday at Gorrono Ranch, an event space in Telluride, Colo. The Rev. Abraham Cho, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony. The bride, 27, and the bridegroom, 28, met at Princeton, from which they graduated magna cum laude.

LIVINGSTON--Audrey. The Board of Directors, Shareholders, and the Wallack Management family mourns the passing of Ms. Audrey Livingston, President of the Board of Directors. Our deepest sympathy goes out to the entire family.

While every hotelier wants in on the Marrakesh action -- Mandarin Oriental, Four Seasons and W hotels are all staking a claim here -- La Mamounia (Avenue Bab Jdid; 011-212-524-38-86-00; mamounia.com; doubles from $760) and Royal Mansour (Rue Abou Abbas El Sebti; 011-212-529-80-80-80; doubles from $1,900) are the two reigning heavyweights. THE STORY: King Mohammed VI himself built this resort just inside the medina wall, sparing no detail or expense to create an over-the-top mix of Art Deco and traditional Moroccan design. The most beloved hotel in North Africa recently underwent a three-year, $150 million renovation under the guidance of the French designer Jacques Garcia.

It's not only men who are fanning the flames of Tel Aviv's hot dining scene. Recently female chefs have started taking over the city's normally testosterone-fueled kitchens and bakeries. (There are at least three new cupcake shops owned by the ladies.) Tamar Cohen-Tzedek opened Cucina Tamar (HaTsfira 10; 011-972-3-639-0407; cucinatamar.rest-e.co.il; entrees about $17 to $26) two years ago, and it's now one of the top Italian spots in town. ''When I decided to open a restaurant, I didn't think, Oh, I'm doing this in a man's world,'' she says. ''I just did it.'' So did Einav Berman, who turns out plates like tomato tarte Tatin at her new restaurant, Asif (Lilienblum 18; 011-972-3-516-5198; entrees $16 to $31). At her home kitchen in the Florentin quarter, the American transplant Rima Olvera (left) cooks up a dinner feast for 14 guests every month (rimaolvera.com; $125). And at Joz ve Loz (Yehuda HaLevi 51; 011-972-3-560-6385; entrees $10 to $22), Niva Eshed heads a team of four women chefs (plus one guy) who serve Mediterranean fare like chicken liver ravioli with horseradish sour cream. Unlike in male-dominated kitchens, she says, ''there is no ego. More than for the food, we cook for the experience.'' ANTHONY GRANT

Shopping in a pharmacy in the souk is much more exciting than a trip to your local drugstore. The stores here offer all sorts of dried herbs, powders and tinctures claiming to cure everything from diabetes to broken hearts. At Herboriste Les Amis II, the lab-coated employees happily diagnose and prescribe. 2 Souk Cherratine, Semmarine; 011-212-675-90-62-41.

As the mortgage market grew frothy in 2006 — leading to a housing bubble that nearly brought down the banking system two years later — ratings agencies charged with assessing risk in mortgage pools dismissed conclusive evidence that many of the loans were dubious, according to testimony given last week to the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, Gretchen Morgenson writes in The New York Times.

Liberal pundits and the politicians whose agendas they favor continue to misunderstand the Tea Party movement and, what is worse, fail to realize how much the disdainful tone of their criticism fuels it. This may be changing now as the ominous signs proliferate - the primary victories of Christine O'Donnell, Joe Miller, Rand Paul and Sharron Angle, the likely election victory of Marco Rubio and, in recent days, the startling news that Carl Paladino and Joe DioGuardi may be closing in on supposed shoo-ins Andrew Cuomo and Kirsten Gillibrand (I say "may be" because there are conflicting polls). George Blanda, whose 26-year career was the longest of any player in N.F.L. history, has died at age 83. The Oakland Raiders, the team with which he came synonymous and from which he finally ended his career, confirmed his death.Blanda played so long that he had what amounted to three pro careers. He spent 10 years with the Chicago Bears, but retired when they tried to make him solely a kicker, and then seven more with the Houston Oilers of the upstart A.F.L. When the Oilers decided he was finished in 1967, he joined the Raiders and played nine more seasons. He wound up in the Hall of Fame with a reputation as one of the greatest clutch performers in football history.

One has to wonder how the designer Patrick Jouin manages to stay so svelte, given his fondness for gastronomy. For the past decade, Jouin, 43, has been collaborating with the Michelin-starred chef Alain Ducasse on numerous projects, including the PastaPot for Alessi and the chic interiors for Ducasse's restaurants at the Plaza Athénée in Paris and the Dorchester in London. ''Patrick Jouin: Design and Gesture,'' which opens Nov. 9 at the Museum of Arts and Design, will showcase his culinary product designs, complete with video sequences that illustrate their functions. Other items include Jouin's sleek stainless steel Zermatt flatware for Puiforcat, plastic Champagne bucket for G. H. Mumm and carbon fiber chairs for Le Jules Verne, the restaurant in the Eiffel Tower. ''My products are not related,'' Jouin said before acknowledging that ''they all come from the same pencil.'' Pieces like his Optic storage cubes for Kartell and C2 Solid chair for MGX will also be on view, along with the light he designed for the museum lobby (above). Designing, it seems, burns a lot of calories.

When designers make gallery pieces, you get sculptural chairs and charred chandeliers. But when artists create furniture, even the pretense of functionality disappears, leading to weird works like homoerotic bunk beds and chandeliers, like the one by Lee Bul (below), that don't light up. These are the kinds of conceptually charged objects cataloged in ''The New Décor,'' the book based on a recent exhibition at the Hayward Gallery in London and traveling to the Garage in Moscow this month. Their purpose is not to elevate the trappings of domestic life but to question our very faith in them. ''Contemporary artists are associating the home with a sense of movement, insecurity and precariousness,'' says the Hayward's director, Ralph Rugoff. ''Rather than being a castle, home is a vulnerable place now.'' While the more absurd pieces - like a giant hot-pink papier-mâché phallus bench by Franz West - explore our private space as a kind of public theater, others are more obviously unsettling. The Swiss artist Fabrice Gygi's tented writing desk is somewhere between a child's fort and a bomb shelter, and Jin Shi's Chinese migrant worker's dwelling is a chilling reminder of how the other half lives.

¶ The much-maligned Rangers defenseman Wade Redden, waived Saturday after two disappointing years with the Blueshirts, clears waivers on Monday without being claimed by another N.H.L. club. He and the $6.5 million cap hit he represents are now clear to go to the Rangers' American League affiliate in Hartford. The long-anticipated move puts the Rangers beneath the salary cap and even leaves them with a couple of million dollars to make a new signing. But some believe that sending Redden to the minors (or to Europe, where he could sign with a club as former Blackhawks goalie Cristobal Huet did last month) could prove problematic under the collective bargaining agreement. Redden, a former N.H.L. all-star with Ottawa who once shared the league's plus-minus award and played for Team Canada at the World Cup, I.I.H.F. World Championship and Winter Olympics, scored 5 goals and 40 points while going plus-3 in 156 games with the Rangers. Those stats are pretty good, but far short of the performance expected from a player who still has four years and $23 million left on his current Rangers deal. Redden does have a third option if he clears waivers: refuse to report to Hartford, which would void his contract and leave him free to seek a deal with another N.H.L. team, which will undoubtedly pay him much less.

Jessie Singer Sylvester moved anonymously through old age in Brooklyn in the 1970s, absorbing one loss after the next - her job of 59 years, her beloved sister, her friends, her sense of security, her sharp mind. Still, she soldiered on, attending to her sister until she died, cooking and cleaning for herself, going to classes at the local senior center and visiting parks, museums and what she called "the Botanical."

With a kind heart, a generous spirit, and a deep devotion to family, Win lived a life of love, accomplishment, adventure, creativity and joy. As a child prodigy and exceptional pianist, he shared his gift of music as a volunteer for many organizations including Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home for over 25 years. He was an award-winning salesman, successful real estate owner, tournament tennis champion, food connoisseur and faithful practitioner of transcendental meditation for 33 years. He traveled extensively including 80 days around the globe. Above all, he was devoted to his family: daughters Susan and Sarah, son Roger, late wife Maureen, nine grandchildren, one great-grandchild and his devoted companion of 28 years Leslie Gottlieb. Funeral service will be held Monday, September 27, 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (91st St.), New York. Donations will be gratefully accepted for music students who are blind or visually impaired: The Irwin H. Widelitz Scholarship Fund, Music School, Lighthouse International, 111 East 59th Street, New York City 10022 www.lighthouse.org

One way to describe the progress on a project to repair a 75-foot wall that collapsed onto Riverside Drive and the Henry Hudson Parkway in Washington Heights is: Finally, really, finished. Almost. Another way is to listen to Carlos Pelletier, the doorman at 1380 Riverside Drive, which was in the path of the debris just north of West 181st Street. How would he describe the repairs?

BOISE, Idaho -- The night before Boise State played Oregon State, Kellen Moore hung out with his family in the lobby of a nearby Courtyard Marriott. He wore flip flops and cargo shorts and blended in seamlessly with a lobby full of fans, loitering members of the news media and travelers waiting to check in. At a sliver under 6 feet, Moore is the everyman quarterback. His shaggy hair and unimposing physique could help him blend in everywhere from a fraternity couch to an intramural team. But the numbers he has put up this year and last make him an obvious Heisman Trophy contender.

With close-cropped hair, a trim physique and body-builder forearms, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi projects a G.I. Joe aura, rough and ready when the going gets tough. By winning a World Series last season -- in his second year on the job in New York -- Girardi seemed a man in full, successful quickly in one of the most demanding jobs in sports and mature beyond his 45 years.

Katy Perry's costumes may be too revealing for the audience of ''Sesame Street,'' but the pop star's outfits should fit right in on ''The Simpsons.'' Ms. Perry will appear as herself, and as the girlfriend of the bartender Moe, in a live-action segment that will feature puppet versions of the show's characters, Entertainment Weekly reported on its Web site. Last week, the Sesame Workshop, which produces ''Sesame Street,'' said it would not broadcast a music video planned for the coming season in which Ms. Perry and Elmo perform a version of her song ''Hot 'N Cold.'' After previewing the video on YouTube, the company received a large volume of complaints about Ms. Perry's low-cut dress. ''In the wake of Elmo's terrible betrayal, the Simpsons puppets wish to announce they stand felt-shoulder-to-shoulder with Katy Perry,'' Al Jean, an executive producer of the Simpsons, said in a statement to Entertainment Weekly.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Thursday about Antonina Pirozhova, the widow of the writer Isaac Babel and the author of a memoir about the last years of his life, misstated the name of the Soviet secret police, who arrested and later executed him. It was the N.K.V.D., not the K.G.B. (The K.G.B. was created in 1954, 14 years after Babel's execution.)

PARIS -- Serving as a member of the European Parliament can be a thankless task. Lobbyists accost you from all corners. Tabloid newspapers complain about your expenses. And after a day of plenary sessions in Strasbourg, you might not be able to watch television shows from your home country without breaking the law. On that last issue, at least, there may be hope for change -- thanks in part to action by the Parliament.

NATIONAL An article on Sept. 17 about the unexpected tightening of the race for Texas governor misstated the number of terms the Democratic candidate, Bill White, served as mayor of Houston. He served three two-year terms, not two three-year terms.

Early in his tenure at The Sunday Times of London, Murray Sayle reported on the escape of an eagle from the London Zoo by following the bird around Regent's Park on a bicycle. It was a minor story in a major journalistic career, but it suggested Mr. Sayle's inventive and audacious approach to his job: he would go anywhere and get there by any means necessary. He reported on an ascent of Mount Everest by joining the expedition. He reported on a trans-Atlantic race for solo sailors by entering it. He chartered a plane to locate the yachtsman Sir Francis Chichester as Sir Francis sailed around Cape Horn as the first solo sailor to circumnavigate the globe using the route once taken by clipper ships. He tramped into the Bolivian jungle in search of the Marxist revolutionary Che Guevara, and he found Kim Philby, the British agent who had defected to the Soviet Union, in Moscow.

8 P.M. (NBC) CHUCK Chuck (Zachary Levi) and Sarah (Yvonne Strahovski), together above, go stylish -- and undercover -- in Milan during fashion week to retrieve a high-tech secret weapon. The model Karolina Kurkova and the actors Lou Ferrigno and Isaiah Mustafa guest star. In ''The Event,'' at 9, the staff of President Martinez (Blair Underwood) races to assess what happened to the plane that was barreling toward him last week until it disappeared into a fissure in the space-time continuum. And in ''Chase,'' at 10, Annie Frost (Kelli Giddish) and a team of United States marshals track a fugitive (Robert LaSardo) intent on killing for what he thinks is rightfully his. 3 P.M. (Fox Business Network) COUNTDOWN TO THE CLOSING BELL Liz Claman broadcasts her 600th episode live from the Hercules Offshore oil rig H 201 in the Gulf of Mexico. Among the topics: the concerns and frustrations experienced by workers because of the moratorium against deep-water drilling imposed after the BP spill.

''Oh, God, doctor, I was hoping it was cancer.'' Those words so affected Dr. William Harrison that for years, he said, he could not repeat them. They made him break down in tears.

Eric Clapton, above during his concert tour in February, is one of three veteran rockers to release albums on Sept. 28. ''Clapton,'' his first studio album in five years, will be joined by ''Going Back'' from Phil Collins -- his first studio album in eight years -- which recreates the Motown sound that influenced him. Neil Young will offer ''Le Noise,'' which has eight songs recorded by Mr. Young playing solo guitar. Newer artists dominate the top sellers, but older rockers like Tom Petty (''Mojo,'' at No. 13) and Ozzy Osbourne (''Scream,'' at No. 27), are well represented. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Clay Matthews III has six sacks, and every time he takes down a quarterback, the Matthews clan (including his father, Clay Jr.; his grandfather Clay Sr.; and his Hall of Fame uncle, Bruce) moves up the list of great football families. The Matthews family has officially registered 75 1/2 career sacks, although the N.F.L. did not count them in the 1950s, when the oldest Matthews played. Sacks are a major issue for the Bears. Jay Cutler and others were dropped 19 times in the preseason. Left tackle Chris Williams (hamstring) did not practice last week, meaning the Bears will have to juggle their blockers and hope Cutler shows the same poise in the pocket he showed against the Cowboys. Pick: Packers.

THE ARTS An article on Wednesday about an Afghan-American film director's efforts to shoot a feature film in Afghanistan omitted attribution for the statement that a producer and a set designer on the film had abandoned the director, Sonia Nassery Cole, in the middle of production. That was Ms. Cole's characterization. The article also omitted responses from the two, who were not named. Michael Carney, the set designer, now says that he left four days before the end of the shoot, after working on the film in Afghanistan for two months.

I.B.M.'s announcement Monday that it is buying Netezza for $1.7 billion highlights how much the fast-growing field of business intelligence is increasingly both a hardware and a software technology. Netezza, based in Marlborough, Mass., makes computer appliances that combine hardware and software for business analytics. The term ''business analytics,'' of course, is the branding upgrade that has been given to business intelligence.

A new study confirms what some in the technology industry have long sensed: that Apple commands an inordinate amount of the media's attention. A yearlong look at technology news coverage by the Pew Research Center's Project for Excellence in Journalism found that 15.1 percent of tech articles were primarily about Apple; 11.4 percent were about Google; and a meager 3 percent were about Microsoft.

On Tuesday Marco Arment, the chief technology officer at the social networking site Tumblr, announced that he would be leaving it to tend to a personal project: Instapaper. I caught up with Mr. Arment on the phone on Wednesday to find out what was next from his personal project.

BANGKOK -- It's been a rough year for Thailand. First there were the images of deadly street battles between soldiers and protesters beamed around the world. Then people living in neighboring dictatorships snickered that Thailand was a democracy in decline. Foreign tourists wondered whether it was safe to travel here. And now this: An Australian chef has the audacity to declare that he is on a mission to revive Thai cuisine.

Paterson's advisers criticized ''Saturday Night Live'' for mocking his impaired vision in its send-up of him, Mr. Paterson confronted his impersonator, Fred Armisen, with a batch of his own one-liners. Hoping to overshadow last month's large rally led by Glenn Beck that drew many Tea Party advocates and other conservatives, a coalition of liberal groups plan to descend on Washington on Saturday to make the case that they, and not the ascendant right, speak for America's embattled middle class. Predicting a crowd of more than 100,000, some 300 liberal groups -- including the N.A.A.C.P., the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the National Council of La Raza and the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force -- are sponsoring a march on Saturday in the hope of transforming the national conversation so it focuses less on the Tea Party. The groups sponsoring the rally, which is called ''One Nation Working Together,'' say they hope to supplant what they say is the Tea Party's divisiveness with a message of unity to promote jobs, justice and education.

Michael Crawford is set to play the Wizard in Andrew Lloyd Webber's new production of ''The Wizard of Oz,'' which will begin previews at the London Palladium on Feb. 7, 2011, according to Mr. Lloyd Webber's Web site. ''We will be going a lot further than simply presenting the movie on stage,'' Mr. Lloyd Webber said in a comment posted on the site. ''We have revisited the original novel and re-conceived our 'Oz' as a piece of new musical theater using the wonderful Arlen/Harburg songs and adding a few new ones where there are gaps.'' Mr. Crawford starred in Mr. Lloyd Webber's production of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' in the West End in 1986 and on Broadway in 1986, where he won a Tony Award for best actor in a musical. Danielle Hope, the winner of the BBC television reality show ''Over the Rainbow,'' will play Dorothy. The production of L. Frank Baum's classic tale will be directed by Jeremy Sams, choreographed by Arlene Phillips, with music and lyrics by Harold Arlen and E.Y. Harburg, with additional music and lyrics by Mr. Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

MILLSTEIN--Diane G. Passed away on September 25, 2010, after a prolonged illness, on her own terms, just as she had lived throughout a full life of family and career. A short obituary is hardly sufficient, but something must be said, beyond acknowledging the love, respect and affection of her husband, children, grandchildren, friends, and the many lives she touched in her professional career. From boarding and public schools, and a challenging family background, she found her stride at NYU as a national and international fencing champion. Her success in this sport gave her the self confidence that would become the mainspring for the pioneering which was the hallmark of many of her endeavors. At 15 years of age, Diane met Ira who, after years of courtship, became her husband and lifelong partner. Following a brief stay in New York and Washington, DC in the early years of their marriage, she found great joy in their moving to Westchester County where they raised a son James, and daughter Elizabeth. Soon thereafter, Diane headed to Columbia University for a Masters in City Planning, graduating and ultimately becoming the City Planner for Greenwich, Conn. Learning the intricacies of local government in city planning, she struck out on her own to become a land developer and build residential town homes with the support of family and friends. Diane was likely the first woman to vigorously contest zoning boards, other government agencies and the like, don a hard hat and actually direct all activities on a building site. Success quickly followed with her signature de-attached town homes (then a new concept for the era and locus) in Larchmont, Mamaroneck and New Rochelle. She later branched out and joined a real estate partnership which managed shopping centers across the country. Her business gains provided her the opportunity to be a generous, and most often anonymous, philanthropist to large and small causes, many of which championed women's and children's issues. An athlete throughout her life, she was an avid tennis player for Quaker Ridge Golf Club and then took up golf later in life with the same ardor and dedication she gave to her professional endeavors, eventually becoming the president of the Westchester Inter club Golf League. Her children are successfully following their own stars, and her five grandchildren will remember her with admiration and affection, seeing a role model of courage and hard work as a means to conquer any obstacle that life may present. All of us mourn her passing, but take genuine comfort that she has overcome an undeserved ordeal. Ira, Jim, Liz, Kate, Joanna, Max, Natalie, and Jack. Funeral Services will be held Tuesday 10am at Larchmont Temple 75 Larchmont Ave. Larchmont, NY 10538 (914)834.6120. Interment will be at Sharon Garden Cemetery in Valhalla, NY. The Millstein family will receive friends at their home (1240 Flagler Dr. Mamaroneck, NY 10543) Tuesday evening 6-9pm.

Seattle may have Amazon.com and its books, vacuums, electronics and pet supplies. But Manhattan can now lay claim to an online shopping service that deals in far more bizarre objects. One of the leading 3-D printing companies is Shapeways, which has just moved its headquarters from the Netherlands to New York. The company brings with it a service that lets people design their own objects, send the design to Shapeways and then receive the printed 3-D object back a few days later in the mail. People using the service print more than 10,000 products each month, ranging from iPad kitchen stands to jewelry and DNA molecule models.

This should boost ticket sales for the musical ''American Idiot'' during Broadway's traditional September doldrums: Billie Joe Armstrong, the frontman and lead guitarist of the rock band Green Day, will step into the role of St. Jimmy in the musical for eight performances from this Tuesday through Sunday evening, the producers have announced. A rock opera of songs by Green Day, drawn chiefly from its 2004 album titled ''American Idiot,'' the musical centers on a young wannabe musician named Johnny (John Gallagher Jr.) who is haunted by St. Jimmy (Tony Vincent), a spectral character who enables Johnny's drug addiction.Mr. Vincent had been scheduled to be out of the show from Tuesday until Oct. 12 to deal with a family matter, and word had been circulating on Broadway last week that Mr. Armstrong might assume the role. Mr. Vincent's understudies will cover the part during the second week of his absence, as Mr. Armstrong will be leaving Broadway to join Green Day in Caracas, Venezuela, to begin a South American tour.

Alfred's knowledge, intelligence and integrity will be missed by all who knew him.

But he has also carved out a long career as one of the leading conservatives in the book business, known for his editing of authors like David Brock, Dinesh D'Souza and the former governor of Alaska, Sarah Palin.

When a journalist recounts a just-completed interview to a friend or a colleague, ''you don't tell him the narrative of your story, you tell him what the person was like,'' said Bill Owens, the executive editor of ''60 Minutes,'' the CBS news magazine. ''60 Minutes'' is applying that insight to a new part of the CBSNews.com Web site, ''60 Minutes Overtime.'' It will feature behind-the-scenes segments about the stories told weekly on television. CBS has signed up a prominent sponsor, Pfizer, for the Web site, which started on Sunday, the day of the television program's 43rd season premiere.

JACOBSON--Seymour Davis. Dress Designer and avid New Yorker died Wednesday atCooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, MA, ten days before his 101st birthday. The youngest of seven brothers, Seymour was born in Brooklyn on October 2, 1909 and weaned on the New York Times. His first job at age ten was filling penny candy machines in the New York Subway. In the mid 1930's Seymour became a partner in Encore Dresses. This launched his career designing and manufacturing elegant cocktail and party dresses through his various labels that included Seymour Jacobson, Ltd. Donna Paula and Luciana Moda. Grace Kelly, Rita Hayworth and Eleanor Roosevelt were among the many influential women who wore his line. Seymour's interests extended beyond fashion: In Lawnside, New Jersey he financed and built a community for returning black veterans of World War II and built offices for the US Postal Service in Nassau and Fairfield Counties. He married Dorothy Lipton in 1932. She died in 1979. He is survived by his three children Jay Jacobson and his wife Patricia, Clifford Jacobson and Lynn Lewin, his four grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. He was a forty-year resident of The Century at 25 Central Park West and spent the last year in Massachusetts, living closer to family. Contributions in Seymour's memory should be addressed to Doctors Without Boarders for Haiti Earthquake Relief at Doctors Without Borders USA, PO Box 5030, Hagerstown, MD 21741.

Qatar will open a new museum on Dec. 30 devoted to modern Arab art in its capital, Doha. Called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, it will house a collection of more than 6,000 works, spanning the 1840s to the present and representing major artistic trends. Its opening exhibition, "Sajjil: A Century of Modern Art," will feature work by more than 100 artists. For now, Mathaf (which means "museum" in Arabic) will be located in a former school building, redesigned for the museum by the French architect Jean-François Bodin. Plans for a permanent home will be announced later. The museum is being established by the Qatar Museums Authority, a government department, and the Qatar Foundation , a government-sponsored entity. In 2008, the authority, run by the daughter of Qatar's emir, opened the Museum of Islamic Art in a building designed by I.M. Pei.

In 1980, convinced that Ronald Reagan's references to "the American people" were not intended to include gay citizens like him, Larry Kramer began writing a book called "The American People," envisioned as a national history of homosexuality. The author of such plays as "The Normal Heart" and "The Destiny of Me," Mr. Kramer focused at first on the 20th century but concluded that he had plenty to say about 19th century, the 18th century, and, ultimately, precolonial gay life. It became a magnum opus, with Mr. Kramer writing on and off for 30 years while he was a co-founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis and the protest group ACT UP and nearly dying from end-stage liver disease until receiving a transplant in 2001.

Wondering what the chicest party during Milan Fashion Week was? The dinner to celebrate the appointment of Sally Singer as editor in chief of T, naturalmente. ¶ The Buffalo Sabres and the Ottawa Senators face off Tuesday night in the first real on-ice event of the N.H.L. season, the Kraft Hockeyville game, played this year at Dundas, Ontario, the picturesque little valley town adjacent to Hamilton. For the Sabres it's the first of several keynote events in this, their 40th anniversary season. On Nov. 6 they will go to Toronto to play the Leafs, their neighbors and historic rivals, in the Hall of Fame game, and from Dec. 26 to Jan. 5 their downtown rink will play host to the world junior tournament. Back to the Hamilton area, where there are a fair number of Sabres season-ticket holders. Still, it's slightly odd that the Sabres' annus mirabilis should start near Hamilton, as their presence just 50 miles down the Queen E. Way is one of two reasons Hamilton cannot get an N.H.L. team (the other reason, of course, is the presence of the Leafs less than 50 miles the other way).

PESSEN--Adele Barlin, died peacefully at home in Brooklyn the day before her 92nd birthday. Adored wife of Edward for 52 years; beloved and proud mother of Beth, Abigail, Dinah, Jonathan, and Andrew and dear mother-in-law of Lucien, Richard, Abe, and MaryAnn; beloved by her sister Marilyn, brother-in-law Aaron and niece Julie and her husband Paul; cherished grandmother of Alex and his wife Sarah, Adam and his wife Julia, David and his wife Camilla, and Zachary, and loved great-grandmother of Oscar and Lola. Adele had a creative and inquiring mind and boundless energy, raising her family into her fifties, working into her seventies, earning her M.F.A. in her eighties, and writing children's books, short stories, screenplays and a blog into her nineties. We will miss her great flair, original style, unconventional opinions, wit, and spunk.

LILLIOTT--William R.,II, 91, died September 24, 2010 in Dunedin, Florida. He was born on a farm in Toombs County, Georgia on January 10, 1919, and moved to Dunedin in 1927. He attended Clearwater High School, went for two years to the University of Florida, and for one year at St. Lawrence University. He joined the US Navy V-7 program in 1939, and went to Midshipman School for three months in Abbott Hall, Chicago. He was commissioned as Ensign in the USNR in March 1941, and he was assigned to duty on the Destroyer USS Hilary P. Jones (427), serving for one year conveying ships from the east coast to Iceland. In January 1942, he was assigned to submarine duty on the SS 213 Greenling out of New London, CT. He made thirteen Submarine War Patrols in WWII, serving on the Greenling and the SS 406 Sea Poacher. He was awarded the Silver Star for his actions. On May 6, 1944, he married Corinne "Lambie" Lamb, and on November 26, 1945 he was released from active duty. He and Lambie had five children through the years. In November 1945, he joined the firm of Merrill Lynch, working with them until December 1985. From 1970-1980 he managed Merrill Lynch, Royal Securities Ltd. in Canada, and was the only American elected to be the Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Toronto Stock Exchange for two years. After his 1985 retirement, he relocated to Summit, NJ where he and Lambie enjoyed retirement together until her passing in 1991. He then moved to Dunedin where he enjoyed the Dunedin Country Club. He is survived by his sons William R. Lilliott III of San Diego, CA, Arthur Henry Lilliott of Bellingham, WA and Richard James Lilliott of Naples, NY, and by his daughters Christine Bradt of Old Forge, NY and Corinne Lilliott of Lebanon, NJ, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. In Lieu of flowers, donations to Suncoast Hospice or to the ASPCA are suggested. Services by Curlew Hills Funeral Home (727) 789-2000.

STEINKE--Russell. "James Russell Steinke", 57, noted artist of New York City, on September 22, 2010. Beloved life partner of Homer Carroll, remembered by his loving family: mother Helen Steinke, brother Bob, sister-in-law Pam, niece Susan and nephew Eric of Nashville and Chicago, sister-in-law Peggy Steinke and nieces Stacey, Kim and Michelle of Decatur and Naperville, Illinois. Preceded in death by father John Steinke and brother Bill. Memorial service will be held at Church of the Holy Apostles, 296 Ninth Avenue at 28th Street on Saturday, October 9 at 4pm. To view his art, visit http://web.mac.com/russellsteinke.

SHAPIRO--Norman, husband of Ruth (deceased), much loved father of Merrill, Steve (deceased), adored grandfather of Jenai and Kiera, cherished brother of Gert, Mel, and Mimi, brother in-law of Eddie and Roz, and loving uncle to numerous nieces and nephews, completed his life on September 24th. Norm, a WWII Navy Vet, had an inspiring career as an educator, culminating in his position as principal at Westinghouse High School. He leaves us with a legacy of love and compassion. Graveside services will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery at 1pm on September 28th.

ORDENE--Norman M.,88, on September 26. Beloved husband of the late Leona Ordene. He is survived by children Dr. Kenneth Ordene and Dr. Marjorie Ordene Brown, grandchildren, Lauren Edelstein, Jason Ordene and Ari Brown. Norman was a graduate of NYU and NYU Dental School. He served as a Captain in the US Army Dental Corps in Aberdeen, MD, 1952-1954. He practiced dentistry in Long Island for over 50 yrs and was the former editor of the New York State Dental Journal.

UDON, THAILAND -- The most dazzling creatures Nui Davis saw when she was a child were the village girls who had found foreign husbands, visiting in their Western finery and handing out candies to the children. ''For me, they were like a princess,'' she said. ''And I kept those pictures in my mind, and I made a wish that one day I would like to be one of those ladies.''

Sotheby's held a successful fire sale on Saturday, auctioning art from Lehman Brothers, which declared bankruptcy in 2008, and its money management company Neuberger Berman. Of the 142 works on the block, solid prices were achieved for contemporary artists who either currently have museum exhibitions or are about to - names like Julie Mehretu, John Baldessari and Glenn Ligon. An abstract painting from 2001 by Ms. Mehretu, who has shows on view in New York at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Gallery Met, was the top seller, bringing $1 million from an unidentified collector. Other popular artists were Gerhard Richter, whose works-on-paper are on view at the Drawing Center in SoHo, and Mr. Baldessari, whose retrospective has been at the Tate Modern in London and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. It is opening next month at the Metropolitan Museum.

Americans are by all measures a deeply religious people, but they are also deeply ignorant about religion. Researchers from the independent Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life phoned more than 3,400 Americans and asked them 32 questions about the Bible, Christianity and other world religions, famous religious figures and the constitutional principles governing religion in public life.

One of the most difficult decisions a man makes about prostate cancer happens long before the diagnosis. Should he get a regular blood test to screen for the disease? Screening for early detection of cancer sounds like a no-brainer, but it's not an easy choice for men considering regular P.S.A. tests, which measure blood levels of prostate-specific antigen and are used to detect prostate cancer. Though use of the test is widespread, studies show that the screening saves few, if any, lives.
MILLSTEIN--Diane. With our deepest condolences to Ira, Jim, Liz and family. Diane's unique combination of drive, wit and spirit has left an indelible mark on our lives. Karen and Barry Wolf

Rahm Emanuel, the White House chief of staff, is ''nearing a decision'' on whether to leave the Obama administration to explore a run for mayor of Chicago and could make an announcement as early as Friday, a person close to Mr. Emanuel said Monday night. Mr. Emanuel has been in the thick of deliberations over whether to run for mayor ever since the current mayor, Richard M. Daley, announced his intention to retire. The filing deadline is Nov. 22, but with speculation swirling his future, Mr. Emanuel, who is assessing the impact of a run on his wife and young children, wants to make a decision soon. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The pastor, Terry Jones, leads the nondenominational Dove World Outreach Center; he is not a Baptist preacher.

No one will know for sure until the end of the year, but a new analysis of state population figures suggests that the state of New York will lose two United States House seats - not just one, as earlier predicted -- in the coming decennial reapportionment. The new analysis, from Kimball W. Brace and Election Data Services, which spends a lot of time sorting through such statistics, also suggests two additional seats will go to Florida (not just one, as has been suggested before).

Egypt's minister of the interior told the official MENA news agency that a museum employee was most likely responsible for the theft of a valuable van Gogh painting from a museum in Giza last month, Agence France-Presse reported. The painting, known as ''Poppy Flowers'' or ''Vase and Flowers'' and valued at more than $50 million, was cut from its frame on Aug. 21 at the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum, where it hung in a room with only some working cameras and no working alarms. Several Egyptian cultural officials, including Mohsen Shaalan, a deputy culture minister who heads the fine arts division of the ministry, have been charged with negligence.

The much-maligned Rangers defenseman Wade Redden, waived Saturday after two disappointing years with the Blueshirts, clears waivers on Monday without being claimed by another N.H.L. club. He and the $6.5 million cap hit he represents are now clear to go to the Rangers' American League affiliate in Hartford. The long-anticipated move puts the Rangers beneath the salary cap and even leaves them with a couple of million dollars to make a new signing. But some believe that sending Redden to the minors (or to Europe, where he could sign with a club as former Blackhawks goalie Cristobal Huet did last month) could prove problematic under the collective bargaining agreement. Redden, a former N.H.L. all-star with Ottawa who once shared the league's plus-minus award and played for Team Canada at the World Cup, I.I.H.F. World Championship and Winter Olympics, scored 5 goals and 40 points while going plus-3 in 156 games with the Rangers. Those stats are pretty good, but far short of the performance expected from a player who still has four years and $23 million left on his current Rangers deal. Redden does have a third option if he clears waivers: refuse to report to Hartford, which would void his contract and leave him free to seek a deal with another N.H.L. team, which will undoubtedly pay him much less. Also sent down to Hartford by the Rangers: Mats Zuccarello Aasen, the Norwegian Hobbit Wizard.

For its new Public Forum series, a program of lectures by and conversations with prominent writers and theater artists that will begin later this fall, the Public Theater is bringing in some big guns. How big? How about a talk between Stephen Sondheim and Tony Kushner, hosted by Rocco Landesman? (Not too shabby, right?) That will be the culminating event for the inaugural season of the Public Forum, which was announced on Monday by the Public Theater and is organized by Jeremy McCarter, a senior writer at Newsweek magazine. The series is to begin on Oct. 18 with a three-part, 90-minute program called ''Chasing the Green Light,'' hosted by Sam Waterston and timed to the Public's sizable production of ''Gatz,'' a word-for-word adaptation of ''The Great Gatsby.'' That program will feature a round-table discussion with the novelist Jay McInerney (''Bright Lights, Big City''), the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks (''Topdog/Underdog'') and Michael Friedman, the composer and lyricist of ''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson''; a discussion between Arianna Huffington, editor in chief of The Huffington Post, and Reihan Salam, a contributor to National Review; and readings of letters written to F. Scott Fitzgerald by Zelda Fitzgerald.

JOINT BASE LEWIS-MCCHORD, Wash. -- Members of an American Army unit consumed with drug use randomly chose Afghan civilians to kill and then failed to report the abuses out of fear they would suffer retaliation from their commander, according to testimony in military court here on Monday. The testimony, in a hearing to determine whether one of those soldiers, Specialist Jeremy N. Morlock, would face a court-martial and a possible death sentence, came the same day that a videotape in the case was leaked showing Specialist Morlock talking to investigators about the killings in gruesome detail with no apparent emotion.

The Web site of The Irrawaddy, a magazine based in Thailand that is a leading source of news and criticism of the junta in Myanmar, has been blocked by hackers, its editor, Aung Zaw, said on Monday. The ''distributed denial of service'' attack just after midnight was similar to but more sophisticated than an attack on the site two years ago. Mr. Aung Zaw said it was not clear whether the attack came from inside Myanmar or from China, a close ally. Visitors to the site, www.irrawaddy.org, have been redirected to a mirror site. ''This is a new game, a new frontier'' in the government's struggle against its opponents, Mr. Aung Zaw said. ''It shows how vulnerable we are.''

FUSILLO-O'BOYLE--Dr. Christine a resident of Greenwich, CT passed away surrounded by her loving husband Robert O'Boyle and her children at home Sunday morning. The devoted mother of Brian, Katie and Maureen O'Boyle; Christine is also survived by her mother Catherine Fusillo of White Plains, NY; sisters Cathy Crocetti, Faith Fusillo, and brother Leonard Fusillo. From an early age Christine was compelled to help people. Christine graduated form New York University Medical School and later decided to specialize in Allergy and Immunology. For the next 24 years she practiced in medicine in Westchester County, NY, with a private practice based in Tarrytown, NY. In addition Christine was also Director of the Pediatric Allergy Clinic at Westchester County Medical Center, Clinical Professor of Pediatrics and Allergy and Immunology at New York Medical College and Director at the Union Community Health Center in Bronx, NY (NPO). Over the past decade, Dr. Fusillo was consistently ranked amongst top doctors, in both New York and America, by Castle-Connolly, Westchester Magazine and New York Magazine. Her passion and capacity for care giving, both professionally and personally, was unbounded. Dr. Christine Fusillo is and will forever be an inspiration to countless students, colleagues and all who were blessed enough to have known her. A capsule summary in some editions on Sunday for an article about an effort by Iran's Atomic Energy Organization to protect its facilities from a sophisticated malware that had infected industrial plants across the country misstated the nature of that malware. As the article correctly noted, it is a worm, not a virus. The headline repeated the error. (A worm is a self-replicating malware computer program; a virus is malware that infects its target by attaching itself to programs or documents.)

8 P.M. (ESPN) INTO THE WIND In 1980, three years after receiving a diagnosis of osteosarcoma, a form of bone cancer, and having his right leg amputated six inches above the knee, Terry Fox decided to run across Canada. What began as one man's journey to raise money and awareness for cancer research has grown into the world's largest one-day fund-raiser for the cause. Though Mr. Fox, who was born in 1958, ran the equivalent of a marathon each day, he never finished his quest: starting in Newfoundland, he made it to Ontario before the cancer spread to his lungs. He died in 1981. In this latest entry in ESPN's ''30 for 30'' documentary series, the first-time filmmaker Steve Nash, a Canadian and a point guard for the Phoenix Suns, and the director Ezra Holland recount the story of Mr. Fox, one of Mr. Nash's childhood idols. ''I remember being a 6-year-old boy and waking up every morning and rushing to the TV to see where Terry was that day,'' Mr. Nash said. ''To see him running or hobbling across our country for the spirit of community and looking out for others was something that has stuck with me ever since. To see his face hiding the pain and to hear his words disguising the sacrifice was as motivating and as educational an experience as I've ever had.'' 8 P.M. The good news for Max Weinberg fans is that he'll have a lot more time to spend with Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band. On Monday, representatives for Conan O'Brien officially announced that Mr. Weinberg, the longtime band leader at NBC's ''Late Night'' and ''Tonight Show'' programs, would not be joining Mr. O'Brien at his TBS series, ''Conan,'' which is to have its premiere on Nov. 8. Mr. Weinberg, who created the Max Weinberg 7 band for ''Late Night With Conan O'Brien'' in 1993, and Mr. O'Brien said in a joint statement that the departure was by mutual agreement. Mr. O'Brien said in the statement that ''Max has been a huge part of my life for the past 17 years and he is an incredible band leader and musician. I hope he can find time to stop by the new show, sit in with the band, and pretend to find my monologue funny.''

The British painter David Hockney has never confined himself to just one artistic medium. (Remember the Polaroid collages?) True to form, he was quick to embrace the iPhone's Brushes app, among others. Even as he was working on large-scale landscapes of his native Yorkshire, England - for a big 2012 exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London - Hockney was drawing energetic, vividly colored images of flowers, places and people at screen scale, which he e-mails to friends. These, along with his drawings on the iPad, are the subject of ''David Hockney: Fleurs Fraîches,'' which runs from Oct. 20 to Jan. 30, 2011, at the Pierre Bergé-Yves Saint Laurent Foundation in Paris. Curated by Charlie Scheips and designed by the New York architect Ali Tayar of Parallel Design, the exhibition will present the artwork in its original digital format, including animations of one or more works. (Brushes records the process of a painting in video.) The iPhones and iPads themselves will be set into fiberboard panels like the ones that line Hockney's studio, and Tayar is even designing special furniture for the installation - which Scheips says ''won't look like an Apple store. It will be more homey.'' The act of iPainting seems no less immediate for its lack of actual pigments; Scheips says Hockney becomes so immersed that he stops to wipe off his fingers.

An article in The Times on Wednesday centers on Tocco da Casauria, a small, traditional town in Italy whose four wind turbines, installed over the past four years, produce 30 percent more energy than its residents use. In fact, money made from the production of clean energy has brought the town back from the brink of insolvency and allowed to renovate its school and perform other much-needed municipal repairs.

Voters who say they watch the Fox News Channel for most of their information about politics and current events are more enthusiastic about the election and more attentive to it, angrier with Washington and more likely to vote for Republican candidates this fall than viewers of any other news network, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted this month.

From Pakistan to New Zealand to Poland, the roster of international fashion weeks reads like a United Nations roll call, and last week it was Mumbai's chance to take its runway turn. India's exotic lure is obvious enough, but don't expect Mumbai to become the next Milan anytime soon. Lakme Fashion Week's best designers tend to think locally, but what looks chic on India's colorful streets can turn clownish on the streets of the Western fashion capitals. So far, Manish Arora, who showed his over-the-top collection to cheers last week, is India's biggest international fashion success story. But other homegrown talents appear to have their eye on Manhattan as well as Mumbai. They all share a sensibility that, while rooted in a sense of place, also reflects a globalized reality - and, most important, won't make you look like an extra in a Bollywood dance number.

After a short break (hair salon, manicure, café time), the European spring collections resumed today in Paris with shows by Dries Van Noten, Rochas and Hakaan, among the top-billed. Mr. Van Noten seemed to stay in the vein of his fall show (minus the leopard print and military drab), opening with wide-leg, patch-pocket trousers in white cotton and matching over-size blazers. The clothes harped on a masculine ease; the washed denim trousers and sleeveless jackets were appealing. On the feminine side, there were silk shifts with floral print that appeared to dissolve to a blur half way down the body.

In this lesson, students learn how an invasive species and a native species experiencing a population explosion may threaten some of the world's oldest trees, bristlecone pines in the Western United States. They then explore invasive species in their own states and develop a multimedia exhibit meant to educate the public about the health of their local forests.

Albert Watson's eye rarely rests on one thing for long. For over four decades, he has refused to settle in one camp, allowing the breadth of his vision and the variety of his work to take in the worlds of fashion, portraiture and reportage. Likewise his sittings have ranged from supermodels to prisoners, from athletes to aristocrats. Add to the list advertising campaigns for clients like Prada, Estée Lauder, Revlon and Gap and it's not hard to see why he is considered such an elastic virtuoso. The graphic intensity and epic intention of Watson's images are now on display in "UFO: Unified Fashion Objectives" (Abrams; $135), a retrospective book of what he considers his best work. (Images from "UFO" are also on show at Hasted Hunt Kraeutler, 537 W. 24th Street, from October 21.) While some of his subject matter has been relegated to the cultural periphery, Watson's ability to dazzle the eye and transcend the immediacy of his art form endure.
Kenny Leon, who directed the Broadway revivals of "Fences" and "A Raisin in the Sun," will direct his first feature film, "Cotton," early next year, Variety reported.

Daniel Larison and Jamelle Bouie both have sharp posts analyzing the much-discussed Pew finding that atheists and agnostics (and Mormons and Jews) tend to score higher on tests of religious literacy than many self-described Catholics, evangelicals, and mainline Protestants. The only thing I'd add to their analysis is this: I wonder how the data would have looked if Pew had created a generic "nonbeliever" category and compared that group to Protestants and Catholics. Instead, they created two categories: Self-described atheists/agnostics, and people who described their religion as "nothing in particular." The first group was 3 percent of the sample; the second group was a much larger 12 percent. And while the atheist/agnostics had the highest religious literacy, the larger "nothing in particular" camp was among the least literate overall.

People who live in glass houses should employ really good window washers. This is one of many impressions left by ''Points on a Line,'' a film by the artist Sarah Morris that explores the intersecting histories (and upkeep requirements) of Mies van der Rohe's Farnsworth House and Philip Johnson's Glass House. Commissioned for the National Trust for Historic Preservation's ''Modern Views'' project, the film gets much of its star power from the architecture, but Morris gives the life in and around it a part, too. Up for best supporting role: the duck that ''guards'' the entrance to van der Rohe's Lake Shore Drive towers in Chicago. ''The custodians of these buildings are pretty territorial,'' Morris said. Go to sothebys.com/modernviews.

The Austrian crystal maker Swarovski has built up a Gibraltar-size reputation for matchmaking the unexpected with the dazzling in fashion and design. What started with a radical rethink of the chandelier - Tord Boontje's crystal dew-crusted branch, Ron Arad's interactive L.E.D. spiral - has now expanded to include jewelry by superstars like Karl Lagerfeld and Zaha Hadid. This fall comes Kryptonite, Atelier Swarovski's latest jewelry collection, by the New York architecture firm Hariri and Hariri. More than statement pieces, these oversize rocks are a manifesto against timid ornamentation. ''We weren't interested in making fake diamonds,'' said Gisue Hariri, who, with her sister Mojgan, took a geological approach. Their inspiration was the firm's design for a condominium carved out of a mountain in Salzburg, Austria. ''We wanted to create jewelry with an added dimension.'' In fact, the sisters worked with Swarovksi to invent a boldly asymmetrical shape. Made in Italy, the collection ($380 to $870) includes a necklace, choker, cuff, ring and belt, each piece cradled in planed silver for a sumptuously futuristic look.

These days there seem to be two types of thinkers in the world of central banking. On one side there are serious people - people who believe that we should raise interest rates in the face of high unemployment and falling inflation, because, well, that's what serious people do. On the other side there are unserious people, who believe that central banks should fight deflation as well as inflation, and try to prevent the current slump from turning into a quasi-permanent state of depression. How ridiculous can you get?

The project that put the Bouroullec brothers, Ronan and Erwan, on the map in 1997 was their ''Disintegrated Kitchen.'' Now the design duo from Brittany aims to stock your kitchen with a new series of stoneware, glass and stainless steel dinnerware and serving pieces designed for the Italian manufacturer Alessi. The Ovale collection plays with multiple variations on a slightly asymmetrical, rectangular silhouette with rounded corners. This sounds simple enough, but the Bouroullecs' delicate balance between whimsy and refinement will make even the biggest design snob smile. The reasonably priced collection (from $14 for the smallest mocha cup to $275 for the elegant stainless steel ice bucket) will be in stores just in time for the holidays - hint, hint.

"Good morning. We're going consider another in a series of recent cases in which the Supreme Court appears to have undermined Congressional efforts to protect hard-working Americans from powerful interests. In Skilling v. United States the court sided with an Enron executive who had been convicted of fraud and gutted a statute vital to combatting public corruption, corporate fraud and self-dealing. In 1953, the architect Benjamin Thompson (1918-2002) opened a store called Design Research on Brattle Street in Cambridge, Mass. Thompson, a former partner of the Modernist master Walter Gropius, wanted a place where people could buy everything they needed for contemporary living. He made Marimekko dresses and Iittala glasses must-haves, eventually opening stores in New York and San Francisco and designing a striking new glass-and-concrete home for the Cambridge store that opened in 1969. ''The architect's place on this planet,'' he said, ''is to create that special environment where life can be lived to its fullest.'' D/R, as it was known, closed in 1978, but many people, including me, never got over it.

Are fragile knees inherited? That intriguing question motivated a new study published earlier this month in The British Journal of Sports Medicine, during which researchers looked at one family's propensity for shredding anterior cruciate ligaments during sports. The report was part of a much larger, ongoing study of risk factors for A.C.L. injury, led by researchers affiliated with the Cincinnati Children's Hospital and Ohio State University, which involves thousands of young athletes. For this pocket version of the larger experiment, the scientists singled out a set of fraternal twin girls who already had been videotaped in the laboratory while wearing reflective markers. The angles of their knees during landing and cutting maneuvers had been analyzed, and the knees themselves measured. At the time of the taping, both girls' knees were healthy. But within a year, each had suffered a catastrophic A.C.L. tear during separate volleyball and basketball games, as had an older sister, who wasn't part of the original study.

An article on Sunday about a water-rights dispute among African nations that share the Nile River misspelled, in some editions, the name of the town in the dateline. As an accompanying map correctly showed, it is Batamda, Egypt, not Batanda. And the map misidentified, in some editions, the lake bordering Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda that is the Nile's main reservoir. It is Lake Victoria, not Lake Tanganyika.

In another tribute to composer Stephen Sondheim in the year of his 80th birthday, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced on Tuesday that it would begin awarding $10,000 grants annually to ''inspirational teachers'' in the arts and a variety of the other fields. The Kennedy Center said in a statement that the grants would be financed from a donation by Freddie Gershon, chairman of the theatrical licensing agency Music Theater International, and his wife, Myrna. The size of the donation was not disclosed, but the Kennedy Center said it was enough to make a handful of grants each year.

CZAJKOWSKA--Theresa A.,died on September 26, 2010. She was a graduate of Hunter College and received her MA in American Literature from New York University. Theresa was a managing editor of various publishing houses; among them Harcourt Brace, MacMillan, Exposition Press, Random House, Scribner's, the University of South Carolina Press, Johns Hopkins University Press and Simon & Schuster, from which she retired in 1996. She is survived by her sister Elizabeth, three nieces, Ursula Ozaki, Delphine Blake and Claudine Bednarek, a nephew, John T. Bestecki and two great-nephews Yukio Ozaki and Daniel Bednarek. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Thursday, September 30, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, October 1 at St. Stanislaus R.C. Church, 101 East 7th St. at 10am. Interment will take place at Calvary Cemetery in the family plot.

It's not uncommon to see super-powered champions switch allegiances from one side to the other in the pages of their comic-book adventures, and so it goes for the people who create and publish their stories. On Monday, DC Comics, the longtime home of heroes like Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman, said that it had named as its new editor in chief Robert Harras, a veteran editor there who had also spent five years as the editor in chief of rival Marvel Comics, the publisher of Spider-Man, the Hulk and Iron Man. DC, a unit of Warner Brothers Entertainment and Time Warner, said in a statement that Mr. Harras will oversee editorial for its comics as well as MAD Magazine and its Vertigo imprint, and will work from the company's New York offices. (Last week DC announced it would move its operations that focus on feature films, television, video games and other media to California from New York.)

BROWN--G. Garvin, III. The entire Avon Old Farms School community mourns the passing of our esteemed alumnus, and former Director, G. Garvin Brown III. A member of the Class of 1962, Garvin Brown represented the highest ideals of Avon Old Farms School to generations of students, alumni, faculty, staff, and families. Garvin served as an active member of Avon's Board of Directors from 1984 through 1999, and thereafter as an honorary member until his death. He provided extraordinary vision, leadership, and support for every aspect of the school. Garvin's sons, Campbell Brown, '86 and G. Garvin Brown IV, '87 have also served Avon Old Farms as members of our Board of Directors. Garvin's generosity made possible our newest dormitory, our student center, and our auditorium, all of which bear his family's name. His energy and positive spirit inspired everyone on campus, and Garvin's remarkable contributions and deep passion for his school have helped position Avon Old Farms, as one of America's great secondary schools. We join in extending heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Dean C. Graham '84, Chairman Kenneth H. LaRocque, Headmaster

FINGER--Minita Angie, passed away on September 23, 2010 at St. Luke's Hospital in New York City at the age of 77. "Min" as she was known to her friends was born September 7, 1933 in Galveston, Texas (BOI). She began her faith journey at Grace Episcopal Church in Galveston, TX, and Graduated from Ball High School in 1950 before starting an incredible journey of service to her fellow man. Whether it was missionary work in Bolahun, Liberia (Africa), serving as a nurse in New York City, serving as director of nursing at Amsterdam House, serving as the Administrative Head Nurse at Columbia University Health Service, working in the Substance Abuse Program at St Luke's Hospital, setting up an AIDS Clinic at St. Luke's Hospital, or serving as reader, leader, acolyte or subdeacon at The Cathedral Church of Saint John Divine, she exemplified what it means to live in relationship with her Lord in work and deed. Minita is predeceased by: Mother, Herminia P. Carmona, father, Fred Lamont Finger Jr., sister, Elizabeth Jane Finger, brother James P. Finger Sr. and nephew, Brandon Lee Finger. She is survived by: Brother, Fred Lamont Finger III, nephews, Perry Lamont Finger, James Perry Finger, Jr., Jason Paul Finger, Brian Lamont Finger, Matthew Lamont Finger, nieces, Judith Lynn Hernandez, Janice Marie Spiers, Christine Renee Schroeder, Victoria Lyn Finger. Whether enjoying food and spirits with her many friends, having a spirited conversation with her nieces and nephews, or showering her grandnieces and grandnephews with endless hugs and kisses, she was a source of immeasurable joy who truly left everyone she touched with the knowledge they were loved and had been blessed with her presence. She will be truly missed. The celebration of Minita's life will be held at the High Alter of The Cathedral Church of Saint John Divine at 1047 Amsterdam Avenue on Thursday, September 30 at 3:30pm.
