It is a rare and exhilarating experience for a photographer to capture a moment in history that then becomes imprinted on the national consciousness. The euphoric V-J Day kiss between sailor and nurse in Times Square. An astronaut's ticker-tape parade. Babe Ruth making a final appearance at Yankee Stadium. These are images that have inspired me and guided me through a 48-year career in photography. But less monumental scenes have shaped my eye, too: a group of stray cats huddled over a New York manhole on a bitter winter day; a sea of barely clad humanity crowded onto Coney Island; Eleanor Roosevelt alone, carrying a suitcase.

In his sharpest critique yet of the nation's highest-rated cable news channel, President Obama said in an interview with Rolling Stone magazine that Fox News promoted a point of view that was ''destructive'' to the growth of the United States. Asked about Mr. Obama's comments, a Fox News representative said the network did not intend to respond. Time will tell whether its individual hosts decide to weigh in.

Bon Jovi, the Beastie Boys, Neil Diamond, Alice Cooper, Donovan, Tom Waits and LL Cool J are among the 15 artists nominated for induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2011. Also on the list: Chic, Dr. John, J. Geils Band, Darlene Love, Laura Nyro, Donna Summer, Joe Tex and Chuck Willis. These are the first nominations for Bon Jovi, Donovan, Alice Cooper, Dr. John and Mr. Diamond; some of the others, including Chic, Donna Summer and Darlene Love, have been nominated numerous times but never made the final cut. (There's hope for them, though: this year the Stooges finally made it in after having been nominated seven times.)

VICINANZA--Ralph, of Old Brookville, NY passed away suddenly on Saturday, September 25, 2010. Beloved son of Louise Manganiello of Yonkers, NY. Also survived by his loving sister and brother-in-law Louise and Michael Billie, niece Cynthia Billie Frank, nephew Jonathan Billie, great-niece Madison Frank, longtime companion Terrance Rooney and many aunts, uncles and close friends. A man who was full of life and possessed an infectious laugh, Ralph could light up a room. From a young age he had a passion for books and literature, sparking his love of history and travel. He owns and operates the successful literary agency Ralph Vicinanza, LTD. His family and friends had the greatest respect for this accomplished man. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7 to 9pm Wednesday and 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Ann's Church, Yonkers on Friday, October 1 at 10:30am.

An article on Tuesday about a hearing in military court in Washington State related to allegations that members of a United States Army unit killed three Afghan civilians misstated, in some editions, the rank of one of the soldiers, Jeremy N. Morlock. He is a specialist, not a corporal.

The publisher Farrar, Straus & Giroux announced on Tuesday that it had acquired the world rights of Larry Kramer's 4,000-page manuscript ''The American People'' and planned to published an edited version of the work in two volumes, with the first scheduled for the spring of 2012. In an interview on Tuesday, Mr. Kramer, below, whose plays include ''The Normal Heart'' and the Pulitzer Prize-finalist ''The Destiny of Me,'' said the book was a national history of homosexuality and AIDS, stretching back to precolonial times and dealing with the sexuality of many famous Americans, including George Washington and Abraham Lincoln. Mr. Kramer, the co-founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis and the protest group Act Up, said he began writing the book in 1980 out of frustration with Ronald Reagan's references to ''the American people,'' a phrase that he believed was not intended to include gay citizens like him. The publishing house is calling the book ''a major work of American fiction,'' which Mr. Kramer said he had no problem with. ''I don't want to be forced to have to defend everything,'' he said.
With the National Football League season in full swing, the water cooler chatter on Wall Street revolves around quarterback ratings as much as it does credit ratings.

An article on Tuesday about a poll in which Americans fared poorly in answering questions about religion misspelled the name of a beatified Roman Catholic nun and Nobel Peace Prize winner. She was Mother Teresa, not Theresa.
A music review on Monday about a concert by Roy Haynes misidentified a song he performed. It was ''Segment,'' by Charlie Parker -- not ''Bouncing with Bud,'' by Bud Powell.

Qatar will open a new museum on Dec. 30 devoted to modern Arab art in its capital, Doha. Called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art, it will house a collection of more than 6,000 works, spanning the 1840s to the present and representing major artistic trends. Its opening exhibition, ''Sajjil: A Century of Modern Art,'' will feature work by more than 100 artists. For now, Mathaf (which means ''museum'' in Arabic) will be located in a former school building, redesigned for the museum by the French architect Jean-Francois Bodin. Plans for a permanent home will be announced later. The museum is being established by the Qatar Museums Authority, a government department, and the Qatar Foundation , a government-sponsored entity. In 2008, the authority, run by the daughter of Qatar's emir, opened the Museum of Islamic Art in a building designed by I.M. Pei. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

She is much loved and missed by her husband of 60 years, Dr. Thomas Roberts; her children, Dirk, Matt, Ann, and Dylan; her sister Leta; and nine beloved grandchildren. Services will be private.

In theory, Crozes-Hermitage offers the potential to be a reliable go-to with an array of foods. A reasonable ticket price and equal measures of fruit, herbs and earth on the palate could carry the day, except for one detail. The best of the wines also exhibit a sense of place, a terroir that suggests you have left Lyon behind as you travel south along the Rhone, and start to think olives, rosemary, fennel and figs. I fastened on black-olive tapenade to season a dozen quail, which baked on toasted fregola, the Sardinian pasta, first cooked like a risotto and seasoned with olives, rosemary and a smidgen of tomato.

MY life in New York is not exactly a whirlwind, but it's busy enough, and if you discount breakfast, I probably eat 90 percent of my meals with someone else. So, when I went up to my place on Cape Cod, alone, for an extended end-of-summer visit, I realized that I would be cooking for myself for an entire week, with the exception of a couple of dinner invitations. I hadn't done that in at least 10 years, and possibly ever, and I wanted to see if it would change the meals I ate. FRIDAY I did not shop on the way up, figuring I could get that done on Saturday morning. Besides, there's nothing I like more than dinner from the pantry. There were cooked white beans in the freezer, cherry tomatoes that I'd snacked on during the drive, onions and garlic in the fridge, and, of course, pasta in my little cupboard. I cooked a chopped onion in olive oil with the tomatoes, adding most of the garlic. I wished I'd had an herb. When the tomatoes softened, the cooked beans went in, along with the remaining garlic. I finished the pasta with more olive oil, and found it quite satisfying. For some reason -- probably because I had not shopped first, and probably also because my lunch had been so meager -- I had only a little left over. I had an apple for dessert.

Green Bay Coach Mike McCarthy cut his team's chances of winning to 3 percent from 10 percent by not surrendering a touchdown to Chicago at the first opportunity late in Monday night's game. That's based on an analysis of N.F.L data of similar situations. The score was 17-17 with 1 minute 44 seconds left, and the Bears had a first-and-goal from the 9. Robbie Gould wound up kicking a game-winning 19-yard field goal with four seconds left.

ROTH--David. The Officers, Trustees, and Staff of Jewish Child Care Association express their profound sorrow at the loss of David Roth, an esteemed and honored former Executive Director of JCCA. But as proxy fights show some signs of waning and competitors emerge, IVS is facing a struggle of its own: how to maintain and expand its business.

An article on Sept. 18 about the potential effect on small businesses of the Obama administration's proposals for extending the 2001 and 2003 tax cuts described imprecisely the businesses that would continue to enjoy lower taxes. Companies with no employees would derive 90 percent of the tax benefits if the cuts were extended. Most, but not all, of those businesses are also sole proprietorships, but being a sole proprietorship does not necessarily mean the company has no employees.

8 P.M. (HBO2) WAR DON DON (2010) In the Krio language of Sierra Leone, ''War Don Don'' is the name of the civil war that raged from 1991 to 2001, during which the Revolutionary United Front fought to overthrow the ruling government. In 2003 the United Nations and the government of Sierra Leone spent more than $200 million to set up a Special Court -- the world's first international war crimes ''hybrid tribunal'' -- in an effort to seek justice and reconciliation. This documentary from Rebecca Richman Cohen, a Harvard Law School graduate who interned for a defense team at the court, follows the war crimes trial of Issa Hassan Sesay, above left, the highest-ranking survivor of the rebel group. It also explores both the limits of international justice and the contradictions in a man who dealt in blood diamonds, commanded child soldiers and oversaw mass atrocities against civilians -- but who is also credited by some with single-handedly ending the war. In 2009 Mr. Sesay was convicted of 16 of 18 charges and sentenced to 52 years in prison. The movie ''is less an investigation of guilt for war crimes than a contemplation of the viability of international courts,'' Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. ''The film suggests that the hundreds of millions of American and British funds spent to build the court might better have been used to revive Sierra Leone's shattered economy.'' 8 P.M. (CW) AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL The photographer Matthew Rolston offers his professional opinion following photo shoots on a roller coaster and under water.

Eager to post an impressive fund-raising total for September, Senator John Cornyn of Texas, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, issued an e-mail plea on Tuesday for last-minute contributions ''to help our Republican candidates like Joe Miller in Alaska, Sharron Angle in Nevada, Marco Rubio in Florida and Christine O'Donnell in Delaware.'' The twist? Not one of those four contenders was initially the favorite of the Republican establishment in Washington, where party leaders like Mr. Cornyn originally had other ideas about who the Republican Senate candidates should be. Now insurgents like Mr. Miller and Ms. O'Donnell are featured by the Senate campaign committee, in a telling example of the volatility of the election cycle.

On the eve of a vote by shareholders of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group on a takeover by Hertz Global Holdings, the Avis Budget Group said on Wednesday that it would offer the one thing Dollar Thrifty had said was lacking in its rival bid: a breakup fee. Avis said that if Dollar Thrifty shareholders rejected Hertz's $1.46 billion offer on Thursday, Avis would make an exchange offer for the company - one that includes a $20 million breakup fee, which it had previously declined to offer.

Buddy Collette, a jazz saxophonist, flutist, clarinetist and bandleader who blended his usually soothing, often pungent sounds with those of many jazz greats and who was a leader in the struggle to break racial barriers in the music industry, died on Sept. 19 in Los Angeles. He was 89. The cause was a respiratory ailment, his daughter Cheryl Collette-White told The Los Angeles Times.

HILL--Priscilla Baker, 89 a long-time resident of Short Hills, NJ and later of Fellowship Village in Basking Ridge, NJ, died peacefully on Saturday, September 25, 2010, after a brief illness. Pril, as most knew her, attended the Chapin School and graduated from Miss Porters School in 1939. She was an avid sportswoman and long-time member of the Short Hills Club, Baltusrol and Somerset Hills Country Club. She was predeceased by her husband of 69 years Serge Jerome Hill. She is survived by her sister Barbara Baker McPherson of Vero Beach, FL, four children, Serge Jerome Hill, Jr. of Somerville, NJ , Robert Foote Hill of New York City, Sally Hill Lloyd of New York City, Priscilla Hill Alexandre of Bernardsville, NJ and seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. "She is one of a kind. I don't believe that in her very long life there was one person who knew her that was not genuinely fond of her. We should all be so blessed." A true summation of a remarkable woman who will be greatly missed. A Memorial Service will be held Tuesday, October 12, 2010 at Christ Church, 66 Highland Ave., Short Hills, NJ at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the The Lustgarten Foundation, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY 11714 for pancreatic research.

The relationship between mentor and pupil is at the core of "Jerry Thompson & Walker Evans: Pictures of People," a new exhibition at the Gallery at Hermès opening on Friday. Thompson met and befriended the legendary Evans in 1971 while he was a student at Yale. Evans's Depression-era street portraits profoundly influenced Thompson's photographs of New York denizens from the 1970s and '80s. The latter are not merely an homage to his teacher but a continuation of the mystery and forwardness of the direct gaze in portraiture. Thoughtfully curated by Cory Jacobs, the exhibition explores both artists' frank visual styles, the ongoing connection between subject and viewer, and the inspiration of one artist on another.

Reading the near-universal (and richly-merited) praise for David Fincher's "The Social Network," it occurred to me that Fincher is gradually building a plausible claim to being the best filmmaker of his generation. Obviously defining "his generation" is a somewhat tricky thing - but suppose we do it roughly by decade, and compare his body of work to other filmmakers who came into their own between 1990 and 2005. (This ends up excluding the Coen brothers and Steven Soderbergh, who would otherwise provide some of his stiffest competition, as well as some recent bloomers like Jason Reitman.) Using that time frame, Fincher is up against Quentin Tarantino, Paul Thomas Anderson, Peter Jackson, Christopher Nolan, Wes Anderson, Sofia Coppola, Alexander Payne, Spike Jonze, Danny Boyle, Ang Lee, and no doubt some others I'm forgetting. Many of the directors on that list have made individual movies that might be better than a given Fincher film. But I'm not sure any of them can match the sustained excellence of his entire body of work.

It's been a good year or so for Gio Ponti. Last fall, Rizzoli reprinted a lavish monograph devoted to the staggeringly prolific Italian designer, critic and bon vivant who, before his death at 87 in 1979, founded Domus magazine, created sets for La Scala, brought a touch of playful luxury to the interiors of the Andrea Doria and planted works in every medium in just about every corner of the world. Meanwhile, auction prices for vintage Ponti pieces have been on a winning streak, not unlike the thoroughbred racehorse named after him. Now ''The Expression of Gio Ponti,'' curated by Germano Celant, gives the designer his biggest local showcase since the days of the old Alitalia ticket offices he created at 666 Fifth Avenue. The whopping retrospective, which opens in early 2011 and is the first exhibition at the brand-new Triennale di Milano design museum in Midtown, includes 250 items, from drawings to majolica to furniture, including the iconic Superleggera chair, which Ponti called, with characteristic flair, ''the chair for all times.'' Classical yet modern, rigorous yet whimsical, Ponti's work conforms to no dogma except his own exhortation to ''make something beautiful!''

Nearly a year after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York deemed the recession over, many small-business owners are still waiting for real signs of recovery. A bicycle manufacturer in Queens has adapted to changing markets and come out a leaner, more diversified company. Meanwhile, a butcher in the Bronx recently closed shop because of outstanding debt.

Did we miss the meeting of the Broadway League where it was ruled that the cast of every musical must feature at least one rock or pop star? "American Idiot" has Billie Joe Armstrong, "Fela!" has Patti LaBelle and now "Rock of Ages" has Dee Snider. On Thursday, press representatives for "Rock of Ages" said Mr. Snider, the Twisted Sister frontman, will join the musical for an 11-week run beginning Oct. 11. Mr. Snider, who is also a star of the A&E reality show "Growing Up Twisted," will play the role of the nightclub owner Dennis, and will host a weekly talkback series called "Rock Senate Hearings" that will begin on Oct. 19. "Rock of Ages," a jukebox musical built around headbanging hits of the 1980s (including the Twisted Sister songs "I Wanna Rock" and "We're Not Gonna Take It"), recently lost its Tony Award-nominated star, Constantine Maroulis, to the show's national tour. In recent weeks, the musical, which is performed at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, has played to about 75 percent capacity and has grossed under $500,000 a week.

When you've built a career working with Tim Burton, as Danny Elfman has, it's inevitable that you end up with entire crypts full of buried material. But now an (un)healthy portion of the catalog created by Mr. Elfman, the musician and composer who has written the scores for nearly all of Mr. Burton's films, including "Beetlejuice," "Batman" and "Edward Scissorhands" - and provided the singing voice for Jack Skellington of "The Nightmare Before Christmas" - is about to be unearthed. On Thursday, Warner Brothers Records said it would release a boxed set commemorating the 25 years that these two artists have worked together, dating back to 1985, when Mr. Burton recruited Mr. Elfman from the band Oingo Boingo to create the score for "Pee-wee's Big Adventure." The "Danny Elfman & Tim Burton 25th Anniversary Music Box," which is planned for a December release, will contain 18 hours of music on 16 CDs, including seven hours of previously unreleased material, a hardcover book with a foreword by Johnny Depp and a DVD conversation between Mr. Elfman and Mr. Burton.

For Dieter Roth, life and art were part of the same messy process. Adam Lewis's new book, ''Billy Baldwin: The Great American Decorator'' (Rizzoli), surveys the life and career of the man whose pared-down versions of the slipper chair and brass bookshelves became famous, and whose work continues to influence designers long after his death in 1983. Baldwin, a charming, well-born native of Baltimore who was the protégé of Ruby Ross Wood (see Lewis's previous book, ''The Great Lady Decorators''), developed a bold, modern style that confidently mixed patterns and periods; he became the go-to decorator for people like Babe Paley, Cole Porter and Diana Vreeland, whose legendary ''garden in hell'' red living room he designed. Baldwin was never afraid of color and is said to have pioneered the use of aubergine walls, in a Maryland house (above) in the 1940s. The book, which has an affectionate foreword by Albert Hadley, Baldwin's former student, is a welcome addition to the two (out-of-print and increasingly expensive) volumes on the decorator's work, ''Billy Baldwin Decorates'' and ''Billy Baldwin Remembers.''

The Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life asked more than 3,400 Americans 32 questions about the Bible, Christianity and other world religions, religious history and geography. On average, people answered half the questions incorrectly, and many flubbed even questions about their own faith. Atheists, agnostics, Jews and Mormons seemed to know the most. Could you pass this test? Answer some of the same questions here, then tell us how you did. How much do you think you know about religion in general, and your own faith in particular?

BEIJING -- The Chinese authorities have released three Japanese citizens accused of videotaping at a military installation in northern China, the state news media reported Thursday. Although one of the men remains in custody, the releases are likely to be construed as a gesture by China to defuse tensions that have been mounting since Sept. 8, when a collision between a Chinese fishing trawler and Japanese coast guard vessels in disputed waters prompted an ugly diplomatic row.

GOLOMB--Dorris Gaines, died clear-minded, peacefully on September 22, 2010, her adoring husband Leon by her side. Staunch supporter of her beloved Fort Greene's art, business, and architecture. Ranking member of the Fort Greene Association, Historic Districts Council, CB2. Herbert Scott-Gibson Lifetime Achievement Award. A Southern belle, lavender hat engaging smile, loving "fun fun fun," Dorris' Grace will always be felt. In lieu of memorial donations can be sent to the Fort Greene Association.

BROWN--G. Garvin, III. The entire Avon Old Farms School community mourns the passing of our esteemed alumnus, and former Director, G. Garvin Brown III. A member of the Class of 1962, Garvin Brown represented the highest ideals of Avon Old Farms School to generations of students, alumni, faculty, staff, and families. Garvin served as an active member of Avon's Board of Directors from 1984 through 1999, and thereafter as an honorary member until his death. He provided extraordinary vision, leadership, and support for every aspect of the school. Garvin's sons, Campbell Brown, '86 and G. Garvin Brown IV, '87 have also served Avon Old Farms as members of our Board of Directors. Garvin's generosity made possible our newest dormitory, our student center, and our auditorium, all of which bear his family's name. His energy and positive spirit inspired everyone on campus, and Garvin's remarkable contributions and deep passion for his school have helped position Avon Old Farms, as one of America's great secondary schools. We join in extending heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Dean C. Graham '84, Chairman Kenneth H. LaRocque, Headmaster

WASHINGTON -- Congress on Thursday adopted a stopgap spending measure to finance the government through Dec. 3 as lawmakers dashed for an earlier-than-expected exodus from Washington and headed home to focus on the midterm elections. ''We may not agree on much, but I think with rare exception all 100 senators want to get out of here and back to their states,'' the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Wednesday afternoon. And by 8:30 p.m., most of them were on their way. A half-dozen senators left before the final vote on a motion to adjourn.

For years, Goldman Sachs seemed to stay aloof when its profits, pay and practices came under public criticism. Now, after a stretch of time when the limelight has been particularly harsh, the company has started its first national advertising campaign aimed not at potential clients, but at ordinary people.

The New York City Opera and the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture have announced a third season of collaboration in 2011, with two programs to celebrate the African-American experience in the world of opera. City Opera will showcase the career of the mezzo-soprano Betty Allen with film and sound clips and live musical selections in A Tribute to Betty Allen on Feb. 28. Ms. Allen, who died last year, was African-American and helped break down racial barriers in opera. She made her City Opera debut as Queenie in ''Show Boat'' in 1954 and from 1973 to 1975, her roles at City Opera included Mistress Quickly in ''Falstaff,'' Jocasta in ''Oedipus Rex,'' and Eurycleia in ''Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria.'' She sang internationally at major opera companies and concert halls and was executive director and later president of the Harlem School of the Arts.

The fight among powerhouse dealers to represent lucrative artists' estates is never-ending. This week the Pace Gallery said it had won the rights to the estate of Willem de Kooning. The Abstract Expressionist painter, who died in 1997, had previously been handled by the Gagosian Gallery. Officials at Pace said they were planning to hold a major drawing exhibition next year. ''We have had a long relationship with de Kooning,'' Arne Glimcher, the gallery's chairman, said in a telephone interview. ''I knew him personally, and after he died the gallery was the first to sell paintings for the estate.'' Over the years Pace has also organized several exhibitions, including ''de Kooning/Dubuffet: The Women'' in 1991.

The case study we published last week chronicled the advertising woes of Firehouse Subs, a fast-food chain that experienced sinking sales in the depths of the recession. The article, written by Kermit Pattison, recounted how the chain stopped collecting its 2-percent-of-sales fee for local advertising and gave the money back to franchisees in the hope that they would do their own marketing. But the local effort fizzled and sales continued to drop, prompting Firehouse to change course and hire a new ad agency to develop a series of radio spots.

Information may be the currency of democracy, but revealing as little of it as possible appears to be corporate America's way. Watching Internet video on your living room TV shouldn't be hard. The stuff already plays on your laptop, so why not just connect your laptop to your TV? A new $99 gadget called Veebeam, introduced a few days ago, promises to make that easy to do. I haven't had a chance to test Veebeam personally, but the product comes with a pedigree. The VP of marketing, Patrick Cosson, has a track record of hot consumer gadgets, first with the Squeezebox music player and then with the Vudu TV console that plays movies on demand. Veebeam is a video player designed for simplicity rather than piling on the features. The idea is: If it plays on your PC, it plays on your TV.

An article on Wednesday about a possible plea deal by Alan G. Hevesi, the former state comptroller, misstated the middle initial for Steven Rattner, the financier whose fund paid $12 million to settle allegations that it paid kickbacks to win pension fund business from Mr. Hevesi. The financier is Steven L. Rattner, not Steven J.

In a study released on Wednesday, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation said that the number of gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender characters on television had reached a new high in the new season. On the broadcast networks, there are 23 gay characters this season, representing 3.9 percent of all series regulars on scripted shows, the group said, up from 3 percent last year. The group, which has tabulated the number of gay characters for 15 years, said it was pleased by the progress but pointed to several areas where it felt the networks could improve. On scripted network television this season, it found, there are no gay characters who are black and no transgender characters.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about the mixed legacy of Yuri M. Luzhkov, who was fired as the mayor of Moscow on Tuesday by President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia, misidentified the official shown. He is Vladimir Resin, the deputy mayor, who replaced Mr. Luzhkov -- not Mr. Luzhkov himself.
People warn me not to sell land to the Chinese. But I run a business. If somebody's buying, I'm selling. KIYOMI KAWAKAMI, a Japanese developer. [B1]

Brutal proxy fights that pit shareholders against executives are the lifeblood of IVS Associates, a private firm with a headlock on the high-stakes business of tallying shareholder votes in corporate battles. But as proxy fights show some signs of waning and competitors emerge, IVS is facing a struggle of its own: how to maintain and expand its business.

NEWPORT, Wales - Seve Ballesteros did not feel well enough to make the journey here from Spain this week, so the European Ryder Cup captain, Colin Montgomerie, placed a call to Ballesteros's home in Santander to let his team - particularly the six rookies - hear for themselves the passion Ballesteros retains for the event. ''The whole team spoke to Seve for about 10 minutes,'' Montgomerie said. ''And that was very motivational, very passionate, and also very sad to hear him - to hear the way he is. But still, the passion is very, very strong within Seve for us as a team, and he just wishes that he could be here.''

In the world of technology start-ups, young founders are nothing new. But 20-year-old Jessica Mah, chief executive and co-founder of inDinero in Mountain View, Calif., and a recent graduate of both the University of California, Berkeley, and Y Combinator's entrepreneurship program, isn't building the next social media sensation or gaming venture. Instead, she has set her sights on creating a simple, cloud-based software solution that helps small-business owners track their finances without any data entry (it pulls the information from your business's financial accounts). This month, the five-employee company, which debuted in July and has more than 5,000 mostly nonpaying users, secured $1 million in investment backing. I talked with Ms. Mah about her decision to target small businesses, how she plans to win paying customers, and the lessons that even a grizzled owner can learn from a millennial. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

6:46 p.m. | Updated The Senate race in Louisiana has long been a test of whether the state's voters are more turned off by the Obama administration or by the serious sins of its junior senator, David Vitter. The anti-Obama sentiment seems to have the upper hand in all the polls, but Representative Charlie Melancon, Mr. Vitter's Democratic rival, has been trying to change that by reminding voters of what his campaign terms ''Forgotten Crimes.'' His latest ad, which has not yet run on television, is a two-minute version of a previously released, and longer, ''Forgotten Crimes'' video about Mr. Vitter's involvement in a prostitution scandal. The unusually long ad, which unfolds somewhat like a ''Dateline'' expose, mentions that Mr. Vitter's number showed up in the client list of a Washington escort service, which he acknowledged in 2007.

A film review on Wednesday about ''Nine Nation Animation,'' an anthology of animated short films, misidentified the organization that assembled it. It is The World According to Shorts, an independent nonprofit group, not the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

MARKS--Robert, died September 27, 2010 at home at the age of 90. He was born in Troy, New York to Lulu and Hyman Marks. He was a graduate of the University of Michigan and Harvard Law School. In 1942, after a year at the law school, he enlisted in the navy, as the communications officer on a destroyer in the north Atlantic and the Mediterranean. When the war ended in Europe he was transferred to the Pacific. He had in his possession the maps that were to be used in the invasion of Japan. The destroyer got as far as Pearl Harbor when the war ended. He returned to Harvard, graduating in 1947. In that year he married Paulina Konoff whom he had met in Cambridge. After a year as a lawyer for the Department of Agriculture dealing with maritime law he joined the family businesses, Conmar Products Corp., manufacturers of zippers, and Margon Corporation, manufacturers of moving eyes for dolls, both in Newark, NJ. From the 1970's to the 1990's he was the president of Measurex, a supplier of specialty measures for the food, drug, and chemical industries. The Marks family lived in New York until 1957 when they moved to Short Hills, NJ, and in 2000 moved to South Orange. In addition to his business interests, Mr. Marks was a founding member of the ACLU of New Jersey, now celebrating it's 50th year. He was treasurer for at least two decades. In the mid 1970's he joined the board of Newark Beth Israel Medical Center, becoming chair two years later. He served as chair for 16 years, in two terms. From the very beginning he felt his service on the Beth board was the most exciting and fulfilling association ever. He was the most honorable, fairest, and kindest of men. Mr. Marks is survived by his wife of almost 63 years, Paulina, his three children Lucy, Edward, and Paul, his son-in-law Scott Sprinzen, his grandsons Alexander and Leo Sprinzen and Jacob and Ethan Marks, and his sister Margery Howard. He was predeceased by his brother John. He was a loving uncle to the Bromberg, Hamerman, Marks and Howard families. Contributions in his memory may be made to the ACLU of New Jersey Foundation or to the Newark Beth Israel Medical Center Foundation. The family will be at home to receive friends from 7-9pm on Thursday, September 30th.

Anyone who has seen a significant number of short plays will know that for every pithy one-act that makes smart, exacting use of the form to provide a concentrated theatrical experience, dozens more are diet drama -- insubstantial narrative morsels that leave little aftertaste. Deirdre Kinahan's ''Hue & Cry'' is such a taut distillation of human experience into a real-time, half-hour encounter that you find yourself piecing together the back stories and future of the two characters, both during and after this 40-minute play.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about ''Poisoning the Press'' by Mark Feldstein, using information from the book jacket, misidentified the university where Mr. Feldstein teaches. He is at George Washington University, where he teaches media and public affairs; he is not currently a journalism professor at Maryland. (He will be moving to the University of Maryland next year.)
GLOVER--Harry M. The Gordon H. Smith Corporation mourns the passing of Harry M. Glover, father of our esteemed colleague and friend James Glover. Our condolences go out to Jim and his entire family.

The Discovery Channel declined to comment on Wednesday on a report that three of the stars of ''Deadliest Catch'' had quit the show. Filming for the popular reality show about Bering Sea fishermen was supposed to resume in October. But the boat captains Johnathan Hillstrand, Andy Hillstrand and Sig Hansen all said on Tuesday that they were ''unable to continue participating'' in the show.

LITTMAN--Benjamin Bertram, MD. Born April 5, 1906, died September 29, 2010. Beloved husband of Ruth (Nee Wertheimer), loving brother of Edith Fixman, devoted father of Dr. Emily Littman (Dr. Steven Eisen) and Dr. Jonathan Littman (Lynne Strode), adoring grandfather of Andrew Eisen and Daniel Littman. Services Friday, October 1 at 10am at B'Nai Israel, Southbury, CT. Burial will follow in Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to Littman-Eisen Fund at the Connecticut Community Foundation, 43 Field St. Waterbury, CT. For more information go to www.munsonloveterefuneralhome.com
Offered in the spirit of Jay Goltz's ''Top 10 Reasons for Entrepreneurial Success:'' 1. Ex-partner's ''growth without profits'' strategy.

CZAJKOWSKA--Theresa A.,died on September 26, 2010. She was a graduate of Hunter College and received her MA in American Literature from New York University. Theresa was a managing editor of various publishing houses; among them Harcourt Brace, MacMillan, Exposition Press, Random House, Scribner's, the University of South Carolina Press, Johns Hopkins University Press and Simon & Schuster, from which she retired in 1996. She is survived by her sister Elizabeth, three nieces, Ursula Ozaki, Delphine Blake and Claudine Bednarek, a nephew, John T. Bestecki and two great-nephews Yukio Ozaki and Daniel Bednarek. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Thursday, September 30, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, October 1 at St. Stanislaus R.C. Church, 101 East 7th St. at 10am. Interment will take place at Calvary Cemetery in the family plot.

Challengers in 11 House races have raised more money than incumbents, according to an analysis by the Center for Responsive Politics. Incumbents generally have a financial edge over their rivals. During the 2010 election cycle, for example, incumbents for all House races have raised an average of $897,100 more than their opponents. Shown below are the 11 races to watch in which challengers have outraised the incumbents by an average of $613,200. All but one of those races are in districts that are competitive, and all but two have Democratic incumbents. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

SCHLEIFER--Jack P. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Jack P. Schleifer, and extends sincere sympathy to his daughter, Natalie, his grandchildren and other members of his family. Arthur S. Loring, President George M. Ross, Secretary

LESSER--Dr. Gerald. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Sesame Workshop deeply mourn the loss of Dr. Gerald Lesser, who developed the curriculum for Sesame Street in 1969 during his time at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. Lesser served as chairman of the Children's Television Workshop (now Sesame Workshop), Board of Advisors from 1969 through 1996. He was determined to ensure the show's value as a learning experience, establishing a strong culture of assessment and writing the 1974 book, Children and Television: Lessons from Sesame Street. He was also instrumental in expanding Sesame Street's presence around the world. His dedication and passion for using television as an educational tool will always be remembered.

SCHLEIFER--Jack. Jim, Carolina, and Tasha Sterling voice our love for our gracious stepfather and step-grandfather, Jack Schliefer. The memory of Jack's kindness, generosity and compassion will always remain in our hearts as an enduring blessing.

Runners on a budget don't have to spend hundreds of dollars for a GPS unit or watch that will accurately record their distance and time on a run, provided they have already spent hundreds on an iPhone. A new $1.99 app from Nike uses the iPhone's GPS and mapping capabilities to track a runner's performance.

Panasonic has put some impressive horsepower under the hood of its new Lumix DMC-GH2 Micro Four Thirds camera. And it will need that processing lift to handle an interchangeable 3-D lens-the world's first-designed for Panasonic's MFT cameras. The Lumix DMC-GH2 sports a new three-core engine that enables it to output full 1080 video at 60 frames per second (fps), shoot bursts at 5 fps, and handle 3-D image processing (sorry, no 3-D video). Panasonic says the new Venus FHN engine also enables the camera to focus as fast as 0.1 second. I had a few hands-on minutes with the camera several weeks ago, and its autofocus was impressively fast and accurate, at least in the context conference-room shooting.

SMALL--Robert. Bob died peacefully after a long illness. Survived by his wife of 64 years, Edwina (Popper), daughters Kathy (Phyllis), Ellen (Jim) and son Daniel (Kate). Grandchildren Sara, Alex, Andy, Rebekah and Nathan. There was never a sweeter man. Services Friday October 1, 10am at "Gutterman's" 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI

Let it be known that I am a dedicated mouse person. When we adopted a cat some years ago, we named him Mouse. But that's another story. This tale is about a pair of newly released devices that should allay the fears of the mouse-o-phile community that the venerable pointing gadget is on life support.

Over at AOL Small Business, Rod Kurtz recently asked his board of directors what questions they like to ask prospective employees. The answers were interesting and got me thinking. Here are some of mine: Tell me the most stressful situation you experienced at your last job with a customer.

WILDER--Marvin L. Endlessly devoted to Dorothy, his loving wife of 56 years, his children Holly, Michael and Ellen and his grandchildren Alex and Jack. Born in Brooklyn; a Korean War veteran; graduated from Brooklyn College on the GI Bill. A successful publishing entrepreneur, world traveler and avid sports fan. He enriched our lives through his warmth, humor, intellect, generosity and spirit. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

PENN--Arthur. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The New School and The New School for Drama deeply mourn the passing of Arthur Penn. Arthur's deep commitment to higher education was demonstrated by the time, energy, and ideas that he contributed to ensuring the continued vitality of The New School for over five decades. As a trustee from 1995 to 2002, he served in active roles on several committees and was deeply influential in the founding and development of the MFA program at The New School for Drama. We are in debt to his wise and devoted leadership as he guided the Drama school during a time of transition and for his decade long service on the school's Board of Governors. Arthur was a recipient of the University's Distinguished Service Award and in 2007 he received an Honorary Degree from the university. Arthur was a most valued member of our community and his passion and dedication to our mission will continue to have great impact on future generations of students. We convey our heartfelt condolences to his wife Peggy and his family. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Michael J. Johnston, Chair, Board of Trustees, The New School Robert LuPone, Director, The New School for Drama

SAN FRANCISCO - A day after the first gubernatorial debate, Republican candidate Meg Whitman started a preemptive attack against allegations that she had knowingly employed a Mexican housekeeper who was living illegally in the United States. The housekeeper, Nicandra Diaz-Santillan, made her claims in an interview arranged by celebrity lawyer Gloria Allred, and broadcast on the gossip Web site TMZ.com. Ms. Diaz-Santillan was employed by Ms. Whitman for nine years, until 2009, and said she was terminated after she approached Ms. Whitman, confessed to not having papers, and asked about trying to become a legal resident.

''One year I wasn't feeling my spirit, so I took everything down,'' Helen Dresslin said. ''On Halloween a little boy came by. He said: 'Excuse me, are you the lady that puts up all the lights? Are you sick, not feeling good? What happened to all the decorations?' That really touched me. I decided never to let it happen again.'' And so Ms. Dresslin sat on her porch on Virgil Place in Castle Hill in the Bronx on Wednesday morning, coffee in one hand, cigarette in the other, surrounded by ghosts and skulls and a mechanical clown with a rainbow wig, brainstorming the decorations for her next-door neighbor's house, getting ready to hit the home stretch on her own, and fully inhabiting the role of Halloween Lady, though the calendar still says September.

THIS summer, executives from the New York-based private equity firm SK Capital traveled to Houston to celebrate the first anniversary of their acquisition of a nylon manufacturing business. Soon they will have a bigger reason to uncork the Champagne.

Chefs from 12 nations had been expected at a Chinese cooking competition that is to begin on Thursday in Duffy Square in Manhattan. But the Chinese-language television network that is sponsoring the contest now says that only 11 nations will be represented -- including Britain, France and Germany -- because one country did not permit its chefs to leave for New York. That country was China.

BOGDONOFF--Harold Jay. September 29, 2010. Beloved father of Lisa Feit and Lori Finkelstein, sons-in-law Sheldon Feit and Paul Finkelstein. Adored grandfather to Stephanie, fiance' Tzvi, Austin, Avery, and Katy, Joel and Peri. Wonderful husband to late Shirley Laszlo. His career had been in advertising and with New House and Hearst newspaper organization. A survivor of cancer and open heart surgery, he valued the wonderful adventure of each new day. He loved his family, his friends, neighbors and community more then he ever expressed. Funeral services Sunday, October 3, at 10am at I. J. Morris in Hempstead , NY.

While there have been a number of notable technology deals recently, the sector is hardly experiencing a boom in mergers and acquisitions. The total value of technology deals in the third quarter fell 26 percent from second quarter. Still, the M.&A. market was stronger than in the depressed third quarter of 2009, when the economy was emerging from one of the worst recessions on record.

So "The Hobbit" will be in 3-D. That is a measure of how much the movie world has changed in the last year or so. In the dimly remembered recesses of, oh, 2009, people involved with the two-movie version of the J. R. R. Tolkien book, then to be directed by Guillermo del Toro, insisted that 2-D screen technology was just right for a pair of movies that were viewed as being a little more intimate than their sweeping precursors in the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy. Then came "Avatar," "Alice in Wonderland," and even the much-maligned "Clash of the Titans" - one film after another proving that viewers would pay a premium for 3-D, as long as the underlying movie wasn't an utter bust.
A group of Texas pharmacies has filed a lawsuit against CVS Caremark, the nation's largest pharmacy health care provider, saying it violates racketeering and privacy laws.

The Times's Media Decoder blog reports that Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer are on the verge of an agreement that would allow the director Peter Jackson to begin shooting a two-part version of J. R. R. Tolkien's "The Hobbit" early next year. The studios have wrestled with their dual ownership of the project over the last year but a financial deal should be in place over the next several days, according to several people who have been involved in the bargaining. Still pending: a labor dispute that has led Mr. Jackson and the studios to say publicly that they would consider moving the films out of New Zealand. People involved with the films said Friday that they expected a resolution to the union dispute imminently. Read more on Media Decoder...

This Saturday was circled on the schedule by many college football fans at the beginning of the season, with Alabama against Florida and Oklahoma versus Texas looming as two of the year's marquee games. But a funny thing happened in September. A few things, actually. Florida, while undefeated, has looked a little sluggish in the first few weeks of the post-Tim Tebow era; Texas appeared lethargic in losing to a seemingly unimposing U.C.L.A. team in Austin last week; and Stanford has developed into a top-10 team behind an explosive offense led by quarterback Andrew Luck. All that means that Stanford at Oregon has become perhaps the most intriguing game of the weekend, with the Cardinal traveling to the always raucous atmosphere of Autzen Stadium to try to prove that they belong in the top tier of the Pac-10. As for Florida, every team in college football wishes they could struggle as well as the Gators. Still, Alabama has been No. 1 since the season's start and the return of Mark Ingram two weeks ago has made a terrific running game that much more formidable. These teams have been the class of the Southeastern Conference for several years and there is always a chance for an epic game when they play each other.

PARIS -- It's not often an automaker tries to distance itself from its own vehicle. In 1992 Olivier Zahm printed the first issue of Purple Prose, a Parisian literary art zine that over the years has evolved into Purple Fashion Magazine. As founder and editor of the biannual publication, Zahm has remained faithful to Purple's mission to foster emerging artists, fashion insiders and sexual creativity. At 47, Zahm is unfazed by his reputation as a louche lady-killer and promotes "alternative love lifestyles" (translation: open relationships). Nor is he averse to playing against type as witnessed by his recent sharing (some would say oversharing) of his heartbreak over being dumped by the model Natacha Ramsay on on his unapologetically pervy blog, purple-diary. The Moment caught up with Zahm in his New York office to chew the fat about downtown New York culture, fashion, art and sex.

Do you have dinnerware designed by Roy Lichtenstein, Keith Haring and James Rosenquist, and glassware by Sol Lewitt in your cupboard? The Museum of Arts and Design does in an exhibit called Eat Drink Art Design. In addition to the big name pieces, there is simple, beautifully crafted rustic Japanese stoneware alongside equally elegant disposable white Japanese dishes made from bamboo and sugar cane pulp. Scores of plates designed by Peter Ting and produced by Royal Crown Derby in England make up a display called Constellation Manhattan. A surreal silver Melting Teapot by Myra Mimlitsch-Gray is one of the rare, highly impractical pieces on view. Eat Drink Art Design is on the third floor of the Museum of Arts and Design at Columbus Circle through March 27, Tuesdays through Sundays 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., except Thursdays when it stays open until 9 p.m. The disposable Japanese Wasara plates are sold in the museum shop, six for $15.

PARIS -- A Porsche sporting a "whale tail" rear spoiler used to be the height of automotive coolness. Originally designed to increase engine cooling and provide extra rear down-force for the 911 Turbo, the unique feature quickly became an over-used cosmetic addition to nearly every spec of 911. Perhaps Porsche is trying to resurrect this cetacean theme, via the distinctly "humpbacked" shape of the new 911 Speedster shown at the Paris Auto Show.

"Densité," an exhibition of paintings by Driss Ouadahi, opens today at Hosfelt Gallery New York. Ouadahi grew up in Algeria and studied architecture before enrolling at the Kunstakademie Düsseldorf, in the German city that is now his home. His subject matter is the built environment of urban alienation: underground passageways, chain-link fencing, the sterile Modernist high-rise buildings that are home to so many immigrants in European cities. Ouadahi's almost pretty color palette makes his screen-like, gridded high-rise facades seem seductive, until you realize that beyond them is a barren, depopulated landscape. His precisely rendered, claustrophobic tiled passages would make Kafka break out in a sweat, and his delicate depictions of chain link cover the canvas to its edges, suggesting a net that leaves no way out. The exhibition continues through Nov. 13. 531 West 36th Street; (212) 563-5454.

Jeffrey Lefcourt and Glenn Harris, who own Jane on West Houston Street and The Smith on Third Avenue in the East Village, will be entering the uptown restaurant mix. They plan to open a big branch of The Smith in the spring at 956 Second Avenue (51st Street), with 10,000 square feet of space over two floors and a zinc bar that stretches for 100 feet. It's an unusual turnaround for the Manhattan real estate scene because it replaces a Rite-Aid drugstore; usually drug stores and banks have replaced restaurants. "We have been looking for so long to find the right place to open a branch of The Smith in Midtown so we're very excited," Mr. Lefcourt said.

PARIS -- It's fitting that the Lamborghini Sesto Elemento made its debut in Paris. The seemingly deconstructed sports car looks like the city's Centre Georges Pompidou on wheels, every working part is open and exposed to the world. Rumored to be the replacement for the current Murciélago supercar, the Sesto Elemento (Sixth Element) is actually a showcase of the Italian sports car company's use of lightweight carbon fiber.

At 5 p.m. on Wednesday, a camera-phone-wielding crowd gathered at the corner of Madison Avenue and 75th Street as a man on the roof of the Whitney Museum prepared to go off it. "Oh, my God," gasped a passerby as the man, the dancer and choreographer Stephen Petronio, achieved liftoff. He let his body fall forward until it was perpendicular to the pavement, and then held perfectly still, looking down at the street and perhaps into his soul as well. After a few moments of awed silence, he began an absurdly casual stroll down the sheer 97-foot granite cliff of the Whitney's side wall, rappelling in slow-motion and pausing, now and then, to let his seemingly weightless feet regain the wall before proceeding to the bottom, where he was greeted with an ovation.

In a season marked by clean, tailored lines and a neutral color palette, the third and latest offering from Uniqlo's +J collection, designed by the purist's purist Jil Sander, feels more appropriate than ever. With prices ranging from $20 to $230, it's doubtful the clothes will be in store much past next Thursday's release date.

In 1966, the furniture company Stendig commissioned Massimo Vignelli to design a promotional calendar. The result, a 3-foot-by-4-foot black-and-white grid of numbers and letters, was snapped up by the Museum of Modern Art for its permanent collection before a single calendar was printed. And it has been in print ever since, becoming at one point a fixture in the office of architects like Richard Meier, whose books and Web site are also designed by the legendary Vignelli. ''I wouldn't do anything without Massimo,'' Meier insisted. ''We both resolve ideas with a grid.'' For Vignelli - who, with his wife and partner in Vignelli Associates, Lella, is also known for designs like New York City's 1972 subway map and stacked plastic dinnerware for Heller, and who co-designed the just-opened Vignelli Center for Design Studies at the Rochester Institute of Technology - the calendar is an exercise in white space (or black; random pages of the calendars are reverse-printed). ''For us, the space outside the type is more important than the type itself,'' he said. Vignelli also designed a smaller version of the calendar, which he wishes were still in production. ''Some people don't have room for the large one,'' he explained. But no matter: even if Vignelli doesn't receive royalties for it, he's happy that the big calendar is still in print. ''It's nice to see how fresh it still looks.'' Go to unicahome.com.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

Did your mother tell you "no dessert first?" Jehangir Mehta is one of those chefs who ignored that rule, started making his name in pastry departments at Jean Georges, Aix and Compass, among others, and then sidled into savories with his first restaurant, Graffiti. Mehtaphor, opening on Oct. 7, is larger, with several dining areas and an inventive menu: beef tartare with guacamole sorbet, shaved foie gras with raspberry compote, an Indian burger, and cod in banana leaf with green chutney. The chef has often given classes for children, which he will reprise for the holiday season. And at Mehtaphor, he will also offer a menu of snacks for children after school: Duane Street Hotel, 130 Duane Street (Church Street), (212) 542-9440.

"The Exile: An Outlander Graphic Novel" is No. 1 on our hardcover list. It is the first graphic novel by Diana Gabaldon, who is no stranger to best-seller lists. Her novel "An Echo in the Bone," the seventh installment in the Outlander series, made its debut at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list of The New York Times Book Review last October and spent five weeks on the list; a trade paperback edition of the novel also made the list in July. The graphic novel "Exile" starts at the beginning of the Outlander mythos, telling the story of Claire Randall, a World War II-era nurse is transported back in time to the side of Jamie Fraser, a kilt-wearing Scotsman in the 18th century.

The San Francisco Patient and Resource Center, or Sparc, is not your average pot club. There's no peephole or scary-looking security guy, no skunky couches or blackened windows. Instead, a collegiate ''community liaison'' stands by the door answering questions from passers-by and checking membership cards and paperwork. (There's no fee to join, but you need a doctor's recommendation to enter.) And with its minimalist oak tables and benches, and jazz on the stereo, Sparc could easily be mistaken for a Japanese teahouse. Welcome to the medical marijuana dispensary of the future.

The collection's curator, Stephen Pinson, spent a year searching through those photographs for 20th-century portraits, and now there is a handsome exhibition, "Recollection ," in the library's Print and Stokes Galleries. On display are portraits from more than 90 photographers of the 20th century, including Richard Avedon, Diane Arbus, Duane Michals, Henri Cartier-Bresson, August Sander and William Wegman.

The Samurai Shopper is a master in the civil arts of social encounters, a mannerly person and a lively guest, trading effortless bons mots with newcomers, outsiders, friends and frenemies. But at some point during such festivities, an awkward situation arises. I enter my host's bathroom for a quick freshening of hands or to minister to an urgent function. There is nothing to do but look around the bathroom, noting fixtures, shower curtains, rugs. Some décor is predictably matchy-matchy; some objects are pleasantly marked by habit and custom. The pictures on the wall prompt idle curiosity: what mysterious forces lurk behind this vapid still life or that totemic oddity? And then it happens - that unwanted glimpse into personal space.

MEHLICH--Astrid C.,passed away September 27, 2010 in her apartment at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, New York. Astrid died just 19 days after her beloved husband of 69 years, William O. Mehlich. They were very much in love. Astrid was born on February 4, 1909 in the Bronx, NY. She was a legal secretary at White and Case Law Firm until the early 1940's. Astrid and Bill brought up their family in Scarsdale, New York. She was an active member of the Scarsdale Woman's Club until she moved to Highland Beach, Florida with her husband, Bill, in the mid 1980's. They were active members of the Delray Beach Club in Delray Beach, Florida and they were the oldest and longest members of the Westchester Country Club in Rye, NY. She is survived by her daughter, Cheryl M. Schmitz of Lake Forest, Illinois, her son, Robert W. Mehlich of Scarsdale, NY, her daughter-in-law, Anne S. Mehlich, her grandsons, Roger W. Schmitz of New York City, Frederick M. Schmitz of Lake Forest, Illinois, Robert W. Mehlich, Jr of New York City and Peter C. Mehlich of Scarsdale, New York. Visiting Hours will be on Sunday, October 3rd at the Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY, from 2:305:00pm. A funeral service will be held at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church, Scarsdale, NY on Monday, October 4th at 2:00pm. Internment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends who wish may contribute to: Project Hope, 255 Carter Hill Lane, Millwood, VA 22646.

FARBER--Harriet Fels, 83, died September 29, 2010. Adored by husband William, daughters Betsy and Joan (Richard), grandchildren Stephanie (Aaron), Heather (Eugene), Craig (Daniela), Edward and Eric, and great-grandchildren Max and Roxanne; loved by all. Services Friday, October 1 at Noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY.

When the Miami Dolphins announced just before the season that Bill Parcells was ceding full control of the football operations to General Manager Jeff Ireland, it started speculation about whether Parcells' peripatetic career would soon take him out of South Florida. On Thursday, during a conference call with New York writers to mark his inclusion in the New York Giants' new Ring of Honor to be unveiled Sunday night, Parcells made his first public remarks since the job change. His vague comments will do little to convince anyone that he will not soon leave the Dolphins, where he is now a consultant, entirely. And that he won't be retiring when he does it.

Grandmother of Josie, Aaron, Noah, Allison and Daniel. Private graveside services Sunday October 3, 2010 in Philadelphia. The family will return Tuesday October 5, 2010 in the afternoon to the residence of Mark and Julie Yadgaroff and respectfully request that contributions in her memory be made to Fred's Team Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27432, New York, NY 10087-7432

HOROWITZ--Dr. Samuel, passed away Wednesday, September 29th at his home in Tarzana, California at the age of 102. Sam Horowitz was born on the Lower Eastside of New York City on June 17th, 1908. He attended New York University and New York Medical College, graduating with an MD in 1933. He served with distinction with the 8th Division in World War II as a Battalion Surgeon in the European Theatre of Operations. After the war, Sam Horowitz met and married Doris Friedman in 1947, and started a family medical practice in Kew Gardens, New York. His medical practice grew to include large extended families. Sam enjoyed every minute of the practice of family medicine. In 1973, the family moved to California. Sam and Doris traveled extensively, visiting many areas of the world. Sam Horowitz was a wonderful, gentle and caring man, and will be missed by many. He is survived by Doris, his wife of 63 years, his sons Bud and Steve, daughter in law Linda and his beloved grandchildren, Seth and Rachelle.

van ECK--Derek, died peacefully asleep at his home on September 30. He was 46 years old. Early this year Derek was diagnosed with a neurological disease. He faced his condition and future bravely, spiritually, and with an unfailing sense of humor. He loved and was loved by his family and friends and enjoyed cycling, tennis and swimming with them. He was planning the speedy resumption of these joyful activities. Born in New York City, September 16, 1964, Derek graduated from The Hackley School in 1982, Williams College in 1986 and Northwestern's Kellogg School of Management in 1993. A visionary and widely respected commodities trader and global assets manager, Derek and his beloved brother Jan have co-managed van Eck Global since 1993 growing the assets from $1 Billion to over $25 Billion. Through his quiet, meaningful leadership, and together with his wife Deborah, Derek personified his family's longstanding commitment to philanthropy. Derek was active in many civic, humanistic, religious, and environmental organizations, serving on the board of The Institute for China and the Fred M. van Eck Forest Trust and assisted his wife, Deborah in her role as Board member of Jericho Project, which serves homeless families and American veterans in New York. As a couple, they were widely recognized for their engaging manner, lack of pretention, and genuine humanity. An extraordinarily accomplished, loyal and selfless man, Derek was an inspiration to his family and friends. His integrity and humility were hallmarks of his character. Derek was a follower of The First Church of Christ, Scientist of Boston whose nurses and practitioners lovingly cared for him. Derek lives eternally and especially in the hearts and minds of his wife, Deborah, his two children Willem (four) and Kathryn (four months); his brother Jan, and his parents Sigrid and John C. van Eck. Visitation Monday, October 4th 2-4pm and 6-8pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. Donations can be sent in Derek's name to The First Church of Christ, Scientist in Boston or Williams College.

One year after Conde Nast stunned the food world by shuttering Gourmet magazine, its editor, Ruth Reichl, has landed a job at Random House, the publisher said on Thursday. Ms. Reichl will be both an author and an editor at large for the Random House imprint, acquiring books and working with writers. Her own books are two new nonfiction titles: a cookbook-slash-memoir, ''The Tao of Ruth,'' and a novel, ''Delicious!''

EISEN--David J.,longtime NYC resident, newspaperman, chess champion and activist, passed on September 16 in Waterville, ME. Born in New York, September 2, 1925, he married Shirley Cetron in 1946 and remained married to her until her death earlier this year. They moved to Staten Island in '51, then to the Washington, DC area in '61. Dave was a reporter for the Staten Island Advance and the Elizabeth Daily Journal before being named Associate Editor, later Editor of the American Newspaper Guild newspaper, and later the Guild's Director of Research and Information. He won the U.S. Chess Federation's Postal Championship in '80 and '81. Always keenly involved in progressive causes, he wrote for many magazines, including The New Republic. Dave moved to Maine in 2005. He is survived by his son Ken of Fairfield, ME and daughter Terry Sinskie of Dedham, MA. A memorial service will be held at Noon on October 10 at the Senator Inn, Augusta, ME.

8 P.M. (TCM) HAMMER HORROR FESTIVAL Turner Classic Movies salutes the heyday of Hammer Film Productions, a low-budget British studio that, from the mid-1950s through the 1970s, created lavish, Gothic fright films replete with striking direction, imaginative sets and a roster of stars willing to slum to campy effect. The tribute, to be shown each Friday in October, begins with a quartet of vampire flicks, starting with Peter Cushing as Van Helsing, the vampire hunter -- and the arch-enemy of Count Dracula, played by Christopher Lee (above) -- in ''Horror of Dracula'' (1958) and, at 9:30, ''The Brides of Dracula'' (1960). Mr. Lee is resurrected as the title bloodsucker at 11 in ''Dracula, Prince of Darkness'' (1966) and, at 12:45 a.m., in ''Dracula Has Risen From the Grave'' (1969). 7 P.M. (21); 9:30 P.M. (13) AT THE PALEY CENTER Pat Mitchell, president and chief executive of the Paley Center for Media, hosts this new six-part series focusing on people who have made significant contributions to television and film. First up: Ted Danson reminisces about his career, from Sam Malone, the ''Cheers'' character that made him a star, to his more recent roles in HBO's ''Curb Your Enthusiasm'' and ''Bored to Death'' and FX's ''Damages.''

TARR--Alan, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, loving husband of the late Jane Silverstein Tarr, devoted companion of Peggy Biesenbach. Services Monday, October 4 at 1:00pm, Mt. Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens.

Because of an editing error, a listing in the Transactions column in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a retail condominium for sale on Madison Avenue described the available space incorrectly. The condominium is 1,100 square feet, including the basement, the ground floor and mezzanine; it is not 1,100 square feet over five stories.

SAINT-AMAND--Cynthia Chisholm died peacefully at her home in New York City on September 29 after a long illness. Cynthia was born in Laurel, Mississippi to Alexander Field Chisholm and Elisabeth Wisner Chisholm. The Chisholm household was filled with the melodies of piano and singing voices sounds that characterized her childhood and remained with her for a lifetime. She and her sisters considered it one of their greatest blessings to grow up alongside the legendary soprano Leontyne Price and her brother General George Price. After graduating from the National Cathedral School in Washington, D.C., Cynthia earned a bachelor's degree in Art History and Theater Design from Smith College. During the next decade, Cynthia lived in Paris, Madrid, and Florence, where she became fluent in the languages of those countries. In keeping with her love for the arts and the theater, she later spent years working for Richard Rodgers in New York. She also worked for John D. Rockefeller, III. In 1972 Cynthia married Dr. Nathan Emile Saint-Amand. After they wed, Cynthia served on several boards and was extremely active in education. She served as President and Chairman of the Board of Trustees of The Episcopal School. Cynthia was also on the boards of The Buckley School and The Garrison Forest School, and was Parents' Chairwoman at St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire. Cynthia is survived by her devoted and loving husband of thirty-eight years, Nathan, her son Nathan Alexander and his wife Sarah, and her daughter Elisabeth Alice. She will be missed forever. Everyone who knew her remarked on her grace, generosity, and keen intelligence. This last trait was evidenced by her skills as a storyteller a classic Southern gift. But her family would say that her greatest achievement was being a loving, generous, kind-spirited, and gentle wife and mother. A memorial service will be held at St. James Episcopal Church at 4pm on Tuesday, October 5th. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Drug Discovery Foundation or the Alzheimer's Disease and Memory Research Center at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

As he departs the White House for Chicago, Rahm Emanuel is an even bigger character than he was when he arrived. Mr. Emanuel, called simply ''Rahm'' around town, was already known as the short, profane, exercise-obsessed former lawmaker with a tendency to explode and then apologize and then explode again. But during his nearly 20 months as President Obama's chief of staff, he also became the implementer of a new Democratic agenda and the protective mother hen for those who slaved for him in the White House. And of course he left a trail of ''Rahm moments,'' memorable encounters with coworkers, lawmakers, lobbyists or adversaries. Here are some of our favorites: During a tour of the Chapel of the Ascension in Jerusalem, Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, received a phone call from an agitated chief of staff. Mr. Emanuel wanted Mr. Graham to help him stop plans by Department of Justice officials to hold trials for top terror suspects in New York City. ''I'm at one of the most holy sites in the world and there's lots of swearing,'' Mr. Graham, who considers Mr. Emanuel ''loyal and effective,'' recalled. ''I'm talking so loud that the tour guide stops and everybody is listening to me exchange one profanity after another with Rahm.'' ''I thought, This is the most bizarre phone call ever,'' Graham said.It was a particularly contentious moment during one of the morning staff meetings, and Carol Browner, the president's top environmental adviser, was the target of Mr. Emanuel's ire. ''Rahm can be fairly intense,'' Ms. Browner said later ''He thought that he had said something that was not fair. So his offer of reconciliation was that he would kiss me.'' It was one of those classic moments, said Ms. Browner, who has known Mr. Emanuel since both worked in the administration of former president Bill Clinton. ''I accepted the offer of the kiss, not the kiss itself,'' she said. Close to three feet of snow dumped on Washington in January of 2010. Those who lived near Mr. Emanuel's D.C. neighborhood in the days after might have been surprised to see the chief of staff to the president of the United States - and his kids - on sleds, holding onto the back bumpers of a black Secret Service SUV. In the Chicago suburbs, this is apparently big, and they call it ''skeeching.''Melody Barnes, the president's domestic policy adviser, had scheduled her wedding for a few months after the inauguration in 2009. When Mr. Emanuel was told, he ordered her to take a week off before her wedding. ''I don't want to see pictures of a bride with bags under her eyes,'' she recalled him saying. She took three days off and was back at the office the Tuesday after her wedding.Two days after Mr. Obama's election, Mr. Emanuel called a reporter friend, as he frequently did. When he was told that the reporter was sitting next to a senior Republican aide, Mr. Emanuel insisted the phone be handed over, surprising the staffer. Remarked another reporter who witnessed the moment: ''Just Rahm being Rahm.''In the midst of the debate over the president's stimulus package, Mr. Emanuel went for the all-time record for phone calls to the Senate Majority Leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada. The calls started at 7 a.m., recalled a top aide, and didn't stop until after 11:30 that night, violating Mr. Reid's rule of no calls after 10 p.m. All told: 15 phone calls in one day.Shortly after Mr. Obama took office, he was meeting with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other lawmakers. Mr. Emanuel started cracking a knuckle on his hand, prompting a comment from his boss. As reported by the Times' Mark Leibovich, Mr. Emanuel ''held the offending knuckle up to Mr. Obama's left ear and, like an annoying little brother, snapped off a few special cracks.''Among Mr. Emanuel's biggest achievements in the White House may have been the day the president signed the health care legislation. That day in March, after Mr. Obama put his signature on the bill during a ceremony in the East Room, Mr. Emanuel walked back to his West Wing office with another senior adviser. Everyone was satisfied - except Mr. Emanuel. ''He was literally already saying, 'we've got to get focused on financial reform. Nobody's focused,''' the adviser said. ''It was just like Rahm.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about delays in the release of Nintendo's new 3DS console misstated the date the device is expected to be available. The company plans to have the console in stores on Feb. 26 in Japan and in March in other markets -- not ''tentatively February.''

Did we miss the meeting of the Broadway League where it was ruled that the cast of every musical must feature at least one rock or pop star? ''American Idiot''has Billie Joe Armstrong, ''Fela!'' has Patti LaBelle and now ''Rock of Ages'' has Dee Snider. On Thursday, press representatives for ''Rock of Ages'' said Mr. Snider, the Twisted Sister frontman, will join the musical for an 11-week run beginning Oct. 11. Mr. Snider, who is also a star of the A&E reality show ''Growing Up Twisted,'' will play the role of the nightclub owner Dennis, and will host a weekly talkback series called ''Rock Senate Hearings'' that will begin on Oct. 19. ''Rock of Ages,'' a jukebox musical built around headbanging hits of the 1980s (including the Twisted Sister songs ''I Wanna Rock'' and ''We're Not Gonna Take It''), recently lost its Tony Award-nominated star, Constantine Maroulis, to the show's national tour. In recent weeks, the musical, which is performed at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, has played to about 75 percent capacity and has grossed under $500,000 a week. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a project to turn an abandoned movie theater in Brooklyn into a charter school and retail space, using information from the architect, misstated the technique the theater used to create a cloud effect on the ceiling. The clouds were projected onto the ceiling, probably by means of a machine called a Brenograph Junior; they were not created by dry ice.

SCHLEIFER--Jack P.,died peacefully at home in Manhattan on September 25 at the age of 96. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Born in Poland, he came to the USA in 1922. He was married for 42 years to his beloved wife Geraldine Schleifer who predeceased him. He later married Marjorie Minskoff Schleifer who also predeceased him. HILL--Ruth Maxwell, of New York, died Friday, September 24, 2010, at home. Ms. Hill was born January 31, 1956, in New York, the only child of Arthur Cheney Clifton Hill and Katherine Johnson Hill of New York City. Ms. Hill was the only grandchild of Louis Arthur Johnson and Ruth Maxwell Johnson of Clarksburg, WV, and Washington, DC. A lifelong resident of New York, Ms. Hill graduated from Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, NY, and completed a Masters of Fine Arts degree at New York University. Bruce Goldstein remembers when he realized that Tony Curtis had ''a spiel.'' One more cook is jumping into the stew that is the South Carolina Senate race. Nathalie Dupree, a prominent Charleston chef and cookbook author, is announcing her write-in candidacy Thursday in an 11th-hour challenge to Senator Jim DeMint, the Republican incumbent, and Alvin Greene, the unemployed Democratic nominee.

The Morgan Library & Museum's landmark McKim, Mead and White building will reopen to the public on Oct. 30 after a $4.5 million restoration of its interior spaces. The Italianate marble villa, designed in High Renaissance style, was formerly the private study and library of the financier Pierpont Morgan. The project completes a physical transformation of the Morgan that began in 2006 with an expansion and renovation by the architect Renzo Piano.
