When you've built a career working with Tim Burton, as Danny Elfman has, it's inevitable that you end up with entire crypts full of buried material. But now an (un)healthy portion of the catalog created by Mr. Elfman, the musician and composer who has written the scores for nearly all of Mr. Burton's films, including ''Beetlejuice,''''Batman'' and ''Edward Scissorhands'' - and provided the singing voice for Jack Skellington of ''The Nightmare Before Christmas'' - is about to be unearthed. On Thursday, Warner Brothers Records said it would release a boxed set commemorating the 25 years that these two artists have worked together, dating back to 1985, when Mr. Burton recruited Mr. Elfman from the band Oingo Boingo to create the score for ''Pee-wee's Big Adventure.'' The ''Danny Elfman & Tim Burton 25th Anniversary Music Box,'' which is planned for a December release, will contain 18 hours of music on 16 CDs, including seven hours of previously unreleased material, a hardcover book with a foreword by Johnny Depp and a DVD conversation between Mr. Elfman and Mr. Burton. Mr. Elfman spoke recently with ArtsBeat about the process of exhuming one's own catacombs and the origins of his partnership with Mr. Burton. These are excerpts from that conversation.Q.How long does it take to put something like this together and how long ago did you get started?A.It was some months ago. My agent and my assistant spent a month sifting through a million hours of demos, work tapes, cassette tapes. I unfortunately have been almost bizarrely committed to not archiving anything. I kept nothing. And when we started getting into it, I realized I didn't even have half of my soundtrack albums. So we started chasing down albums on eBay, literally. Q.Why weren't you saving any of this?A.It's like for some weird reason, once I finish a project, it doesn't exist to me anymore. They literally had to go through storage rooms, sifting through cardboard boxes filled with junk, until they came up with anything that looked like tapes, DATs, CDs, reel-to-reel stuff. What amounted to zero effort of saving anything for a quarter-century. Now I'm becoming the other way around. Now I really want to get ahold of stuff, I want to organize it. I want to have shelves.Q.So if you weren't hanging on to these materials, where were you finding them?A.My old work tapes just got dumped into boxes and put in the back room. I had six, seven storage rooms throughout the city. Places I haven't gone into in decades. My agent used his tentacles in the underground film music world to try to find versions of things that didn't exist anywhere. It was happening above and below the surface. Lots of detective work.Q.How far back were you searching? Like, Oingo Boingo, ''Bachelor Party''?A.They were finding everything, but they were only bringing to me the stuff that was connected with Burton. Now that my brain is into that mode, I'm going to have them continue. Because now I've got a good, new storage space, and when you get a new space you get motivated. It really is a better idea just to know where stuff is.Q.And what kinds of things were you finding?A.It's a mixed bag of work tapes, demos, and in those demos, ideas that didn't make it into movies. There's a whole stretch of a ''Batman'' work tape, of ''Batman'' music that never made it into the movie. On the one hand, that was cool for me to listen to. I'd forgotten I had all these ideas that never survived. On the other hand, I was horrified that 20 years ago, demos sounded really bad. I'm in the middle of writing this huge disclaimer, trying to explain what a work tape is, and the difference of what I was working with 20 years ago. Between ''Beetlejuice'' and ''Alice in Wonderland,'' you can hear, oh, O.K., big difference.Q.When Tim first started working with you, were you looking for a way that you could make the transition to scoring films?A.I wasn't thinking that at all. It was totally out of the blue. Tim and Paul [Reubens] came to me together. I was shocked. It wasn't like I was looking for an opportunity for film scoring. I hadn't even really fathomed the possibility - that didn't seem possible. ''Pee-wee's Big Adventure,'' my first time ever writing for orchestra, was a very simple score. And I really did think I was totally destroying his film with a score that was so out of left field.Q.Why do you think you and Tim have remained close collaborators all these years?A.We literally did grow into our abilities together. Our aesthetic is similar.Q.Do you share his appreciation for the odd and the gothic?A.Not necessarily, so much as, for whatever reason, his world was an easy place to fall into. It was a place I was comfortable in. We grew up very similar, alienated kids, feeling like a stranger in a strange land. You find yourself gravitating toward fantasy and horror. We both grew up on horror films in the same period, relatively. I grew up around the block from a movie theater, and I spent every weekend of my life there that I can remember. Every weekend was a new double bill, and to be able to see, every single weekend, two new films was really cool. He saw more of them on television, but all the same movies: Hammer films, Roger Corman films. It was a very fertile era to be into the movies.Q.Given those circumstances, I can see why you were so compatible.A.He was in Burbank, I was in Baldwin Hills. They were different suburbs of Los Angeles, but our origins weren't that far apart. So when we met, I said to him, ''Why do you want to hire me?'' He goes: ''I don't know. I've seen your band, I think you could do other stuff.'' The ability to succeed as a composer, you have to be able to relax, take no shape and fall into a new place and re-form yourself. That's the best way I can describe it.That's part of what allows a composer to thrive. I was falling into a lot of different spaces, but every time I fell into Tim's space, I found it was a particularly fun and comfortable space to be.

Giants wide receiver Mario Manningham sustained a concussion in a 29-10 loss to the Tennessee Titans but did not alert the medical staff until Sunday night. Manningham did not practice Wednesday, and his status for Sunday night's game against the Bears is uncertain. He was unavailable for comment on Wednesday. Manningham had medical tests Monday, and Coach Tom Coughlin said he appeared to be fine. On Wednesday, Manningham performed balance and coordination tests, according to a team spokesman, but did not undergo the ImPACT test, a computerized evaluation of memory, brain processing and visual motor skills.
On Friday, because of the Jewish holiday of Simhat Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

Is this the face of a hardened criminal? Joel Grey, the original Wizard of ''Wicked,'' the impish M.C. of ''Cabaret'' and Amos Hart of the ''Chicago'' revival, is headed back to Broadway in Roundabout Theater Company's coming revival of ''Anything Goes'' as one of musical theater's best-known, least-intimidating gangsters. On Thursday, publicists for Roundabout said Mr. Grey will play the role of Moonface Martin - a k a Public Enemy No. 13 - who helps provide several changes of identity for Billy Crocker, a lovesick stowaway on the S.S. American. Sutton Foster was previously announced to play the role of the singer Reno Sweeney in Roundabout's production, which will be directed by Kathleen Marshall; it is to begin previews at the Stephen Sondheim Theater on March 10 with an opening night set for April 7. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Because of an editing error, the Deal Professor column in the special DealBook section on Thursday, about changes in defense strategies against hostile takeovers, misstated the size of the board of Airgas, which is trying to fend off a suitor. Airgas has 10 directors, not nine.

Begin typing into a Google search box and you will quickly see a list of suggested searches. Google describes this feature, known as autocomplete, as ''a reflection of the search activity of all Web users.'' For example, typing the name of a Senate candidate usually reveals ''for senate'' or ''wiki'' as the top item in the list. But not always. Below, the first suggestions that appeared this week for some candidates.

An article last Friday on the use of midwives in Illinois had the incorrect given name for a nursing school graduate who is starting a three-year course to become a legal nurse midwife. She is Kristina Stevens, not Christina.

An article on Aug. 5 about the growth of India's legal outsourcing industry misstated the number of lawyers working at CPA Global, an outsourcing company with offices in Europe, the United States and India. The company currently has a total of about 1,500 employees -- not 1,500 lawyers. (The company has plans to increase its staff in India to 1,500 over the next few years, a majority of whom will be lawyers.) A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Aug. 7; this correction was delayed because the reporter did not follow through on the complaint.

An article on Sept. 13 about the subdued celebratory enthusiasm in Mexico in advance of the country's Sept. 16 bicentennial misstated the number of states there. Mexico has 31 states, plus a federal district that includes the capital, Mexico City. It does not have 32 states.

A picture with an obituary on Wednesday about the jazz musician and bandleader Buddy Collette carried an incorrect credit in some editions. The photograph of Mr. Collette performing at Lincoln Center in 1997 was taken by Alan Nahigian -- not by Vince Bucci/Getty Images.

J. Joseph Ricketts, the Ameritrade founder and an owner of the Chicago Cubs, is moving into the political big leagues. Saying he is outraged over the sorry state of the federal budget, Mr. Ricketts is beginning a crusade against Congressional spending on pet projects known as earmarks and threatening to jump into the re-election campaigns of lawmakers of both parties if he determines that they are abusing the system.

NAIMAN--Lee, died at home on September 30, 2010. Her many close friends and family feel so lucky to have known her and her remarkable spirit. She was born in Baltimore on September 2, 1926, and attended Goucher College. Lee met her husband of 59 years, Dr. Robert Naiman, in Paris. They have three children by birth, Eric, Cara and Tom; three by marriage, Anne Nesbet, Clark Sugg and Marguerite Holloway; and eight grandchildren, Kate, Thera, Caroline, Eleanor, Ada, Sarah, Auden and Julian. Lee is also survived by her brother, Leonard Helfgott, and his family. Lee loved travel, art, music, theater and intense discussion, and inspired her children and grandchildren to embrace the world. She founded the international rental agency At Home Abroad, as well as Tapestry Associates and Lee Naiman Fine Art, collecting and selling works by many artists, including Nevelson, Warhol and Gunter Grass. She was a dedicated board member of Global Kids and NARAL New York. Lee lived her life fully, with great love, generosity and dynamism. She loved pistachio ice cream, yellow tulips, oysters, the human spirit and scrabble. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent in her honor to Global Kids, 137 East 25th Street, New York, NY 10010.

Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a Rutgers student who committed suicide after video showing him in an intimate encounter was streamed on the Internet misidentified, in some editions, the hometown of Molly Wei, a student who was charged with invasion of privacy in the case. She is from Princeton Junction, N.J., not Plainsboro.

Representative Michael N. Castle of Delaware announced late Wednesday night that he would not run as a write-in candidate for the Senate, ending speculation that anger over his defeat for the Republican nomination at the hands of Christine O'Donnell would keep him in the race. In a statement e-mailed to reporters, Mr. Castle said he was humbled by the encouragement from many people to run a write-in campaign, and he said he had carefully considered it.

Greg Giraldo, a comedian famous for his stinging insult humor, disgruntled rants and frequent appearances on Comedy Central's highly watched roast series, died on Wednesday at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 44. Mr. Giraldo had been hospitalized since Saturday night after he was found unconscious in a hotel room in New Brunswick, where he was scheduled to perform at a club. Mr. Giraldo had suffered a drug overdose, The Home News Tribune of East Brunswick, N.J., reported, citing New Brunswick police. The precise cause of death on Wednesday was unclear. A hospital spokesman said the family declined to release that information.

NITZBURG--Patricia. The entire JBFCS family mourns the loss of Pat Nitzburg a master clinician and a woman with a huge heart. Pat worked for our agency for 34 years in a variety of positions. Most recently, before her retirement in 2005, she worked as Director of our Counseling Center in Pelham. Lives were changed for the better because Pat cared about people and what made them tick. Exquisite judgment was her forte. Time spent with Pat, whether across the table for supervision or across the room for therapy, let you know you were in the presence of a fine and exceptional human being. Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services Anthony E. Mann, President Paul Levine, Exec. V.P. and CEO

An article on Saturday about Japan's decision to release the captain of a Chinese trawler who had been arrested earlier in September near disputed islands misstated the date of Japan's 1931 invasion of northeast China. Japan began its invasion and subsequent full-scale occupation of the area, then known as Manchuria, on Sept. 18, 1931 -- not on Sept. 8. (This came to be known as the Manchurian Incident.)
GLOVER--Harry M. The Gordon H. Smith Corporation mourns the passing of Harry M. Glover, father of our esteemed colleague and friend James Glover. Our condolences go out to Jim and his entire family.

TWINING--Cynthia Thebaud, an artist, died in Old Lyme, CT on September 29th, 2010 at age 91 after a long illness. Born Cynthia Crawford Thebaud in New York City. Married Kinsley Twining in 1946 and lived around the world. Survived by sister Renee Wilson. Had four children: Dorothy Globus, Kinny Kreiswirth, Alexander Twining and Edith Twining and nine grandchildren. Memorial service at Old Lyme Congregational Church 2pm, October 2.

Entering the final day of the regular season, none of the playoff matchups have been set. Wins by and the Yankees on Saturday ensured that the American League East winner and the A.L. wild card would be determined Sunday. But the situation in the National League is more complicated: two playoff spots are left, and three teams have the chance to claim them. San Francisco needed to win only one game this weekend to clinch the N.L. West, but the Giants to the Padres, cutting their lead in the division to one. The Padres' two wins, combined with , resulted in a tie in the N.L. wild-card standings. SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - We haven't seen a George Bredehorn "Split Decisions" puzzle in a while. If you're new to these, read the instructions carefully. If the going is slow, take a break and come back to it later. It's an acquired skill, but it's one that helps with solving crosswords as well. Speed solvers often talk about how they get at least as much information from the letters already in the grid as they do from the clues.

Ezra Klein has written in, asking for a post laying out the difference between the more or less Keynesian model Brad DeLong and I work with and the models others have been using - and how their predictions differ. It's a good request, although the truth is that the other side in this debate doesn't necessarily agree on a single model, or even use models at all. Still, I think it is possible to describe the general views of the other guys -- and to see how off their predictions have been.

9 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS: CHARLIZE THERON AND JANE GOODALL Ms. Theron, above left, the Academy Award-winning actress, grew up in South Africa on a farm outside of Benoni, about 15 miles east of Johannesburg. Ms. Goodall, above right, the English primatologist and conservationist, first traveled into the dense forest of Tanzania in her early 20s to study chimpanzees. In this fifth-season premiere, the women meet at the Jane Goodall Institute's Tchimpounga Sanctuary in Congo, where Ms. Goodall and her staff rehabilitate orphaned chimpanzees rescued from illegal commercial hunting. Ms. Theron and Ms. Goodall also discuss issues facing the young people of Africa and the continent's wildlife, as well as the efforts of the Charlize Theron Africa Outreach Program to teach AIDS prevention. ''Monster'' (2003), starring Ms. Theron in her Oscar-winning role as the serial killer Aileen Wuornos, follows at 10. 10:30 A.M. SCHLEIFER--Jack P.,died peacefully at home in Manhattan on September 25 at the age of 96. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Born in Poland, he came to the USA in 1922. He attended CCNY and became a CPA in 1941. His life long career in Real Estate Investment began in 1954, specializing in Hotels, Ballparks and Shopping Centers. Real Estate Weekly recently chose him as their "Man of the Week", the same honor he had received exactly 50 years previously. He was married for 42 years to his beloved wife Geraldine Schleifer who predeceased him. He later married Marjorie Minskoff Schleifer who also predeceased him. He is survived by his beloved daughter Natalie Schleifer; his sisters Gloria and Joan; his brother Daniel Schleifer predeceased him, grandchildren Rachel, Geraldine, William; and great-grandson Mazin; step-daughter Jean Minskoff Grant; step-daughters Deva and Danielle; step-grandsons Michael and Richard Sands; his family will be receiving visitors on Sunday October 3 from 2 to 5pm at his home in Manhattan.

HARRIS--Charles Eugene, 67, of New York City, died at home on September 30, 2010. Beloved wife of Susan and father of Elizabeth and David, he is also survived by his mother, Kathryn K. Harris, his sister, Kathryn H. Harris, his brother William K. Harris, and one grandchild. His father, Clyde E. Harris, predeceased him in January. A graduate of Princeton and Columbia Business School, he was the retired Chairman and CEO of Harris & Harris Group, Inc. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory or the Center for Nanotechnology Science at the Koch Institute at MIT.

WEEKEND A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown,'' at the Belasco Theater, misstated the date previews begin. It is Friday, Oct. 8 -- not this coming Tuesday. (Go to Article)

The dazzling shows of the Builders Association make just about every other theater company look as if it's living in the past. Three-dimensional computer animation, floating videos, seamless integration of the real and the virtual -- the eye-popping stagecraft seems from the future, but the content is typically of the moment. Technology moves fast, so the revival of the group's 2000 drama ''Jet Lag'' -- a moody, multimedia production that surrounds its puzzled characters in a media-saturated world -- is, perhaps inevitably, going to seem like a period piece. Staged elegantly by the Builders' artistic director, Marianne Weems, with the help of the architectural firm Diller Scofidio and Renfro, ''Jet Lag'' follows two tragic characters escaping the world through travel.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Sept. 10 about the possibility of expanded long-distance bus service in Germany, using information from Deutsche Bank, misstated the passenger load on the rail line Deutsche Bahn between the cities of Hamburg and Berlin. According to financial records prepared by the bank, the rail line carries about 370,000 passengers each month -- not each day -- between the cities. (Go to Article)

The new Broadway musical ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown'' has delayed the start of preview performances for a second time, switching from Tuesday Oct. 5 to Friday Oct. 8. In a brief interview, the show's director, Bartlett Sher, said the production was ''an enormous, complex undertaking'' and required a few more days for technical rehearsal, when all facets of a production - lighting cues, sound, special effects and costume changes, as well as the acting, choreography and music - come together on an actual stage. It was only on Tuesday afternoon that the cast - which includes Sherie Rene Scott (''Everyday Rapture''), Patti LuPone (''Gypsy,'' ''Evita''), Laura Benanti (''Gypsy''), and Brian Stokes Mitchell (''Kiss Me, Kate'') - sang the score with the full orchestra for the first time. Mr. Sher also said in the interview that the cast had only recently begun work on a new finale.

HILL--Ruth Maxwell, of New York, died Friday, September 24, 2010, at home. Ms. Hill was born January 31, 1956, in New York, the only child of Arthur Cheney Clifton Hill and Katherine Johnson Hill of New York City. Ms. Hill was the only grandchild of Louis Arthur Johnson and Ruth Maxwell Johnson of Clarksburg, WV, and Washington, DC. A lifelong resident of New York, Ms. Hill graduated from Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, NY, and completed a Masters of Fine Arts degree at New York University. She pursued artistic interests in painting, silk screening, photography, video and music. She participated in group shows and taught art in underprivileged schools in the Bronx. Ms. Hill is survived by her dearest friend, Timothy Druckrey of Brooklyn, a half-brother, Peter Hill of Keene, NH, and his children, as well as by numerous cousins. Friends will be received from 2 until 3pm on Sunday, October 3, 2010 at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York (212-674-8055). Services for Ms. Hill will be held at 3pm that same day. Interment in the family plot in Clarksburg, WV, will be at the convenience of the family. For online condolences, please contact: www.greenwichvillagefuneralhome.com.

GILBERT--Marvin Marshall ("Bud") on September 30, 2010 in his 86th year, finally at peace after a lengthy battle with Parkinson's Disease and its complications. He passed with the same unfailing dignity with which he led his life. Truly beloved husband and constant companion of Elaine for 62 years. Devoted father of Scott and Glen -- along with their wives Anne and Beth. Adored and adoring grandpa of Daniel (and his wife Leah), Rebecca, Sarah, David and Samantha. Inseparable from brother and best friend, Ronald and his wife Arlene. He leaves behind an indelible legacy of kindness, love and humor. Service Sunday 12:45pm at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

KISHINSKY--Judy (nee Chernoff), West Orange, NJ. Formerly of Woodmere, cherished wife of Llyod, adored mother of Debra Lewis (Arthur) and Alisa Hare (Jeffrey), loving grandmother of Dan, Adam, Alex, Harrison and Scott. She leaves a legacy of laughter and love.
HENRY--Blake. Sept. 29, 1925 -Oct. 2, 2009 SO DEEPLY MISSED.

HECHT--Natalie B.,passed away September 30, 2010 at age 84. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and aunt. Funeral service Sunday 12noon Zion Memorial Chapel 785 E. Boston Post Rd Mamaroneck. 914-381-1809. Interment to follow at Cedar Park Cemetery.

Three-dimensional computer animation, floating videos, seamless integration of the real and the virtual -- the eye-popping stagecraft seems from the future, but the content is typically of the moment. Technology moves fast, so the revival of the group's 2000 drama ''Jet Lag'' -- a moody, multimedia production that surrounds its puzzled characters in a media-saturated world -- is, perhaps inevitably, going to seem like a period piece. INTERNATIONAL An article on Sept. 6 about pressure by the Thailand government on political opponents in Udon Thani, a northern stronghold of the so-called ''red shirt'' protest movement, misstated the location of Bangkok, the capital, where the military had violently crushed a prolonged red-shirt demonstration nearly four months earlier. As an accompanying map correctly showed, Bangkok is nearly 300 miles to the southwest -- not southeast -- of Udon Thani. (Go to Article)

GOLDFelicia. Loving daughter of the late Abraham and Ann Gold, beloved cousin and friend. All who knew her mourn the loss of this courageous, loving woman. Services Sunday October 3rd, promptly 11:15am, "Riverside", 180 W. 76 St., NY.

Creative Artists Agency, the prominent talent agency, said Friday that it sold a 35 percent stake to the buyout firm TPG Capital. The two companies agreed to control a $500 million fund earmarked for future investments like sports-related businesses. The alliance bolsters C.A.A., already Hollywood's strongest talent agency, with expansion capital and money to help its partners and employees cash out some of their holdings.

NAIMAN--Lee, died at home on September 30, 2010. Her many close friends and family feel so lucky to have known her and her remarkable spirit. She was born in Baltimore on September 2, 1926, and attended Goucher College. Lee met her husband of 59 years, Dr. Robert Naiman, in Paris. They have three children by birth, Eric, Cara and Tom; three by marriage, Anne Nesbet, Clark Sugg and Marguerite Holloway; and eight grandchildren, Kate, Thera, Caroline, Eleanor, Ada, Sarah, Auden and Julian. Lee is also survived by her brother, Leonard Helfgott, and his family. Lee loved travel, art, music, theater and intense discussion, and inspired her children and grandchildren to embrace the world. She founded the international rental agency At Home Abroad, as well as Tapestry Associates and Lee Naiman Fine Art, collecting and selling works by many artists, including Nevelson, Warhol and Gunter Grass. She was a dedicated board member of Global Kids and NARAL New York. Lee lived her life fully, with great love, generosity and dynamism. She loved pistachio ice cream, yellow tulips, oysters, the human spirit and scrabble. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent in her honor to Global Kids, 137 East 25th Street, New York, NY 10010.
MAGAZINE An article this weekend about the baseball executive and former pitcher Nolan Ryan misstates the year he made his debut in the major leagues. It was 1966, not 1968. (Go to Article)

WHITE--Dorothy A. The staff of the Department of Medicine of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center notes with sadness the death of our esteemed colleague Dorothy A. White. A pulmonologist, Dr. White was internationally recognized for her expertise in caring for patients with cancer whose immune systems have been compromised by the disease and medical treatments such as chemotherapy or the immunosuppressive drugs given to prevent rejection after bone marrow transplantation. Such patients may confront serious pulmonary problems, and Dr. White's clinical experience informed her research, which focused on recognizing and diagnosing different types of toxicity that can occur in the lungs of immunocompromised patients. Dr. White came to MSKCC as Chief Resident in Medicine and joined the staff in 1984. Throughout her more than 25 years at our institution, she played major roles as clinician, scientist, and mentor, teaching at the bedside as well as in the classroom. Her legacy will span generations, and her warmth, enthusiasm, and dedication to improving the lives of patients will be profoundly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to her family. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a contribution to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in the name of Dorothy A. White, MD. George J. Bosl, MD Chair, Department of Medicine Diane E. Stover, MD Chief, Pulmonary Service Mark G. Kris, MD Chief, Thoracic Oncology Service Robert E. Wittes, MD Physician-in-Chief, Memorial Hospital

van ECK--Derek, died peacefully asleep at his home on September 30. He was 46 years old. Early this year Derek was diagnosed with a neurological disease. He faced his condition and future bravely, spiritually, and with an unfailing sense of humor. He loved and was loved by his family and friends and enjoyed cycling, tennis and swimming with them. He was planning the speedy resumption of these joyful activities. Born in New York City, September 16, 1964, Derek graduated from The Hackley School in 1982, Williams College in 1986 and Northwestern's Kellogg School of Management in 1993. A visionary and widely respected commodities trader and global assets manager, Derek and his beloved brother Jan have co-managed van Eck Global since 1993 growing the assets from $1 Billion to over $25 Billion. Through his quiet, meaningful leadership, and together with his wife Deborah, Derek personified his family's longstanding commitment to philanthropy. Derek was active in many civic, humanistic, religious, and environmental organizations, serving on the board of The Institute for China and the Fred M. van Eck Forest Trust and assisted his wife, Deborah in her role as Board member of Jericho Project, which serves homeless families and American veterans in New York. As a couple, they were widely recognized for their engaging manner, lack of pretention, and genuine humanity. An extraordinarily accomplished, loyal and selfless man, Derek was an inspiration to his family and friends. His integrity and humility were hallmarks of his character. Derek was a follower of The First Church of Christ, Scientist of Boston whose nurses and practitioners lovingly cared for him. Derek lives eternally and especially in the hearts and minds of his wife, Deborah, his two children Willem (four) and Kathryn (four months); his brother Jan, and his parents Sigrid and John C. van Eck. Visitation Monday, October 4th 2-4pm and 6-8pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. Services will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church, 91st St. and Park Ave., at 11am, Tuesday, October 5. Donations can be sent in Derek's name to The First Church of Christ, Scientist in Boston or Williams College.

Andrew Lloyd Webber has finally acknowledged reality. After weeks of omens that his new musical, ''Love Never Dies,'' would not reach Broadway next spring as planned, a spokesman for the production said on Friday morning that the show would not go on (at least for now).'' 'Love Never Dies' will not be opening on Broadway this spring,'' the spokesman, Adrian Bryan-Brown, wrote in an e-mail. ''Further news about the show will be announced shortly.'' The Lloyd Webber public-relations waltz on ''Love Never Dies,'' his much-anticipated sequel to the blockbuster ''Phantom of the Opera,'' is a window into the workings of ego-driven Broadway.

WANDERMAN--Sidney, Elian M.D.,September 7, 1910 -- September 29, 2010. A native of Manhattan, he practiced medicine in that borough for over 50 years. Born in a tenement on Orchard St., the son of Helen Toft and Fischel Wanderman and the brother of Florence, Ann and Rosalie Wanderman, all deceased. He was married twice: to Thelma Eisenberg Wanderman (divorced, deceased), and for 57 years to Jeannette Boskoff Wanderman, who predeceased him in 2006. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, NYU and New York Medical College, he was on the staff of Beth Israel Hospital, Mt. Sinai Hospital and the Metropolitan Hospital. He was a Fellow of the International College of Surgeons, the International Proctologic Society and the New York Colon and Rectal Society. He wrote two books about Proctology: "The Hemorrhoid Book" and "Hemorrhoids". He was a flight surgeon in WWII, retiring as a Lt. Colonel, and was recipient of the prestigious Soldier's Medal. Survived by his loving daughters Lisa Wanderman Gottlieb (Paul), Marcia Wanderman Brill (William, deceased), granddaughter Robin Davis (David), and grandson Tony Brill (Mindy). Services to be held Sunday October 3, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Ave. and 20th St. at 11am. Contributions can be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association.

BRENNER--Milton, died September 29, 2010 (82 years). son to David and Esther Brenner. Husband to Joyce, brother to Judy (Jerry). Milton is survived by his children, Susan (Chet), and Gary, and his grandchildren, Matthew, Zachary, and Dylan. He, with Joyce, lived in Plainview since 1965. Milton was president of Aeroflex Laboratories Inc., (Plainview, NY) from 1973 until retiring in 1987. He remained a board member until 2007. Milty was 'larger than life' and will be loved and missed by us forever. Services Sunday, October 3, 1pm at Gutterman's. 8000 Jericho Turnpike. Woodbury, LI.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday 10am at Corpus Christi RC Church. Interment St. Raymond Cemetery. MANHEIMER-SCHWARTZ--Bernice. Died peacefully September 29th, loving mother of Stephen and Arnold. Funeral services Sunday, October 3 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 91st and Amsterdam 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Jewish Center of Princeton, 435 Nassau Street, Princeton, New Jersey 08540.

PHOENIX -- Rodney Glassman, the Arizona Democrat running an uphill battle to unseat Senator John McCain, has found his campaign thrown off track in recent days as he has been forced to defend his 246-page doctoral dissertation on arid land resource sciences. A Tucson blogger alleged this week that several passages in Mr. Glassman's dissertation from the University of Arizona were lifted word for word from other sources. The blogger said he had received a plagiarism tip from an anonymous e-mailer.

In Alaska, the G.O.P. and the Tea Party are strong. But the most durable political brand just might be Uncle Ted. Even the Democratic candidate, Scott McAdams, is paying tribute to Ted Stevens, the late Republican senator whose passion for pork to benefit Alaska was even more legendary than his cantankerous disposition over 40 years in office.

The rain Friday at the Ryder Cup in Wales disrupted not only the matches, but also the television schedule. Under the revised schedule, ESPN will be on live Saturday from 2:30 to 8 a.m., Eastern time, followed by NBC live from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. On Sunday, NBC will broadcast from 4 a.m. until play ends. And on Monday, the USA Network, which is owned by NBC Universal, will carry the tournament from 2 a.m. until its conclusion. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

AMHERST, N.Y. -- You can tell something about a man by what he names his dog. At Paul Kurtz's house, I was greeted in his driveway by a pug puppy named John Dewey. The dog's predecessors, I learned, included Voltaire and Bentham. Mr. Kurtz, an 84-year-old who names his dogs for free thinkers throughout history, is the exiled founder of the Center for Inquiry, which is devoted to promoting humanism and criticizing religion. He founded the center's two affiliates: the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry, which investigates claims of the paranormal, like U.F.O. sightings and mental telepathy, and the Council for Secular Humanism, which promotes ethics and values without God.

Arthur E. Holch Jr., an Emmy Award-winning television documentarian whose work at midcentury and afterward tackled charged subjects like race relations, Nazism and Communism, died on Sept. 23 in Greenwich, Conn. He was 86 and a longtime Greenwich resident. The cause was heart failure, his family said.

After the Mets had agonized for weeks over the fates of their manager and general manager until the final few days of the season, word leaked Friday that Jerry Manuel would not be asked back as manager and that Omar Minaya would lose his role as the top baseball decision-maker, as has been expected for weeks. The Mets have finally made their decision, but their have not told the principals or the public, leaving themselves open to criticism by Manuel for remaining silent while he and Minaya heard of their impending dismissals through news media reports. And so for the third consecutive time, a Mets managerial change will be accompanied by turbulence and criticism.

SEOUL, South Korea -- In a sign of a possible easing of tensions between North and South Korea, the two countries agreed on Friday to hold a series of reunions of families separated by the Korean War, with 100 families from each side to be reunited at the Diamond Mountain resort in the North from Oct. 30 to Nov. 5. Red Cross officials from both Koreas met Friday to finalize the details of the reunions, and a spokeswoman from South Korea's Unification Ministry said that a concession by North Korea had made the deal possible.

By day, bathing caps are required, but at an offbeat party on Thursday night at the Seahorse Swim Club, a pool in the Masaryk Towers housing complex on the Lower East Side, some swimmers left their caps -- and their swimsuits -- behind. Guests started the evening clothed, and followed instructions in a cryptic invitation they had received by e-mail that morning to convene at an ice pop stand on Rivington Street around 6 p.m. They had paid $20 to $45 for the event, held by Les Salonnieres. At the stand, they licked clean the ginger crème and salted black tea Brewla ice pops to reveal directions to the party's secret location printed in now-runny ink on the wooden sticks.

It is quite acceptable in Western video games to kill the Taliban; it is not acceptable to be able to play as the Taliban. That was the message on Friday from Electronic Arts, the big game publisher, as the company decided to remove the ability to play as a Taliban fighter in Medal of Honor, its coming combat game.

To finish all the Ryder Cup matches by Sunday evening, the PGA European Tour and the P.G.A. of America plan to squeeze four remaining sessions into three. Replacing Saturday's scheduled four fourball and four foursome (alternate-shot) matches will be the finish of the remaining holes of the Friday morning fourball matches; six foursome matches; and a combination session of two foursome and four fourball matches, all to be completed, weather permitting, by midday Sunday. The traditional 12 singles matches will follow. Players who sat out Friday's fourball matches will play only three matches. All 12 players will play the next two sessions, and singles.

Moviegoers seeking early looks at Hollywood's latest action and science-fiction franchise films or just a place to dress as their favorite member of the X-Men can continue to look forward to gathering in San Diego each summer. Comic-Con International, the collectibles convention that has grown into an annual must-attend event for the makers and consumers of fantasy entertainment and pop culture, said on Friday that it would remain in San Diego through 2015, The San Diego Union Tribune reported. The convention, which drew 300 attendees when it started in 1970 and now attracts more than 130,000 people to the city and $163 million to the local economy each year, was set to have its contract with the San Diego Convention Center expire in 2012. Tourism officials in Anaheim and Los Angeles had been trying to steer the convention to their cities, amid concerns that it had outgrown the San Diego Convention Center and that local hotels were inflating their rates during their event. The Union Tribune said 64 San Diego hotels in the vicinity of the convention center had committed to discounted rates through 2015, and convention organizers were persuaded to remain in the city without the use of adamantium claws or optic blasts.

When the Wildlife Conservation Society recently discovered another beaver living in the Bronx River - the first to be spotted there in three years, and only the second in two centuries - it did the neighborly thing and asked local residents to help name the floppy-haired, buck-toothed little critter. And when the Bronx Zoo opened the competition to online voting, it all but guaranteed the end result: ladies and gentlemen, say hello to Justin Beaver. On Friday the Wildlife Conservation Society said ''the overwhelming majority of the votes'' in a poll at bronxzoo.com were cast for the name ''Justin Beaver,'' almost certainly inspired by Justin Bieber, the 16-year-old pop singer and sometime ''CSI'' star. Justin -- the beaver, not the Bieber -- joins his companion Jose the beaver, who was discovered near the Bronx Zoo in early 2007 and named for Representative Jose E. Serrano, Democrat of the Bronx.

There has never been much that could be called a frontier at corner of 39th Street and Third Avenue. There was once an elevated train line there, but these days, no demarcation of neighborhood or mood can be discerned. Yet that is where the Frontier Coffee Shop stood since 1976, an East Side restaurant with a Wild West name, serving a thick-book diner menu to booths full of regulars and tourists who could watch the passing traffic through its immense windows.

Dish Network subscribers are caught in the middle of a dispute between the company and the News Corporation over the fees paid to carry channels. On Friday, FX, the National Geographic Channel and Fox's regional sports networks had disappeared from Dish. In dueling statements, Fox Networks claimed that Dish ''decided to no longer carry Fox Networks cable programming,'' while Dish claimed that Fox Networks was ''blocking'' access to the channels. During the impasse Dish said that it would make the NFL Network, Big Ten Network and many other regional sports channels available.

For Republican candidates, the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, is a favorite target these days - a San Francisco liberal and leader of the Democratic incumbents whom the insurgent, resurgent G.O.P. challengers want to oust. But as vilified as she may be at times, Ms. Pelosi is planning an aggressive itinerary to raise money for individual Democratic candidates and for her party in the closing weeks of the campaign. This weekend, Ms. Pelosi will speak at fund-raisers for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in New York and Los Angeles, according to her office. She will then attend committee fund-raising dinners with President Obama on Oct. 11 in Coral Gables, Fla., and on Oct. 23 in Minneapolis, and one with Michelle Obama in San Francisco on Oct. 25.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Thursday about Arthur Penn, the film and stage director, described incorrectly a play he directed on Broadway, ''Golda,'' starring Anne Bancroft as Golda Meir. While it initially played to near-sellout audiences, it closed after 93 performances when illness forced Ms. Bancroft to drop out. It was not considered a financial success. (Go to Article)

Sharron Angle, the Republican candidate for Senate from Nevada, faces a number of obstacles in her attempt to defeat Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader and perhaps the top target of Republicans this year. High among them is the fact that the November ballot includes an official Tea Party candidate, Scott Ashjian, who clearly threatens to draw votes away from Ms. Angle in what is shaping up to be a very tight race with Mr. Reid. (This despite the fact that Ms. Angle has the support of much of the national Tea Party).

In his column today, Tom Friedman quotes Lewis Mumford on the decline of Rome, and applies it to ourselves. It's a common trope, and I don't have any problem with Tom using it. But I do think we should be aware that the Roman Empire was a very different kind of society from anything existing in the modern world, and that when someone draws morals from Rome's decline, the reality of Rome almost never comes into the thing.

One of my most frequent reader questions is, "Can I use Facebook Chat without specific people seeing that I am online? I don't want those people to bother me." I answered this question last year, but Facebook has recently changed its chat interface to allow more selective filtering. Still, there are details to which you should pay attention, lest you accidentally reveal yourself to the very people from whom you're trying to hide.

Andy Van Slyke, a former major league outfielder, once joked that a movie made about him would be named "The Summer of 4-to-3." But first comes his first novel, "The Curse," written with the St. Louis sportswriter Rob Rains, in which the Cubs are churning toward their first World Series since 1945 before fate intervenes. So much for suspension of disbelief. In Van Slyke's version of Chicago tragedy, the charter plane carrying the first-place Cubs crashes, killing the entire organization except for two players. The team is a patchwork of players from other teams who soldier on together, while the crash becomes a backdrop whodunit. Clue: it isn't Steve Bartman.

Chase Cohl, the singer-songwriter turned accessories maven behind the Littledoe label, went into design on a whim. The craft fanatic sourced vintage materials to make herself a floral headband; it caught the attention of her friends, who urged her to go into business. Any fears she may have had were quelled during the shoot for her first look book, when a chance meeting with the singer Fergie led to two of her pieces being purchased on the spot. Cohl incorporates gems, crystals and feathers into her work, making it all very Lady of the Canyon, a nostalgic take on '60s southern California that has found fans among latter-day bohemians like Kate Hudson and the Olsen twins. Her crystal necklaces range from $300 to $400, while the hand-stitched custom headdresses that are her calling card start at $300. Since the company's humble beginnings a little over two years ago, Cohl has graduated from college (she studied Native American poetry) and is now spending more time in Los Angeles. ''I love New York,'' she explains, ''but we weren't getting along too well.''

DUBINER--Jack, 91, on September 7, peacefully surrounded by family. Devoted husband of 63 years to Florence (Falek). Beloved father of David (Cynthia) of Gainesville, and Dr. Karen of New York. Caring grandfather of Rachel Dubiner, and Anni and Simon Turkel. Son of the late Oscar and Yetta (Jancko). Brother of the late Louis and Ruth (Zaber). Step-son and -brother of the late Shirley (Schwartz) and children, Dolores Hodesblatt and Jerome Schwartz. A proud veteran of WWII, Jack was born in the Bronx, and lived in Rockland County for many years, where he was a successful retailer (Ben Franklin Stores) and member of civic associations. Following retirement, he maintained homes in Bloomingburg, NY and Leesburg, FL, before recently moving to Gainesville. Jack's strength of character, work ethic and pragmatism, and generosity toward friends and family have been an inspiration to all who knew and loved him. May he be remembered with affection and rest in peace.

GREEN--Dr. Marvin, prominent New York psychotherapist, mental health administrator, college professor, writer, consultant, and decorated World War II veteran (Bronze Star), died in San Francisco on September 22, after a short illness, at the age of 92. During a long and distinguished career, he maintained for over 30 years a psychotherapy private practice in Valley Stream, NY. He served as Mental Health Commissioner for the Borough of Queens, Executive Administrative Director of the South Shore Child Guidance Center (Freeport, NY), Chief of the Community Services Division of the New York City Housing Authority, Executive Director of the Mental Health Association of Westchester County (where he devised some of the first live telethons for fund raising), Executive Director of the Queens Division of the American Jewish Congress, National Program Department Director for the National Council of Jewish Women. As a consultant to the New York City Board of Education's Community Education Bureau, he pioneered a number of innovative programs to combat juvenile delinquency using Caribbean steel drums and sports figures as role models. He was a longtime Adjunct Professor in the Sociology Department of Nassau Community College. He received his Ph.D. from NYU, his M.S.W. from Columbia University, and his B.S. from City College. Born to poverty in Newark in a broken home, he grew up in the East Village and the Lower East Side of New York. He was a Diplomat in Clinical Social Work of the National Association of Social Workers, a Life Fellow of the American Orthopsychiatric Association, the American Sociological Society, and a Board Examiner in several fields. A tireless advocate for human and civil rights, while serving as President of the Valley Stream District 13 Board of Education, he was contacted by President Kennedy to organize support for the civil rights movement. His publications are diverse, ranging from essays on group dynamics in anthologies to opinion pieces on conformity for the NY Herald Tribune. He wrote regular book reviews for the journal of the American Orthopsychiatric Association. As a consultant, he journeyed to China (where he observed the treatment of the institutionalized mentally ill), to the Soviet Union (where he observed group education and treatment methods) and to the emerging nation of Jamaica (where he advised officials on plans for group development of underprivileged youth). He was a decorated veteran of World War II (Bronze Star medal): during the Battle of the Bulge, he administered medical aid and performed an amputation under fire, saving the lives of his comrades (while he sustained injuries). His son, Dr. Geoffrey Green, his daughter-in-law, Dr. Marcia Green, and numerous nephews and nieces survive him. His son, Arne, and his wife, Martha, predecease him. The unveiling and an informal commemoration of his life will be held October 10 at 3pm at The Sanctuary at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, 7800 Myrtle Avenue, Glendale, NY. 718.821.0200. RSVP to: marvingreenmemorial@gmail.com

You might expect a personal butler at a posh London address. But you might actually need one in Lhasa, Tibet, elevation 11,975 feet. If so, the St. Regis Lhasa Resort is opening on Nov. 15, becoming the first luxury chain to open an outpost in the Tibetan capital. The butler will be on hand to address altitude sickness as well as less urgent tasks like shining shoes and suggesting monasteries to visit. Such service is among the many amenities uncharacteristic of lodging in the area.Other features include guest rooms furnished with vintage photographs, plasma TVs, DVD players and high-speed Internet access. The resort, which offers views of the Potala Palace, also has three restaurants: an upscale Tibetan dining room that serves local dishes including yak, a Chinese one featuring Cantonese and Sichuan food, and an all-day restaurant touting international fare, including egg-and-bacon breakfasts. Rare, aged blends highlight menus in both the wine bar and the tea room.

HARRIS--Charles E. III. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's Board of Trustees, faculty and administration mourn the passing of Charles E. Harris, III. Charlie and his wife, Susan have been generous and enthusiastic supporters of the research and educational programs at the Laboratory for many years. Elected to the Board of Trustees in 1998, Charlie graciously served on the Investment, Audit, Development and Research Committees and was a founder of the President's Council. His leadership, keen intellect, and gentle manner were valued by all at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. He will be greatly missed. To his family and many friends, we express our deepest sympathies. Eduardo G. Mestre, Board Chairman Bruce Stillman, President James D. Watson, Chancellor Emeritus W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer

DAKAR, Senegal -- A day after car bombs ripped through Nigeria's independence day celebrations in the capital, Abuja, killing at least 12 people, a former senior leader of the militant group that claimed responsibility has been arrested, Nigerian officials said Saturday. The former leader, Henry Okah, of the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta, was arrested in South Africa, a senior government official and a spokeswoman for Nigeria's State Security Service said.

Albert Watson's eye rarely rests on one thing for long. For over four decades, he has refused to settle in one camp, allowing the breadth of his vision and the variety of his work to take in the worlds of fashion, portraiture and reportage. Likewise his sittings have ranged from supermodels to prisoners, from athletes to aristocrats. Add to the list advertising campaigns for clients like Prada, Estee Lauder, Revlon and Gap and it's not hard to see why he is considered such an elastic virtuoso. The graphic intensity and epic intention of Watson's images are now on display in ''UFO: Unified Fashion Objectives'' (Abrams; $135), a retrospective book of what he considers his best work. (Images from ''UFO'' are also on show at Hasted Hunt Kraeutler, 537 W. 24th Street, from October 21.) While some of his subject matter has been relegated to the cultural periphery, Watson's ability to dazzle the eye and transcend the immediacy of his art form endure. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

THE easy way to take delivery of my 2011 BMW 128i would have been to make a 45-minute train ride from my home in Queens to the dealership in Huntington, on Long Island. I chose the not-so-easy way: Queens to Huntington, via Munich. In the end, picking up the BMW twice -- first at the company's cavernous delivery center in Munich and again five weeks later at the showroom where I had made the actual purchase -- let me experience the emotional kicks of BMW's European delivery program. Similar opportunities are offered by a handful of European automakers.
The 36 Hours column last Sunday, about Chicago, contained several errors. The well-known shopping district along Michigan Avenue is the Magnificent Mile, not the Miracle Mile.

PALERMO and San Telmo may have the cool factor in Buenos Aires, but the Recoleta neighborhood remains the magnet for upscale boutiques and hotels, like the new Algodon Mansion, a 1912 town house with 10 sleek suites. The floors are ebony, the furniture is high-end Italian, and the expansive use of marble and limestone in the bathrooms gives them a look of a Baroque mausoleum. The Royal Suites, starting at $1,815 a night, come with a personal chef, a baby grand piano, a wine tasting set and pajamas. A pool and a cocktail lounge share the roof with the 95degrees Spa. But why stint? You can also rent out the entire place for about $20,000 a day. ROCKY CASALE
Film Mike Hale

WANDERMAN--Sidney, Elian M.D.,September 7, 1910 -- September 29, 2010. A native of Manhattan, he practiced medicine in that borough for over 50 years. Born in a tenement on Orchard St., the son of Helen Toft and Fischel Wanderman and the brother of Florence, Ann and Rosalie Wanderman, all deceased. He was married twice: to Thelma Eisenberg Wanderman (divorced, deceased), and for 57 years to Jeannette Boskoff Wanderman, who predeceased him in 2006. A graduate of Stuyvesant High School, NYU and New York Medical College, he was on the staff of Beth Israel Hospital, Mt. Sinai Hospital and the Metropolitan Hospital. He was a Fellow of the International College of Surgeons, the International Proctologic Society and the New York Colon and Rectal Society. He wrote two books about Proctology: "The Hemorrhoid Book" and "Hemorrhoids". He was a flight surgeon in WWII, retiring as a Lt. Colonel, and was recipient of the prestigious Soldier's Medal. Survived by his loving daughters Lisa Wanderman Gottlieb (Paul), Marcia Wanderman Brill (William, deceased), granddaughter Robin Davis (David), and grandson Tony Brill (Mindy). Services to be held Sunday October 3, at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 2nd Ave. and 20th St. at 11am. Contributions can be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association.

THE SON ALSO RISES ''If you wanted to,'' says Barnaba Fornasetti, ''you could easily live in a Fornasetti world.'' As the only son of Piero Fornasetti, he knows of what he speaks. Often referred to as the ''designer of dreams,'' Piero was nothing if not prolific. The application of his fanciful patterns and simple, classically inspired illustrations knew no boundaries, and his fertile imagination conjured up objects, clothing and furniture, including the iconic Trumeau-bar, a combination sideboard, bar and bureau, originally designed with the architect Gio Ponti and still in production today. The Fornasetti archive, which holds about 13,000 pieces -- some of which are shown in ''Fornasetti: The Complete Universe,'' out this month from Rizzoli -- is said to be one of the largest of its kind. After Piero's death in 1988, Barnaba took over the dream factory, which by then was something of a nightmare. ''When he died, the company was drowning in debt,'' says Barnaba, who like his father, was born an artist, not a businessman. But his creativity has served him well. Today he heads a team of 20 working out of his home and atelier in the Città Studi neighborhood of Milan, in a house built by Piero's father. The laboratory for his father's wildest creations is now Barnaba's treasure box.
The ultimate conversation piece.

Skirt lengths are in flux. Some designers are showing longer lengths for spring during the shows taking place right now. As women change into autumn dresses for luncheons, the predominant length is mid-knee. Other women are not relinquishing their above-the-knee skirts. And then there is a group already experimenting with calf-length skirts, which have no relationship to the street-sweepers of summer. One woman, at right, couldn't make up her mind. Shoes continue to be highly creative. And if the prospect of lowered hems doesn't bother you, what about fingerless gloves?

Fashion shows tend to cover every contingency, so it's not unusual to see leather and dark colors in the spring collections. But, this season, I bet we've seen more leather motorcycle jackets than bikinis. (In fact, where are those bathing suits and caftans?) Burberry was the first show to focus on leather biker jackets and trench coats with quilted leather sleeves. Even though Christopher Bailey always offers a wide range of outerwear - mainly to reflect Burberry's heritage - people were nonetheless struck by the amount of studded leather in his spring 2011 show. The company was also making pieces available for immediate online sales, with delivery in about two months. If you live in New York, your jacket would arrive just as the weather was turning cold - not when the tulips are popping up.

The British painter David Hockney has never confined himself to just one artistic medium. (Remember the Polaroid collages?) True to form, he was quick to embrace the iPhone's Brushes app, among others. Even as he was working on large-scale landscapes of his native Yorkshire, England -- for a big 2012 exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London -- Hockney was drawing energetic, vividly colored images of flowers, places and people at screen scale, which he e-mails to friends. These, along with his drawings on the iPad, are the subject of ''David Hockney: Fleurs Fraîches,'' which runs from Oct. 20 to Jan. 30, 2011, at the Pierre Bergé-Yves Saint Laurent Foundation in Paris. Curated by Charlie Scheips and designed by the New York architect Ali Tayar of Parallel Design, the exhibition will present the artwork in its original digital format, including animations of one or more works. (Brushes records the process of a painting in video.) The iPhones and iPads themselves will be set into fiberboard panels like the ones that line Hockney's studio, and Tayar is even designing special furniture for the installation -- which Scheips says ''won't look like an Apple store. It will be more homey.'' The act of iPainting seems no less immediate for its lack of actual pigments; Scheips says Hockney becomes so immersed that he stops to wipe off his fingers. PILAR VILADAS

On Wednesday, the eve of the Paris auto show, Jaguar unveiled a gas-electric hybrid two-seat sports car concept that the automaker says is capable of a top speed of 205 miles per hour, and up to 68 miles of all-electric operation. The exotic-looking C-X75 concept, so designated in honor of Jaguar's 75th anniversary this year, ''explores the outer limits of both performance and sustainability,'' the company said in a news release.
Above the fray

When designers make gallery pieces, you get sculptural chairs and charred chandeliers. But when artists create furniture, even the pretense of functionality disappears, leading to weird works like homoerotic bunk beds and chandeliers, like the one by Lee Bul (below), that don't light up. These are the kinds of conceptually charged objects cataloged in ''The New Décor,'' the book based on a recent exhibition at the Hayward Gallery in London and traveling to the Garage in Moscow this month. Their purpose is not to elevate the trappings of domestic life but to question our very faith in them. ''Contemporary artists are associating the home with a sense of movement, insecurity and precariousness,'' says the Hayward's director, Ralph Rugoff. ''Rather than being a castle, home is a vulnerable place now.'' While the more absurd pieces -- like a giant hot-pink papier-mâché phallus bench by Franz West -- explore our private space as a kind of public theater, others are more obviously unsettling. The Swiss artist Fabrice Gygi's tented writing desk is somewhere between a child's fort and a bomb shelter, and Jin Shi's Chinese migrant worker's dwelling is a chilling reminder of how the other half lives. MONICA KHEMSUROV

I was buying a jumbo pack of diapers. Instead of ''Alex Kuczynski,'' I wrote ''Snooki'' with a heart over the ''i.'' The clerk stared at her screen gummy-eyed and handed me my receipt and diapers.

BAER--Edward of Yorktown Heights, died September 20 after a long and courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 53. Mr. Baer was born in Brooklyn on June 25, 1957. He graduated from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law and earned a B.A. from SUNY Oneonta. Known for his rigorous and combative intellect, Eddy was a devoted husband and father and an accomplished litigator who enjoyed life passionately. Ed was a partner at the New York City law firm of Belkin Burden Wenig & Goldman, LLP and trial counsel on some of the most significant cases in landlord-tenant court. He was co-chair of the Landlord-Tenant Proceedings Committee of the New York State Bar Association and a member of the Executive Committee of the Real Property Law Section. Eddy is survived by his wife Donna, children Lindsay and Benjamin; parents Ralph and Terry, sister Randye. Donations may be made in his memory to The Lustgarten Foundation.

JAIME GROSS The writer Jaime Gross lives in the Mission District of San Francisco, where marijuana is no longer taboo. ''If a cop saw someone smoking a joint outside of a cafe and someone riding a bike on the sidewalk, he'd go after the guy on the bike,'' she says. Still, Gross was surprised to happen upon ''a girl who looked like she could work at Banana Republic'' giving a tutorial on a volcano vaporizer. That's business as usual at Sparc, a sleek medical-marijuana dispensary designed by Sand Studios (''Splendor in the Grass,'' Page 50). A former editor at Travel & Leisure, Gross recently joined the staff of Dwell, the Bay Area design magazine. ''I have an eye for things,'' she says, ''but a flea-market budget.''

a designer's oeuvre from soup to nuts Given his fondness for gastronomy, one has to wonder how the designer Patrick Jouin manages to stay so svelte. For the past decade, Jouin, 43, has been collaborating with the Michelin-starred chef Alain Ducasse on numerous projects, including the PastaPot for Alessi and the chic interiors for Ducasse's restaurants at the Plaza Athénée in Paris and the Dorchester in London. ''Patrick Jouin: Design and Gesture,'' which opens Nov. 9 at the Museum of Arts and Design, will showcase his culinary product designs, complete with video sequences that illustrate their functions. Other items include Jouin's sleek stainless steel Zermatt flatware for Puiforcat, plastic Champagne bucket for G. H. Mumm and carbon fiber chairs for Le Jules Verne, the restaurant in the Eiffel Tower. ''My products are not related,'' Jouin said before acknowledging that ''they all come from the same pencil.'' Pieces like his Optic storage cubes for Kartell and C2 Solid chair for MGX will also be on view, along with the light he designed for the museum lobby (right). Designing, it seems, burns a lot of calories. MELISSA FELDMAN

BOSTON -- The first 161 games were not enough. The American League East title will come down to the final day of the regular season, the Yankees' third game in 24 hours. Maximizing the drama from a captivating season-long race with Tampa Bay, the Yankees, after splitting a doubleheader Saturday with the Red Sox, are tied atop the division with the Rays. Only one scenario -- a victory combined with a Rays loss -- will give the Yankees the division championship and home-field advantage throughout the A.L. playoffs. If the Yankees and Tampa Bay finish in a tie, the Rays will win the title because they won the season series. After beating the Red Sox, 6-5, in 10 innings, the Yankees committed four errors, then blew a two-run lead in the eighth and lost, 7-6, in the second game on a 10th-inning single by Eric Patterson off Ivan Nova at 1:22 a.m.

People who live in glass houses should employ really good window washers. This is one of many impressions left by ''Points on a Line,'' a film by the artist Sarah Morris that explores the intersecting histories (and upkeep requirements) of Mies van der Rohe's Farnsworth House and Philip Johnson's Glass House. Commissioned for the National Trust for Historic Preservation's ''Modern Views'' project, the film gets much of its star power from the architecture, but Morris gives the life in and around it a part, too. Up for best supporting role: the duck that ''guards'' the entrance to van der Rohe's Lake Shore Drive towers in Chicago. ''The custodians of these buildings are pretty territorial,'' Morris said. Go to sothebys.com/modernviews. SANDRA BALLENTINE

PATTERSON--William J. SPO Partners & Co. mourns the passing of Bill Patterson, whose extraordinary intelligence, confidence and leadership permeated our firm from the first day he joined us. Since founding the firm with John H. Scully and William E. Oberndorf in 1991, Bill helped lead a number of extremely successful investments and the firm's assets grew from $40 million to over $8 billion. At the time of his death, he served as a Managing Director of SPO Partners, Chairman of the Board of Calpine Corporation and was a director of Rosewood Hotels and Resorts. He was a former board member of the Plum Creek Timber Company, where he played an instrumental role in the repositioning and growth of that business. Bill's passion for excellence and hard work coupled with his warmth and core humanitarian instincts made him truly inspirational to the many he touched. He is, simply stated, irreplaceable. We extend our condolences to his family and friends.

The Austrian crystal maker Swarovski has built up a Gibraltar-size reputation for matchmaking the unexpected with the dazzling in fashion and design. What started with a radical rethink of the chandelier -- Tord Boontje's crystal dew-crusted branch, Ron Arad's interactive L.E.D. spiral -- has now expanded to include jewelry by superstars like Karl Lagerfeld and Zaha Hadid. This fall comes Kryptonite, Atelier Swarovski's latest jewelry collection, by the New York architecture firm Hariri and Hariri. More than statement pieces, these oversize rocks are a manifesto against timid ornamentation. ''We weren't interested in making fake diamonds,'' said Gisue Hariri, who, with her sister Mojgan, took a geological approach. Their inspiration was the firm's design for a condominium carved out of a mountain in Salzburg, Austria. ''We wanted to create jewelry with an added dimension.'' In fact, the sisters worked with Swarovksi to invent a boldly asymmetrical shape. Made in Italy, the collection ($380 to $870) includes a necklace, choker, cuff, ring and belt, each piece cradled in planed silver for a sumptuously futuristic look JULIE V. IOVINE

A review on Sept. 19 about ''The Elephant's Journey,'' by José Saramago, misstated the book's publishing history. Though the translation under review appeared only last month, it is not a ''new posthumous novel''; it was published in the original Portuguese in 2008 (Saramago died in June of this year). The error was repeated in the Editors' Choice column last Sunday.

Richard Goldstein, an author and historian of the Second World War who has been our guest expert on City Room this week, provided the following second batch of answers to readers' questions. A third and final set of answers about all aspects of New York and the war will be posted on Monday; the first set can be read here. Q.I was born in Brooklyn in 1941 and have vivid memories of the war far beyond what one would expect from someone so young -- I take that as evidence of how deeply involved New York City was in the war.

THE NEWS President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia ousted Moscow's longtime mayor, who had tried in recent weeks to cast Mr. Medvedev as a weakling unfit to run the Kremlin. BEHIND THE NEWS Mr. Medvedev's decision to sack Yuri M. Luzhkov seemed intended to show that he was an assertive leader and viable candidate for president in 2012. (Vladimir V. Putin, the former president and current prime minister, has refused to say whether he will run for his old job.) An alternative view held that Mr. Medvedev had taken too long to dismiss Mr. Luzhkov.

As afternoon shadows lengthen, residents of Mumbai flock to Juhu Beach, trading the congestion and noise of this surging city for the open space and breezes off the Arabian Sea. Children play cricket on the sand, while families line up for classic Mumbai snacks like bhel puri at beachside stands. Just ashore from the lengthy beach, Juhu's streets become especially crowded on weekend evenings, with traffic headed to top-notch seafood restaurants along with newly renovated hotels and their upscale bars. The neighborhood has long been home to a slice of Bollywood royalty. But lately, there's much more than just stars and sand. DAN PACKEL GADDA DA VIDA [ Hotel Novotel Juhu Beach Balraj Sahani Marg (91-22) 6693-4444 At night, this pool- side lounge fills with men in designer jeans and women in spa- ghetti-strap dresses. But it's at its casual best from 6 to 8 p.m. -- drinks are two for one, and only sand and sea get in the way of sunset.

Rolling Up TARP, Though the Cleanup Isn't OverON Sunday, the Treasury Department officially loses its ability to make new commitments under the Troubled Asset Relief Program. Thegovernment created the bailout fund -- originally set at $700 billion and lowered to $475 billion by the Dodd-Frank Act in July -- to aid troubled companies and to bring stability to the economy at the height of the financial crisis two years ago.While the program has essentially expired, much remains to be resolved. Despite repayments of $200 billion by nearly 100 companies, more than $180 billion is outstanding, mostly concentrated among 616 banks, twoaautomakers and the troubled insurance giant A.I.G. And the Treasury still has the authority to spend up to $46 billion to help homeowners facing foreclosure -- money that would not be reclaimed.But the Treasury is optimistic that the bulk of the outstanding money will be returned and that profits -- nearly $27 billion so far from interest, dividend payments and the sale of warrants -- will mostly offset any losses.Last week, the Treasury even announced that its commitments to A.I.G. -- at one point projected to cost taxpayers up to $50 billion -- might actually make money in the end, though that remains speculative. Indeed, the Congressional panel that overseesTARP, and will continue to do so through next April, suggested in a recent report that cost estimates should be taken with a grain of salt.''The panel is very pleased with the improvements we have seen with the cost projections for TARP, but the public needs to understand that these calculations are complicated and involve a lot of assumptions,'' Damon Silvers, the deputy chairman of the panel, said on Friday. ''The numbers could get better or they could get worse.''

I am waiting, more or less patiently, in the right lane of the southbound Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, crawling toward the exit for the Brooklyn Bridge. A maroonish blur zooms by on my left, and I take a deep breath, already guessing what I'll see: the car, at the last possible minute, slows down and nudges into the line, right up by the exit. Suddenly, the stentorian voice of James Earl Jones booms from a megaphone affixed to my car: ''I saw what you did, driver of the burgundy PT Cruiser. You should be ashamed of yourself. You cut in front of this line of decent citizens, waiting their turn. Who do you think you are?''

If there were any further proof required of the much-vaunted convergence of the worlds of art, fashion and celebrity, the model-actress Jerry Hall is about to sell part of her art collection at Sotheby's and simultaneously launch her new book, ''My Life in Pictures'' (Quadrille Publishing) - all to coincide with London's ''Frieze week'' in mid-October. Both the auction and the book reveal Hall's connoisseurship and her close relationships with distinguished artists. Best known as the supermodel who epitomized 1970s glamour, as the former wife of Mick Jagger and as an actress with a decade of treading the boards on Broadway and the West End, Hall is now bringing to the surface another role she has played since she arrived in Paris from Gonzales, Tex., at age 16 - the role of muse.

To the Editor: Freda Moon's attempt in ''Twain's Nicaragua, 144 Years Later'' (Sept. 19) to retrace Twain's journey through southern Nicaragua would have been more complete if she had finished the trip down the Rio San Juan instead of stopping for lunch at the tourist restaurant in El Castillo. Tourists from the nearby lodges and tarpon fishermen from Costa Rica tour Greytown, visit the old cemetery, see the old rail line, marvel at the short segment of aborted canal and photograph the rusting dredge in Greytown harbor. The people of the town might argue that the assessment that ''Greytown surrendered long ago to the jungle's relentless en- croachment'' is a bit disingenuous. In 1984 Greytown was destroyed for the second time (the first by the United States warship Cyane in 1854) in a Sandinista battle with Contra forces supported by the C.I.A. Land mines, bomb craters, unexploded ordnance and the ghosts of the dead had a lot more to do with moving Greytown up the river than did that pesky jungle. PETER H. DANA, PH.D. Austin, Tex.

IN 1951, a decade before Wayne Thiebaud became famous for his still lifes of cakes and pies, he had his first one-man museum show at the Crocker Art Museum in Sacramento, where he had recently moved. The Crocker has been closely linked to the artist ever since, mounting several large solo exhibitions of his work over the years and letting him riffle through its storage rooms for inspiration. Now, with the museum reopening on Oct. 10 after a major expansion, Mr. Thiebaud is returning the favor with a gift: his new painting ''River Intersection,'' based on the snaking waterways and cultivated fields of the Sacramento River Delta. Since the mid-1990s, when he began a series devoted to this landscape, Mr. Thiebaud has found the palette and patterns offered by the delta region to be a rich source of inspiration. He began the painting by walking around the fields and levees -- sometimes climbing them to get higher vantage points -- and making sketches and studies that he later reconfigured from memory back in the studio. '' 'River Intersection' tries to express various seasons, various times of the day, various vantage points, and then tries to get the thing to come together like a whole,'' he said. ''For me, painting has a lot to do with the exercise of empathy, where you have to believe that you're walking the path or under the trees, that you are somehow able to transfer yourself into that picture.''

When I was young my mum used to complain that I spent too much time daydreaming. That was because I liked to stare at the sky. She thought that while I was dreaming I could be doing something useful as well, like knitting. Now that I am a writer, I have the privilege of daydreaming as part of my job. And I still love to gaze at the sky. The view from my workroom in my North London house has a lot of sky, and I couldn't work without it. There are never any structured thoughts in my head when I look up. They just come and go and change shape like the clouds. I have a wonderful view of Alexandra Palace. This is not a royal palace but a 19th-century leisure center for exhibitions and events -- a people's palace, known locally as ''Ally Pally.'' It was the place from which the world's first regularly scheduled television transmissions were broadcast, in the 1930s, and the famous antenna is still there. Below it I can see the doors of the studios where modern television began, and I find that thrilling. The palace is still a venue for the occasional exhibition, but mostly it just sits there on the hill, waiting for someone to find a good use for it in this information age.

Architype/ (är$(4$) ke tip) / n. / A design neologism that refers to the character of a house or a building, not to mention the personalities of the people who inhabit it, as in, ''My boyfriend would be content to dwell in a cave, while I am a modernist at heart. We could never live under the same roof; he's simply not my architype.'' ALIX BROWNE

Q.My family of five is planning to rent a house in the Cotswolds at Christmas. We would like to travel to different places like Bath and Oxford and even to London for the day. None of us is confident enough to drive. Would you please suggest a village that is centrally located and would accommodate train and bus travel? - Eleanor Seitter, ChicagoA.Public transportation in the Cotswolds is scarce, but if you plan and base yourself in a well-connected town, you shouldn't have a problem. In an e-mail, Henry Shukman, who grew up in the area and is a contributor to The Times Travel section, recommended the larger towns of Cheltenham or Cirencester, easily accessible by train (nationalrail.co.uk) from other parts of Britain. To Cheltenham, from Paddington Station in London, you may have to change trains at Bristol or Swindon; to Cirencester, take a train to Kemble (four miles southwest) and then change to a bus. Both towns offer train or bus service - or a combination of both - to Bath and Oxford. Traveline (www.traveline.org.uk) is a source for routes, and for trains and buses to the smaller Cotswolds towns.
