NAIMAN--Lee, died at home on September 30, 2010. Her many close friends and family feel so lucky to have known her and her remarkable spirit. She was born in Baltimore on September 2, 1926, and attended Goucher College. Lee met her husband of 59 years, Dr. Robert Naiman, in Paris. They have three children by birth, Eric, Cara and Tom; three by marriage, Anne Nesbet, Clark Sugg and Marguerite Holloway; and eight grandchildren, Kate, Thera, Caroline, Eleanor, Ada, Sarah, Auden and Julian. Lee is also survived by her brother, Leonard Helfgott, and his family. Lee loved travel, art, music, theater and intense discussion, and inspired her children and grandchildren to embrace the world. She founded the international rental agency At Home Abroad, as well as Tapestry Associates and Lee Naiman Fine Art, collecting and selling works by many artists, including Nevelson, Warhol and Gunter Grass. She was a dedicated board member of Global Kids and NARAL New York. Lee lived her life fully, with great love, generosity and dynamism. She loved pistachio ice cream, yellow tulips, oysters, the human spirit and scrabble. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent in her honor to Global Kids, 137 East 25th Street, New York, NY 10010.

It's been a good year or so for Gio Ponti. Last fall, Rizzoli reprinted a lavish monograph devoted to the staggeringly prolific Italian designer, critic and bon vivant who, before his death at 87 in 1979, founded Domus magazine, created sets for La Scala, brought a touch of playful luxury to the interiors of the Andrea Doria and planted works in every medium in just about every corner of the world. Meanwhile, auction prices for vintage Ponti pieces have been on a winning streak, not unlike the thoroughbred racehorse named after him. Now ''The Expression of Gio Ponti,'' curated by Germano Celant, gives the designer his biggest local showcase since the days of the old Alitalia ticket offices he created at 666 Fifth Avenue. The whopping retrospective, which opens Nov. 13 and is the first exhibition at the brand-new Triennale di Milano design museum in Midtown, includes 250 items, from drawings to majolica to furniture, including the iconic Superleggera chair, which Ponti called, with characteristic flair, ''the chair for all times.'' Classical yet modern, rigorous yet whimsical, Ponti's work conforms to no dogma except his own exhortation to ''make something beautiful!'' MARK ROZZO

POST-PERESTROIKA, Moscow evoked a giant college dormitory gone wild. Free from oppressive and overbearing Soviet leaders, Muscovites set upon their city with freshman-like zeal, indulging in the fruits of capitalism, hangovers be damned. But the current global slowdown, which knocked some of the sparkle out of Russia's economic growth, also appears to have injected a bit of maturity -- and perhaps even some sobriety -- into a city where subtlety once seemed taboo. There is, however, plenty of debauchery left, so bring your tight leather trousers and leopard-print hot pants, if that's your thing. In 1966, the furniture company Stendig commissioned Massimo Vignelli to design a promotional calendar. The result, a 3-foot-by-4-foot black-and-white grid of numbers and letters, was snapped up by the Museum of Modern Art for its permanent collection before a single calendar was printed. And it has been in print ever since, becoming at one point a fixture in the office of architects like Richard Meier, whose books and Web site are also designed by the legendary Vignelli. ''I wouldn't do anything without Massimo,'' Meier insisted. ''We both resolve ideas with a grid.'' For Vignelli -- who, with his wife and partner in Vignelli Associates, Lella, is also known for designs like New York City's 1972 subway map and stacked plastic dinnerware for Heller, and who co-designed the just-opened Vignelli Center for Design Studies at the Rochester Institute of Technology -- the calendar is an exercise in white space (or black; random pages of the calendars are reverse-printed). ''For us, the space outside the type is more important than the type itself,'' he said. Vignelli also designed a smaller version of the calendar, which he wishes was still in production. ''Some people don't have room for the large one,'' he explained. But no matter: even if Vignelli doesn't receive royalties for it, he's happy that the big calendar is still in print. ''It's nice to see how fresh it still looks.'' Go to unicahome.com. PILAR VILADAS

SCHLEIFER--Jack P.,died peacefully at home in Manhattan on September 25 at the age of 96. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Born in Poland, he came to the USA in 1922. He attended CCNY and became a CPA in 1941. His life long career in Real Estate Investment began in 1954, specializing in Hotels, Ballparks and Shopping Centers. Real Estate Weekly recently chose him as their "Man of the Week", the same honor he had received exactly 50 years previously. He was married for 42 years to his beloved wife Geraldine Schleifer who predeceased him. He later married Marjorie Minskoff Schleifer who also predeceased him. He is survived by his beloved daughter Natalie Schleifer; his sisters Gloria and Joan; his brother Daniel Schleifer predeceased him, grandchildren Rachel, Geraldine, William; and great-grandson Mazin; step-daughter Jean Minskoff Grant; step-daughters Deva and Danielle; step-grandsons Michael and Richard Sands; his family will be receiving visitors on Sunday October 3 from 2 to 5pm at his home in Manhattan.

Entering the final day of the regular season, none of the playoff matchups have been set. Wins by the Rays and the Yankees on Saturday ensured that the American League East winner and the A.L. wild card would be determined Sunday. But the situation in the National League is more complicated: two playoff spots are left, and three teams have the chance to claim them. San Francisco needed to win only one game this weekend to clinch the N.L. West, but the Giants lost the first two to the Padres, cutting their lead in the division to one. The Padres' two wins, combined with two Braves losses, resulted in a tie in the N.L. wild-card standings. Here is a look at how Sunday could play out, with the Braves playing the Phillies at 1:35 p.m. Eastern and the Giants hosting the Padres at 4:05 p.m. Eastern: IF BRAVES AND GIANTS WIN The Giants will win the N.L. West and the Braves will have the wild card.

In a season marked by clean, tailored lines and a neutral color palette, the third and latest offering from Uniqlo's +J collection, designed by the purist's purist Jil Sander, feels more appropriate than ever. A crisp white shirt with a perfectly conceived collar (not straight, not quite a Peter Pan), ribbed cable-knit sweaters without the waist-expanding bulk, and the only suit you'll need all season (slim, two-button in charcoal wool) are the ingredients to a seamless fall wardrobe. Wear the pieces individually or layered on top of one another to get the maximum out of a minimalist look. With prices ranging from $20 to $230, it's doubtful the clothes will be in store much past next Thursday's release date. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Andy Van Slyke, a former major league outfielder, once joked that a movie made about him would be named ''The Summer of 4-to-3.'' But first comes his first novel, ''The Curse,'' written with the St. Louis sportswriter Rob Rains, in which the Cubs are churning toward their first World Series since 1945 before fate intervenes. So much for suspension of disbelief. In Van Slyke's version of Chicago tragedy, the charter plane carrying the first-place Cubs crashes, killing the entire organization except for two players. The team is a patchwork of players from other teams who soldier on together, while the crash becomes a backdrop whodunit. Clue: it isn't Steve Bartman. (Nickelodeon) STICKS, STONES AND CYBERSLAMS As suicides in the wake of bullying increase, and with as many as 60 percent of middle-school students saying they have been tormented by their peers, ''Nick News With Linda Ellerbee'' meets with victims and their aggressors to discuss the epidemic and what can be done to stop it. Among the cases examined by Ms. Ellerbee, center above, are those of Carl Walker Hoover, who hanged himself at age 11 after becoming the target of gay slurs, and Jon Carmichael, who hanged himself at 13 after being picked on because of his short stature. Other participants include Emma, a 17-year-old from South Hadley, Mass., where, in 2010, Phoebe Prince, a 15-year-old transfer student from Ireland, committed suicide after being relentlessly taunted about her sexual history. And then there is Maria, 13, who was suspended for harassing a classmate and has since been part of an anti-bullying program in Atlanta. The program helps girls ''feel better about themselves,'' Maria says. ''I think it helped me a lot.'' She sighs. ''I wish I hadn't bullied that girl.'' 9 A.M. The Samurai Shopper is a master in the civil arts of social encounters, a mannerly person and a lively guest, trading effortless bons mots with newcomers, outsiders, friends and frenemies. But at some point during such festivities, an awkward situation arises. I enter my host's bathroom for a quick freshening of hands or to minister to an urgent function. There is nothing to do but look around the bathroom, noting fixtures, shower curtains, rugs. Some décor is predictably matchy-matchy; some objects are pleasantly marked by habit and custom. The pictures on the wall prompt idle curiosity: what mysterious forces lurk behind this vapid still life or that totemic oddity? And then it happens -- that unwanted glimpse into personal space. The orderly lives of others are laid bare by their toothbrushes, lying moribund with flayed bristles or pocked with Jackson Pollock-like flecks or stuck in cloudy glasses of lowly origin. The charmed atmosphere in the living room is foredoomed by unwanted details. True, what others do behind closed doors is their business. But images confound. They are vivid, indelible, often as welcome as uninvited guests. If our aesthetic reach stops short of our most personal utensils, what does that say? Dirty brushes say a lot. Hair, nail and makeup brushes demand cleanliness and get extra points for style. A dirty toothbrush -- well, who'd want to kiss someone who had just used that?

Go to casatigallery.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE 1. Casati has a soft spot for this $18,000 limestone sculpture (circa 1999) by Angelo Mangiarotti, one of his favorite designers. ''The powerful, sensual shapes of his pieces and the original way he balances and combines them have had a strong impact on me.'' 2. Adam Lewis's new book, ''Billy Baldwin: The Great American Decorator'' (Rizzoli), surveys the life and career of the man whose pared-down versions of the slipper chair and brass bookshelves became famous, and whose work continues to influence designers long after his death in 1983. Baldwin, a charming, well-born native of Baltimore who was the protégé of Ruby Ross Wood (see Lewis's previous book, ''The Great Lady Decorators''), developed a bold, modern style that confidently mixed patterns and periods; he became the go-to decorator for people like Babe Paley, Cole Porter and Diana Vreeland, whose legendary ''garden in hell'' red living room he designed. Baldwin was never afraid of color and is said to have pioneered the use of aubergine walls, in a Maryland house (above) in the 1940s. The book, which has an affectionate foreword by Albert Hadley, Baldwin's former student, is a welcome addition to the two (out-of-print and increasingly expensive) volumes on the decorator's work, ''Billy Baldwin Decorates'' and ''Billy Baldwin Remembers.'' MOSCOW -- Georgi A. Arbatov, who was the senior ''Amerikanist'' in the Soviet Communist Party in the final decades of the cold war and served as the Kremlin's voice for a generation of television viewers in the United States, died here on Friday. He was 87. Mr. Arbatov had cancer, according to his colleagues at the Institute for U.S.A. and Canada Studies in Moscow, which he founded and had directed.

In 1953, the architect Benjamin Thompson (1918-2002) opened a store called Design Research on Brattle Street in Cambridge, Mass. Thompson, a former partner of the Modernist master Walter Gropius, wanted a place where people could buy everything they needed for contemporary living. He made Marimekko dresses and Iittala glasses must-haves, eventually opening stores in New York and San Francisco and designing a striking new glass-and-concrete home for the Cambridge store that opened in 1969. ''The architect's place on this planet,'' he said, ''is to create that special environment where life can be lived to its fullest.'' D/R, as it was known, closed in 1978, but many people, including me, never got over it. The history and influence of D/R are examined in ''Design Research: The Store That Brought Modern Living to American Homes'' (Chronicle), a new book by Jane Thompson and Alexandra Lange. Thompson, a respected urban planner (who won this year's Lifetime Achievement honor at the National Design Awards), is the architect's widow and, after meeting him in the 1960s, worked with him on pioneering projects like Faneuil Hall Marketplace and the South Street Seaport. Lange is a design writer and architectural historian. (See her profile of the toy designer Renate Müller on Page 46.) In their prologue, the authors characterize Design Research as ''a warm, eclectic, colorful and international version of modernism, one that mixed folk art and Mies van der Rohe, Noguchi and no-name Bolivian sweaters, offering newlyweds and Nobel Prize winners one-stop shopping for tools to eat, sleep, dress, even to party in a beautiful way.'' By the time D/R closed (Thompson had lost control of the company eight years earlier), it had attracted a fan club that included Julia Child and Jackie Kennedy, and influenced retailers like Gordon Segal, the founder of Crate & Barrel, and Rob Forbes, who founded Design Within Reach. In his foreword to Thompson and Lange's book, Forbes said that in 2000, when he conducted a customer survey of influential design stores, Design Research came out on top -- and it had been closed for 22 years.

WOLF--Maurice, retired heating contractor, servicing New York City for over 70 years, dies at his home in Sarasota, FL at age 100. Maurice. Wolf was a friend to the environment before it became a cliche. A pioneer in the modern heating industry, he specialized in the analyzation of heating systems for economy and heat conservation. To that end Mr. Wolf designed the Clarke National Oil Burner, and in the late 50's invented a spill-less fuel box. A Heating Contractor from 1934 to 2005. Mo Wolf, as he liked to be called, was instrumental in converting a major part of New York City--50 to 60 thousand residential and commercial buildings -- from coal to fuel oil. He installed heating systems in many of the largest residential and commercial buildings in the City, including Knickerbocker Village, Vandeveer Estates, 330 Seventh Avenue, No. 1 Fifth Avenue, Marble Collegiate Church and St George's Church and West Point. A long time consultant for the Department Of Air Resources, Mr. Wolf was a trustee in Local 32E, the Building Trades Union, for many years. He has the distinction of having the longest held Oil Burner's Installer's License. An avid tennis player from age 10 to 93, Mo Wolf played socially with the likes of Don Budge and Bobby Riggs. Mo graduated UNC Chapel Hill in 1932 Summa Cum Laude with a degree in chemistry. Maurice leaves behind a son, Lawrence P Wolf, ESQ., daughter-in-law Wendy Wolf of Chappaqua, NY, a daughter, Susan Wolf, of East Hills and Sarasota, Florida, two granddaughters Robyn Wolf and Abby Wolf of New York City. Every day of Mo's life was an adventure, whether he was playing tennis, or steering a windjammer or analyzing an oil burner in the bowels of a Manhattan skyscraper or eating oysters on the half shell. He will be missed.

Richard Branson may have started the Virgin Group as a mail order record retailer back in 1970, but it has since extended to include more than 300 branded companies, covering everything from worldwide mobile phone services and Formula 1 racing to space tourism and, most notably, air transportation. The organization recently announced that it will soon make a logical addition to this roster: hotels. The Virgin Hotels group, which debuted its Web site this week, is in the initial stages of acquiring existing properties in North America. The hotels will be midsize -- 150 to 400 rooms, depending on the market -- and will include restaurants and communal public spaces, in the hope of attracting local residents as well as hotel guests.

Imagine one of those glacially chic early-20th-century Modernist interiors. What do you see? White walls and wide windows? Gleaming glass and tubular steel furniture? Constructivist paintings? A natty young woman with fashionably bobbed hair reclining langorously on a leather chaise longue? Whatever you imagined, I'll bet it was in black and white. It's a safe bet, because our perceptions of early Modernism -- at the Bauhaus design school in 1920s Germany, or the purist villas that Le Corbusier was building in France -- are shaped by the photographs taken at the time, and they were all in black and white.
Partners that work well together.

For Dieter Roth, life and art were part of the same messy process. His creative output included a multimedia diary of six months of his life, which he produced for the 1982 Venice Biennale, and cumulative works like ''Gartenskulptur,'' which started out as a self-portrait in chocolate and birdseed and acquired enough collateral material over the course of several years -- various household objects, ladders, television monitors, even a live rabbit in a hutch -- to fill an entire room. Other pieces Roth made used the clothes off his back. From the 1970s until his death in 1998, the German-born Swiss artist lived and worked in cities like Mosfellsbaer, Seydisfjordur, Basel and Vienna, but the one constant, no matter where he set up shop, were his worktables with their protective mats. These sheets of gray cardboard soaked up the life of the studio, some of it deliberate (say, a drawing), some of it accidental (the ring left by a cup of coffee or a glass of water), until they were retired from duty and hung on the wall. Roth's son Björn, who worked by his father's side the last two decades of his life, recalls how even a failed cake for Dieter's 40th birthday -- glorious to look at but ultimately inedible -- became content for a mat when it was spat out after one bite along with gulps of hot cocoa, adding credibility to Roth's theory that art was neither cool nor hot, neither emotional nor intellectual, but simply a smear on something. (That mat was ultimately cut up into postcards; the cake was framed under glass.) Another mat was cut up to fit into a suitcase for transport and then reassembled as a collage. A selection of these ''Tischmatten,'' as they are called, are at Hauser & Wirth in New York from Oct. 6 to 30. Some of them inevitably look like glorified doodles -- the assumption being, perhaps, that every mark the artist makes has equal value, aesthetic or otherwise. The best examples, however, vibrate with the effortless beauty of happenstance. As the Roth scholar Andrea Büttner wrote in the introductory essay to the show's catalog, Roth discovered that ''even covering things up and leaving them alone were strategies that produced a beauty of their own, one that was ultimately more beautiful and more entertaining than pieces that he might previously have labored over.'' ALIX BROWNE

When Bianca and Sierra Casady, the sister act known as CocoRosie, recently performed at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, it was a amid an atmosphere of gypsy celebration complete with miscellaneous congratulatory balloons, a massive video projection, several classical musicians, a French beatbox star and a table full of noise-making children's toys. The duo mostly performed songs from their recent album, "Grey Oceans," but were joined intermittently by the performance artist Kembra Pfahler and the poet Rebecca Wright. Brought back to the stage by thunderous applause and the stamping of feet, the Casadys gleefully treated the audience to not one but two encore sets before embarking on the rest of their tour of the United States.

From Sunday brunch to Shakespeare in the Park, lines are a ubiquitous, frustrating but largely tolerated part of New York life. (This is perhaps why we have our own way of talking about it: "on line" to the rest of the country's "in line.") Lines are also generally treated as sacrosanct: any effort to cut and head directly to the front is usually met with fiercely righteous wrath from all those who have sacrificed the better part of their day for some scarce, coveted item or experience.

Over 100 former members of Congress - many of whom won their own races by pointing out defects in their opponents-- have written to all members of Congress as well as House and Senate candidates, imploring them to reject excessive partisanship as they enter the home stretch of this highly contentious political season.
Once again, Mom was right: clean up your things before you trip on them.

Sundance is going abroad. As part of an effort to foster crosscultural understanding through cinema, the Sundance Institute said on Monday that it would work with a smattering of other nonprofit arts groups to present 10 independent films in New York and at American embassies and other locations overseas. The program, called Film Forward: Advancing Cultural Dialogue, will consist of five American and five international pictures. (Sundance did not announce any titles but likely candidates are films the organization has heralded in the past, like "Winter's Bone," about an Ozark woman's quest to find her drug-dealing father.)
It is going to take more than a two-hour meeting with Citigroup executives to make a believer out of the financial analyst Michael Mayo, left.
John Oliver, British comedian of "The Daily Show" fame, announced that he's engaged to Kate Norley, an Army medic who spent time in Iraq. The couple met in 2008 at the Republican National Convention.
A Maclean’s article calling Quebec the “most corrupt province” has set off criticism, not least because of its use of a beloved character to illustrate the piece.

Over the weekend, the National Republican Congressional Committee began releasing 27 spots in 20 states, many of which aim to portray Democrats as part of the Washington establishment and link them to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi of California.

Richard Goldstein, an author and historian of the Second World War who was our guest expert on City Room last week, provided the following third and final batch of answers to readers' questions about all aspects of New York and the war. You can find previous installments in this Q & A here.

DEARBORN, Mich. - Ford announced Monday that it would create a real-time interactive event called Focus Rally: America to help introduce the 2012 Focus compact car, which was scheduled for dealer showrooms early next year.

6:04 p.m. | Updated There are much more important things to focus on than an utterly misconceived mini movie blowing up kids to recruit carbon cutters, so it's welcome that Eugenie Harvey, the director of the 10:10 UK group that commissioned the film, has moved toward closure by issuing a real apology (text below). The rather reluctant regrets note posted on Friday essentially encouraged YouTube visitors to copy and disseminate it by saying, "We won't be making any attempt to censor or remove other versions currently in circulation on the internet."

Mexico City is a well-documented hotbed of contradictions: wealth side by side with poverty, globalization nuzzling indigenous tradition, beheadings alongside leisurely afternoons in lush parks sucking jicama pops. In a city that contains 2,000 official colonias (neighborhoods), even intrepid visitors who come to explore end up sticking to one safe corner of this metropolis. A short taxi ride from the trendy Condesa/Roma area is the colonia Narvarte, a charming middle-class neighborhood where Che Guevara lived while plotting the overthrow of the Batista dictatorship with Fidel Castro. The area is known for its wide avenues with palm-lined camellones (traffic islands) and a somewhat old-fashioned atmosphere, and it also happens to house some of the city's greatest taquerias. Here's where to go.

In this week's Critics' Pick, A. O. Scott looks back at Ismail Merchant and James Ivory's 1992 adaptation of the E. M. Forster novel "Howards End." The film stars Emma Thompson and Anthony Hopkins and explores class struggles and relationships in Edwardian England. Among the features Mr. Scott praises are the "lovely period clothing, gorgeous cinematography, lavish and historically-appropriate production design and scrupulous fidelity to the literary source."

After a decade of research and more than 540 ocean expeditions, scientists presented the world with the first-ever census of marine life on Monday. The census involved the work of 670 institutions and 2,700 researchers and made direct observation of 120,000 marine species, including some 6,000 newly discovered species.

A new Web site for finding jobs in the food business - at the likes of Brooklyn Larder, not Burger King - has launched, goodfoodjobs.com. A national Craiglist for the sustainable set, the site aims to connect job seekers with such diverse employers as Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the Momofuku Restaurant Group, the Monterey Bay Aquarium, and individual farmers.

In this lesson, students learn the key terms associated with the United States court system, then engage with core texts and subjects through the mock trial process.

UPS announced Thursday that it has ordered 130 new diesel hybrid electric delivery trucks to complement its existing fleet of 250 of the vehicles, which are made in two sizes by Freightliner with hybrid drive systems from the Eaton Corporation.

The national tour of "Pandemonium: The Lost and Found Orchestra," the latest show from the composers Luke Cresswell and Steve McNicholas, the creators of "Stomp," has been canceled after fewer than three weeks of performances.

Many of us have at least part of our financial lives on autopilot. Maybe Netflix and your gym automatically bill your credit card each month. Or perhaps you've authorized your credit cards and cable company to pull money directly from your checking account.

New York Fashion Week may be long gone, but for all of those not on the Europe circuit, that means taking a closer look at the collections in the labels' showrooms, an appointment better known as "re-see." On one such recent visit with Eviana Hartman, the designer behind the eco-conscious label Bodkin, T was thrilled to find that Hartman, now in her fourth season, is expanding into swimwear. "I was heading to Mal País, Costa Rica, for my first surf trip," says Hartman of her decision to dive into new territory. "I couldn't quite find a bathing suit that was me." Her decision was sealed when she stumbled upon a pile of dead-stock gray and mint heather fabric in a Los Angeles warehouse. For now, the swimwear line features only two styles - the two-piece "Bodkini" and the one-piece twister suit (twisting and knotting is also featured throughout the lively spring/summer clothing collection) - but Hartman is optimistic that it will make a splash with her loyal fan base. "If the Bodkin girl isn't already a surfer," she says, "she probably wants to be."

The typical resident of Westchester County in New York pays more in property taxes  than the typical resident of any other major American county, according to a new analysis of Census data from the Tax Foundation.

FremantleMedia is the production arm of the RTL Group unit of the media giant Bertelsmann.

For American women, the days of overt "Mad Men"-style discrimination are largely gone. Women outnumber men at universities, have career options beyond the secretarial pool, and are (slowly) narrowing the pay gap with their male peers. So why has this half of the population failed to reach critical mass in leadership roles across industries? She Owns It explored the topic here, and author Gloria Feldt answers the question in her new book, No Excuses: 9 Ways Women Can Change the Way We Think About Power and Leadership. Ms. Feldt, the former president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood, recently spoke with me about why women's progress is stalled, her hope that a female Steve Jobs will soon emerge and the dangers of being a stay-at-home mom. A condensed version of the conversation follows.

Throughout much of the 1980s and '90s, a certain segment of the East Village appeared to be in nearly perpetual rebellion. There were the squatters who took over abandoned city-owned buildings. There were the gardeners who reclaimed trash-strewn lots. And there were the anarchists and artists who declared rhetorical war on developers while holding roving protests and sometimes skirmishing with the police.

In a case of "Freedom" meets "The Corrections," Jonathan Franzen's British publisher has apologized for a printing error that left dozens of spelling and punctuation mistakes in the first edition of his new novel.

Shareholders pushed up Sara Lee's stock price on Monday, on a report by The New York Post that the consumer goods giant had dismissed a takeover proposal by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. By early afternoon, Sara Lee shares were still up about 8.5 percent at $14.57.

On days when there are shows in the tent in the Tuileries garden, you expect to cross the hard, pebbled ground, wedge your way through the rigid crowd of onlookers and standing-ticket holders, and see something quite different once the show starts. Today, however, at Chloé, the models looked older and more world-wise this time. With their buns and ballet flats, in their streamlined coat dresses and plain white cotton dresses, they looked like young ladies who study dance or music. That is, they looked like an ideal.

Monday is the 55th anniversary of the Brooklyn Dodgers' 1955 World Series victory over the Yankees, a moment that Dave Anderson has duly noted in a Sports of The Times column. That day was clearly a big moment in the life of Fred Wilpon, the Mets' principal owner, who grew up in Brooklyn as an avid Dodgers fan and high school teammate of Sandy Koufax, and who, of course, modeled Citi Field after Ebbets Field, which is now long gone.

Hours before their debate on Monday night, the Republican candidate for Senate in Connecticut, Linda McMahon, released a video showing her opponent, Richard Blumenthal, suggesting that he served in the Vietnam War, though he did not.

Once again this season for the fourth straight year, some N.H.L. teams are opening in Europe, with six teams -- Carolina, Minnesota, Boston, San Jose, Columbus and Phoenix -- beginning their schedule overseas. The first game on the regular season schedule (this Thursday at noon Easter) features the Hurricanes and the Wild from Helsinki.

Graham Bowley and David Gillen on why cash-rich companies still aren't hiring, the value of vague terror warnings for travelers and a look back at the discovery of insulin.

Speaking of rock stars with Broadway ambitions: at a concert Sunday night in Coimbra, Portugal, U2 added a new song to its set list called "Boy Falls From the Sky." If that title makes your spider-sense - or maybe just your memory neurons - tingle, that's because it is one of the tracks that Bono and the Edge created for the coming Broadway musical "Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark." Reeve Carney, who will play Spidey and his alter ego, Peter Parker, in the musical, played the song last month in an appearance on "Good Morning America"; now you can hear how it sounds when it's performed by its composers.

With so many putting so much on self-promotional, self-debasing display (e.g. the Naked Cowboy's presidential run, etc.), it can be easy to lose track of all the things that still remain shrouded in the city, its hidden treasures and sub rosa machinations.

Nearly a year after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York deemed the recession over, many small-business owners are still waiting for real signs of recovery. In this video, part of a series of articles and videos that have followed several small businesses in New York City since 2008, one gets a glimpse of how unevenly the economic rebound is playing out across the city and various industries. A bicycle manufacturer in Queens has adapted to changing markets and come out a leaner, more diversified company. Meanwhile, a butcher in the Bronx recently closed shop because of outstanding debt.

Have you called 411 recently? If so, you just racked up a needless directory assistance fee. Instead, you could have used free services.

The Broadway musical "American Idiot" received a healthy shot in the arm last week as Billie Joe Armstrong, the frontman and lead guitarist for the rock band Green Day, performed in the devilish role of the heroin dealer St. Jimmy for a regular complement of eight performances. A rock opera set to more than 20 Green Day songs, "American Idiot" grossed $1,092,334 for the week, according to the producers - a significant improvement over the show's weekly average gross of $740,000 since opening on April 20 at the St. James Theater. The maximum possible gross for that week of performances would have been about $1.3 million.

During a recent visit to the set of his new series, "Running Wilde," we weren't necessarily going to ask Mitchell Hurwitz, the creator of the cult comedy "Arrested Development," about the long, long awaited possibility of an "Arrested Development" movie, figuring it comes up in every interview Mr. Hurwitz gives, and besides, he probably has more pressing concerns right now.

Sometimes, the spartan lines of a caption can't begin to tell the story behind the picture they describe. A striking example is the photograph we published in this weekend's issue with Serge Schmemann's review of "The Victims Return: Survivors of the Gulag After Stalin," by Stephen F. Cohen.

The Chicago Symphony Orchestra's love fest with its new music director, Riccardo Muti, has come to a sudden halt because of Mr. Muti's illness. He canceled his appearances with the orchestra halfway through his one-month fall stint with it so he could fly to Milan on Monday to seek treatment for what the orchestra called "extreme gastric distress." Mr. Muti suffered stomach pains over the weekend and canceled a Saturday-evening gala performance at the last minute -- the orchestra played with no conductor -- and decided on Sunday to consult with his own doctors in Milan.

This is the fourth article in a series on the accuracy of polls and polling averages. In the first two installments, we demonstrated that polls have been extremely accurate at forecasting the winners of governors' and Senate races in recent years - much more so than you might expect based on intuition alone.

The Sauber team  survived  after the German car manufacturer BMW pulled out of the team and the sport over the winter. Motherlode sends its congratulations to Robert G. Edwards, who won the Nobel Prize for Medicine this morning. He is, figuratively, the father of the technology that, literally, has allowed four million babies to be born over the past three decades.

A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

John Key, the prime minister of New Zealand, has become the latest and arguably the most influential person this side of the wizard Gandalf to seek a resolution in a labor dispute that has hobbled a planned two-film adaptation there of "The Hobbit" by J. R. R. Tolkien.

The Supreme Court reconvenes today, but don't blink if you want to catch a glimpse of its newest member, Justice Elena Kagan. She has recused herself from 25 of the 51 cases the court has accepted so far this term because she argued the cases during her 14-month tenure as solicitor general. The Times's Adam Liptak will have the first look at the session later today.

¶ The recently retired N.H.L. enforcer Georges Laraque requires 12 stitches to his forehead -- not from a fight, but because his partner in CBC's "Battle of the Blades" accidentally cut him with her figure skate. Laraque's injury occurs on Saturday during a rehearsal for Sunday's premiere of the competition portion of the figure-skating contest show, as he and his partner, Anabelle Langlois, practice a maneuver called the Chainsaw. The 97-pound Langlois, swinging from the 275-pound Laraque's neck, loses her balance and starts to fall headfirst. As Laraque reaches to break her fall, her skate blade slices his forehead.

The United Nations Millennium Development Goals were adopted in 2000 as a commitment to improve health and education as well as end poverty in less fortunate parts of the globe. The eight goals include targets like universal childhood education, reducing infant mortality and ensuring environmental sustainability.

Stella McCartney's super-trim, no-nonsense collection could be seen as a response to the boxy, over-layered clothes we've been served in the past day. I refer to the tent shapes at Céline and the leopard-and-chiffon layers at Givenchy, a moment of fashion gluttony in Paris. Ms. McCartney took a more healthful, fresh-air approach today. Her pantsuits, worn with fine buttoned-up polo shirts, were well-tailored, trim but easy, with somewhat high-waist trousers and a pale pastel palette of rose, pistachio, blue and lavender. She showed two or three colors in combination, and it worked. The clothes are a natural follow-up to fall's classically slim trousers and crewnecks, and the shoe is now a low-heeled sandal with a single buckled strap at the front and an ankle strap.

The photographer André Kertész straddled three identities -- Hungarian national (he was born in Budapest in 1894), enthusiastic Paris émigré (he posthumously donated his negatives to the Ministère de la Culture), and adopted American (he was a Manhattan resident for 49 years). The exhibition of his work at the Jeu de Paume (1, Place de la Concorde; 33-1-47-03-12-50; jeudepaume.org), which runs through Feb. 6, embraces all three eras, calling itself the first "proper retrospective" of his work in Europe.

Tim Hetherington's "Infidel" (Chris Boot Ltd., 2010) is more of a family album than a traditional photojournalism book. There are of course powerful images of life for a platoon in the Korengal valley in Afghanistan that Hetherington and Sebastian Junger documented in the film "Restrepo." But there are also thorough catalogs of the soldiers' tattoos, their official Army ID photos and the magazine centerfolds in their barracks, and remarkably revealing interviews with seven of the soldiers. The book stands on its own, separate from the movie.

Michael Wolff, the Vanity Fair columnist and troublemaker who seems to relish public feuds and collecting enemies as much as chronicling the folkways of the Manhattan media world, has agreed to become editorial director of a group of trade publications that includes Adweek, Brandweek and Mediaweek. For Mr. Wolff, the job occupies a corner of the media industry less sexy than he is accustomed to, but he said he would bring his usual combative sensibility to the position.

KARTER--Jesse, DDS, passed away peacefully in his sleep on October 2, 2010 at the age of 87 after a long and valiant fight with Parkinson's. His legacy of honesty, integrity, commitment to family, friends and patients, and his wonderful sense of humor live on in the hearts of his beloved and devoted wife of 56 years Ruth, his loving children Michael and Marcia, Philip and Rhonda, and Linda and Larry Merlin, and his adored and adoring grandchildren Andrew, Kara, Melissa, Michelle, Kimberly and Max. He is also survived by his dear sister Miriam Posner. In addition to the joy of family relationships, some of his happiest times were spent gardening, and all who knew him enjoyed the bounty of those endeavors. He will be deeply missed by those whose lives he touched. Services, Wednesday, October 6 at 12:00pm at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

WALLBERG--Marilyn, 67, of New York, NY died on October 3, 2010. Loving mother to Alli and Ruth and exceptional mother-in-law to Peter. Doting granny to Matthew, Harper, Tucker, and TJ. Devoted sister to Amy and Aunt to Daniel. Affectionate partner to Bob. Dedicated relative, friend and colleague to many. Marilyn fought a long and courageous battle with ALS, but she never once stopped living, laughing, loving, or providing others with happiness. An amazing and generous woman who has inspired so many to celebrate the good in life. A memorial service will be held in New York City on October 4, 2010 at 11:15am at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 180 West 76th Street. Memorial donations may be made to: ALS Association (www.alsa.org) and Columbia Presbyterian Eleanor & Lou Gehrig MDA/ALS Research Center (www.columbiaals.org/donations.html).

BURKE--Dorothy B.,of New Canaan, CT and Quogue, NY died at home surrounded by family on September 19, 2010, a few days before her 90th birthday. Born to Robert and Dorothy Mott Burns of Brooklyn in 1920, Dorothy attended Packer Collegiate Institute, the Ethel Walker School and Vassar College. She married her childhood sweetheart Bob Burke, who predeceased her along with brother Ed. She is survived by her children Casey, Barbara and Bob, Jr., in addition to her beloved grandchildren Andy, Jenny, and Joanna. Dorothy loved music of the classic American Songbook, and her home was filled with the recordings of Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald and countless others. She herself had a beautiful voice and could be heard singing throughout the day. She relished the bright sparks of life and had a singularly keen wit. She was a voracious reader, particularly of British mysteries. She delighted in puns and wordplay, and always kept her dictionary nearby. Dorothy and Bob had a wonderful marriage for close to 50 years. She loved her children, her home and her friends. She played a nifty game of golf and was a member of the National, Shinnecock Hills, and the Quogue Field Club in Long Island. In her later years, Dorothy made close friends in San Diego and La Quinta in the high California desert. Her inner circle was always evolving and was in the last years her family grew to include Angelina, who along with Christina, Stella, Bob, Georgina, Pauline and Penny shared their lives and talents with her. Everyone will deeply miss her unique and wonderfully hip spirit. Donations in her name can be sent to the New Canaan Library, the Quogue Library, or the library of one's choice.

ZOLA--Dr. Benjamin E. Loving husband of Ling, proud father of Daniel and Joshua, adored brother of Lawrence, Michael, and Geoffrey, devoted son of Marcia and Joseph and beloved brother-in-law, uncle, cousin and dear friend, left us on October 2, 2010 after a heroic and valiant battle. He will always remain in our hearts and minds as a faithful and dedicated family leader, deeply loyal friend, and remembered for his love of life. Dr. Zola will be remembered as a gifted, talented and caring cardiologist with an extraordinary ability to treat each patient as family. Ben was an extraordinary athlete, competing on national and international levels in many sports which he also shared with family and friends. His proudest athletic achievements were the medals he won at the Maccabiah Games and skiing two million feet over the course of twenty years in Canada. He was everyone's first phone call. Funeral 9:30am Monday, October 4, 2010 at Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, New York, NY.

In the entertainment category tracked by the Nielsen Company, which includes music, video and sports, some sports sites had a slight decline from August 2009 to August 2010. Traffic to iTunes and Netflix increased, in Netflix's case partly because more customers own devices that can download movies directly from the Web. The site that gained the largest percentage of visitors was Zynga, which makes role-playing games like Mafia Wars, and virtual world games like Farmville, above, that have become popular on a little Web site called Facebook. SHELLY FREIERMAN

EVERS--Sally J.,died on September 24, 2010, after a brief, valiant battle with cancer, she was 68. A long-time resident of the Upper East Side, Sally's heart never left the City. She loved the intelligence, creativity and class of New York, and the small village friendliness and convenience of her neighborhood around 86th and York. All of which she enjoyed with her much loved companion, Gerry Weiler, dear NY friends, and family. Sally's 38-year career in TV and film production began with "Eye on New York" and wound up at Weiler Communications where she was a producer. In retirement, Sally worked part-time for the Tamarind Foundation. Sally was a generous and unfailing source of strength for her entire family, and all who knew her. She was also a frustrated Yankees fan. Losing (in baseball) just wasn't an option. Sally has left us much too soon and our hearts are shattered. No one can ever replace her adored, caring and guiding presence in our lives. Sally is survived by her brother Bill, and her sisters Barbara, Helen and Susan; sister-in-law Joanne; brothers-in-law Raymond and Rick; two nieces, three nephews, a great-niece, and three great-nephews. In lieu of flowers, kindly make donations to Women In Need, 115 W. 31st St., 7th FL, NY, NY 10001 or Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, NY, NY 10018. A memorial celebration will be announced in the spring. Barbara, Bill, Helen, Susan

10 P.M. (Logo) THE A-LIST: NEW YORK Step aside, ladies. Bravo's ubiquitous hausfraus get a bit a competition from six gay men living large in the city in this latest creation from the producers of ''The Real Housewives of Atlanta.'' The roster includes Reichen Lehmkuhl, a winner of ''The Amazing Race'' and a onetime partner of Lance Bass; Mr. Lehmkuhl's latest love, Rodiney Santiago, a Brazilian model; Mike Ruiz, a photographer who claims to transform celebrities with his artistry; Austin Armacost, a model and ex-boyfriend of Marc Jacobs; Derek Saathoff (above right, with Mr. Santiago), a modeling agent and friend of Lindsay Lohan's who has never met a velvet rope that wouldn't open to him; and Ryan Nickulas, the owner of a salon responsible for the coifs of Pamela Anderson and Isaac Mizrahi. In ''The Arrangement,'' at 11, 10 floral designers are challenged to gussy up ''smart'' cars, drag queens and naked sushi models. Gigi Levangie Grazer, the author of ''The Starter Wife,'' and the floral designer Eric Buterbaugh host. 6 P.M. (Fox Movie Channel) LET'S MAKE LOVE (1960) A billionaire, Jean-Marc Clement (Yves Montand), learns he's going to be satirized in an Off Broadway revue and goes to check out the show. While he's there the director mistakes him for an actor -- and the perfect person to play his character. Which doesn't bother Clement, since he has heard the show's star, Amanda Dell (Marilyn Monroe), sing ''My Heart Belongs to Daddy'' and fallen in love. Milton Berle plays a man teaching Clement how to be funny.

If Washington normally blends the business of government with electoral politics, this week signifies a turn toward an unalloyed electoral brawl. Democratic Congressional leaders have sent members home without resolving their greatest outstanding disagreement with Republicans, over the Bush tax cuts due to expire at year's end. After months on the defensive as Republicans surged in the polls, Speaker Nancy Pelosi calls it time for Democrats to attack.

Her 13-month-old son, Henry, played with Ori, a Rottweiler-pit bull mix, who rushed to greet other customers as they arrived. The smell of garlic and scallions hung in the air.

NICHOLSON--Frederic, age 82, Norfolk, VA. UVA law school graduate. Served in the 82nd Airborne. Adjunct professor at Rutgers, Georgetown and New York University. Legal career spanned 45 years in New York City and Norfolk. Fred is survived by his wife Miriam (Mimi) and two daughters, Gail and Leslie, from an earlier marriage.

Most of the companies that hope to take on Apple in the white-hot market for tablets are industry giants like Dell, Google, HP, Microsoft and Samsung. But among the startups looking to become tablet contenders, Kno stands out. I first wrote about Kno in June, when the company unveiled a dual-screen tablet aimed at college students. The knock against the chunky, 14-inch screen was its heft; it weighs 5.5 pounds, or nearly four times more than Apple's iPad, and each slab was more than half an inch thick.

EUGENE, Ore. -- Nearly 2,500 miles from the psychedelic blend of yellows and greens that provided the backdrop for Oregon's rout of Stanford here on Saturday, top-ranked Alabama put forth a more traditional performance in a blowout of Florida. Alabama delivers classic uniforms, a Bear Bryant pedigree and a conventional pro-style offense -- comfort food for the college football purists. The race to become the Crimson Tide's potential foil in the Bowl Championship Series title game, however, could cause some ripples among those old-school fans.

Twitter, the company that early on never wanted to talk about money, now has a money-making strategy that it says is working well. On Tuesday, Dick Costolo, Twitter's chief operating officer, introduced some new ways Twitter will make money. Advertisers will soon be able to pay for Twitter to suggest that people follow their accounts, and next year, Twitter advertising will expand to small businesses, which will be able to place ads using a self-serve system.

HOWARD--James L. Sr. age 78, died at home, in Annapolis, Maryland, on October 2, 2010, surrounded by his family, after a brave battle with cancer. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania in 1932 and graduated from the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Connecticut in 1954. He went on to graduate from MIT, and served until reaching the rank of Captain, resigning his commission in 1969 to accept the presidency of Kvaerner Moss, US, he retired in 1997. Jim was active in the Norwegian-American Chamber of Commerce, and the American Scandinavian Foundation and in 1994, in recognition of his contributions to the Norwegian-American community, he was appointed Knight First Class in His Majesty's Court by King Harald VI of Norway. After retirement he lived in Annapolis, Maryland, where he met and married Angela Eggleston-Howard and enjoyed sailing and traveling the world. He is survived by his beloved wife, Angela Eggleston-Howard and her children Angela Meade Eggleston and Stephen Weller Eggleston; his brother John Howard and wife Kate; his daughters Sally Ann and husband James, and Kate and husband John; and his sons, James Jr. and wife Patricia and Christopher and wife Stacey. He is also survived by eight grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and numerous cousins, nephews and nieces. Visitation will be held at the John M. Taylor Funeral Home, Inc. 147 Duke of Gloucester St., Annapolis, MD 21401 on Tuesday, October 5 from 6 to 8pm and then on Wednesday, October 6 from 10am to 1pm. There will be a service at St. Anne's Church Church Circle, Annapolis, Maryland at 2pm Wednesday followed by a burial at Service Creek Presbyterian Church Cemetery in Raccoon Township, Pennsylvania. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Anne's Parish, Church Circle, 199 Duke of Gloucester St, Annapolis Md. 21401. Online condolences may be made to www.johnmtaylorfuneralhome.com

STEARNS--Rebecca Grimes, 84 - on September 23 in Fort Myers FL. Beloved mother of Matt and Becky (Ken), grandmother of Jim and Ben, she was a cherished sister, aunt, and friend. Iowa born, educated at Shimer College, University of Iowa, and Stanford, longtime resident of Leonia, NJ, and retired speech instructor at Baruch College and Yeshiva University, Becky shared her love of music, opera, art, books, political discourse, fashion and fabulous shoes with all who knew her. Packers (2-0) at Bears (2-0)Monday, 8:30 p.m.Line: Packers by 3 Clay Matthews III already has six sacks this season, and every time he takes down a quarterback, the Matthews clan (including father Clay Junior, grandpa Clay Senior and Hall of Fame uncle Bruce) moves up the list of great football families. The Matthews family may never catch the Mannings, but it should slide past the Hasselbecks, and should catch Tiki and Ronde Barber as soon as the Panthers find a quarterback who doesn't throw interceptions straight into Ronde's chest. The Matthews family has officially registered 75.5 career sacks and counting, though that number is misleading. The N.F.L. didn't count sacks in the 1950s when the oldest Matthews played, and Clay Senior certainly sacked the great quarterbacks of his era -- Johnny Unitas, Otto Graham, Brett Favre -- at least once or twice.

ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. -- The Jets trudged deceptively into the visitors' locker room at Ralph Wilson Stadium, absent smiles, fist pumps, or any of the usual signs of celebration. Their body language suggested they expected this result. The night before, Coach Rex Ryan addressed them. He implored them to play physically, told them to expect to win, told them, according to linebacker Bart Scott, ''to show this league exactly who we are.'' Then, seriously, the Jets ate a gosh darn snack.

The threat by McDonald's to discontinue its health-insurance coverage is one recent aftershock of the health care overhaul, as my column this week discusses. In the end, McDonald's seems unlikely to follow through on that threat. But another part of the new law will lead to real changes: the requirement that insurers offer coverage to all children, including those with pre-existing illnesses.

Before the Alexander McQueen show tonight, Sarah Burton said her main objective with the collection - her first since taking over as creative director - was to impart a strong sense of craft. She also used the word "tender" to describe the general feeling of the collection, which was based on a decaying nature. The narrow tailcoats and low-rise trousers certainly follow the McQueen silhouette. The prints and ribbon embroideries were consistent with the style of the last few years. Some of the more sculptural shapes recall his sense of theatre. And Ms. Burton used materials and references associated with him, like feathers, designs that appear to have partially disintegrated, and the hand-painted leather butterflies that clustered on dresses.

The head of the Nevada Tea Party resigned Tuesday after its candidate for Senate leaked a recording of Sharron Angle - the Republican running to replace Senator Harry Reid, the leader of the Democratic majority - in which she complained about Republican leaders and confessed that she does not know if she can win.

Dozens of President Hamid Karzai’s relatives and friends, many of whom used to live in the United States, have returned home to take on powerful positions in government and business, allowing the family to shape policy and benefit financially. Only a few family members remain in the United States.

Breast cancer research is an undeniably worthy endeavor, but the container-loads of pink objects that have been sold to help pay for it aren't always what you'd call high design. Which is why the arrival of the Pink Wishbone Project is welcome news. Thanks to Suite New York, a Manhattan furniture showroom, Hans Wegner's famous Wishbone Chair, made in Denmark by Carl Hansen & Son, will be available in pink for the next year, with 20 percent of its sales going to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. And to draw attention to the program, Barneys New York will exhibit chairs that were customized by 20 leading women designers. (A kickoff cocktail party takes place on Thursday evening at Barneys.)

As reported in the Big Deal column of the Real Estate section on Tuesday, the 40-acre Greenwich, Conn., estate of the late hotel magnate Leona Helmsley has sold for $35 million. The 21,987-square foot mansion, owned by Ms. Helmsley and her husband, Harry, was at the center of a high-profile tax evasion case against the couple in the late 1980s. Read the full article.

Two combat tours in Afghanistan placed Army Sgt. Osvaldo Hernandez under frequent attack by the Taliban and tested his judgment and courage daily. In the age of "The Social Network" and Evites, it's nice to see that a new crop of eco-conscious letterpress houses are bringing a fresh approach to an antique practice. "For me, Facebook and e-mail are great ways to keep in touch, but there is something really special about getting a card or letter in the mail," says Lehua Chong, whose New York City-based company Hour of Nine creates organic cards with funky motifs inspired by the streets of Manhattan. Made from ever-abundant bamboo, the cards are free of chlorine and pesticides, and using them just might mean that your friends won't be able to R.S.V.P. to your next party via a status update.

Andy Harman's first installations were fun houses that he set up in the basement his childhood home - he would pull the neighborhood kids through the creepy space on a sled. Fast forward a decade plus, and Harman, who got his M.F.A. in sculpture at Yale, is an established production and set designer working with renowned photographers like Terry Richardson, Roe Etheridge and Ellen von Unwerth. Recently, his career working with props and sets led him to reinvestigate sculpture via furniture design, resulting in a new kind of fun house.

Deloris Van Cartier, the aspiring disco star turned murder witness turned woman of the cloth, now has a New York home to hide out in: the musical adaptation of "Sister Act," the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg comedy, will come to the Broadway Theater this spring, press representatives for the show said on Tuesday. The musical, which has a score by Alan Menken, lyrics by Glenn Slater and a book by Cheri and Bill Steinkellner, will be directed by Jerry Zaks, a consultant on the Broadway incarnation of "The Addams Family." It is to begin previews on March 24 with an opening night set for April 20. No casting was immediately announced for the show's Broadway run; a West End version of "Sister Act" starring Patina Miller as Deloris opened at the London Palladium in June 2009.

On Tuesday morning, the federal government revealed details of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's new 5-Star Safety Rating System and released new ratings for some of the most popular 2011 model-year vehicles. Of the 33 vehicles tested, only two received an overall rating of five stars, which is the best: the BMW 5 Series (4-door and rear-wheel-drive models) and the Hyundai Sonata built after July 2, 2010.

In low-lying Sehwan, Pakistan, home of the country's largest Sufi shrine, floodwaters from this summer's devastating storms are draining slowly, or not at all. Kanye West has given fans some extended (and sometimes unsettling) glimpses inside his psyche lately, from his decadent Dalí-esque video for "Power" to the pristine troupe of ballet dancers that surrounded him during his recent performances on "Saturday Night Live." So it's only fitting that the title of his next album should reflect the summation of his alternately playful and twisted soul: the record will be titled "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy," Mr. West wrote Tuesday morning on his Twitter account, and will be released on Nov. 22. Mr. West said the first song on the album would be "Dark Fantasy," a track produced by RZA along with No I.D. and Mr. West, and the next single to be released would be the song "All of the Lights." Mr. West also shared a small image that appeared to be a frame from a video for his song "Runaway," but without our gemological microscope it was hard to say for certain.

Anyone who has seen the Resnais film "Last Year at Marienbad" (1961) will recognize the source for Karl Lagerfeld's black-and-white garden at the Chanel show today. ¶ A potential labor stoppage is averted on the brink of opening night as the N.H.L. and the N.H.L. Officials' Association reach a tentative deal on a new collective bargaining agreement Monday evening. The league's 39 referees and 35 linesmen had been working exhibition games without a contract, which expired on Aug. 31. The tentative four-year agreement, which assures that league arbiters will work Thursday's season openers, must still be approved by the officials' union and the N.H.L. board of governors. Both sides declined comment until the contract is ratified.

Last Thursday, the CNN anchor Rick Sanchez called Jon Stewart a "bigot" and, shortly after Mr. Stewart's Judaism was invoked, remarked that "everybody that runs CNN is a lot like Stewart." On Friday, Mr. Sanchez was fired. And on Monday, Mr. Stewart took to his "Daily Show" to react, sister blog The Caucus notes.

Goodness! In a grievous insult to trans-Atlantic fraternity, the American man of letters Jonathan Franzen was calamitously accosted at a party in London on Monday night, in an incident in which his spectacles were stolen straight off the end of his nose, The Bookseller.com reported. Mr. Franzen, the author of such novel-length entertainments as "The Corrections," was being celebrated for the British publication of his latest fictional monograph, "Freedom," at the Serpentine Gallery when, around 8 p.m., two interlopers entered the event. One of the malefactors plucked Mr. Franzen's glasses from his face and absconded, while the second handed the author a note before he also fled. According to The Bookseller, the note read: "$100,000 - Your glasses are yours again!"

After the stunning Chanel show this morning, I stopped by the new H&M flagship designed by Jean Nouvel on the Champs Elysées. Almost everything in the windows was covered with leopard spots - on jackets, blouses and pants. Editors have been wearing leopard prints all week. At the Chloé show on Monday, you could see Carine Roitfeld, the editor of French Vogue, in a spotted jacket, standing next to Anna Dello Russo in a leopard print minidress covered with fringe, next to Virginie Mouzat of Le Figaro in a white blouse flocked with leopard spots. If leopard prints are already going mainstream this fall, it makes you wonder if this trend will still have legs for spring, even though designers like Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy are betting on it.

Democratic poll-watchers were having a pretty good Monday. Rasmussen Reports had shown Republicans with a relatively small 3-point advantage on the generic ballot -- the narrowest advantage that Rasmussen has shown for Republicans in about a year. Meanwhile, two polls in a pivotal Senate race, Connecticut, showed the Democrat Richard Blumenthal with a solid lead there. Perhaps there was something to all the talk about a Democratic rebound in the polls, which has been in fashion lately.

For El Greco, Toledo, Spain, had an almost mystical significance. After the artist left his native Crete in the early 1570s and passed through Italy, the town provided him with a home, a place where his astoundingly original manner of painting was appreciated and an environment where his intellectual ambitions could be realized. The artist expressed his relationship with the town in his "View and Plan of Toledo," a magnificent late work that normally calls the El Greco Museum in Toledo home. The piece is now on display, through Feb. 27, at the Prado  Museum in Madrid.

Richard Blumenthal and Linda E. McMahon questioned each other’s truthfulness and qualifications in a debate marked by tart exchanges.
The co-creators of the new Fox comedy talk about its chances after getting poor early reviews and ratings.
Real estate agents are having units decorated in a manner that matches the tastes of potential buyers.
The defendant in the Cheshire murder case faces 17 charges, including six capital felony counts.
The Ryder Cup came down to the final match after an American rally, but Graeme McDowell sealed a victory for Europe.
Though higher than in July, home sales were than 20 percent below the pace of a year ago. Factory orders were driven lower by a decline in the demand for aircraft and motor vehicles.
Ichiro Ozawa, who helped guide the Democratic Party to power in Japan, is likely to face charges over a financing scandal.
The carmaker announced the closing after a search for an outside investor ended without success.
Thai judges on Monday appeared to quash the prospect of a lengthy second trial of the suspected arms dealer Viktor Bout, who is wanted in the U.S.
Coming this week are the monthly jobs survey and an earnings report from the Dow component Alcoa.
Robert G. Edwards of Britain won the prize in medicine for a breakthrough that helped millions to have children.
More than a dozen oil tankers carrying fuel destined for NATO troops were torched on Monday.

VIETOR--Thomas Frederick III, 66 of Katonah, NY died October 1st of cancer. The son of Carolyn Raymond and Thomas F. Vietor Jr. Tom was born and raised in Manhattan, graduated from St. Paul's School, the University of Pennsylvania and served in the Air National Guard. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club and a former Board Member of the Orchestra of St. Luke's. He spent his career at Johnson & Higgins and then Marsh. He retired as Chairman of Marsh FINPRO Global. He is survived by his wife Jeanne K. Windbiel, son Tommy Vietor of Washington, DC, daughter Taylor Vietor, stepson John Cunningham, sister, the Reverend Julie (Vietor) Kelsey of Branford, CT and numerous nieces and nephews. A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY on Thursday, October 7th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to: GU Oncology Research Fund, Dr. David Nanus, 1305 York Ave., Box 403, New York, NY 10021.

BOCKLAGE--Maj. Norman W.,US Air Force, retired, passed away October 3 at the Atlantis Rehabilitation and Residential Health Care Facility in New York after a long illness. He was 71. Maj. Bocklage was born in Washington, MO, and traveled the world during his 20-year career with the Air Force. After he retired from the service, he moved to the Princeton, NJ, area, working as a driver for A-1 Limousine until 2004. He enjoyed the freedom of the open road, and meeting the many interesting and sometimes well known people who were his clientele. He was a graduate of St. Edward's University in Austin, Texas. Son of the late Victor F. and Ann C. Bocklage, he is survived by his daughter, Michelle Bocklage-Shibata, and her husband, Makoto Shibata, of New York; his sister, Judy Bocklage of Plainsboro, NJ; aunts, cousins and many friends. He will be remembered for his devotion to family, service to his country and his dry sense of humor. Reposing at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, New York City. Funeral Mass will be held on Thursday, October 6th, 9:30am Our Lady of Pompei Church. Friends may call Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9pm.

DIENST--Richard A. The Respect for Law Alliance notes with extreme sadness the passing of its Executive Vice President and Director. He ardently supported RFLA's mission promoting respect for law and honoring outstanding members of law enforcement, the judiciary and journalism. Condolences to his loving wife Greer and his family. General Arthur Gerwin, Pres. Judge Gregory W. Carman and Judith A. Livingston, Esq. Co-Vice Chairs

DIENST--Richard A.,of Manhattan died on Saturday, October 2. Richard, 71, leaves behind his beloved wife Greer G. Griffith and his three loving children Daniel, Jonathan and Jennifer. He was a devoted father-in-law to Jill Dienst, Victoria Dienst and Jeffrey Kolitch; and an adoring grandfather of Emma, Nicole, Jared, Teddy, Sam, Kate, Ben and Tess. Richard had a long, distinguished career as a trusted counselor and leading attorney for government officials as well as leaders in the fields of insurance, finance and philanthropy. He represented law enforcement unions and also served as a law school professor. Richard passionately argued the constitutional rights of his clients in state and federal courts including the U.S. Supreme Court. For more than 30 years, Richard served as counsel to the NYPD's Detectives Endowment Association, Lieutenants Benevolent Association and Captains Endowment Association. He defended some of the highest ranking members of the NYPD concerning investigations and allegations of official misconduct before the Knapp Commission, the Office of the Special State Prosecutor and the Mollen Commission. He also served as counsel to the Federal Bureau of Investigation Agents Association. Richard will be remembered for his kind and generous heart, his loyalty and his sense of humor. He loved art, music, travel, literature and his dogs. Some of his happiest times were spent cooking for his family and friends. Richard was born and raised in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of Alfred University and Brooklyn Law School. He was previously married to Linda Dienst, the mother of their three children. He is pre-deceased by his sister Norma Bernstein. Richard served on the board of the Respect for Law Alliance. He was an advocate for 'Angel on a Leash' and the 'Delta Society' groups - which help therapy dogs bring joy to children and adults in health care facilities. Visitation at 4pm and Celebration of His Life at 5:30pm, Wednesday, October 6 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers can go to: Angel On A Leash, 630 9th Ave., New York, NY 10036 or Delta Society, 875 124th Ave., Bellevue, WA 98005. Richard will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him.

KESSLER--Irving, 88, passed away on Saturday, October 2, 2010. He was an esteemed leader devoted to the well being of the Jewish Community worldwide, and nurturing Israel. Kessler was Director of the Hartford Jewish Federation, and as Executive Vice Chairman of the United Israel Appeal. He served with many local, national and international Jewish Community, and Zionist organizations. Irving Kessler is survived by his wife Greta, brother George, children Seth, Susan, Deena, Alex, and seven grandchildren. Gifts in Irving's memory may be sent to Touro Synagogue, Touro Street, Newport, Rhode Island O2840. A Funeral Service will take place on Wednesday, October 6, 2010 at 2pm at the Hoffman Jewish Memorial Chapel, Fowler Avenue, Newport. Burial will take place at Beth Olam Cemetery, Wyatt Road, Middletown, RI.

KARTER--Jesse, DDS, passed away peacefully in his sleep on October 2, 2010 at the age of 87 after a long and valiant fight with Parkinson's. His legacy of honesty, integrity, commitment to family, friends and patients, and his wonderful sense of humor live on in the hearts of his beloved and devoted wife of 56 years Ruth, his loving children Michael and Marcia, Philip and Rhonda, and Linda and Larry Merlin, and his adored and adoring grandchildren Andrew, Kara, Melissa, Michelle, Kimberly and Max. He is also survived by his dear sister Miriam Posner. In addition to the joy of family relationships, some of his happiest times were spent gardening, and all who knew him enjoyed the bounty of those endeavors. He will be deeply missed by those whose lives he touched. Services, Wednesday, October 6 at 12:00pm at Riverside Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

LEACH--Ralph F. Ralph F. Leach died at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Florida on Sunday, October 3, 2010. He was born in Elgin, Illinois on June 14, 1917, the son of Harry A. and Edith (Saunders) Leach. He graduated with an A.B. degree from the University of Chicago in 1938. Mr. Leach served as a captain in the Marine Corps from 1940-45 in the South Pacific. After his armed service, he began a highly successful financial career. He worked as an investment analyst at the Harris Trust & Savings Bank in Chicago from 1945-48 and at the Valley National Bank in Phoenix from 1948-50. From 1950-53, he was Chief of the Government Finance Section at the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, DC. Mr. Leach was Treasurer of the Guarantee Trust Company in New York City from 1953-59, and Vice President and Treasurer of the Morgan Guarantee Trust Company in New York from 1959-62, and held various positions there from 1962-71. From 1971 through 1977, Ralph Leach was Chairman of the Executive Committee of J. P. Morgan and Morgan Guaranty Trust. After retiring from Morgan & Company in 1977, Mr. Leach served on many boards, including Merrill Lynch (1978-89), Southern Railway Company, the Continental Corp. in New York, and the Urban National Corp., a venture capital firm for minorities in Boston. After serving on the board of Energy Conversion Devices, Inc., a Michigan company engaged with photo-voltaic cells and other energy sources during the 1970s and 1980s, he was named Chairman Emeritus. Because of his strong interest in the arts, he supported several arts organizations, such as the Florida Philharmonic Orchestra. He also served on the board of The Juilliard School from 1963-87, and as Vice-Chairman from 1968-87. In 2009, he was awarded the President's Medal, presented by Juilliard President Joseph W. Polisi, for his exceptional encouragement of philanthropy in the arts. He is survived by his loving wife, Harriet S. Leach of Ft. Lauderdale, and his children C. David Leach and Laurie H. Leach of Dayton, Ohio, H. Randall Leach and Anne Leach of Pasadena, California, Barbara E. Leach-Bloemers and Freek Bloemers of Akersloot, Netherlands, and seven grandchildren Megan Leach McCann (John), Katherine Leach Brennaman (Jim), Justin Leach, Cara Leach, Charlotte, Heather and Christopher Leach-Bloemers, and five great-grandchildren, Zachary, Jackson and Samantha Brennaman and Walter and David McCann. He will be greatly missed by all of his family and friends. A private family service will be held in the future. Contributions in memory of Ralph F. Leach may be made to The Juilliard School.

FINGEROTH--Blanche S. Age 93, died peacefully on October 4, with her children at her side. An independent spirit, she thrived and inspired as wife, mother and teacher. An example of how to live a meaningful life. Born in the Bronx, daughter of Dr. Morris and Fanny (Hartman) Silverman, and step-daughter of Jane Silverman. A Phi Beta Kappa Society graduate of Hunter College, obtained a Master's degree in education from Columbia University Teachers College. As wife of the late Cantor Robert R. Fingeroth, she formed a bond of love and partnership with him that lasted three decades. Beloved mother of James N. (Patricia), Daniel J. (Varda) and the late Ethan S. (Barbara) Fingeroth. Devoted grandmother, aunt, cousin, mentor and friend. An inspiration and role model, modest in her triumphs and courageous in the face of adversity. She loved Jewish life and culture, French, Shakespeare and the world of ideas. A gifted speech therapist she helped many express themselves clearly and effectively. Funeral 11am, Wednesday, October 6 at Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St., New York, NY.
