BARRY--Gladys. 81, Died while traveling in Nice, France strolling the promenade with her daughter when a motorcycle jumped the sidewalk. Just as she went out with style she lived in style. Following retirement feted as a math teacher in the New York public school system, she was as accomplished at the Foxwood poker tables as she was at the desks of the gifted students she tutored. She was beloved mother of Dr. Michele Barry and Dr. Leland Barry. Mother-in-law of Dr. Mark Cullen and of Peggy Barry. Cherished sister of Susan Kleinberg and Aunt of Dr. Lawrence Kleinberg. To her grandchildren - Zoe, Esme, Matthew, and Justin - the shining stars of her life she was their darling Gigi. She loved her family fiercely and unconditionally and they adored her. Services will be held at Schwartz Bros. at 11:30am Thursday, October 7th, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY.

In a case of ''Freedom'' meets ''The Corrections,'' Jonathan Franzen's British publisher has apologized for a printing error that left dozens of spelling and punctuation mistakes in the first edition of his new novel. About 8,000 copies of the edition containing errors were sold before the mistakes were discovered, said Susanna Frayn, a spokeswoman for HarperCollins, the British publisher. The company has rushed to reprint the book and has promised replacement copies to customers who purchased the flawed edition.

PATTERSON--William J. A prominent San Francisco investor and philanthropist who led the effort to revitalize the California Academy of Sciences, died on Friday, September 24 at age 48 surrounded by his wife, Elizabeth, and their three children. The cause of death was a brain tumor. He was a devoted husband, father, son, brother and friend, who vastly touched so many with his warmth, generosity of spirit, and zest for living. His unwavering commitment to making a difference in the world was illuminated by his community leadership, his environmentally focused philanthropy, and the building of a highly successful investment partnership. From a young age, he displayed a natural talent for leadership and excellence. Born in Columbus, Ohio, he spent his childhood in Grand Junction, Colorado, where he developed his reverence for the outdoors that led to his becoming an avid sportsman and environmentalist. He went on to attend Harvard College, graduating magna cum laude in 1984. In his senior year at Harvard he was Co-Captain of the Varsity Lightweight Crew and President of the A.D. Club. He studied economics for one year at Australia National University in Canberra, Australia as a Rotary Foundation Scholar before attending the Stanford Graduate School of Business, graduating as an Arjay Miller Scholar in 1989. After graduating Stanford, he founded SPO Partners & Co. together with John H. Scully and William E. Oberndorf in 1991, which has become one of the nation's leading investment partnerships. At the time of his death, he served as a Managing Director of SPO Partners, Chairman of the Board of Calpine Corporation and was a director of Rosewood Hotels and Resorts. As Chair of the Board of Trustees of the California Academy of Sciences, his leadership helped complete its $500 million capital campaign to build its widely praised new home in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park and greatly expand its environmentally based education programs. He was also a former trustee and board president of the Bay Area Discovery Museum, chaired the Stanford Business School Trust, served as a member of the Advisory Council for the Woods Institute for the Environment at Stanford, and was named a Henry Crown Fellow of the Aspen Institute in 2004. He was an avid runner, collected wine, kept bees, and embraced remote travel and discovery to continually learn about the world around him. In addition to his wife of 23 years, he is survived by his children, William, Eleanor and Graham. He is also survived by his mother, Joan T. McNab of Aspen, Colorado, his father, Dr. William R. Patterson of Grand Junction, Colorado and his siblings Robin J. Blackwood of Bozeman, Montana and Thomas A. Patterson of Portola Valley, California. A memorial service will be announced at a later time. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Mr. Patterson's name to either the California Academy of Sciences or a charitable organization of their choice.

A test new to the antidoping movement was used for the first time at the Tour de France last summer, and now it appears that the three-time Tour winner Alberto Contador -- who tested positive for a banned drug at the race -- may have more explaining to do. That new test detects a specific type of chemical, called a plasticizer, that is found in plastic IV bags. Evidence of that chemical in an athlete's urine could mean the athlete has used a blood transfusion to boost endurance. The World Anti-Doping Agency bans blood transfusions or any intravenous infusions, except in a medical emergency.

The ickiness factor of ''Parker Spitzer'' may subside, but the first glimpse of CNN's latest offering on Monday was hard to watch. Former Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and the conservative syndicated columnist Kathleen Parker playfully, almost flirtatiously, discussed the news of the day -- ''Crossfire'' meets ''Moonlighting.'' Last week, Larry King told the duo that they had ''chemistry'' -- if so, it carries a queasy whiff of sulfur. ''I'm from the South, you're from the North, I'm a journalist, and you're a... pol-i-ti-cian?'' Ms. Parker said archly in the introduction.

A review on Wednesday about the newly restored print of the 1948 film ''Nuremberg'' included several errors. This restoration is a complete version of the film and it was taken from a new negative of a German print of the original; it is not assembled from fragments and it is not presented in a truncated state. In addition, ''Nuremberg: Its Lesson for Today'' is an alternative title for ''Nuremberg''; it is not the title of a separate film adapted by the United States government from the original. (The review also erroneously used ''Lessons'' when it referred incorrectly to the film.)

The Broadway musical ''American Idiot'' received a healthy shot in the arm last week as Billie Joe Armstrong, the frontman and lead guitarist for the rock band Green Day, performed in the devilish role of the heroin dealer St. Jimmy for a regular complement of eight performances. A rock opera set to more than 20 Green Day songs, ''American Idiot'' grossed $1,092,334 for the week, according to the producers - a significant improvement over the show's weekly average gross of $740,000 since opening on April 20 at the St. James Theater. The maximum possible gross for that week of performances would have been about $1.3 million. For his final performance on Sunday night, Mr. Armstrong also composed a brief number that he played - and which can be watched here or in the above video - after the curtain call and before the encore, ''Good Riddance (Time of Your Life).'' He pulled out a piece of paper, laid it by the lip of the stage, and began strumming out an ode about his musical theater debut:

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: FREDRIC MARCH''Stardom is just an uneasy seat on top of a tricky toboggan,'' March once said. ''Being a star is merely perching at the head of the downgrade. A competent player can last a lifetime. A star, a year or two.'' Indeed, March arrived in Hollywood with the classic good looks of a leading man. But he kept his career going for 50 years by daring to appear ugly in films like the first in this monthlong tribute, ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' (1931), for which March, above with Miriam Hopkins, won a best actor Oscar (tying with Wallace Beery for ''The Champ'') as the tormented doctor with a split personality, aided by a makeup job that turned him into a hideous sight. The salute continues with ''The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit'' (1956), at 10, based on Sloan Wilson's novel about corporate life in the 1950s, with Gregory Peck as an urban commuter taking personal inventory, and March as the network head who is demanding his attention. ''I Married a Witch'' (1942), at 12:45 a.m., finds March playing a gubernatorial candidate opposite Veronica Lake's blond sorceress and performing a convincing love scene, even though the two were said to loathe each other in real life. In ''... Tick ...Tick ... Tick'' (1970), at 2:15, he plays the mayor of a small Southern town in which a black sheriff (Jim Brown) sets off racial fireworks. The marathon ends at 4 with ''Christopher Columbus'' (1949), starring March in the title role. 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women chat with Jennifer Garner. Liza Minnelli performs.

The Magazines listing in the Most Wanted chart on Sept. 20 alphabetized the names of five travel magazines instead of correctly ranking them by the number of ad pages in their September issues. The correct listing is: Condé Nast Traveler, with 114.7 pages; Travel + Leisure, 88.4 pages; A.F.'s Budget Travel, 52.9 pages; National Geographic Traveler (Sept./Oct.), 48 pages; and Islands (Sept./Oct.), 42.7 pages.

When I was a boy, I ached to be a scientist. I was the kind of kid who needed to know why and how - right now! - not to mention who, what, where and when. How can there be lightning, but no rain? Why do eels wriggle in the skillet when you're frying them up? Why do dirty socks smell like corn chips? The summer porch was my lab, where I wrote and drew (and dreamed), dissected mummified goldfinches and fiddled with my chemistry set, hoping against hope that something interesting would happen.

Let the verbal combat begin. Starting in earnest this week, candidates across the country are facing each other in high-profile, high-risk debates that political consultants say could matter more than anything else they do before Election Day. More than a half-dozen debates are scheduled for the next two weeks. ''The debate is usually the only full Monty event in the campaign,'' says Chris Lehane, a Democratic strategist with a long history of advising candidates on debate strategy. The typical debate, Mr. Lehane said, ''is that moment when the candidates are on a stage, by themselves, on their own and where the public will extrapolate an awful lot about their character by how they handle themselves.'' In Connecticut tonight, Richard Blumenthal, the Democratic candidate for Senate, will face Linda E. McMahon, his Republican challenger just hours after Ms. McMahon lodged an explosive new charge about Mr. Blumenthal's veracity in describing his record of military service. And in the California governor's race, Jerry Brown and Meg Whitman, who clashed in a debate filled with vitriol over the weekend, mutually agreed this afternoon to cancel another face-off that was scheduled for KGO radio in San Francisco on Tuesday morning. ''There is no debate tomorrow,'' Sterling Clifford, a Brown spokesman, said. An official with Ms. Whitman's campaign also wrote in an email that ''there's no debate. The campaigns have jointly communicated that fact to KGO. There was interest but organizers failed follow through correctly on initial interest.'' Debates between candidates for statewide office often fly well below the national radar. They are typically not televised nationally, or are heard only on local radio or television stations. But the outcome can either cement the direction of a race or sharply alter it. And when political mistakes happen during a debate, the Internet-fueled political media can turn them into part of a broader narrative about their campaigns and about the battles being waged by the political parties more broadly. In the debate between Senator Barbara Boxer and her Republican challenger, Carly Fiorina, for example, Ms. Boxer has opened up a lead with television ads after a debate exchange with Ms. Fiorina, a businesswoman, about shipping jobs overseas. ''Debates are these political performances that produce moments,'' said Kevin Madden, a Republican strategist who served as national press secretary to former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney in 2008. ''Moments that crystallize the attributes, either good or bad, of a candidate and the race itself.'' Florida's Senate candidates will engage in a three-way face-off on Wednesday. The candidates for Senate in Wisconsin - who are locked in a very close race - will debate on Friday. The Illinois Senate contenders will debate on Sunday morning. Debates for Senate races in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Colorado, and for the Colorado governor's race, are also on the books. The candidates for governor in Florida are facing each other for the first time on Friday. In a debate on Monday, Deval Patrick, the Democratic governor of Massachusetts, clashed with his Republican challenger, Charles Baker, in a debate at the Massachusetts Biotechnology Council For Democrats who are running behind their challengers, the debates offer the best opportunity to shake up the race and knock their opponents off track. Republicans can use the personal confrontations to help make use of a national mood in which voters appear to be angry at the establishment. But strategists in both parties said the candidates --and especially the Republicans candidates who are new to big-time politics - should be careful. A bad debate can derail a campaign, they said. ''The political climate is ripe for change,'' said Scott Reed, a Republican strategist who helped run Bob Dole's presidential campaign. ''But candidates in both parties still need a strong debate performance to really close the deal with voters.'' Voters are watching Tea Party-endorsed candidates, in particular, strategists said, to see how they stand up to scrutiny. Many of those candidates are in the glare of big-time politics for the first time. ''The debates are going to be major moments where some of these candidates may steps across the character Rubicon for better or worse,'' Mr. Lehane said. ''In this sense, these are even more important debates for the Republican nominees to address their past comments and controversial positions.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Updated 3:02 p.m. | Two men who had been sought by the police as potential murder witnesses were shot and killed as they sat in a parked sports utility vehicle in the Flatiron District early Monday morning, the police said. The victims had just left a nightclub on East 19th Street, but their slayings may have been connected to two unsolved homicides in Coney Island last year, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Monday. Detectives had identified the men, whose names were not immediately available, as potential witnesses and had sought to speak with them.

An appraisal on Saturday about the actor Tony Curtis, who died on Wednesday, misstated the color of his eyes. They were blue, not ''dark.''

The noise, dust, barricades and occasional explosions associated with construction of the long-awaited Second Avenue subway are driving away customers from businesses along the avenue and plunging many shops and restaurants into deep financial trouble, two dozen merchants said. In July, the Manhattan Chamber of Commerce counted 29 shuttered storefronts between 63rd and 96th Streets -- a once-bustling stretch where the subway's first three stations and the connecting tunnel are being dug. Since then, at least two other businesses have closed. And while the anemic economy has surely taken its toll, many merchants say business has declined 25 percent to 50 percent over the last three years because of the hurdles posed by construction.

At 245 pounds and 6 feet 3 inches, Jeffrey West knows he looks more like a football player than a runner. But that hasn't stopped him from competing in nine marathons in the past three years. ''When I go by, people say, 'Go, big fella, you can do it!''' laughs Mr. West, 45, of Carol Stream, Ill., who plans to be one of 45,000 runners in this weekend's Bank of America Chicago Marathon. ''But I know at the end of the race most people don't want to get beat by the big guy who doesn't look like he can run very fast.''

For a quarter century, Jewish children have hungrily followed the kooky adventures of the Shpy, the adventurous hero of The Moshiach Times, a family-friendly magazine that is published six times a year in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. (Think Highlights, but Jewish.)

MADDALONI--James, 88, of Deer Park, NY on October 2, 2010. Beloved brother of Rose DeChristopher. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Jimmy served his first career as night editor of the New York Post. He later began his second career as a Latin teacher at Irvington High School where he worked for over 20 years. "Madd" as he was affectionately known by his students continued to this day to correspond with and mentor many of his former students on a regular basis. The family will receive friends Tuesday and Wednesday 2-5pm and 7-9:30pm at the Mangano Funeral Home, 1701 Deer Park Avenue, Deer Park, NY. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:15am at SS Cyril and Methodius RC Church in Deer Park. Interment in St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make memorial contributions to: The James Maddaloni Foreign Language Scholarship Fund, Irvington Board of Education, Irvington, NY 10533.
HOFFMAN--Joel, CPA, died October 1, 2010. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Shiva through October 8th. Details at: www.yiwoodmere.org.

The Donmar Warehouse in London said on Monday that it would resume performances of Stephen Sondheim's ''Passion'' on Thursday after an actor in the production was injured by a prop gun during a performance on Saturday. David Birrell, who is playing Colonel Ricci in the Donmar production of the musical, was injured during Saturday's matinee performance and taken by ambulance to a nearby hospital, The Guardian reported. A spokeswoman for the theater said in a statement on Monday: ''Following initial inquiries into the accident at the theater on Saturday, it appears that during the duel scene in 'Passion,' David Birrell's licensed replica stage gun misfired causing some debris to enter his eye. We are, as a matter of priority, carrying out further investigations into the incident. David is recovering well in hospital and is in good spirits.''

A music review on Tuesday about the prolific performer Merzbow, who appeared at Le Poisson Rouge, omitted the name of a musician involved in another productive group, Jazkamer. Besides Lasse Marhaug, John Hegre is also part of Jazkamer.

The planned foreclosure sale of the sprawling Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes was suddenly postponed Monday morning, shortly before the 80-acre, 11,226-unit development was to be sold in the eighth-floor rotunda of the Federal Courthouse downtown. Gregory Cross, a lawyer for CWCapital, the company handling the sale on behalf of the senior debt holders, confirmed that the sale had been postponed until Oct. 13. He declined to comment further. With no bidder willing to put up $3.7 billion to pay off the mortgage, CWCapital had expected to take over the property.

An article on Monday about a strike by the musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra, using information from an orchestra official, misstated the number of black players in the symphony, which faced criticism over its racial makeup and then became a leader in trying to bring blacks into the symphony world. There are three, not two.

John Key, the prime minister of New Zealand, has become the latest and arguably the most influential person this side of the wizard Gandalf to seek a resolution in a labor dispute that has hobbled a planned two-film adaptation there of ''The Hobbit'' by J. R. R. Tolkien. In an interview on New Zealand's TV One Mr. Key said that his government was holding discussions with the feuding camps and that he would be ''greatly concerned'' if the project were moved out of the country, BBC News reported.

Christine O'Donnell wants you, the voter, to know that she is not a witch. ''I'm not a witch'' are the first words Ms. O'Donnell utters in her debut general election ad, a 30-second spot released Monday that will start airing in Delaware Tuesday.

The Magazines listing in the Most Wanted chart on Sept. 20 alphabetized the names of five travel magazines instead of correctly ranking them by the number of ad pages in their September issues. The correct listing is: Condé Nast Traveler, with 114.7 pages; Travel + Leisure, 88.4 pages; A.F.'s Budget Travel, 52.9 pages; National Geographic Traveler (Sept./Oct.), 48 pages; and Islands (Sept./Oct.), 42.7 pages.

An obituary on Saturday about Joseph Sobran, the conservative writer, misstated the manner of his departure from National Review. He was fired after criticizing the magazine's founder, William F. Buckley Jr., in a column for another publication; he did not step down. It also misstated the distributor of his syndicated column and the publisher of his book ''Single Issues: Essays on the Crucial Social Questions.'' The column was distributed by Universal Press Syndicate, not United Press International, and the book was published by Human Life Press, not Griffin Communications.

Two streaks will collide when the Yankees play the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday in Game 1 of their division series. In three previous first-round matchups between the teams, the Yankees have won all five games played in Minneapolis. True, all those games were played at the Twins' old home, the Metrodome. Now they are outdoors, at Target Field, where home runs are not as easy to hit and where Minnesota put together an American League-best home record of 53-28 this season.

Over 100 former members of Congress - many of whom won their own races by pointing out defects in their opponents-- have written to all members of Congress as well as House and Senate candidates, imploring them to reject excessive partisanship as they enter the home stretch of this highly contentious political season. Signed by people including Geraldine A. Ferraro of New York and Bob Packwood of Oregon, the letter says: ''None of us shrank from partisan debates while in Congress or from the partisan contests getting there. During our time in Congress, partisans on the other side may have been our opponents on some bills and our adversaries on some issues. They were not, however, the enemy.''

ROLSTON--Whitfield B.,Jr. September 26, 2010. Born March 3, 1918. Devoted husband and loving father grandfather and great-grandfather. Lifelong New Yorker and artist; He enriched our lives with his spirit. Service, Thursday, October 7th, 11am, Woodlawn Cemetery. The family requests, in lieu of flowers, donations to Harlem Children's Zone, 35 East 125th Street, New York, NY 10035.

An article last Tuesday about efforts by Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, to win re-election as a write-in candidate erroneously attributed a distinction to Strom Thurmond of South Carolina. The Republican senator was one of two people -- not the only one -- to be elected to the United States Senate as a write-in candidate. (William F. Knowland, a Republican from California, was the first to do so, in 1946; Mr. Thurmond followed him, in 1954.)

LONDON -- The British government said Monday that it would no longer pay a universal child subsidy to wealthier families, opening a campaign that may end up transforming Britain's welfare system by reducing benefits to the middle and upper classes. The decision, announced by George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham, departs from the Tory campaign promise to not place income restrictions on this hugely popular benefit and represents perhaps the most direct attack yet on the rich menu of broad-based entitlements that have underpinned European welfare states.

The Chicago Symphony Orchestra's love fest with its new music director, Riccardo Muti, has come to a sudden halt because of Mr. Muti's illness. He canceled his appearances with the orchestra halfway through his one-month fall stint with it so he could fly to Milan on Monday to seek treatment for what the orchestra called ''extreme gastric distress.'' Mr. Muti suffered stomach pains over the weekend and canceled a Saturday-evening gala performance at the last minute -- the orchestra played with no conductor -- and decided on Sunday to consult with his own doctors in Milan. Mr. Muti had been with the Chicago Symphony for only two weeks, beginning his tenure as its new music director after a long courtship and much hoopla accompanying his arrival. ''I cannot express the depth of my regret,'' he said in a statement issued by the orchestra. Its president, Deborah F. Rutter, said, ''The most important thing is that Maestro Muti makes a complete recovery.'' The Chicago Symphony has engaged Harry Bicket, Asher Fisch and Pierre Boulez to replace him for concerts this month.

Is the Democratic guilt trip working? President Obama, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and a host of Democratic Party leaders have been ratcheting up their arguments, urging Democrats to pay closer attention to the midterm elections. And while it will not be known until Election Day whether the pitches pay off, there are signs that at least some Democrats are taking the messages seriously enough to contribute money to the party's effort.

GOLDFARB--Edward, DDS. December 8, 1910 - October 3, 2010. Husband of Norma Goldfarb for 55 years. He graduated from NYU School of Dentistry in 1948 and practiced dentistry in East Meadow, NY, retired to Hemlock Farms, PA and Delray Beach, FL and lived, after Norma's death, in Cadbury at Cherry Hill, NJ. He will be missed by his sons David and Neil Goldfarb, his daughter-in-law Lisa Saiman, his sister Muriel Gray and his grandchildren Ben and Philip Goldfarb.

An article on Sept. 22 about the labeling of genetically engineered salmon misstated the Food and Drug Administration's position on dairy companies' labeling of milk from cows not injected with bovine growth hormone. The F.D.A. suggested that the companies include a statement on the label saying that the F.D.A. had found no differences in the milk from treated and untreated cows. It did not prohibit the labeling unless such a statement was included.

Researchers at Yale and New York University have developed a supercomputer based on the human visual system. On this week's Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Eugenio Culurciello, an associate professor of electrical engineering at Yale who has helped create this supercomputer. He says it could someday allow a car to drive itself. Embedded on a single chip, the system runs more than 100 billion operations a second using only a few watts, which Mr. Culurciello says is less power than a cellphone uses. Other potential applications, he says, include motion monitors in assisted living facilities that could summon help should an elderly person fall and all-around vision for soldiers in the battlefield.

Facebook did something bold today. The world's largest social network now lets members download all the information they've ever uploaded into Facebook - their Wall, photos, videos, friends, messages, events and notes - into a Zip file that can be browsed, for example, to see every photo ever uploaded from your account.
Who's got more Facebook friends, Rahm Emanuel or Michael R. Bloomberg?

Widespread coral bleaching caused by abnormally high sea temperatures is hitting reefs throughout the Caribbean, according to reports from field researchers in the region. It's just the latest development in what is shaping to be one of the worst years on record for the world's coral reefs.

The poet Ted Hughes has always been somewhat overshadowed by his estranged wife Sylvia Plath, whose 1963 suicide at 30 continues to fascinate. That pattern continues even after his death with the discovery of a previously unknown poem he wrote about the night of Plath's suicide. A version of the poem was read on the evening newscast in Britain Wednesday night by Jonathan Pryce, The Guardian of London reported.

In two words: Crazy Juice. But watch and see for yourself.

There was a bittersweet symphony in the air on the penultimate day of Paris Fashion Week, and not just on the sound system at the Grand Palais. There are few things more foreboding, more memorable, than those ominous Steadicam tracking shots of little Danny Torrance riding his Big Wheel down the long halls of the Overlook Hotel in Stanley Kubrick's "The Shining." The way the camera glides smoothly behind him as he pedals his way to freaky twin girls and blood-drenched elevator doors is one of the most enduring shots in all of moviemaking.

The news that the New England Sports Ventures, owner of the Boston Red Sox, agreed to buy the Liverpool Football Club appears to be the penultimate chapter in an intriguing sports-business story that started long before Tom Hicks and George Gillett Jr. went looking for a buyer in April.

The Paris spring shows closed on quite a high as exhausted, sniffling, shuffling editors and buyers saw the collections of Louis Vuitton, Hermès and Miu Miu. On a raised runway, Marc Jacobs seemed to pitch Louis Vuitton to the affluent Asian consumer, or at least acknowledge the considerable influence that China and other Asian countries have on fashion and luxury retailing. Virtually every look seemed dipped in electric-bright colors - fuchsia, red, jade, purple, orange - and then rolled in glitter. The models, their hair smoothed into tight rolls with a flip over one eye, sometimes walked three or four abreast on the catwalk, like shows in the past - and maybe in the future. The clothes, which included a black and white gown with the silhouette of a panda's head, were tempting for their New World sheen. Mr. Jacobs made his campy point without overdoing it.

The Atlantic sturgeon, an armored, ancient, kayak-size denizen of eastern rivers and coasts, is still ailing despite strict fishing limits, so federal officials on Tuesday proposed giving it protection under the Endangered Species Act. The plan, after a period of public comment, would give endangered or threatened status to five populations of the species grew out of a petition last year by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

The Park Avenue Armory, as the venue for the Winter Antiques Show, has seen its share of American quilts. But it has never seen an extravaganza quite like what the American Folk Art Museum will bring to the 55,000-square-foot Drill Hall from March 25 to 30. The museum will present an exhibition of more than 650 red and white American quilts, owned by the New York collector Joanna Rose. In announcing the exhibition, which will be free to the public, the museum's executive director, Maria Ann Conelli, described it as an effort to reach new audiences. Ms. Rose and her husband, Daniel, are covering the costs of the presentation and also donating 50 quilts to the museum.

As the Rangers and Rays series gets under way on Wednesday, you should not be surprised if a Rangers pitcher throws a low-hit gem at some point during the series. The Rays had five games this season when the opposing pitching staffs allowed one or no hits. This includes the May 9 perfect game by the A's Dallas Braden and the June 25 no-hitter by the Diamondbacks' Edwin Jackson. Add in the three one-hitters thrown at the Rays by Cleveland, Toronto and Boston, and the Rays had the most low-hit games in a single season since 1920 with five.

On June 13, 1948, the 25th anniversary of the opening of Yankee Stadium, Babe Ruth stood alone at home plate acknowledging the cheers of thousands in a ceremony retiring his number. Nat Fein, a photographer for The New York Herald-Tribune, took a big chance. He didn't line up with the other photographers along the first-base line or alongside the Life magazine photographer Ralph Morse, who took the shot from somewhere near the pitcher's mound. Instead, he stood behind Ruth, capturing the stadium and teammates in the same frame. He said of that day: "The Number 3 was the thing I was interested in. I felt the only way to tell the story of Babe retiring was from the back."

We're all used to hearing that everything we once thought was good for us is not. But even within that framework, the latest science about antioxidants, free radicals and exercise is telling. As many of us have heard, free radicals are molecules created by the breakdown of oxygen during metabolism. Each of us constantly creates free radicals simply by living and breathing. But these molecules are highly reactive and capricious, sometimes attacking other cells and damaging tissue. Wilding free radicals have been linked with a number of diseases and with aging. Exercise, because it requires increased oxygen consumption, also increases the production of free radicals. So, many experts began urging the fitness-minded to pop large doses of antioxidant vitamin supplements, like vitamins C and E, to counteract the presumed damaging effects of the free radicals. Food alone would not supply sufficient levels of the necessary antioxidants, it was thought. The exercising body needed help from vitamins.

In total, 155 measures are on the ballots in 36 states, a number roughly unchanged from previous years.
Scientists at a California research facility appeared likely to lose their challenge to the checks, judging from the justices’ questions during arguments at the Supreme Court.

The more ornery side of Carl P. Paladino insists on being heard.

Phillies pitcher Roy Halladay prepares to start a division series opener Wednesday against the Reds.

A four-bedroom contemporary house in Virginia, a one-bedroom condo in Boston, and a three-bedroom house with views of downtown Boise, Idaho.

Soon Americans won’t have to pick between bad insurance or none. Until then, expect marketplace disruptions.

Food events, ranging from a book discussion to a truffle shaving to a Brooklyn tasting.

Morphoses at the Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series employs a formula that could use some new ideas.

FINGEROTH--Blanche S. Age 93, died peacefully on October 4, with her children at her side. An independent spirit, she thrived and inspired as wife, mother and teacher. An example of how to live a meaningful life. Born in the Bronx, daughter of Dr. Morris and Fanny (Hartman) Silverman, and step-daughter of Jane Silverman. A Phi Beta Kappa Society graduate of Hunter College, obtained a Master's degree in education from Columbia University Teachers College. As wife of the late Cantor Robert R. Fingeroth, she formed a bond of love and partnership with him that lasted three decades. Beloved mother of James N. (Patricia), Daniel J. (Varda) and the late Ethan S. (Barbara) Fingeroth. Devoted grandmother, aunt, cousin, mentor and friend. An inspiration and role model, modest in her triumphs and courageous in the face of adversity. She loved Jewish life and culture, French, Shakespeare and the world of ideas. A gifted speech therapist she helped many express themselves clearly and effectively. Funeral 11am, Wednesday, October 6 at Plaza Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St., New York, NY.

TALBOT--Phillips, New York, NY. He was respected and loved as president of Asia Society from 1970 to 1981. Our Trustees and friends salute him as an astute diplomat, groundbreaking observer of Asian affairs and a great leader.

TALBOT--Phillips. Phil was one of the kindest, nicest persons I have ever known. Both he and Mildred were very special human beings. How blessed I was to have known them and to have had them as my friends. Deepest condolences to Nancy, Susan and David. Ann Phillips

For his next movie, Zack Snyder will once again take to the skies - not with owls, but with one of the most recognizable and enduring heroes in comic books: Superman. On Monday, Warner Brothers said that Mr. Snyder was in negotiations to direct a new Superman movie for the studio that is planned for release at the end of 2012. Though Mr. Snyder is best known for darkly stylish, high-adrenaline action movies like ''300'' and ''Watchmen,'' both adapted from popular graphic novels, his most recent film is the animated feature ''Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole,'' which has grossed about $30 million domestically over 10 days of release. Mr. Snyder is currently working on ''Sucker Punch,'' an action movie focusing on an ensemble of fetishized females, which is planned for release next year.

LudoBites, the Los Angeles pop-up restaurant, is totally going to the San Fernando Valley. Krissy Lefebvre, who runs LudoBites with her husband, Ludo Lefebvre, said that the sixth iteration of their roving guerrilla-style kitchen and dining room will temporarily take over the space that had been the restaurant Max, at 13355 Ventura Boulevard in Sherman Oaks, Calif., east of the 405 Freeway.

FLAMM--Gerald H.,M.D., of New Haven, CT, entered into eternal rest on October 5, 2010. Husband of the late Ruth S. Flamm, he died at Branford, CT. He was the father of Attorney Brett C. Flamm and Sheila F. Taylor-Flamm of New Haven. Son of the late Maxwell and Sadie Flamm, Gerry was born in Brooklyn, NY on March 15, 1920. He is predeceased by his infant daughters, Marjorie Heather and Vickie Sue and brothers, Arthur and Robert Flamm, both of NY. Gerry was the first chairman of the Department of Psychiatry at the Hospital of St. Raphael, New Haven, CT and served in numerous administrative and teaching positions at Bronx Municipal Hospital, Downstate Medical Center, State University of NY, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Yale University School of Medicine. He held several offices in the American Psychiatric Association and served on other national and CT medical commissions and boards. He was the founder and first president of the American Association of General Hospital Psychiatrists. On October 7, the family will receive visitors beginning at 3:00pm at the Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, 543 George Street, New Haven. Rabbi Benjamin Scolnic will conduct a service at 4:00pm. A graveside service will be held on October 8, at 11:00am at New Montefiore Cemetery, West Babylon, Long Island, New York. Shiva will be held at 177 Stepstone Hill Rd., Guilford, CT on October 9th, 6:30 to 9:00pm and on October 10th from 3:00 to 9:00pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the Hospital of St. Raphael, c/o Marshall Mandelkern, M.D., Chairman Department of Psychiatry, 1450 Chapel Street, New Haven, CT 06510; Connecticut Hospice, 100 Double Beach Road, Branford, CT 06405; or Smilow Cancer Center, Department of Complimentary Services, Development Office, 2 Howe St. #

Not too long ago, the Atlanta Braves and the San Francisco Giants were regulars on the October stage. The teams made 20 combined playoff appearances from 1987 to 2005, winning seven pennants. Yet in each of the last four seasons, the Giants and the Braves went home early. Neither team fell into total disrepair, but both were under .500 in their playoff absences, and the Giants fell to last place in 2007, the final season of the Barry Bonds era.

9 P.M. (13, 49) MACBETH ''Great Performances'' presents Rupert Goold's film adaptation of his stage production of Shakespeare's Scottish tragedy, relocated to a nameless 20th-century netherworld and starring Patrick Stewart, below, and Kate Fleetwood in their Tony-nominated roles. Reviewing the play, which originated at the Chichester Festival Theater in England before appearing at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and moving to Broadway in April 2008, Ben Brantley wrote that Mr. Goold's ''good and nasty interpretation'' has ''enough flash, blood and mutilated bodies to satisfy a Wes Craven fan.'' He added: ''What makes this one a must-see is Mr. Stewart's thrilling recognition that his character is as close kin to the fatally introspective Hamlet as he is to power-wielding men of ill will like Richard III. His performance is the first I have seen to realize completely what the scholar Harold Bloom means when he calls this play 'a tragedy of the imagination.' '' 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW The women interview Patrick Stewart, who is back on Broadway, with T. R. Knight, in a revival of David Mamet's two-man comedy, ''A Life in the Theater,'' now in previews and scheduled to open on Tuesday at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater.

DIENST--Richard A.,of Manhattan died on Saturday, October 2. Richard, 71, leaves behind his beloved wife Greer G. Griffith and his three loving children Daniel, Jonathan and Jennifer. He was a devoted father-in-law to Jill Dienst, Victoria Dienst and Jeffrey Kolitch; and an adoring grandfather of Emma, Nicole, Jared, Teddy, Sam, Kate, Ben and Tess. Richard had a long, distinguished career as a trusted counselor and leading attorney for government officials as well as leaders in the fields of insurance, finance and philanthropy. He represented law enforcement unions and also served as a law school professor. Richard passionately argued the constitutional rights of his clients in state and federal courts including the U.S. Supreme Court. For more than 30 years, Richard served as counsel to the NYPD's Detectives Endowment Association, Lieutenants Benevolent Association and Captains Endowment Association. He defended some of the highest ranking members of the NYPD concerning investigations and allegations of official misconduct before the Knapp Commission, the Office of the Special State Prosecutor and the Mollen Commission. He also served as counsel to the Federal Bureau of Investigation Agents Association. Richard will be remembered for his kind and generous heart, his loyalty and his sense of humor. He loved art, music, travel, literature and his dogs. Some of his happiest times were spent cooking for his family and friends. Richard was born and raised in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of Alfred University and Brooklyn Law School. He was previously married to Linda Dienst, the mother of their three children. He is pre-deceased by his sister Norma Bernstein. Richard served on the board of the Respect for Law Alliance. He was an advocate for 'Angel on a Leash' and the 'Delta Society' groups - which help therapy dogs bring joy to children and adults in health care facilities. Visitation at 4pm and Celebration of His Life at 5:30pm, Wednesday, October 6 at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers can go to: Angel On A Leash, 630 9th Ave., New York, NY 10036 or Delta Society, 875 124th Ave., Bellevue, WA 98005. Richard will be greatly missed by all who had the privilege of knowing him.

Henry R. Kravis, the billionaire private equity executive, has pledged $100 million to Columbia Business School, the largest gift in the school's history and the biggest donation he has ever made. The money from Mr. Kravis, a co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and a 1969 graduate of the school, will help finance the school's move to Columbia's planned satellite campus in Harlem. One of the two new buildings for the school will be named after him.

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Friday about the pairings for the United States Ryder Cup team reversed the identifications of the two golfers shown during a practice round. Jeff Overton was at the right, swinging a club, while his playing partner Bubba Watson watched.

What's next for Nathan Lane, after his Broadway run in ''The Addams Family'' ends in the spring? Mr. Lane is considering Douglas Carter Beane's new play, ''The Nance,'' about a performer who played the role of the nance in burlesque shows in the early-20th century. Nance, or nancy boy, is disparaging slang for an effeminate or homosexual man, and nances were popular theatrical figures, akin to blackface performers, during the 1920s and '30s. Mr. Beane, in a telephone interview, said he held a reading of the play in his living room about a month ago with Mr. Lane, Benjamin Walker (''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson''), Daphne Rubin-Vega (''Rent'') and Kevin Chamberlin (''The Addams Family''), and that he was hoping to do a reading guided by a director at Lincoln Center Theater this season.
The United Tastes article last Wednesday about Baltimore's love of lake trout misspelled a bread that accompanies the dish in one Caribbean-style restaurant. It is coco bread, not coconut bread.

Activision, the big video game publisher, announced on Tuesday that Call of Duty: Black Ops, the highly anticipated combat game scheduled to be released Nov. 9, will be available in 3-D. The decision is a significant step forward for 3-D gaming, even though very few consumers own televisions or computer video cards able to display such images. Call of Duty is one of the premier game franchises in the world and Black Ops is one of the first big-budget games to fully use 3-D systems. Black Ops will deliver 3-D on both the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 in addition to Windows PCs that use 3-D-capable video cards from Nvidia.

An article on Friday about the campaign strategy of Marco Rubio, the Republican Senate candidate in Florida, misstated his earnings as a lawyer. He earned $1.2 million from 2004 to 2008; he did not earn $1.2 million in a single year.

The quality of life that we came here for was quiet. You don't live in a place where you have to take an hour-and-15-minute ferry ride to live next to an industrial park. And that's where we are right now. CHERYL LINDGREN, who lives near wind turbines in Vinalhaven, Me. [A1]

When Elizabeth Goodyear died late last month, at 103, a handful of friends, all more than two generations younger, sat vigil. They toasted her over dark chocolate, the elixir Ms. Goodyear had savored daily since she was 3 years old, and Champagne, a more recent favorite. Two years ago, a front-page article in The New York Times featured Ms. Goodyear, a lifelong lover of books, and the small group of people who would stop by her apartment, in Murray Hill, to read to her after she lost her sight. Those readers became a family to Ms. Goodyear, who had outlived her relatives and loved ones.

DRUSS--Dr. Richard, age 77, died peacefully at home on October 4th, 2010 in New York City from complications of Parkinson's Disease. Dr. Druss was a Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at Columbia-Presbyterian College of Physicians and Surgeons, and a supervising and training analyst at the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research. Dr. Druss is survived by his wife, Margery, a sister, Susan, and his two children, Benjamin and Elizabeth. He is also survived by four grandchildren, his son's children, Noah and Jared and his daughter's children, Jonah and Maya. A small family service will be held on Friday at 12:00pm Westchester Hills Cemetery. Contributions in his memory can be directed to VNSNY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, 7th floor, New York, 10001.

SPIEGEL--Dr. Gregory W. A prominent surgical pathologist at St. Thomas' Hospital in London, England, died September 27, 2010. Greg was a first-rate diagnostician who worked at prestigious hospitals abroad and stateside. Before moving to the UK in 2003 he was a histopathologist at Roswell Park Cancer Institute, a major teaching hospital in Buffalo, NY. He did residencies in his field at Memorial Sloan-Kettering in New York City, Albert Einstein School of Medicine in the Bronx, and Barnes Hospital in St. Louis, MO. He attended medical school and did his undergraduate work at Washington University in St. Louis. Greg was born in St. Louis, MO in 1945. He lived in New York City for many years where he married his beloved wife Linda Christian and raised two children, Christopher and Gretchen. Greg was the son of Adam and Mary Jane (Wulf) Spiegel. His mother, younger brother Clifton and wife Linda predeceased him. He leaves his father Adam of St. Louis, his son Christopher of St. Petersburg, FL and his daughter Gretchen of Brooklyn, NY. His burial will be at a later date and for family members only. Donations in Greg's name may be made to Baystate Visiting Nurse & Hospice, 50 Maple Street, P.O. Box 9058, Springfield, MA 01102-9058.

A Reporter's Notebook article on Monday about the trial of four men on charges of plotting to bomb synagogues in the Bronx quoted incorrectly from comments by the judge, Colleen McMahon. Judge McMahon, speaking of her preference for brevity, said, ''My goal in life is to pare words from overly long, redundant, verbose, disorganized charges that have grown like Topsy over time.'' She did not say ''grown like top seed.'' (''Grow like Topsy'' is a reference to a character in ''Uncle Tom's Cabin,'' who says at one point, ''I spect I grow'd.'')

In the early years of the Seamen's Church Institute, sailors arriving from the Atlantic would congregate for prayer in floating chapel barges anchored in Lower Manhattan. The institute replaced the chapels with a pair of hotels on South and State Streets, where in 1913 seamen paid 25 cents for a room. But after 176 years in the South Street Seaport area the institute, whose mission had gone well beyond its original incarnation as a maritime ministry, was leaving New York, officials said last week.

On June 13, 1948, Babe Ruth acknowledged the cheers of thousands as his number was retired. Nat Fein of The New York Herald Tribune stood behind Ruth, capturing the crowd and the players in the same frame. An appropriately overcast day nailed the mood: Ruth would live just two more months before dying of cancer. This summer, I attended a groundbreaking ceremony for Heritage Field at the site of the old Yankee Stadium. I stood where Fein snapped his famous photo, which won the Pulitzer Prize, and faced in the same direction. Ruth's teammates would have stood where the flags were set up for the groundbreaking, and home plate would

FREEDMAN--Lee B, died suddenly on October 3, while vacationing at the beach in the Mexican Riviera. The devoted son of the late Beatrice and Jerome Freedman of Brooklyn, NY. He was born on October 25, 1934. He was an attorney who worked in the title insurance industry for many years. He is loved and will be greatly missed by his wife of 50 years, Vivienne Soren Freedman; his children Jill and Bruce Sharp; Andrew Freedman and David Freedman; his six wonderful grandchildren, Ryan, Erica and Jalynn Sharp; Alexander and Jared Freedman and Isabel Lau Freedman; sister Ruth P. Freedman of Ann Arbor, MI; in-laws Stan and Ruth Soren and Helene and Murray Kaplan. His nieces, nephew, grandnephews, cousins, dear friends and business associates will remember him for his keen and joyful sense of humor and robust laugh, his interest in all things political and his unending generosity of spirit and in other ways. His passing has left a gaping hole in our hearts. Funeral on Thursday, October 7, 2010 at 11am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY. (516-921-5757). Burial to follow immediately at Mt. Golda Cemetery, 500 Old Country Rd., Huntington Station, NY. The family will observe Shiva through Sunday evening, October 10 at the home of Jill and Bruce Sharp.

The conservative American Crossroads and its related advocacy group, Crossroads GPS - both brainchildren of Mr. Rove and the Republican strategist Ed Gillespie - announced a nearly $4.25 million nationwide advertising campaign today in eight crucial Senate races.

VIETOR--Thomas Frederick III, 66 of Katonah, NY died October 1st of cancer. The son of Carolyn Raymond and Thomas F. Vietor Jr. Tom was born and raised in Manhattan, graduated from St. Paul's School, the University of Pennsylvania and served in the Air National Guard. He was a member of the New York Yacht Club and a former Board Member of the Orchestra of St. Luke's. He spent his career at Johnson & Higgins and then Marsh. He retired as Chairman of Marsh FINPRO Global. He is survived by his wife Jeanne K. Windbiel, son Tommy Vietor of Washington, DC, daughter Taylor Vietor, stepson John Cunningham, sister, the Reverend Julie (Vietor) Kelsey of Branford, CT and numerous nieces and nephews. A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY on Thursday, October 7th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to: GU Oncology Research Fund, Dr. David Nanus, 1305 York Ave., Box 403, New York, NY 10021.

Do you have dinnerware designed by Roy Lichtenstein, Keith Haring and James Rosenquist, and glassware by Sol Lewitt in your cupboard? The Museum of Arts and Design does in an exhibit called Eat Drink Art Design. In addition to the big name pieces, there is simple, beautifully crafted rustic Japanese stoneware alongside equally elegant disposable white Japanese dishes made from bamboo and sugar cane pulp. Scores of plates designed by Peter Ting and produced by Royal Crown Derby in England make up a display called Constellation Manhattan. A surreal silver Melting Teapot by Myra Mimlitsch-Gray is one of the rare, highly impractical pieces on view. Eat Drink Art Design is on the third floor of the Museum of Arts and Design at Columbus Circle through March 27, Tuesdays through Sundays 11 a.m. to 6 p.m., except Thursdays when it stays open until 9 p.m. The disposable Japanese Wasara plates are sold in the museum shop, six for $15. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Chur Journal article last Wednesday, about efforts in the eastern Swiss city of Chur and surrounding region of Graubünden to preserve Romansh, the local language, misstated the method used to cure a thinly sliced raw beef for which the region is famous. The beef is air-dried, not smoked. The article also misstated the timeframe during which the first Romansh translation of the Bible was published. It was in the mid-16th century, not 1973. And because of an editing error, the article misstated the percentage of the Swiss population that the 60,000 speakers of Romansh represent. It is less than 1 percent, not 1 percent.

NITZBURG--Patricia, of NYC and Dublin, NH, daughter of Lucius Thayer and Virginia Speare, died of post-surgical complications on September 29. Her loss is deeply mourned by her daughters Amy Case and Jessica Thayer, her son-in-law Alex Case, other family, friends, and colleagues. She was married from 1960-1982 to Stanley Nitzburg, recently deceased. She graduated from Beaver Country Day School and Smith College, and received a MSW from Columbia University. In 1971 she joined the Jewish Board of Family Services (JBFCS) and served for 34 years. In 1984 the National Academies of Practice in Social Work celebrated her as "A Distinguished Practitioner." She is remembered at JBFCS as "always the voice of sanity" and "a major force in clinical services who understood what it was to be in need. Everybody wanted to work with her." She devoted herself to the lives of others. Her musical passions included the Metropolitan Opera, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. She was an avid traveler, and in July had returned from her 12th African Safari to see beloved elephants. A memorial service will be held October 10 at 1pm at The Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the World Wildlife Fund, www.worldwildlifefund.org

Deloris Van Cartier, the aspiring disco star turned murder witness turned woman of the cloth, now has a New York home to hide out in: the musical adaptation of ''Sister Act,'' the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg comedy, will come to the Broadway Theater this spring, press representatives for the show said on Tuesday. The musical, which has a score by Alan Menken, lyrics by Glenn Slater and a book by Cheri and Bill Steinkellner, will be directed by Jerry Zaks, a consultant on the Broadway incarnation of ''The Addams Family.'' It is to begin previews on March 24 with an opening night set for April 20. No casting was immediately announced for the show's Broadway run; a West End version of ''Sister Act'' starring Patina Miller as Deloris opened at the London Palladium in June 2009. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

An article on Monday about college football teams that are jockeying for the No. 2 ranking misstated, in some editions, the position of Nevada in The Associated Press poll. It is No. 21 -- not No. 25, which was its ranking the previous week.

Virtually every playwright has an unfinished or unresolved script tucked in a drawer somewhere. For Tony Kushner, that play was ''Henry Box Brown,'' a one act written in the early 1990s while he was finishing his epic ''Angels in America,'' whose two parts went on to win back-to-back Tony Awards for best play in 1993 and 1994. Mr. Kushner wrote ''Henry Box Brown'' for Juilliard School of Drama students to perform while he was playwright-in-residence there from 1990 to 1992, but the play never ended up being mounted through Juilliard, or anywhere else, until now. For just seven performances that conclude on Tuesday night, graduate acting students at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts are quietly holding a world premiere production of the play, now titled ''Henry Box Brown: Political-Historical-Doggerel-Vaudeville,'' in a tiny theater space in the East Village.The real-life title character, a Virginia slave in the 19th century, became internationally known for encasing himself in a box used to ship tobacco and then sent via mail delivery to the safe hands of a group of abolitionists in Philadelphia. Brown eventually left the United States for Great Britain, to insure his continued freedom as a fugitive slave, and began touring music halls through northern England to share his life story.

LEACH--Ralph F. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the passing of Ralph F. Leach, a member of the Juilliard board from 1974 to 1992 and its vice chairman from 1976 to 1988. With extraordinary intelligence, judgment, and grace, Ralph helped guide the School through several transitional periods and was an important voice for many programs that exist to this day. Our deepest condolences go out to his wife, Harriet, his children David, Randy, and Barbara, and his grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and many friends. The Patient Money column on Saturday, about the complexities of signing up for Medicare this year, misstated the top level of the so-called doughnut hole in Part D prescription coverage. As the column noted, the hole opens when the insured reaches $2,830 in total prescription expenses for the year. After that, beneficiaries must pay for drugs out of pocket until expenses exceed $4,550 -- not $6,440.

The attraction of reading what a sitting Supreme Court justice has to say about interpreting the Constitution is undoubtedly what has turned Justice Stephen G. Breyer's new book, "Making Our Democracy Work," into a surprise best seller. Commentators and reviewers have also emphasized the Constitution-related passages in the book, particularly Justice Breyer's cogent analysis of why "originalism" falls short and why the interpretive goal should be to engage with the framers' deepest values rather replicate their 18th-century frame of reference. His point, as the book's title suggests, is for judges to make their way through the mists of history to a Constitution that works today.

City limits, property lines and state borders appear clear and inviolable on a map. It's a hoary old chestnut, but New York truly is the city that never sleeps - at least not while there is an opening in town. Last night, T's fashion department split up and hit the streets. The Garment District showroom of Loden Dager, the American men's-wear clothing label, threw a friends and family shopping event. In SoHo, Uniqlo celebrated the launch of the +J collection, designed by Jil Sander, by allowing guests to pre-shop without the public frenzy. Nearby, the Romanian footwear import Musette hosted fashionable feet at the opening of its first Stateside store. And across town at the Earnest Sewn boutique in the Meatpacking District, David Yurman feted his son Evan's latest men's jewelry collection. Yurman the Younger's offerings included a line of sterling silver bracelets with intricate wave carvings and identification tags with classic onyx inlays. "The inspiration was Japanese prints and ornaments," he said. "I wanted to bring craftsmanship to modern times with antiquated, traditional techniques. I feel like that is something that is lacking."

Once a design consultant for Etro and Missoni and the creator of her own high-end knitwear line, Uberta Zambeletti personifies both Milan's scrappy entrepreneurial side and its affinity for bourgeois, slightly bohemian luxe. Now she is channeling her finely edited high-low sensibility at Wait and See, the boutique she just opened in a former convent near the Duomo. ''Milan is so full of brands, but it's either cute little dresses or Balenciaga, with no in-between,'' she says. ''You should be able to get a great, affordable dress without having to go to Zara.'' Wait and See carries jeans, sparkly platform shoes, organic potpourri and evening wear, with prices ranging from about $3 to $1,300. Among Zambeletti's favorites: Sandrina Fasoli's cocktail dresses, Owen Barry's sheepskin coats, Isaac Reina's leather and silicone handbags and the American label Hazel Brown's soft leather pants. ''Everything has a bit of an edge to it,'' she says, ''but nothing is too extreme.'' Via Santa Marta 14; 011-39-02-7208-0195; waitandsee.it.

My assistant and I go through all the letters sent to the Public Editor. Starting this week, we will post selected letters responding to my columns, beginning with the group below. This week's letters are in response to my most recent column, Scholarly Work, Without All the Footnotes.

MINNEAPOLIS - As he so often has in the past, Mariano Rivera recorded the most important out in the Yankees' Game 1 victory Wednesday night. Getting Denard Span to ground out with two on and two out in the eighth inning improved the Yankees' win probability by 13 percent, according to baseball-reference.com, to 92 percent over all. Their second most important out came from someone whose brightest career postseason moment also came against the Twins in last year's American League division series. Derek Jeter started calling Dave Robertson "Houdini" last year after he escaped a bases-loaded, no-out jam in the 11th inning of Game 2. This time, Robertson was asked to get only one out, but what an out it was, striking out Jim Thome and thwarting a two-on, two-out rally in the seventh. Robertson threw three straight curve balls to Thome. The second dropped over the plate for a called second strike. The third bounced in front of the plate and drew a feeble swing. "That was a beautiful sequence," Alex Rodriguez said. "He came with the fastball then threw him three nasty breaking balls." Omitting a second left-handed reliever was a calculated risk by Joe Girardi, who, with left-handed starters set to pitch in four of five games, figured that Boone Logan would be sufficient to navigate through Joe Mauer, Thome and Jason Kubel. To start the seventh, Girardi went with Logan, who got two outs but gave way to Robertson after Mauer singled. The Yankees had seven more outs to get, but the bullpen was set up almost perfectly. Kerry Wood matched up well with the bottom of the Twins' order, which had right-handed hitters in three of four slots, and the Yankees never have to worry about matchups when Rivera came in. Every one is in Rivera's favor. If a save situation arises again Thursday, Girardi will obviously turn to Rivera again, though he was uncertain whether he would ask him to pitch multiple innings for a second straight night. Rivera's struggles last month began on Sept. 11, when he surrendered two ninth-inning runs in Texas, the night after working two innings, and Girardi said he was cognizant of a possible link. "I would prefer not to do it tonight, but I said that last night," Girardi said.

Thanks to its fame as a literary device, the tiny madeleine has an outsize reputation. But France has as many varieties of pastries as it has cheeses (though, to our knowledge, no one has ever linked them to a resistance to being governed). Two of them, the canelé, a custardy confection with a caramelized crust from Bordeaux, and the financier, an almond-flour tea cake that was first sold in the area around La Bourse (traders prized them as a convenient snack, hence the name), are favorite afternoon treats with the French.

The weather has been hot, and fall flowers, like goldenrod, have thrived. As I strolled through the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens the other day, scouting with a colleague to prepare for a coming school field trip, I was jealous that local Brooklyn beekeepers had it so good, as hundreds, if not thousands, of honeybees mingled with native pollinators on lush native flora in the park.

When Meera Oliva last wrote for Motherlode, she shared thoughts about her son, Elan. The boy was born with a cleft lip, and, several days before the surgery, Oliva described how she would miss his imperfect smile, even though she knew the repair was necessary and the timing was right. (Elan's doing wonderfully, she reports, with " just the slightest scar to show where his cleft once was, and we love his new smile just as much as we loved the old one, which we do still miss from time to time.")

For an international style capital, home to A-list designers who set the trends and dominate the news, Milan gets no respect. The fashion pack descends four times a year and complains about the weather, the traffic. They shop, pillaging the stores on Via Montenapoleone, and then they leave, in a hurry to get to Paris. Even the Italians dislike Milan. Or rather, the Italians in particular dislike it. Any native of Rome or Florence or Bologna will tell you that all people do there is work work work, that it's gray, industrial, unwelcoming, without a soul. I've heard nicer things about Cleveland.

First Cuba, now Russia. American Ballet Theater has added Moscow to its touring itinerary for the 2010-11 season, the company announced Thursday. The March engagement, part of the Mstislav Rostropovich Week Festival, will include the premiere of a new work by Benjamin Millepied commissioned by the festival. American Ballet Theater last performed in Moscow in 1960. That was also the last time it appeared onstage in Havana, where the company will be returning next month.

Our friends at the Wheels blog report that Honda has the greenest vehicles in the United States, according to a study released on Thursday by the Union of Concerned Scientists. The automaker barely edged out Toyota and Hyundai, which tied for second place. The results were based on the fleets' impact on global warming.

Of all the houses that designers create, their own are often the most interesting, since they tend to be the most revealing. Leslie Williamson, a San Francisco photographer, assumed that this was true of Modernist designers, too, but had a hard time finding books on the subject. Thus, "Handcrafted Modern: At Home With Midcentury Designers" (Rizzoli) was born. An intimate look at 13 houses and one apartment (that of the furniture designer Vladimir Kagan), Williamson's book visits the homes of masters of studio furniture like Wharton Esherick, George Nakashima and J.B. Blunk; industrial designers like Russel Wright, Charles and Ray Eames, and Irving Harper; and the architects Walter Gropius and Albert Frey.

The global drug market will grow  5 to 7 percent in 2011, to $880 billion, as higher spending in nations like China, Brazil and India makes up for slow growth and patent losses in the United States, according to a forecast released Wednesday by IMS Health, an industry data company.

The international furlough means the world's top leagues will go dark this weekend while their best players don the jerseys of their national teams. Most of the compelling games will be played in Europe, where teams will continue the Euro 2012 qualifying campaign. (Rob Hughes suggests these games to watch.) Elsewhere, teams will play friendly matches, including the Americans' Oct. 9 exhibition against Poland and their Oct. 12 match with Colombia.

François Nars's makeup can be described as dramatic, but his limited-edition Bento Box lipstick set takes the concept literally. Inspired by a porcelain pot of lip stain used for kabuki actors that Nars found in Japan 10 years ago, the set of two cups of hand-poured color comes in a handsome wooden box with a wisteria-handled lip brush. "I've always been fascinated with the concept of kabuki makeup," Nars says. "It's about symbolism and using color to create drama." The lipstick application is as seductive as its presentation. "You dip the brush into the cup, around the perimeter, to pick up product, and simply paint," he says. "It's a beautiful process." Unless you want to look like a Japanese theater character, however, Nars recommends using a little restraint: "It's highly pigmented, so I suggest starting out light and building for desired intensity. It seems intimidating, but the texture is creamy and light and will move easily." The set will be available for $125 beginning November 1 at Saks Fifth Avenue and Barneys New York, or go to narscosmetics.com/bento to pre-order.

A long-term study of corn production in the Midwest has found that the widespread use of varieties engineered with a bacterial gene that kills insect pests has had big benefits in adjacent fields of conventional corn -- cutting infestations there and boosting farmers' income by billions of dollars. The paper, "Areawide Suppression of European Corn Borer with Bt Maize Reaps Savings to Non-Bt Maize Growers," is being published in the Oct. 8 edition of the journal Science.
Richard Johnson, who has edited The New York Post's Page Six gossip column for nearly 25 years, is leaving the New York tabloid for a job in Los Angeles.

Honda has the greenest vehicles in the United States, with Toyota and Hyundai tying for second place, according to a study released on Thursday by the Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit advocacy group.

Driven by declines on Wall Street, total personal income earned by residents of metropolitan New York fell last in 2009 for the first time in 40 years - by 4.1 percent - according to the latest data from the government's Bureau of Economic Analysis.

A few weeks ago, we asked you to submit recipes and photos of your go-to potluck dishes. We received more than 350 entries, which came from around the world and varied from Shanghainese style belly pork to triple chocolate pecan bites. It was really tough to narrow it down to our top 20, not to mention the five we selected as "editors' picks," but after much debating, testing and tasting, we managed to make the call.

A Montana woman was arrested Wednesday at a Colorado museum after she destroyed an artwork that some observers say depicts Jesus engaged in a sex act. The Denver Post reported that Kathleen Folden of Kalispell, Mont., was taken into police custody after she entered the Loveland Museum/Gallery in Loveland, Colo., and destroyed a work called "The Misadventures of Romantic Cannibals," a lithograph by Enrique Chagoya. The police told The Post that Ms. Folden had used a crowbar or similar tool to break the plexiglass in front of the work and then tore it up. She has been charged with criminal mischief, a felony punishable by a fine of up to $2,000.

A second veteran of Martin Picard's quirky Montreal restaurant Au Pied de Cochon is coming to New York. Medhi Brunet-Benkritly, who worked for four years there, and at Toqué before that, will be the chef at Fedora, the venerable Greenwich Village bistro that Gabriel Stulman, an owner of Joseph Leonard, and his partners bought and are renovating, to open in November.

The documentary on the life and career of Ayrton Senna, the great Brazilian Formula One racecar driver, will have a special screening in Suzuka, Japan, on Thursday, as teams prepare for the Grand Prix of Japan, according to The Globe and Mail. The film opens in theaters across Japan on Friday.

Updated, 1:05 p.m. | A young woman fell from an eighth-floor window of a public housing building on Staten Island, fire officials said. We erroneously reported that she had died, but fire officials say she is in serious condition with multiple fractures and broken bones. The full extent of her injuries was not immediately known. Police officials say the woman is 19, but they have not released her identity.

Virginia's attorney general, an outspoken climate change skeptic, continues his investigation of the former University of Virginia climate researcher Michael Mann, issuing a second civil subpoena demanding documents related to a state-funded grant application, which he contends was marred by fraud. A previous subpoena had been rejected by a state judge, who concluded that Attorney General Ken T. Cuccinelli had failed to provide any justification for suspecting that fraud had been committed. The federal government's exit plan from the American International Group involves one of the largest corporate reorganizations in history. It contemplates the conversion and sale of $49.1 billion in the government's preferred share ownership interests, the $15.5 billion sale of A.I.G.'s Alico subsidiary to MetLife, the approximately $15 billion initial public offering of the company's American International Assurance subsidiary and the repayment of a $20 billion loan to the Federal Reserve.

A Bucks blog post ponders a recent study from Princeton University that found that people reported an increase in happiness as their incomes rose to $75,000 a year. "Then, the impact of rising income on happiness levels off," the post says. What do you think of this finding? How much money do you think you would need a year to be happy? Do you think more money would make you more happy? If so, then how, as the blog post asks, do you explain the fact that "there are plenty of people who seem to have very little money and lots of happiness"?

The Rockefeller Foundation has announced the winners of its 2010 Cultural Innovation Fund competition, which will provide more than $3 million to New York City arts organizations in the form of two-year grants of $50,000 to $250,000. Among the winners are the Park Avenue Armory, the Queens Museum of Art, Dance Theater of Harlem, Creative Time, 3-Legged Dog, the New York Hall of Science, the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts and the New York Foundation for the Arts.

The radical challenge presented to the engineers at Bose, who've dealt with their share of radical challenges through the years, was to incorporate a high-quality, surround-sound audio system invisibly inside a flat-panel television set. Dr. Amar Bose, the engineers' boss, gave the order 10 years ago. The VideoWave arrives next month.

An article on Sept. 5 about people whose birthdays are on Sept. 11 erroneously included an Italian fashion designer on the list. Valentino was born on May 11. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail on Sept 7; this correction was delayed because The Times failed to follow through on the complaint.

The DealBook column on Tuesday, about the possibility that taxpayers will not lose money on the federal bailout of the American International Group, misstated the given name for A.I.G.'s chief executive. He is Robert Benmosche, not Ben.

Bernadette Peters, above left, and Elaine Stritch, above right, giving acclaimed performances in the Broadway musical ''A Little Night Music'' since replacing Catherine Zeta-Jones and Angela Lansbury in July, have agreed to remain with the show through the holiday season, the producers have announced. They will appear through Jan. 9, when the production will close after more than 13 months. The extension will undoubtedly reap financial rewards for the producers and their investors, given that Thanksgiving week through New Year's weekend is usually the most lucrative time of year for Broadway shows.

CHASE--Kenneth S. Loving husband to the late Gertrude S. Chase; beloved father to Peggy, Andy and Beth; dear brother to Larry and Bobbi; A treasured relative and friend who left us with so many wonderful memories that his spirit will be with us everyday. Good things are in our heart for him. And he asked us to say "thanks" to all he knew. Donations in his memory can be made to the Cancer Research Institute www.cancerresearch.org
