An article on Wednesday about the business culture at the Tribune Company after its acquisition by Sam Zell referred incorrectly to federal taxes on an S corporation, which Tribune became after the deal. S corporations pay no federal taxes because shareholders are responsible for all taxes; therefore, taxpayers do not become ''essentially silent partners in the deal.''

LEACH--Ralph F. The Juilliard School deeply mourns the passing of Ralph F. Leach, a member of the Juilliard board from 1974 to 1992 and its vice chairman from 1976 to 1988. With extraordinary intelligence, judgment, and grace, Ralph helped guide the School through several transitional periods and was an important voice for many programs that exist to this day. Our deepest condolences go out to his wife, Harriet, his children David, Randy, and Barbara, and his grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and many friends. His wise counsel and special wit will be missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

A bank loan is not always the mark of trouble. At the end of a political race, it can be a sign of opportunity. The National Republican Congressional Committee said Wednesday that it was taking steps to secure a loan of more than $6.5 million to pay for advertising in the final weeks of the midterm campaign. The infusion of cash is intended to test the waters in a handful of newly competitive districts and keep the ads on air in existing places.

He has tangled with cold-blooded creatures in the ''Jurassic Park'' movies and played both a man of the cloth (on ''The Tudors'') and the spawn of Satan (in the ''Omen'' sequel you probably never saw), so maybe Sam Neill, left, has the ideal qualifications to settle a long-running labor dispute that has plagued the planned film adaptation of ''The Hobbit.'' In an interview with The Otago Daily Times of New Zealand, Mr. Neill, who was raised in New Zealand and lives there, in Queenstown, said ''a cup of tea'' should be enough to resolve a fight between Peter Jackson, the producer and likely director of a two-film ''Hobbit'' franchise, and actors' guilds there that have sought a worldwide boycott of the movies. Over the weekend John Key, the prime minister of New Zealand, said he was ''greatly concerned'' that New Zealand could lose ''The Hobbit'' films to another country. The Otago Daily Times also reported that Gerry Brownlee, the country's minister for economic development, and Chris Finlayson, its minister for arts and culture, met on Monday with Mr. Jackson and Fran Walsh, his wife and producing and writing partner. But Mr. Neill told The Otago Daily Times, ''Unless they wish to calm the situation or indeed mediate, our politicians should absolutely be quiet.'' Mr. Neill added: ''Both parties, it seems to me, need to sit down, take a deep breath and begin talking and -- more importantly -- listening, in the friendly and cooperative way we do things in the New Zealand film industry.''

HomeAgain, a company makes microchip ID devices for pets and supports a pet rescue network, has released a free iPhone app to help volunteers reunite lost pets with their owners. The app, called PetRescuers, taps into a database of 500,000 volunteers who receive e-mails to alert them of lost pets in their area. The company said that 600,000 pets had been reunited with their families by the network since 1996.

The New York Philharmonic will add a concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Oct. 19 to plug a hole caused by the cancellation of a visit to the Republic of Georgia. The orchestra and its music director, Alan Gilbert, right, will tack on another performance of the program being presented Oct. 14-16, which consists of Brahms's Symphony No. 4 and Violin Concerto (with Pinchas Zukerman as soloist), and Webern's Passacaglia (Op. 1). Brahms's ''Academic Festival Overture'' will replace the Webern work in the Oct. 19 concert. The visit to Georgia was to have been the first stop on a European tour but was canceled by Georgia's government because of what it said were money problems.

LOS ANGELES - It's shaping up as two of the more star-studded Republican events of the fall: Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, and Michael Steele, the head of the Republican National Committee, appearing on the same stage - first in Orange County and the following week in Orlando - at what is being billed as ''final path to victory'' rallies, intended to raise campaign funds and build enthusiasm among conservatives as Election Day approaches. But what may be the most interesting thing about the California rally next Saturday is not who is on the stage - but who is not.

Roman Polanski (above left, with ArielleDombasle), who was freed from house arrest in Switzerland in July after officials there rejected an extradition request from the United States, is stepping out in public to a round of French cultural events, from a movie museum display to a new Monet exhibition. This 77-year-old director, who fled the United States in 1978 before being sentenced for having sex with a 13-year-old girl, appeared at a cocktail party on Monday at the French Cinémathèque to celebrate the opening of an exhibition of hairstyles in cinema, ''Brune/Blonde.'' The following night he accompanied his son and friends to a dinner buffet at the Musée Marmottan Monet, which was promoting its new exhibition, which opens on Thursday. The Marmottan director, Jacques Taddei, said he had invited Mr. Polanski, a friend, along with other dignitaries, for an advance viewing of the exhibition.

With his square jaw, flat-top crew cut and steely gaze, B.J. Kang, an F.B.I. special agent, looks as though he just stepped out of central casting.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about criticism of a Maclean's cover article dealing with corruption in Quebec misidentified the government post held by Jean Charest, the provincial leader who demanded an apology to all Quebecers. He is premier, not prime minister.

WEINBERG--Sidney. The Rockefeller University community mourns the passing of our cherished friend Sidney J. Weinberg, Jr. An esteemed and longtime member of The Rockefeller University Council, Jim was a philanthropist of generosity and distinction and an enlightened partner in the struggle against human illness. He was deeply committed to advancing research and education, embracing important health, science, and education initiatives at The Rockefeller University and many other prestigious institutions. We celebrate a life remarkably well lived, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to Jim's wife, Elizabeth, and the entire Weinberg family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Russell L. Carson, Chair John C. Whitehead, Trustee Emeritus Paul Nurse, President

An obituary on Sept. 27 about the reporter Murray Sayle erroneously attributed a distinction to the yachtsman Sir Francis Chichester, about whom Mr. Sayle wrote. He was the first solo sailor to circumnavigate the globe using the route once taken by clipper ships; he was not the first person ever to circumnavigate the globe. (Joshua Slocum is credited with being the first in recorded history to sail around the world singlehandedly.)

It's not uncommon to see grass-roots Web campaigns meant to create opportunities and bring people together. But one disgruntled music listener who says he is acting on behalf of Weezerfans everywhere has started an online movement to persuade that band to break up. The Line Out blog of The Stranger reported that a Seattle resident named James Burns was seeking donations -- to the tune of $10 million -- that he says he will give to Weezer to ''take our money and disappear.'' In a pitch posted at the online campaign site thepoint.com, Mr. Burns writes: ''I am tired of my friends being disappointed year after year. I am tired of endless whimsical cutesy album covers and music videos.'' The effort has apparently caught the attention of Weezer: Patrick Wilson, the band's drummer, wrote on his Twitter account that ''if they can make it 20'' million, ''we'll do the 'deluxe breakup.' ''
An article on Sept. 24 about the killing of a Nicaraguan official in the Bronx misstated the name of the building where he lived. It is the Augusta Arms, not the August Arms.

If you're obsessed with sharing your life in video - and equally enthusiastic about multitasking - you might want to take a look at the Looxcie, a $199 camcorder that you wear over your ear to enable hands-free video capture. The Looxcie connects to a smartphone via Bluetooth to record and share video. (It also doubles as Bluetooth headset for your phone, albeit an inelegant one.) For now, the Looxcie is compatible only with Android 2.0 phones, although the eponymous company says it will add compatibility with BlackBerrys and iPhones later this fall.

9 P.M. (Bravo) THE REAL HOUSEWIVES OF D.C. At last, the moment Washington watchers have been waiting for. The inaugural season comes to a close amid a media frenzy as viewers hear, along with the rest of the incredulous housewives, about the presence at President Obama's first White House state dinner of Michaele and Tareq Salahi, above. They were accused of crashing it last November. The Salahis will join Andy Cohen on ''Watch What Happens: Live,'' at 10:15, to discuss their experiences and to answer viewer questions. 8 P.M. (Fox) BONES Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) investigate the remains of a young man who was last seen strutting his stuff at a nightclub near a New Jersey beach.

WEINBERG--Sidney. The family of Sidney J. Weinberg, Jr announce with great sorrow the death of their beloved husband, father and grandfather on October 4, 2010 of prostate cancer, in Marion MA. A longtime partner of Goldman Sachs and a thoughtful and dedicated philanthropist, he will be missed by all who knew him. The family will receive friends and associates at the Knickerbocker Club, 807 5th Avenue at 62nd St., from 4-8pm on Wednesday, October 13, 2010. In lieu of flowers or any gifts, the family asks that contributions be sent to Columbia University Medical Center for the benefit of the Cerebral Palsy Center, 100 Haven Ave, Suite 29D, New York, NY 10032

DRUSS--Richard, M.D. The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the Association for Psychoanalytic Medicine mourn the loss of our distinguished beloved colleague. He was a master clinician-educator who contributed to the understanding of psychosomatic conditions, a matchless story-teller who repeatedly touched us with his inimitable sense of the absurd, and a psychoanalytic teacher of great depth. A doctor's doctor, he delivered his expertise with humor and wisdom. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Margery, his son Dr. Benjamin, his daughter Dr. Elizabeth and his grandchildren. Eric R. Marcus, M.D. Director CU Psychoanalytic Center Jules Kerman, M.D., Ph.D. President, APM

The Constitution is the rock upon which our nation rests. We must follow it not only when it is convenient, but when fear and danger beckon in a different direction. To do less would diminish us and undermine the foundation upon which we stand. JUDGE LEWIS A. KAPLAN of United States District Court in Manhattan, who barred testimony from a crucial witness in the first trial of a former Guantánamo detainee. [A1]

FINGEROTH--Blanche. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Blanche Fingeroth, beloved mother of James Fingeroth and mother-in-law of Patricia, who are greatly admired for their extraordinary generosity in New York, in Israel, and around the world. We extend our sympathies to James and Patricia and to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

A photograph with an art review on Oct. 1 about the show ''Abstract Expressionist New York: The Big Picture'' at the Museum of Modern Art, and several other pictures in an online slide show, appeared to show museum visitors viewing the exhibit. In fact, the people shown were museum staff members, who were asked by museum officials to be present in the galleries to provide scale and context for the photographs. The photographer acknowledged using the same procedure in other cases when an exhibition was not yet opened to the public.
DEAN--Harry. Fenway Golf Club expresses profound sorrow at the passing of it's esteemed member Harry Dean and extends sincere condolences to his entire family. Jeffrey Citron, President

2:23 p.m. | Updated In response to the White House's pushback against his idea that Hillary Rodham Clinton and Joseph R. Biden Jr. might exchange places, Bob Woodward said this afternoon that the idea of a Biden-Clinton swap is ''on the table'' in the sense that ''any legitimate vote-getting strategy is always on the table in politics.'' Mr. Woodward said in an e-mail to The Caucus that ''the issue is outlined in the book, as Mark Penn laid out the possibility, when Hillary Clinton was considering the offer to be secretary of state.''

A committee of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation on Wednesday recommended that the corporation allocate at least $100 million for the performing arts center planned for ground zero. The money would come from a pool of some $200 million formerly designated for utility companies. At the corporation's board meeting on Wednesday, Kate D. Levin, the New York City cultural affairs commissioner, said the money was important ''to fulfill this critical part of the master plan.'' The financing, which requires approval by the full board, would add to $50 million in federal money set aside for the project, which is controlled by the development corporation. Still unresolved is whether to build the center on the World Trade Center site, as called for in the master plan, or at 130 Liberty Street, site of the former Deutsche Bank building. The center's primary tenant is to be the Joyce Theater, which presents dance.

The bridge column on Monday misstated the schedule of the biggest bridge world championships. They are going on now in Philadelphia and are held every four years. They are not held in ''even-numbered, non-Olympic years.'' (There are no such years under the current Summer and Winter Olympics schedules.)

The TV Watch column in some copies on Tuesday, about the new CNN program ''Parker Spitzer,'' co-hosted by Kathleen Parker and Eliot Spitzer, misidentified which one first said ''Nascar'' when Mr. Spitzer was asked to identify his secret ''guilty pleasure.'' Ms. Parker said it -- not Mr. Spitzer, who nodded in agreement and smiled.

MOORE--Isadore. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Museum at Eldridge Street offer condolences to David Moore, our dedicated Trustee, and his family on the loss of Isadore Moore. Michael Weinstein, Chairman, Board of Directors Bonnie Dimun, Executive Dir.

Philadelphia On the eve of Cincinnati's first playoff game in 15 years, Dusty Baker gushed when he met the news media. ''It feels great to be back,'' he said. ''This is what you yearn for. Sometimes when you've been in this situation many times you sort of take it for granted until it's not there anymore.''

Two new albums, from Kenny Chesney and Lil Wayne, took the top spots on the Billboard chart this week. Mr. Chesney's highly anticipated ''Hemingway's Whiskey'' (Sony Nashville/BNA) earned him his sixth No. 1 album on the chart, with 183,000 in sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Lil Wayne's ''I Am Not a Human Being'' (Cash Money), released while the rapper is still in jail, opened at No. 2 with an expected 110,000 in digital sales. The physical album will be released on Tuesday. The two pushed last week's No. 1 album, ''You Get What You Give'' (Atlantic/Southern Ground) from the country-rock ensemble the Zac Brown Band, to No. 3, with 70,000 albums sold. It landed just ahead of a new release from Gucci Mane, ''Appeal: Georgia's Most Wanted'' (Asylum Records), which moved just over 60,000 copies. Eminem's ''Recovery'' (Aftermath/Interscope) rounded out the Top 5 with just short of 60,000 copies sold.

When Daniella Romano was hired as archivist of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, she figured she would spend time cataloging engineering and architectural drawings from the days when warships docked and departed from there. She did not expect to receive an urn containing a diva's ashes - a diva who had sung her way into history. The singer was Ada Eugenia von Boos Farrar, who performed ''I Love You Truly'' in an inventor's Manhattan laboratory in 1907. The inventor had a microphone and some odd-looking equipment. One thing led to another, and what happened that night is believed to have been the first radio broadcast of a song.

KAPLAN--Milton, 90, passed away on October 5. Beloved husband and best friend of Doris (Liman) for 63 years. Loving pop of Barbara Aspelin (John), Sam (Kathy), grandson Will, and sister Stephanie Horowitz. Services at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Flatbush Avenue and Avenue U at 12 noon on Friday. Shiva at home on Saturday, Sunday and Monday after 11am.

GREHER--Darcy, of Riverdale, NY, died at home on October 1. She was 86 years old. Beloved wife of Harold from 1946 until his death in 2004. Mother of Stephanie Biddle, of Washington, DC and Leslie Greher (Mrs. Al) Zimmermann of New York City. Grandmother of Alexandra Biddle (Mrs. Adam) Mouw, AGW (Jack) Biddle III (Foree) and James Biddle. Great-grandmother of Jackson Biddle, Caldwell Biddle, Brooks Biddle and Ethan Mouw. She is also survived by her sisters-in-law Joan Masket, Barbara Weiss, Trudy Mark, Edna Sacks and Sylvia Reiff, as well as many nieces and nephews. An industrial psychologist, she worked for decades for the New York State Department of Labor as an employment counselor. A past President of the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital, she was also a life member of the Riverdale Chapter of the Brandeis Women's Committee. The family will be at home to friends at Darcy Greher's residence on Monday, October 11 from 3-8pm.

AITA AL SHAAB, Lebanon -- It was from this shrub-ringed border town that Hezbollah instigated its war with Israel in 2006, and supporters of the militant Shiite movement sound almost disappointed that they have not fought since. ''I was expecting the war this summer,'' said Faris Jamil, a municipal official and small-business owner. ''It's late.'' He has yet to finish rebuilding his three-story house, destroyed by an Israeli bomb that year.

There are few things more foreboding, more memorable, than those ominous tracking shots of little Danny Torrance riding his Big Wheel down the long halls of the Overlook Hotel in Stanley Kubrick's ''The Shining.'' The way the camera glides smoothly behind him as he pedals his way to freaky twin girls and blood-drenched elevator doors is one of the most enduring shots in all of moviemaking. Tiffen, the company that created the Steadicam camera mount and harness that allowed for shots like that, now has a hand-held version for smartphones and hand-held video cameras like the Flip. Called the Smoothee, it will be available in December and sell for $180.

HIRSCHFELD--Hannah Lissauer, passed away peacefully on October 5, 2010 at age 97. Beloved daughter, wife, mother, sister, Oma, great-grandmother and friend. Funeral service Thursday, October 7, 2010 11:15am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, New York.

''NCIS'' on CBS delivered Tuesday night's largest audience with 19.5 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates, but other new and returning series had losses as the fall season continues to unfold. ''No Ordinary Family'' (8.9 million), the new ABC science-fiction series, was down by nearly 2 million viewers from its premiere, and the network's new cop drama, ''Detroit 1-8-7'' (8.3 million), was also down. On Fox, a religion-theme episode of ''Glee'' (11 million) was off about 2 million viewers from last week's Britney Spears extravaganza. CBS won the night over all with a lineup that also included ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (16.2 million) and ''The Good Wife'' (12.7 million). ABC was second as ''Dancing With the Stars'' (16.4 million) bade farewell to the comedian Margaret Cho.

The Minnesota Twins and the Texas Rangers are in the American League playoffs together for the first time. In a general sense, each is bound to two failed Washington Senators franchises. More precisely, their ties go through a man in Huntsville, Ala. ''I'm the answer to a trivia question,'' Don Mincher said, rather proudly, by telephone.

A headline on Tuesday about the British government's overhaul of the welfare system overstated the effect of planned cuts in child benefits. The error also appeared in a front-page capsule summary. The change will reduce -- not eliminate -- benefits to the middle class.

BIRENBAUM--William M.,passed away October 4th at home. An innovative educator, whose leadership over 50 years influenced reform in higher education, Dr. Birenbaum enlisted in the U.S. Air Force to serve in WWII following his graduation from high school. From the military he was admitted directly to the University of Chicago Law School where he was awarded a Doctor of Law degree. Dr. Birenbaum had a very distinguished career: Dean of Students at the University of Chicago, Assistant Vice President for the Graduate School at Wayne State University, Dean of the New School for Social Research, Vice President and Provost of The Brooklyn Center, Long Island University, President, Education Affiliate of the Bed-Sty Restoration Corporation with Robert F. Kennedy, President of Staten Island Community College/CUNY, President of Antioch University, and author of Overlive (1969) and Something for Everyone is Not Enough (1972), two books relevant for education today. Dr. Birenbaum inspired those who knew him from around the world to strive for the best within themselves. He is dearly loved by his wife, Helen, his children, Lauren and Charles, his son-in-law Stephen, his daughter-in-law, Janet, and his grandchildren, Alex, Jason, Benjamin, and Julia. Memorial services will be held in Wellfleet, MA and New York City.

MAUTNER--Ariane, on October 5, 2010. Employee of NBC for 40 years. Beloved daughter of the late Alfred and Fanny Mautner. Dear friend of Betty Dy. Service Thursday, October 7, 2010, 7pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St.

An article last Thursday about environmentalists and their guilt over ''ungreen'' habits misstated the daily gasoline consumption in the United States. It is about 378 million gallons, according to the United States Energy Information Administration, not 22 million gallons.

How many television commercials can $3 billion buy? Enough to set a record for political spending on TV ads this election cycle, which is on track to hit $3 billion by the November election, breaking the previous highs of roughly $2.7 billion in 2008 and $2.4 billion in 2006.

Of the five panelists discussing Japanese fashion on Tuesday night, only one, a Japanese illustrator and designer, did not speak English. But to an uninitiated observer, the four others might have been speaking a different language as well. They were talking about a fashion called Gothic Lolita, an aesthetic reminiscent of a Hello Kitty doll come to life, only, if possible, more cute.

YEAGER--Dennis R.,69, of San Antonio, TX died October 5, 2010. A graduate of Columbia University Law School, he lived in New York City where he practiced corporate law for 45 years. He was a 32 year member of the University Club, an avid horseman and reader of history and biography. He is survived by his wife of 47 years. Jere Jean (Jones), three daughters and five granddaughters. Services with Porter Loring Mortuary 800-460-2704 www.porterloring.com.

HOUSTON--David T.,Jr., of Short Hills, New Jersey passed away suddenly, with his family by his side, on Monday, October 4, 2010. David was a life time New Jersey resident, graduating from the Pingry School, Dartmouth College and receiving an MBA from Columbia University. David started his real estate career with the David Houston Co. in 1971, shortly after his tour as a Naval Officer, and quickly rose through the ranks to become its president. Since that time, David was instrumental in growing the firm to one of the most prestigious and well respected firms in New Jersey. He led the organization to become Colliers Houston & Co. and most recently the firm was merged into Cassidy Turley, a national real estate service provider firm. Considered one of the premier brokers and consultants in the New Jersey real estate industry, David was passionate regarding serving on various boards and simply giving back to the community. The many organizations and advisory groups in which he was active include The National Association of Realtors, Society of Industrial and Office Realtors, IOREBA, Port Authority Development Advisory Committee and The Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act Advisory Committee. He served on many of the above groups as Chairman or President. He was also a Fellow in the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors and was a member of the Counselors of Real Estate. He was a frequent speaker at many real estate events throughout the country. David is survived by Jane, his wife of 42 years, his three sons, William Houston and his wife Meghan of Morris Plains, New Jersey, their son, David's beloved grandson, Liam, Dr. James Houston of Seattle, WA, and Andrew Houston and his fiance Elizabeth Verhagen of New York City. He is also survived by his two sisters, Cindy Houston and her partner, Rete Carie, of Bloomington, IN, and Anne Bentzen, her husband Rick and her family, of Armonk, NY. Relatives and friends are invited to call Friday, October 8, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave., Summit. Funeral Services will be Saturday, October 9, 11:00am at Christ Church in Short Hills. Cremation will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations in David's memory may be sent to The Scholarship Fund at SIOR, 1201 New York Avenue, NW, Suite 350, Washington, DC 20005 or Children's Aid and Family Services, 200 Robin Road, Paramus, New Jersey 07652.
Because of an editing error, the Skin Deep column on Sept. 23, about skin-care products aimed at younger women, misspelled the name of a company that makes such products. It is Kiehl's, not Keihl's.

PALMER--Myrna. Beloved wife for 57 years of Mark, passed away on October 5, 2010. She was the loving mother of Stephen (Sharon) and Brandon (Loren), adoring grandmother of Jason, Michael, Jacyln, Carly and Shira. Devoted sister of the late Bernice Lewkowitz and Martin Skorecky. She will forever be in our hearts, our beloved Bubbie.

The Environmental Protection Agency signaled on Wednesday that it would require an Arizona power plant, one of the largest coal-fired ones in the nation, to install $717 million in pollution controls to curb emissions that spread haze over the Four Corners region of the Southwest, home to national parks like Mesa Verde. The proposal to install the equipment on the oldest three units of the massive 2,250-megawatt plant is likely to have a long-term effect on both the territory and the economy of the Navajo Nation, which covers an area three times the size of Vermont across Arizona, New Mexico and Utah.
HIRSCHFELD--Hannah. A great friend known to five generations of our family. Hannah, we will miss you dearly. The Grunebaum Family

WEINBERG--Sidney. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Sidney J. Weinberg, Jr., a great benefactor to our institution, and generous supporter of our Department of Orthopaedic Surgery. His friendship and vision have been crucial to the establishment of the Columbia Cerebral Palsy Center, which would not exist without the kindness and leadership of Mr. Weinberg and his family. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Elizabeth; son Peter and daughter-in-law Deborah; daughters Elizabeth and Sydney; and the entire Weinberg family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Executive Vice President, Columbia University

FINGEROTH--Blanche. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family of Jim Fingeroth, a longtime supporter of and adviser to JTS, in mourning the loss of his mother, Blanche Fingeroth. Mrs. Fingeroth was a wise, generous, witty, and intellectually curious woman who felt as strongly about her Jewish identity and religion as she did about culture and the arts. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

It has become fashionable to speak of a Democratic comeback, but we're not really seeing one in our forecasting models. Certainly there are some individual races -- particularly on the East and West Coasts, as well as some gubernatorial contests outside these regions -- that look better for Democrats than they did a few weeks ago. But we're showing Republicans gaining ground where they need to gain it to maintain decent chances of taking over the Senate. We also show improvement for them in the House forecast this week.

Are you one of the 46 million Americans without health insurance? Well, you may not have that, uh, luxury for much longer. "A federal judge in Michigan on Thursday dismissed one of more than 15 legal challenges to the new health care law, becoming the first to rule that the law is constitutional," reports The Times's Kevin Sack. "The central question, which may ultimately fall to the Supreme Court, is whether the Commerce Clause of the Constitution gives Congress the authority to require citizens to obtain a commercial product, namely health insurance. Starting in 2014, the law will require most Americans to obtain health insurance ..."

Despite some last-minute chatter in arbitrage circles that Airgas had turned the corner and a very good presentation by Ted Mirvis of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, Air Products and Chemicals won an important decision in Delaware Chancery Court late Friday in its takeover quest for Airgas. Chancellor William B. Chandler III ruled that a new corporate bylaw that would move up the Airgas annual shareholders meeting to January was valid under Delaware law.

Last Saturday brought a wealth of marquee matchups, including Florida-Alabama, Stanford-Oregon and Texas-Oklahoma. At first glance, this weekend doesn't look as glitzy. But that's only because teams are now into the grind of conference play, where each week brings a familiar opponent and the chance to be lulled into complacency. Alabama has one of the more absurd conference schedules in recent memory, with South Carolina the first of six SEC opponents that will be coming off a bye week when they face the Tide. That will make the Tide's road through the league that much more difficult. Florida will try to bounce back from being handled easily by Alabama when it faces Louisiana State in the Swamp. The Tigers, through a combination of good defense and horrendous clock management, are 5-0 but being treated like they are underachievers. A win against the Gators could give them some credibility. Elsewhere in Florida, Florida State and Miami will play the latest installment of a rivalry that was one of the best in college football over the last quarter century. While that rivalry has lost some of its luster, Michigan-Michigan State has gained some glitz thanks to the outsize performance of Denard Robinson this season. Coach Mark Dantonio is expected to return to the Spartans after missing two games after having a mild heart attack. In the Pac-10, Stanford is coming off a loss to Oregon and Southern California is hoping to prove that it still deserves to be considered one of the conference's top teams. There is plenty to be excited about now that conference play has started in earnest and the history and familiarity between teams always makes prognosticating that much more difficult. As always, if you agree, disagree or simply find the picks laughable, feel free to let us know.

A 20-year-old college student in California says that during a visit to his mechanic for a routine oil change, the mechanic found a suspicious wire sticking out at the right rear of his car. The garage owner pulled on it, and detached a GPS transmitter that had been attached to the chassis with a magnet. According to Wired.com, the student, Yasir Afifi, who attends Mission College in Santa Clara, recognized it as a GPS tracking device and posted photos of it on the Reddit site.

That an exhibition called "White Trash Mystic" is opening in a pop-up gallery space in the new luxury-condominium building at 211 Elizabeth Street (where the actor Gabriel Byrne reportedly coughed up more than $3 million for a two-bedroom) is either ironic or, well, just plain trashy. Celebrity chefs are crowding Manhattan this weekend for the New York City Wine and Food Festival, which runs through Sunday. Most of the dinners, wine and food tastings, cooking demonstrations and hands-on classes take place in the meatpacking district. Many popular events are sold out, but there are still tickets available, $10 to $275. The proceeds benefit Share Our Strength and the Food Bank For New York City.

And to think that Betsy Wetsy shares the same phylum as Kaori the Nurse. Both are dolls, of course, but Kaori is a limited-edition designer toy meant for grown-ups who can afford four figures for a "cuddly" five-inch work of art. The scope of these plastic critters, which range from the abstract to the downright lewd (see Cathy Cowgirl, the heifer with big teats), is wonderfully surveyed in "I Am Plastic, Too" (Abrams, $45), by Paul Budnitz, the designer and collector behind the art-toy company Kidrobot. What began in 1996 with some handmade toys by two Chinese artists in Hong Kong has now spread west with collectors lining up for hours to buy the latest releases. Globalism strikes again!

The pre-release of four styles from the Mulberry for Target line sold out within minutes on GiltGroupe.com in August, proving the public's desire for the English luxury house's leather goods. Now, the stellar collaboration is having its official introduction, in Target stores and on target.com, today. Priced from $14.99 for the mobile-phone-friendly Mini Messenger to $49.99 for large satchels and totes, the collection features 18 pieces available in leather and denim, including a winning pink leopard print. Says Emma Hill, Mulberry's creative director, "Leopards are king this season."

Some prominent climate scientists, like James Hansen of NASA, think the safe threshold for carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is no higher than 350 parts per million. Beyond this point, they say, we risk severe climatic consequences: melting ice caps and glaciers, rising seas, and a sharp increase in heat waves, droughts, crop failures and extreme weather events.

Until the Tribe opened in Nairobi two years ago, boutique hotels were almost unknown to the Kenyan capital, where accommodations tend to be more shabby than chic. Travelers dubbed the high-tech, 137-room lodge serving the diplomatic community in the parklike Gigiri suburb "the Soho House of Nairobi." That was partly because Mark Somen, its general manager, is a former director of that New York club. A Kenyan native and a believer in deluxe creature comforts like flat-screen TVs, organic food and fine linens, he gave the Tribe the look and feel of a hip resort and turned the stylish bar and lobby into a thriving nightspot.

The German drug maker Boehringer Ingelheim announced Friday that it had stopped work on a pill for low libido in women, the latest setback in the controversial efforts to produce a "female Viagra."

''Photography is relevant because it sits at the axis of true, false and fake,'' said Massimo Torrigiani, the Milan-based publisher and editor-at-large behind the year-old magazine Fantom. The English-language quarterly, which is edited by Cay Sophie Rabinowitz and Selva Barni, explores ''the uses and abuses'' of photography - artistic, commercial, scientific, etc. - with essays, interviews between photographers and picks from curators and gallery owners. Fantom is riding two trends that Torrigiani finds exciting: the return of intellectual debate in the art world and the emergence of cool independent magazines in Milan like Apartamento and Mousse. And, of course, it makes debate look great.

To the average New York City helicopter parent, Julia Landauer's scholastic trajectory would be the stuff of daydreams. Last spring, she graduated from Stuyvesant High School. This summer, she reported to Stanford University, where she is fashioning her own undergraduate concentration within the Management Science and Engineering department.

Raisins grown in Parwan Province, Afghanistan, will once again land on food shelves in Britain thanks to an unusual alliance among Afghan farmers, a U.S. aid organization, and a British food producer.

Jobs report portends long slog to economic recovery, the media await the surfacing of 33 Chilean miners and reader questions about the all electric Nissan Leaf answered.

It's been a busy day for the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman. Along with disclosing his 16.5 percent stake in J.C. Penney, Mr. Ackman has revived the ghost of Howard Hughes.

A calm, gentle breeze seemed to permeate its way onto the stage last evening at the New York City Ballet Fall Gala. And members of high society seemed all the more pleased to leave their winter coats at home in place of a stunning assortment of gowns as they made their way into Lincoln Center's David H. Koch Theater. The spotlight was on the principal dancer Benjamin Millepied's world premiere of "Plainspoken," set to music by the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer David Lang, with costumes by Karen Young.

On Friday afternoon, the federal Administration on Aging unveils its new, improved elder care locator. The major change: anyone who dials the toll-free number, (800) 677-1116, from 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Eastern time on weekdays should get an actual human on the line, ready to answer questions about government services and refer seniors and caregivers to local agencies that can help.

Raven -- Raven Patrick De'Sean Dennis III, a celebrity favorite -- has also been accused of cheating his workers on pay.

Crumbles are an easy way to turn simple fruit into a decadent, crispy dessert. And for the growing number of diners who can't tolerate the gluten in wheat, it's easy to make crumbles that are gluten free without sacrificing taste, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week's Recipes for Health.

"The Last Lecture" will not be the final chapter in the story of Randy Pausch, the computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University who turned his ruminations on life and his own impending death into a wildly popular oration and that best-selling book.

A surprise inspection uncovers major safety violations at another Massey Energy Company coal mine in West Virginia. Last year an explosion at a Massey coal mine in the state killed 29 workers. The latest violations, discovered on Sept. 28, could have caused a similar explosion, officials say. "This is a reflection of the problem that we have in this mining industry with some who, regardless of what you do, ignore the mine law," said Joe Main, the director of the federal Mine Safety and Health Administration. "There is absolutely no justification to be operating a mine in this condition." [The Associated Press]

5:54 p.m. | Updated First Timothy Cahill's top aides quit his campaign, followed by his running mate, Paul Loscocco, who proclaimed that Mr. Cahill, an independent candidate in the Massachusetts governor's race, had no shot at winning. In another twist of the knife, Mr. Loscocco promptly endorsed Charles Baker Jr., the Republican.

What did I learn last week? Well, I learned that Alabama is much better than Florida. I learned that Oregon cannot be stopped on offense. I also learned that in college football it's not always the games that are circled on your calendar that end up providing the most drama. Case in point, last week's LSU/Tennessee game and the Michigan/Indiana game. Those two games went down to the wire in thrilling fashion, but the marquee games provided little late game intrigue.

Cake Man Raven, the celebrated and well-connected Brooklyn baker who has blanketed much of the city in red velvet cake from his shop in Fort Greene, was shut down by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene this week for sanitary violations that it said included the presence of flies, lack of a hand-washing station near the food preparation area and toilet room, and the supervisor of operations' lack of a food protection certificate.

Congratulations to Liu Xiaobo for winning the Nobel Peace Prize - and to the Nobel committee for giving it to him. China has countless dissidents and people pushing for democracy, of course, but there's a reason Liu rose to the top in Nobel estimations. He has combined relentless courage and persistence in pushing for democracy over 21 years with a broad vision of democracy, all tethered to moderation and willingness to work with Communist Party leaders.

The biggest surprise about Milan's galleries is how few Italian artists show there. Scattered about town or gathered in a few clusters, they wield enough international clout to make up for the time it takes to travel between them. Most ambitious is the Naples-based Lia Rumma's new temple to minimalist cool at Via Stilicone, 19. One of the largest commercial galleries in Europe, it opened last May and has attracted a fashionable clientele. Its triple-height space, designed by CLS Architetti, easily accommodates anything the artists on its blue-chip roster (Marina Abramovic, Andreas Gursky, Anselm Kiefer, Ettore Spalleti, Vanessa Beecroft) can think up.

Happy 80th birthday, Stephen Sondheim! The gifts you've been receiving for the occasion this year keep getting better and better: a Broadway revue of your unparalleled body of work; a new series of Kennedy Center grants established in your honor; a Broadway theater with your name on the marquee. And if you were watching television on Thursday night and not working on a crossword puzzle, maybe you got to see a network sitcom make mincemeat of one of your best-known works. Indianapolis has lost two divisional games and all of its experienced safeties are injured, but there has been little hand-wringing about the team's playoff chances. This week, the Nobel Prize in Literature was awarded to the Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa. If you were in charge of giving a prize to a writer, what would the prize be for and to whom would you give it? Pretend that you could give it to any writer you like for any reason at all. For instance, you might choose to give a prize for "best characters" to a favorite children's book writer, or you might give an award for "best play-by-play" to a sportswriter, or "most realistic dialogue" to a writer of young-adult books. Whom would you like to honor? Why?

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Sept. 13 about train service to the New Meadowlands Stadium misstated the frequency of service. Many trains -- not just one -- run each game day between Secaucus Junction and the stadium.

PHILADELPHIA - The Mets will begin interviewing candidates to be their next general manager early next week. The team announced Thursday that it had received permission to interview Rick Hahn, the White Sox' assistant general manager, and Allard Baird, the Red Sox' director of professional scouting. They have also scheduled an interview with the former Diamondbacks general manager Josh Byrnes. Hahn is considered a promising future top executive who attended the University of Michigan, where Fred Wilpon is not only an alumnus, but also one of the university's biggest contributors and advocates. The White Sox had previously turned down the Seattle Mariners for permission to speak to Hahn before they eventually hired Jack Zduriencik in 2009. He also interviewed for the St. Louis Cardinals' job before withdrawing his name.

An article on Thursday about a proposal by the Environmental Protection Agency to require the installation of costly air pollution controls at the Four Corners Power Plant, which is fired by coal, misidentified the state in which it is located. It is on Navajo territory in New Mexico, not in Arizona.

Funeral services will be held at 11:15am on Friday October 8th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

An entry in the ''What's On Today'' television highlights on Thursday about a discussion of the federal debt on the ''Stossel'' program misstated the name of the channel on which the program is shown. It is Fox Business Network, not Fox Business News.

Democrats in Cleveland will get a political twofer later this month: a joint campaign appearance by President Obama and his wife, Michelle.The first couple will visit the city on Oct. 17 to stump for Ohio Gov. Ted Strickland, who is in a tough race for re-election against John R. Kasich, a former Republican congressman. On Monday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in Youngstown headlining a rally and fundraiser for the Democratic governor. The Cleveland visit will mark the first time the Obamas have campaigned together in this election cycle. The White House press secretary, Robert Gibbs, announced Thursday afternoon that not only will Mrs. Obama be going to Cleveland, she will also appear with Mr. Obama at a rally in Columbus later that day aimed at encouraging young people to go to the polls.

BOBER--Senta, 91, died at 4:40pm on October 7, 2010. No one was more giving, loving and courageous then Senta. She was a tireless worker for Hadassah and for the State of Israel. Her 60 year marriage to her deceased husband Arnold was the highlight of her life demonstrated by deep affection. Her marriage was a pillar of support for her in her later years. Her many, many friends were a testament to her kindness. She was a deep intellectual thinker, a devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was particularly proud of attending Fordham University when she was 60 years old and earning her bachelors degree, something she wanted all her life but was interrupted by her having to flee Natzi Germany. She is survived by her son Frank, her brother Henry, grandchildren Suzanne, Sarah, Jenia, Bronwen, David and Gabrielle and great-grandchildren Teddy, Sam and Laila. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th Street, New York City at 11:15am Sunday, October 10, 2010.
An obituary on Thursday about the painter Stephen Pace misidentified the town in Indiana to which his family moved in the 1930s and where he died. It is New Harmony, not Harmony.

The New York Public Library has named Anthony W. Marx as its next president, after a unanimous vote by the board of trustees late Wednesday afternoon. Mr. Marx, a political scientist and the president of Amherst College, will succeed Paul LeClerc on July 1.

Senate Republicans pulled a folksy campaign ad produced on behalf of John Raese, the Republican Senate candidate in West Virginia, after it was disclosed that the regular people featured in it were not just plain folks -- they were actually out-of-state actors. Adding insult to injury, the casting call put out to round up Philadelphia talent for the spot attacking Gov. Joe Manchin III, the Democratic Senate candidate, for his ties to President Obama sought men who could convey ''a 'hickey' blue-collar look.'' The casting call document was first reported by The Politico Web site and later obtained from Democratic officials.

The Big City column on Sept. 28, about the city of Buffalo and Carl P. Paladino's campaign for governor, referred incorrectly to a Rite Aid store where people were discussing a recent holdup. The drugstore is not one of the many Rite Aid stores Mr. Paladino developed for the company.

KRASINSKI--Keith, MD, beloved husband of Debra, devoted father of Kathryn, Anna, and Stephanie and father-in-law to Brian, adoring son of Lorraine and the late Richard Krasinski and brothers Kenneth (Donna) and Kurt (Nancy). Keith was Professor of Pediatrics and Environmental Medicine at NYU who dedicated his career to the study, care, and prevention of pediatric AIDS. He was the hospital epidemiologist at Bellevue, a long-standing member of the NYS AIDS Advisory Council and past director of the NYU IRB. He worked tirelessly alongside NY Assemblywoman Mayersohn to successfully establish a newborn HIV screening program. Visitation begins at 1:00, service at 3:00 on October 10 at Fred McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville. Contributions may be made to the Pediatric AIDS Program, NYU School of Medicine, Division of Pediatric Infectious Diseases.

An obituary last Friday about the structural engineer Ysrael Seinuk referred imprecisely to the O-14 office tower in Dubai, one of many buildings for which he designed support systems. His work on that building was done for his firm Ysrael A. Seinuk P.C. -- not for his other firm, Cantor Seinuk.

David Plouffe, the manager for President Obama's 2008 campaign, said today that he doubts Sarah Palin will run for president next year, saying ''something tells me we won't get that lucky.'' Mr. Plouffe made the comments to reporters during a question-and-answer session in which he argued that the Tea Party movement will force Republican candidates to be more conservative in 2012 and beyond.

WEINBERG--Sidney J.,Jr. The Trustees, Life Trustees, Physicians and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the loss of our dear friend and Life Trustee Sidney J. (Jim) Weinberg, Jr. Elected a Trustee of the then-Presbyterian Hospital in 1970, Jim Weinberg served Presbyterian Hospital/NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital for 40 years. Unfailingly gracious, enthusiastic, and willing to help the Hospital in any way that he could, Jim Weinberg will be sorely missed. Throughout his lifetime of service to the Hospital, Jim Weinberg held several significant leadership positions, including Vice Chairman of the Board, Vice Chairman and Chairman of the Budget and Finance Committee, and Chairman of the Joint Conference Committee. He was a member of the Executive and Planning Committees as well. Jim Weinberg was the greatest enthusiast for the Hospital and always a delightful, upbeat optimist, as well as a most generous supporter. In a word, he was a "prince" of a man. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Elizabeth, their children, grandchildren and family. John J. Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Frank A. Bennack, Jr. Charlotte M. Ford Peter A. Georgescu Jerry I. Speyer Vice Chairmen Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO

An article on Sept. 25 about bed bugs in the city's public schools misstated the timeframe during which a Staten Island company, Superior Pest Elimination, began working for the city's Department of Education. It started work in 2004, not in the 1990s.

Two years after the near collapse of capitalism, we certainly have our fill of financial reforms. The 2,200-page Dodd-Frank Act, which President Obama signed this summer, creates an Orwellian alphabet soup of new agencies, oversight boards and offices intended to protect us from ourselves. The problem is that since the incentives on Wall Street have not been changed one iota by the new laws - nor are they likely to be changed by any of the soon-to-be-written regulations of federal agencies - we're no better protected from bankers' potentially reckless behavior than we were before the latest round of reforms.

BROAD--Stanley. 92, from Parkinsons Disease WWII Veteran and receipient of many battle stars. Devoted husband to Arlene. Father of Marla and Arthur. Grandfather of Erica, Dana, Samantha, Nikki and Adam. Stepfather to Dale and Karen. Buddy and partner in life to David Canner. Friend and confident to all who knew him. Will be terribly missed but loved always. Till we meet again. Your heartbroken family.

MULCAHY--Paul N. Former marketing executive with Campbell Soup Co., died October 7 in Rutland, VT following a stroke. Born in Boston in 1930. Graduate of Boston Latin School and Harvard. Served in U.S. Army Counter Intelligence Corps in Germany. During forty years with Campbell's, held key positions in sales and marketing, including Vice President -- Marketing Services; and President, CSC Advertising, Campbell's in-house agency. Created Labels for Education, a program that awards educational equipment to schools. Active in industry organizations, including the Ad Council, which presented him with the Robert V. Goldstein Award for distinguished public service. Paul loved tennis, Vermont, mystery novels, crossword puzzles, Rodney Dangerfield, the Red Sox, and his family. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Jeanne Grace; children Patricia, Joanne, Susan, Christine, Paul Nicholas Jr., and Matthew; five grandchildren; sisters Winifred Kilday and Mary Brophy; nieces and nephews. Funeral mass, October 12, Christ the King in Rutland, VT. Memorial service in Philadelphia at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please support the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research (michaeljfox.org) or the Special Olympics of Pennsylvania (specialolympicspa.org).

It's very difficult for a Latin American writer to avoid politics. Literature is an expression of life, and you cannot eradicate politics from life.'' MARIO VARGAS LLOSA, the Peruvian novelist, after winning the Nobel Prize in Literature.[A6]

Had you been inclined to wager on the winner of the 2010 Nobel Prize in Literature based on the odds set by Ladbrokes, the British bookmaking chain, you might have put your money on the Swedish poet Thomas Transtromer, the Syrian poet Adonis, the Kenyan novelist Ngugi wa Thiong'o or the South Korean poet Ko Un. And you would have come home with a big fat goose egg when the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa (who was given 25-1 odds by Ladbrokes) was named the winner on Thursday morning. That hasn't stopped the betting company from suspending wagers on the Man Booker Prize amid suspicion that that award's winner may be a foregone conclusion. The Guardian reported Ladbrokes closed bets on the prestigious British literary prize after receiving nearly 15,000 (about $24,000) in wagers on Wednesday morning for Tom McCarthy's novel ''C.'' Since July, Ladbrokes said, it had received a total of only 10,000 (about $16,000) in bets for the prize, whose other finalists include Peter Carey's ''Parrot and Olivier in America'' and Emma Donoghue's ''Room.''

Representative Bobby Bright, a conservative Alabama Democrat in a tough fight for re-election, became the first incumbent member of his party to say definitively that he would not support Nancy Pelosi for speaker next year if the Democrats retain control of the House. His statement illustrated the lengths some Democratic lawmakers are going to distance themselves from the speaker, who has been cast by Republicans as the embodiment of excessive liberalism. In an interview with television station WSFA in Montgomery, Ala., Mr. Bright said he would vote for neither Ms. Pelosi nor Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the Republican leader and likely speaker candidate should Republicans win control of the House. He said he would instead vote for ''a centrist who is much more like me and also much more like 80 percent of the people in America.''

First Cuba, now Russia. American Ballet Theater has added Moscow to its touring itinerary for the 2010-11 season, the company announced Thursday. The March engagement, part of the Mstislav Rostropovich Week Festival, will include the premiere of a new work by Benjamin Millepied commissioned by the festival. American Ballet Theater last performed in Moscow in 1960. That was also the last time it appeared onstage in Havana, where the company will be returning next month. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
International INDONESIA SENDS MILITARY

8 P.M. (CMT) PETTY BLUE Think of Nascar, and chances are the name Petty is going to come to mind. This new documentary follows the family dynasty around the track, starting with its patriarch, Lee Petty (above, center, with his sons Maurice, left, and Richard), who raced under No. 42 and was the face of Nascar's earliest days in 1949. It continues with his son Richard (No. 43), the Hall of Famer and driver with the most wins in the sport's history -- and the only motor sports athlete to earn the Presidential Medal of Freedom -- and Richard's son, Kyle (No. 44), who has twice won one of Nascar's most prominent honors, the Myers Brothers Award. It also follows the family tragedy. In 2000 Kyle's son Adam (No. 45) was killed, more than 50 years after his great-grandfather's first race, when the throttle of his car stuck while he was practicing in New Hampshire -- sending him barreling into a wall. Kevin Costner narrates this film, whose title refers to the distinctive blue color of Richard's cars in the 1960s and '70s, the most famous of which was probably the Plymouth Superbird -- the character Richard played in the 2006 animated Pixar film ''Cars.'' In ''Invitation Only,'' at 10, Toby Keith performs songs from his new album, including the title track, ''Bullets in the Gun,'' as well as ''Somewhere Else'' and his latest single, ''Trailerhood.'' He backs them up with old favorites, among them ''Good as I Once Was'' and ''I Love This Bar,'' and answers audience questions. 8 P.M. (NBC) DATELINE NBC Dennis Murphy reports on the capital-crimes conviction of Steven J. Hayes in the triple murder of Jennifer Hawke-Petit and her two daughters, Michaela and Hayley, on July 23, 2007, in Cheshire, Conn.

GOLD--Martha R.,101, died on October 7, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Samuel M. Gold, devoted mother of Martin and the late Leonard, loving mother-in-law of Billie and Lois, adoring grandmother of David (Corinne), Jonathan (Heather), and Eric, and cherished great-grandmother of Abraham, Etta, Ezra, and Milo. Funeral services on October 8, 2010, at noon. Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

A lawyer for Mets closer Francisco Rodriguez and the Queens district attorney's office are negotiating a plea agreement that could spare Rodriguez prison time, both sides said Thursday after a court hearing. The plea agreement must include an anger-management program that would be more stringent than the one Rodriguez had already agreed to as the result of his suspension by the Mets in August, prosecutors said. That program was arranged through an agreement between Major League Baseball and the players union.

An article on Sept. 27 about Carl P. Paladino and his hometown of Buffalo described a neighborhood in the city incorrectly in some editions. Though Mr. Paladino's father raised his children in a part of the East Side of Buffalo that was heavily Italian, the East Side as a whole was not largely Italian.

If Giants fans needed another reminder that the seven-year, $126 million contract the team lavished on Barry Zito was not a very good investment, they got one when he was left off the 25-man roster for San Francisco's National League division series with the Atlanta Braves. Game 1 was Thursday night.

BENKERT--Ernst G.,82, died October 5th, 2010 after living for three and a half years with angiosarcoma, a rare form of cancer. With him at the end were his children, Louly Williams and Edward Benkert, his grandchildren, Ellie and Max Williams, and his companion of twenty-eight years, Alexandra Walcott. He is also survived by a brother, Kyle Benkert, a grandson, Harris Benkert, and his former wife, Lisa Woods. He was predeceased by a son, Max Benkert. Ernst's dedication as an artist, his knowledge of art history, his appreciation of the written word, and his inquisitive intelligence were the delight of a multitude of friends and colleagues. He lived in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn and was a frequent visitor to galleries, museums and friends across the East River. Donations in his memory may be made to Proteus Gowanus Gallery and Kentler International Drawing Space, both in Brooklyn. A memorial service will be held at noon Saturday, October 9th at Christ Church Cobble Hill, 326 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

Will Wright, who let players control families and metropolises in the computer games The Sims and SimCity, now wants to let players control a television series. Mr. Wright has developed Web technology for ''Bar Karma,'' a series that will start early next year on Current TV, the fledgling cable channel co-founded by Al Gore. The plan, announced Thursday, is for players (Current calls them viewers) to take part in the conception of each episode.

What will you be doing on 10-10-10? The organizers of One Day on Earth don't care what the answer is as long as you videotape yourself doing it. After two years of planning, One Day on Earth, an experiment in group filmmaking, arrives on Sunday. The goal: To compile an online archive and subsequent feature film showcasing what was going on in every country during a single 24-hour period.
An article on Sept. 29 about golfers' handling pressure at the Ryder Cup misstated Padraig Harrington's final-round score at the Vivendi Cup on Sept. 26. He shot a 64, not a 65.
Genzymesaid Thursday that its board had again rejected an $18.5 billion hostile takeover offer from Sanofi-Aventis of France, saying the bid remains too low.

An article on Wednesday about the political consequences confronting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in deciding whether to extend a freeze on Jewish settlement building in the West Bank in order to salvage peace talks with the Palestinians misstated the number of members in his so-called security cabinet, a group of ministers within the full cabinet of 30. It is 15 members, not 16.

HOWARD--Joanne. We are saddened at the lost of our beloved friend and colleague. Joanne lived her life with dignity and passion. She was a humble, kind, good natured and generous and lead by example. We will miss her deeply, but will cherish her memory always. Our hearts go out to Michael, Beth, Jill, Phyllis and Paul. Your Colleagues from Goldman Sachs

DePODWIN--Horace John, 87 of Pompton Plains, NJ died Tuesday, October 5, 2010. Born October 28, 1922, Brooklyn, NY to Thaddeus and Lena (Kornat) Podwin. Horace served as Sergeant Major, U.S. Army, 85th Mountain Infantry Regiment, 2nd Battalion, 10th Mt. Division, 1942-1946, Bronze Star. Attended Middlebury College, B.A.; Columbia University, Ph.D. economics, 1953. He started his career as Manager, Economic Research, General Electric Company and was a consultant to President John F. Kennedy's administration, General Agreement on Tariffs & Trade. Horace was the President of Horace J. DePodwin Associates Co., Inc./ Economic Studies, Inc., from 1963-2005. He was also Dean of Rutgers University Graduate School of Management, 1966-1982. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Carolyn (Ohlander) formerly of Maplewood, NJ, three loving children: Andrew H., Margaret D. Harwood, and David A.; six grandchildren: Kevin S. DePodwin, Karen B. San Giacomo, Daniel A. and Michael T. DePodwin, John H. and Maggie B. Harwood. He is also survived by his sister, Rita Fink. Horace was predeceased by his sister Lucille Mulvihill. His family, friends, and business associates will remember him for his high intellect and sense of purpose, droll sense of humor, firm handshake, love for the outdoors (especially skiing), craftsmanship, integrity, generosity and public service. He was a giant to fellow mankind who he served with honor. A memorial service will be held 11am on Wednesday, October 13th, at the Wyoming Presbyterian Church, 432 S. Wyoming Ave., Millburn, NJ. For further information please contact Gallaway & Crane Funeral Home at 908-766-0250 or to light a candle to leave a message for the family visit gcfuneralhome.com. In lieu of flowers, donations are asked to be made to: Horace J. DePodwin Scholarship Fund, c/o Rutgers University Foundation, attn.: Terri Suarez, RBS Dev. Office, One Washington Park, Newark, NJ 07102; or 10th Mountain Division Hut Association, 1280 Ute Ave., Suite 21, Aspen, CO 81611.

A Montana woman was arrested Wednesday at a Colorado museum after she destroyed an artwork that some observers say depicts Jesus engaged in a sex act. The Denver Post reported that Kathleen Folden of Kalispell, Mont., was taken into police custody after she entered the Loveland Museum/Gallery in Loveland, Colo., and destroyed a work called ''The Misadventures of Romantic Cannibals,'' a lithograph by Enrique Chagoya. The police told The Post that Ms. Folden had used a crowbar or similar tool to break the plexiglass in front of the work and then tore it up. She has been charged with criminal mischief, a felony punishable by a fine of up to $2,000. For several days the museum has faced protests for displaying the work, which also depicts comic book characters, images from Mexican pornography and Mayan symbols. The Post reported that Daryle Klassen, a Loveland city councilman, objected to the display during a council meeting, calling it ''smut'' and adding, ''That's not what our community is about.'' Some Roman Catholics in Loveland had also sought to have the work taken down.

Policing tactics in New York City Housing Authority developments are under a microscope. A class action lawsuit, filed in January against the Police Department and the housing authority, is winding its way through federal court. It claims that public housing tenants and their visitors are subjected to police aggression and unwarranted arrests for trespassing. And the City Council is planning to hold a hearing on the broad topic of safety in the city's public housing complexes.

de PLANQUE--Dr Gail, died on 8 September 2010. On the one month anniversary of her passing, BHP Billiton has commemorated the many achievements of esteemed former Board Director, Dr Gail de Planque. After joining the BHP Billiton Board in September 2005, Dr de Planque served until her retirement due to ill-health in January 2010. BHP Billiton has expressed its deepest sympathy at the loss of one its dear colleagues and extends condolences to Dr de Planque's loved ones. Dr de Planque has been remembered for her substantial contribution to the BHP Billiton Board, and particularly her deep scientific knowledge and significant experience with nuclear and environmental regulatory issues. Her career in the field of nuclear energy and industry regulation spanned more than 35 years after earning a Bachelor of Arts in Mathematics from Immaculata University, a Masters in Science degree in physics from the New Jersey Institute of Technology, and a Ph.D. in environmental health sciences from New York University. Dr de Planque was a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Fellow and past President of the American Nuclear Society, a member of the National Academy of Engineering, and served as a Commissioner with the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission and as Director of the United States Department of Energy's Environmental Measurements Laboratory. She was the recipient of numerous awards recognizing her groundbreaking achievements, including the Outstanding Woman Scientist of the Year award from the New York Metropolitan Chapter of the Association for Women in Science in 1991.

The On the Road column on the Itineraries pages on Sept. 28, about in-flight Wi-Fi, quoted incorrectly from comments by from Richard A. Baldridge, president of ViaSat, a satellite communications company that will provide Wi-Fi to JetBlue. In commenting on downloads via Wi-Fi, Mr. Baldridge referred to a 50-megabyte file, not a 50-megabit file. (File sizes are typically described in bytes and transfer rates in bits.)

ENGELMAYER--Ilene (Zelman), 79, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, died on October 7, 2010 of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Born December 6, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, she was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of New York University, from which she later earned two masters degrees. After working initially in advertising (market research), she later became a dedicated teacher of remedial reading in the New York City public schools. She married Louis Engelmayer in 1955 and remained devoted to him through his death in 2000, and to their two children Paul Engelmayer and Jean Engelmayer Kalicki, their spouses Emily Mandelstam and Jan Kalicki, and her four grandchildren, Sasha and Peter Kalicki and Caroline and William Engelmayer. She was a loving daughter, devoted sister to her brothers Fred and Milton and their wives Celie and Helen, and a dedicated matriarch to an extended family of Zelman nieces and nephews and their children, for whom she hosted family Thanksgiving reunions for more than 45 years. She was a forceful intellectual with a playful sense of humor, and was an avid reader, a strong believer in civic participation, a gracious host and cook, and a proud celebrator of Jewish heritage. A memorial service will be held on Monday, October 11, 2010 at 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. The family will be sitting shiva at 300 Central Park West, Apt. 5B, on Monday, October 11, between 6:30pm and 10pm, and on Tuesday, October 12, between 4pm and 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations in her memory be sent to the Jewish Museum of New York, Development Department, 1109 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY, 10128, in honor of Ilene Engelmayer. We will miss her kindness, wisdom, whimsical humor and abiding love.

WEINBERG--Sidney. The family of Sidney J. Weinberg, Jr announce with great sorrow the death of their beloved husband, father and grandfather on October 4, 2010 of prostate cancer, in Marion MA. Three short hours from the cosmopolitan city of Brisbane, Australia, and a world away, I have arrived in the Solomon Islands. Stepping from the crisp tubular world of jet travel into the familiar thickness of tropical air, I descend the gangway into a place that once echoed with the thunder and stench of the Battle of Guadalcanal, a place first visited by American Museum of Natural History biologists nearly a century ago during an expedition that really did change the world, and a place still alive in a timeless blend of biological and cultural wonder that inspired my career as a biologist.

After the Asian financial crisis of 1997-1998, it was often said that a key barrier to recovery was the uncertain state of property rights: so much debt had been run up during the boom, and there had been so many defaults in the bust, that it was no longer clear who owned anything. All this was said, of course, in a tone of superiority: we Americans had solved such problems.

Vanguard is effectively cutting its fees on certain mutual funds by allowing a wider swath of investors to invest in its Admiral shares, which carry lower expenses. Now, investors will need a total account balance of $10,000 per fund to qualify for the lower-cost index funds, down from $100,000. A total of 52 Vanguard mutual funds offer Admiral shares.

With New Yorkers being asked once again to pay more for less transit service, the NYC columnist, Clyde Haberman, asked readers to suggest low-cost ways for the perpetually cash-starved Metropolitan Transportation Authority to make taking the subway a more pleasant experience. They responded in droves - apparently all that waiting around on crowded platforms incubates ideas (among other things). Eliminating excess noise (oh, those alarm gates), improving pedestrian traffic flow, prosecuting litterers and starting adopt-a-station programs all received multiple mentions. Here are some of our favorite responses, lightly edited and condensed.

O'CONNOR--Jeremiah, W.,Jr., 68, died peacefully at his home in Bronxville, New York Friday October 8, 2010. He was also a resident of Osterville, MA and Lost Tree Village, North Palm Beach, FL. Jerry was sustained throughout his life by an unfaltering devotion to his faith and family. He was a generous and loving husband, father, brother, friend and colleague. He is survived by his beloved wife of forty-two years, Joan (Bruton), five adoring children, Bill (and Eileen) of Rye, NY, Chris and M.E. of New Canaan, CT, Marjorie (O'Connor) and Nat Furman of New Canaan, CT, Karina (Lagos) O'Connor of Bronxville, NY, Catherine (O'Connor) and Matt Williams of New York, NY, John O'Connor and his fiance, Erin Dougherty of New York, NY. Jerry was predeceased by his son Jeremiah William, III who passed away early last month. He is also survived by fifteen beautiful grandchildren: Jack, Emiliano, Sarah Jane, Erin, Maggie, Will, Cate, Patrick, Margot, Christopher, Jay, Chip, Annie, Connor, and Sophia who loved to play, tease, swim, and spend time with their beloved Grampy. Jerry was born and raised in Newton, MA, the second of eleven children of the late Jeremiah William and Marjorie Quigley. He is also survived by his step-mother, Rose Ann, brothers, William, Peter, Joseph, Michael and Charles and his sisters, Dorothy, Maura, Kathleen and Margaret, and their spouses. He was predeceased by his brothers Paul and Chris. Jerry loved nothing more than to be with his wife, children and siblings to him life was a celebration of family his favorite of which took place often on his beloved Cape Cod. Jerry began his career at Lazard Freres and Co and with their sponsorship he helped found Corporate Property Investors, a private REIT with significant shopping center and office holdings. Jerry was an early pioneer in the development of the regional mall business. He started his own firm, The O'Connor Group, in 1983 and continued to focus much of his efforts in the shopping center industry, investing in and developing many notable properties, among them; The Westchester in White Plains New York, and Menlo Park Mall in Edison, NJ. He enjoyed every detail of development including choosing art for these properties. (In the Menlo Park Mall he placed a sculpture with six children jumping over a puddle, as a memento of his most important achievement, his children.) Jerry was a past president of the International Council of Shopping Centers ("ICSC"). The O'Connor Group, now O'Connor Capital Partners, continued in the mall development and management business and later managed a series of private equity funds that remain active today. In addition to his retail work he was most proud of the rejuvenation of Parkchester, a residential community in the Bronx. Jerry truly believed "to whom much is given, much is expected" and as such was a generous supporter of numerous charities among them: The Papal Foundation, Gregorian University, Catholic Relief Services, Partners in Health, and The Bronxville School Foundation. Jerry also served for many years as a Trustee and Chair of the Investment Committee of The College of the Holy Cross. After a Catholic Relief Service visit to Ethiopia which moved and inspired him, he devoted recent philanthropic efforts to building wells throughout that country. Jerry was a graduate of the College of the Holy Cross 1963, Harvard Business School 1967 and served as a Lieutenant (J.G) in the U.S. Navy. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Partners in Health, www.pih.org or Catholic Relief Services, www.crs.org. A wake will be held on Monday, October 11th, 4-8pm at Fred McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY and a Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Tuesday, October 12th at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, NY. A private burial will be held on Cape Cod. It was a wonderful life.
