5:11 p.m. | Updated Harry Reid can now boast a second Republican feather in his cap, of sorts. Less than 24-hours after earning the endorsement of Bill Raggio, a highly influential Republican and Nevada state senator, the Senate majority leader on Friday landed the support of Dema Guinn, the wife of the former governor who died unexpectedly this year. In a statement, Mrs. Guinn described the commitment of her husband, Kenny Guinn, to education, concluding: ''That is why I am supporting Senator Harry Reid for reelection.''

An art review on Friday about ''Man, Myth and Sensual Pleasures: Jan Gossart's Renaissance'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, using information from the museum, misspelled the name of the wife of Hercules as it is rendered in the title of a painting in the exhibition showing the couple. It is Deianira, not Deianeira. The error also appeared in a picture caption with the review.

What are some things you can find in a courtroom? You can see judges, you can see gavels, you can see bailiffs, and you might soon see Caitlin Sanchez, a 14-year-old former star of the animated series ''Dora the Explorer,'' who is is suing Nickelodeon, MTV Networks and Viacom, saying she is owed millions of dollars for her work on the show. The Hollywood Reporter said that Ms. Sanchez was 12 years old when she was hired on ''Dora'' to play the bilingual title character and that her suit asserts she was dismissed from the job when she hit puberty and could no longer provide her perky, imperious voice.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about a 103-year-old book lover and the people who read to her in her final years misspelled the name of a play she wrote. It is ''Final Chukker,'' not ''Final Chukkah.''

And so it came to pass that on the 55th day -- 55 days, that is, after firing its chief executive, Mark V. Hurd, for playing footsie with a consultant and fudging his expense accounts -- the board of directors at Hewlett-Packard proudly announced it had found a new man to lead the company out of the wilderness. His name is Léo Apotheker, a suave European -- how many American C.E.O.'s have an accent aigu in their name? -- who had spent most of his career at SAP, the giant German maker of business software. SAP has one primary competitor: Oracle, the very same company that hired Mr. Hurd barely a month after H.P. let him go, in a move clearly intended not only to bolster Oracle but to humiliate H.P.

You've heard Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the House Republican leader, wants to be speaker. Did you also know that he is running for re-election? In a rare campaign event in his decidedly safe congressional district in southern Ohio, Mr. Boehner, in a Network-meets-glam-rock-band-Twisted-Sister moment, told voters on Friday that the American government was being disrespectful, and that they don't have to take it.

READING--Charles Guild, Jr.,89, died September 27, 2010 in New York. Born in Trenton, NJ, he taught classical singing in New York for 50 years. He served in the U.S. Army from 1943-1945 in Italy, where he began voice study with Giuseppe De Luca, revered Italian baritone of opera's Golden Age, who became his mentor. A passionate advocate of the bel canto style of singing and an opera lover since childhood, he devoted his life to the study and teaching of voice and the nurturing of his students. His technical mastery was shaped by vocal wisdom from some of the most famous opera singers of the last century, who were his friends. He is survived by family, his grateful students, and special friend, Pyramid Sellers. Memorial at 10am, November 13, St. Malachy's. Interment in Arlington National Cemetery.
Two New Jersey lottery results in some editions on Thursday were in error. The correct Pick 4 number for Wednesday was 8501. The correct Cash 5 numbers were 4, 18, 19, 27 and 29.

An article on Wednesday about federal approval of two planned solar power projects on federal lands in California, quoting Interior Secretary Ken Salazar, misstated the position of the Sierra Club on one of the projects. The group says it takes no position on the Imperial Valley solar project; it does not support it.

EIDENBERG--Karen, on October 8, 2010. Beloved daughter of Harry and Sally. Loving sister to Joyce. Devoted Auntie to Tim and Lindsay. Sister-in-law to Bill. Funeral services Sunday, October 10 at 10am at Hirsch Funeral Home (Bronx).

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Friday about betting in Britain on the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature and the Man Booker Prize misspelled the given name of a Swedish poet who was considered a contender for this year's Nobel Prize, which was won by Mario Vargas Llosa on Thursday. He is Tomas Transtromer, not Thomas.

LOS ANGELES - It's not quite a monster movie, but it has some of the same elements: an outsize character, a mysterious death, plenty of metaphor for mankind's destruction. And lots and lots of excessively teased hair. HBO Films has decided to tackle Phil Spector, the bewigged record producer who created the ''wall of sound'' in the 1960s but is now serving a prison sentence of 19 years to life for murder. Starring will be Al Pacino. (Think about it.)

An article on Thursday about the closing of the television studios at Edward R. Murrow High School in Midwood, Brooklyn, misstated part of the title of a biography about Mr. Murrow. It is ''With Heroic Truth,'' not ''The Heroic Truth.''

SCHRECKINGER--Jinny. The Friedman Family and the employees of Penmark Realty Corp., and Friedman Management Co., acknowledge with sadness the passing of our colleague and friend, Jinny Schreckinger. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family.

The Senate contest in Illinois has been in a stalemate for months, with questions of trust about both candidates hovering in the background. Not anymore.

An article on Page 1 of the section this weekend about large companies paying the expenses of rock bands to help burnish their corporate images misstated remarks made by Chris Kaskie, president of the music Web site Pitchfork. Mr. Kaskie discussed Nike as an example of a company whose work with musicians does not draw significant debate among current music fans. He did not refer to Nike's labor practices during that discussion.

Carl Richards, a certified financial planner, regularly publishes new sketches at BehaviorGap.com that try to simplify complex money decisions. While I can't prove it scientifically, I'm pretty sure there's a correlation between our personal financial situation and the amount of time we spend complaining about the practices of big banks, Wall Street, credit card companies and mortgage lenders.

5:54 p.m. | Updated First Timothy Cahill's top aides quit his campaign, followed by his running mate, Paul Loscocco, who proclaimed that Mr. Cahill, an independent candidate in the Massachusetts governor's race, had no shot at winning. In another twist of the knife, Mr. Loscocco promptly endorsed Charles Baker Jr., the Republican. Then Mr. Cahill himself ramped up the drama, filing a lawsuit Thursday against the aides who jumped ship, essentially accusing them of high treason. The highly unusual suit charges that the aides not only orchestrated Mr. Loscocco's defection, but shared campaign secrets with the Baker shop.

Many of us have at least part of our financial lives on autopilot. Maybe Netflix and your gym automatically bill your credit card each month. Or perhaps you've authorized your credit cards and cable company to pull money directly from your checking account. It all runs like a well-oiled machine, until you've canceled your gym membership or another service -- and the biller won't stop deducting money, long after you've asked it to stop.

''The Last Lecture'' will not be the final chapter in the story of Randy Pausch, the computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University who turned his ruminations on life and his own impending death into a wildly popular oration and that best-selling book. Jai Pausch, the widow of Mr. Pausch, who died of pancreatic cancer in 2008, will write a memoir about the final months of her husband's life and her experiences as his caregiver, the emotional trials her family underwent and her life now as a single mother of three children. The Crown Archetype imprint of Crown Books, a division of Random House, said it had acquired the untitled memoir and planned to publish it in the spring of 2012.

RUBIN--Cynthia, age 60, died on October 7, 2010 of metastatic melanoma. Cherished twin sister of Corinne, beloved sister of Norma, and the late Janice; dear sister-in-law of Michael, Stanley, Ian, and the late Howard; much adored aunt of Elena and Charlie, Cheryl and Matt, Nicki and Joey, Doug and Kim, Joy, Mindy, Barry and Jackie, and Stewart; doting great-aunt of Jacob, Max, Victoria, Dustin, Tyler, Logan, Alex, Amanda, Harry, Justin, and Hilary. Devoted labor and delivery nurse for 37 years: New York-Presbyterian for 23 years; North Shore-LIJ at Manhasset for the remainder of her career. Lover of Manhattan, movies, Broadway theater, the New York Times, and most of all, her family. Our lives were immeasurably enriched by her love and devotion. Life will not be the same without her. May she finally rest in peace. Private graveside service on Sunday, October 10th, at 10:30am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Shiva will be observed at the home of Corinne and Michael Bronson, Huntington Station, NY through Tuesday evening.

William A. Ackman, the hedge fund manager who has rarely shied from a challenge, appears to have identified the two companies he would like to shake up next: J.C. Penney and Fortune Brands, the owner of the Jim Beam whiskey and Titleist golf brands.

LONDON -- No nation can expect to stage a World Cup or the Olympic Games these days without fulfilling the legacy pledge. It is no longer enough to promise to host sporting events for their own sake. Beijing won the 2008 Olympics on a promise to open up China to the world. This year's World Cup in South Africa had a double legacy, setting the mammoth soccer tournament in Africa for the first time and celebrating Nelson Mandela's lifetime achievements for that country.

BENKERT--Ernst G.,82, died October 5th, 2010 after living for three and a half years with angiosarcoma, a rare form of cancer. With him at the end were his children, Louly Williams and Edward Benkert, his grandchildren, Ellie and Max Williams, and his companion of twenty-eight years, Alexandra Walcott. He is also survived by a brother, Kyle Benkert, a grandson, Harris Benkert, and his former wife, Lisa Woods. He was predeceased by a son, Max Benkert. Ernst's dedication as an artist, his knowledge of art history, his appreciation of the written word, and his inquisitive intelligence were the delight of a multitude of friends and colleagues. He lived in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn and was a frequent visitor to galleries, museums and friends across the East River. Donations in his memory may be made to Proteus Gowanus Gallery and Kentler International Drawing Space, both in Brooklyn. A memorial service will be held at noon Saturday, October 9th at Christ Church Cobble Hill, 326 Clinton Street, Brooklyn.

6:30 P.M. (49); 7 P.M. (13) THE THIS OLD HOUSE HOUR An oldie proves it's still a goodie as this pioneering home-renovation series begins a new season by giving an Auburndale, Mass., house -- a dated 1940s dwelling on a picture-perfect plot next to the Charles River in suburban Boston -- what the show's crew is calling a Cinderella transformation. The building, owned by Raveen and Allison Sharma, will receive a sorely needed curb-appeal makeover, the better to fit into a neighborhood of charming cottages and Colonial Revivals. The renovation will also include an updated kitchen and bathrooms, a new family room, an improved roofline and enlarged windows to take advantage of the panoramic view. In this first of 16 episodes, the general contractor, Tom Silva, conducts a structural investigation and cites concerns about a new law from the Environmental Protection Agency on professional remodelers' handling of materials covered in lead paint. But that's not the only hazard lurking: the structure will require nearly two full weeks of asbestos removal. Above, a scene from the show. This half-hour episode is followed by a new season of ''Ask This Old House,'' which will tackle viewer questions from Toronto; Los Angeles; Fargo, N.D.; and Wichita, Kan. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton reports on the relationship between the Tea Party and activists from the religious right, including tensions over how to approach social issues like abortion and gay marriage. Fred de Sam Lazaro looks at the efforts of the Friends of the Earth Middle East, an umbrella organization representing environmental nongovernmental groups in the region, to protect the endangered Jordan River, where Christian tourists and pilgrims come to retrace the footsteps of Jesus and be baptized. And Bob Abernethy leads a discussion on Snyder v. Phelps, the case currently before the United States Supreme Court about the rights of members of a small Baptist church in Kansas to picket military funerals to spread their message that God is punishing the United States for its tolerance of homosexuality by killing American troops. Protesters have carried signs that said, ''Thank God for dead soldiers'' and ''God hates you.''

SIEGAL--Arthur died peacefully Friday morning, October 8th surrounded by his four loving children, Linda, Jane, Andrew, Julie and son-in-law Mark Florin and dear friend Hal. He is the beloved grandfather to Wyatt, Skylar, Daniella and Sam. Family, friends and associates will remember Arthur for his creative funny mind, kindness and love of life and people. He will be greatly missed and loved by all. There will be a graveside service on Sunday at Sharon Memorial Park in Sharon; Mass at 10:45am. A memorial service will be held Monday, October 11th at 3:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Ave. The family will be sitting Shiva Monday directly after the memorial service and Tuesday and Wednesday at 5:00 at the home of Linda and Mark Florin.

BOBER--Senta, 91, died at 4:40pm on October 7, 2010. No one was more giving, loving and courageous than Senta. She was a tireless worker for Hadassah and for the State of Israel. Her 60 year marriage to her deceased husband Arnold was the highlight of her life demonstrated by deep affection. Her marriage was a pillar of support for her in her later years. Her many, many friends were a testament to her kindness. She was a deep intellectual thinker, a devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was particularly proud of attending Fordham University when she was 60 years old and earning her bachelors degree, something she wanted all her life but was interrupted by her having to flee Nazi Germany. She is survived by her son Frank, her brother Henry, grandchildren Suzanne, Sarah, Jenia, Bronwen, David and Gabrielle and great-grandchildren Teddy, Sam and Laila. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City at 11:15am Sunday, October 10, 2010.

ENGELMAYER--Ilene (Zelman), 79, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, died on October 7, 2010 of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Born December 6, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, she was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of New York University, from which she later earned two masters degrees. After working initially in advertising (market research), she later became a dedicated teacher of remedial reading in the New York City public schools. She married Louis Engelmayer in 1955 and remained devoted to him through his death in 2000, and to their two children Paul Engelmayer and Jean Engelmayer Kalicki, their spouses Emily Mandelstam and Jan Kalicki, and her four grandchildren, Sasha and Peter Kalicki and Caroline and William Engelmayer. She was a loving daughter, devoted sister to her brothers Fred and Milton and their wives Celie and Helen, and a dedicated matriarch to an extended family of Zelman nieces and nephews and their children, for whom she hosted family Thanksgiving reunions for more than 45 years. She was a forceful intellectual with a playful sense of humor, and was an avid reader, a strong believer in civic participation, a gracious host and cook, and a proud celebrator of Jewish heritage. A memorial service will be held on Monday, October 11, 2010 at 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. The family will be sitting shiva at 300 Central Park West, Apt. 5B, on Monday, October 11, between 6:30pm and 10pm, and on Tuesday, October 12, between 4pm and 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations in her memory be sent to the Jewish Museum of New York, Development Department, 1109 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY, 10128, in honor of Ilene Engelmayer. We will miss her kindness, wisdom, whimsical humor and abiding love.

President Obama will continue his attempts to engage younger voters this week, holding a rally with a musical guest, the Roots, in Philadelphia on Sunday and a town-hall-style meeting on MTV on Thursday. Younger voters were among the Democrats' strongest supporters in 2008, and they have the highest approval ratings of the president. But in the last two midterm elections, only one in four people under age 30 voted, about half the rate for recent presidential elections. And, according to a poll by the Pew Research Center in September, young Democrats are currently even less engaged than they were in 2006.

OK, that's weird. I just taped This Week, which included an interview with Christine Lagarde, the French finance minister. In her defense of austerity, she asserted that unemployment in France is down from 9.6 to 9.3. But I looked it up on Eurostat (pdf), which has French unemployment in August at 10.1, up from 9.6 a year ago.

The 350.org network organized by Bill McKibben, the writer and climate campaigner, is having a "work party" all day today. The House forecast that we released on Friday establishes an over-under line for Republican gains at a net of 47 or 48 seats. But, as I noted at the end of the article, the confidence interval on this forecast is very wide. Its margin of error is about ±30 seats -- meaning that a gain of as few as 17 seats, or as many as 78, is entirely possible -- and there is a small chance of even larger or smaller gains.

The Associated Press reports that United States and Sochaux forward Charlie Davies was fined $1,040 and had his driver's license suspended by French police after a speeding incident in the Jury region of France. Few hotels offer views to rival those of the Savoy Hotel. Sitting on the bend of the Thames River, its riverside rooms afford views (which inspired artists like Monet and Whistler) of the Houses of Parliament to the west and St Paul's Cathedral and beyond to the east. Of the hotel's 268 guest rooms and suites, two-thirds have riverside views.

The most newsworthy dance item in Europe during the remainder of 2010 is not occurring onstage. It's an exhibition: ''Diaghilev and the Golden Age of the Ballets Russes 1909-29'' at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London (through Jan. 9, 2011). Because among the many ways that Diaghilev transformed ballet was by persistently upgrading and modernizing its scenery and costumes, no dance company in history suits an exhibition better than his. You went to the Ballets Russes in Diaghilev's day not just to see the greatest dancers and choreography; you went to hear sensational new music (scores were commissioned from Debussy, Poulenc, Prokofiev, Ravel, Stravinsky and others) and to see dazzlingly imaginative works of visual art. His designers -- demonstrating different aspects and phases of artistic modernism -- included Bakst, Chanel, Derain, Goncharova, Larionov, Matisse and Picasso.
MEIER--Frederick P. Nov. 1924 - Oct. 2003 When we lost you, our hearts were broken & will never mend. Devoted wife & daughter, Ann & Eunice

Gitarcafe (gitarcafe.com) on Istanbul's Asian shore is a small music hall and cafe-bar that has become a fixture among music lovers in the city. Housed in a 19th-century building, the intimate performance space (pictured) -- lighted by candles and a chandelier that dangles from the lofty ceiling -- is a cozy setting in which to hear a range of mostly acoustic music, from master musicians like the Italian guitarist Carlo Domeniconi to traditional Turkish folk bands. Founded in 2000 by Onok Bozkurt, a classical guitar player, the cafe encourages audience participation with open-mic events and workshops. Ferries for the Kadikoy neighborhood, near the cafe, leave from several city docks, and from there, a short walk will take you to the music hall, which is nestled among other cafes and restaurants on lively Sakizgulu Street.

SPORTS An article in some editions last Sunday about Michigan State's victory over Wisconsin misidentified the Michigan State player whose fumble after a reception contributed to the Spartans' early struggles. He is Keith Nichol, not Keshawn Martin. And a picture caption in some copies misidentified the Wisconsin player shown being tackled. He is running back John Clay, not quarterback Scott Tolzien. (The caption was for a picture of Tolzien published in other copies.) (Go to Article)

Russia has some spectacular museums -- the Hermitage in St. Petersburg evokes gasps at nearly every turn -- but they tend to have a stuffy, staid feel. The exhibit halls are typically watched over by the kind of matrons who wag their fingers when you get too close to a Kandinsky. Not so at the Garage Center for Contemporary Culture, one of Russia's first attempts to present modern art with a modern sensibility. At nearly 100,000 square feet, the Garage (19A Obraztsova Street; 7-495-645-0520; garageccc.com/eng) is housed in a former bus depot that was designed by the Constructivist architect Konstantin Melnikov in the 1920s. The project was spearheaded by Dasha Zhukova, a 29-year-old fashion editor and the girlfriend of one of Russia's richest men, Roman Abramovich. In the two years that it's been open, it's already managed to attract a host of major exhibitions.
GREENBERG--Charles H. You will be cherished and adored forever. Doree, Andy, Deanne, Emily, Charlie, Lynn, Hillary, Scott, Joely and Eric

FRONT PAGE An article last Sunday about the economic travails of Las Vegas because of the recession misstated the year that an earlier recession ended. Economic data showed that the recession ended in March 1991, not 1992 (though it was still a major issue in the 1992 presidential race.) (Go to Article)

ENGELMAYER--Ilene (Zelman), 79, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, died on October 7, 2010 of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Born December 6, 1930 in Brooklyn, NY, she was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of New York University, from which she later earned two masters degrees. After working initially in advertising (market research), she later became a dedicated teacher of remedial reading in the New York City public schools. She married Louis Engelmayer in 1955 and remained devoted to him through his death in 2000, and to their two children Paul Engelmayer and Jean Engelmayer Kalicki, their spouses Emily Mandelstam and Jan Kalicki, and her four grandchildren, Sasha and Peter Kalicki and Caroline and William Engelmayer. She was a loving daughter, devoted sister to her brothers Fred and Milton and their wives Celie and Helen, and a dedicated matriarch to an extended family of Zelman nieces and nephews and their children, for whom she hosted family Thanksgiving reunions for more than 45 years. She was a forceful intellectual with a playful sense of humor, and was an avid reader, a strong believer in civic participation, a gracious host and cook, and a proud celebrator of Jewish heritage. A memorial service will be held on Monday, October 11, 2010 at 10am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. The family will be sitting shiva at 300 Central Park West, Apt. 5B, on Monday, October 11, between 6:30pm and 10pm, and on Tuesday, October 12, between 4pm and 8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that donations in her memory be sent to the Jewish Museum of New York, Development Department, 1109 Fifth Avenue, New York, NY, 10128, in honor of Ilene Engelmayer. We will miss her kindness, wisdom, whimsical humor and abiding love.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Saturday, September 25th 2010, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
LAIDMAN--Thomas, artist, died October 3, 2010. Survived by wife, Janet, children, John, Jean and four grandchildren.

MYERS--Jack, almost 95 years old died in New York City of congestive heart failure. He received his BA and Masters at New York University were he was also a Ph.D. candidate. After his retirement as an accountant with the IRS for 37 years, he taught sociology at several colleges. A sculptor, essayist, playwright and poet, he is survived by his wife of 59 years Nohmie, his children Tedd, Elissa and Saul, his son-in-law Shelly and his granddaughters Arielle, Lilly, Nina and Sasha.

Perched high on the eastern slopes of Paris, the 20th Arrondissement has historically been a spot for local residents, with an emphasis on raucous music and hard-left politics. The few tourists who do broach the district usually get no farther than the Père Lachaise cemetery. Plentiful graffiti and one or two watch-your-step side streets attest to the area's still-rough edges, but these are being smoothed over by growing clusters of dining and night life options. Much of the evening action trickles off the Rue de Ménilmontant, a jagged ribbon of a street that peers over the Pompidou Center and the Seine. The neighborhood anchor remains La Bellevilloise (labellevilloise.com), which opened a century ago as an artisan co-op, and today is a multi-room free-for-all of art, dance and dining. JEFF JOHN ROBERTS LA FAILLE96, rue Ménilmontant (33-1) 47-97-34-10 This new spot has attracted D.J.'sfrom across the city to spin in asmall lounge that serves up spe-cialty shooters (4 euros) and bot-tles of Champagne. By day it is alaid-back spot to sip coffee andwatch a soccer match.

The cover article last Sunday, about the market for second homes around the region, misidentified the town on the North Fork of Long Island where a three-bedroom house with a dock and bulkhead is for sale. It is Greenport, not Greenpoint.

METROPOLITAN An article last Sunday about the emergency room at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn described an angiogram incorrectly. It is a test in which a catheter -- not a tiny camera -- is threaded into the body to help produce X-ray images of arteries that might be blocked. (Go to Article)

Is there anything James Franco can't do? The multihyphenate's multihyphenate, whose latest offerings include a starring turn as Allen Ginsberg in the movie ''Howl'' and ''Palo Alto'' (Scribner), a collection of short stories being released on October 19, appears in drag on the cover of the fall issue of Candy magazine. Billed as ''the world's first transversal style magazine,'' the ambisexual publication plays limbo with the markers of gender and high-fashion and is the brainchild of Luis Venegas, the Madrid-based publisher of the cult magazines Fanzine 137 and Electric Youth. In addition to Mr. Franco's fashion shoot with the photographer Terry Richardson, the new issue of Candy features a photo spread of Mr. Venegas impersonating Vogue editor in chief, Anna Wintour. Divino! This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print

Think you've seen every Tintoretto canvas there is to see in Venice? Oddly, the church of Madonna dell'Orto, where the 16th-century artist is buried, is not on many visitors' itineraries. The church, which is not far from the house on the Fondamenta dei Mori where Tintoretto died in 1594, is in a largely untrodden section of the Venetian neighborhood of Cannaregio. Besides visiting Tintoretto's resting place in the chapel to the right of the main apse of the Madonna dell'Orto church, you can view some seldom-seen works, including the gargantuan ''Worship of the Golden Calf'' and ''Last Judgment,'' both of them in the presbytery. Another work, the lush ''Presentation of the Virgin in the Temple,'' is on the right aisle above the door to the sacristy. If you're in the mood for something more modern -- yet similarly undiscovered -- head over to the Fondazione Emilio and Annabianca Vedova, (fondazionevedova.org/en) at the waterfront esplanade in the Dorsoduro neighborhood. It features the work of one of Italy's most renowned 20th-century artists, Emilio Vedova, who died in 2006. The museum has two parts. One occupies the studio where he worked for the last 30 years of his life -- a former 16th-century boatyard that opened in June of this year and features a series of his sculptures. The other inhabits a renovated space in the adjacent Magazzini del Sale, former salt warehouses (pictured), where Vedova also had a studio. That space opened in June 2009 after a restoration by the architect Renzo Piano, who consulted with Vedova on the design for many years. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

STANTON--Dr. Frederic Robert Stanton, 86, passed away on September 22, 2010 in Mission Viejo, CA. A graduate of Ohio State University and Middlesex University (MA), he was a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine, United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation officer, New York and Florida businessman. After World War II, he sailed on several voyages to Europe, including Poland and Greece, for UNRRA to replace thousands of horses and cattle wiped out during the war. Later, he founded a veterinary practice in Arkansas, and afterward entered business in New York and Florida. He survived two wives, Ruth and Josephine. He is survived by his sons, Mark and Kim and daughter-in-law Carol, his brother Ivens and companion Julia, and grandchildren Leah and Eric as well as many nephews and nieces. Burial was at Fort Myers (FL) Gardens and Memorial Park.

On Tuesday morning, the federal government revealed details of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's new 5-Star Safety Rating System and released new ratings for some of the most popular 2011 model-year vehicles. Of the 33 vehicles tested, only two received an overall rating of five stars, which is the best: the BMW 5 Series (4-door and rear-wheel-drive models) and the Hyundai Sonata built after July 2, 2010. David Strickland, the agency's administrator, said he thought this group of vehicles performed ''as expected.'' He added, ''A number did not do as well as in past years, but the tests are more severe. As a whole, we think the new standards are fair, and they represent the most significant risks in crashes that passengers and drivers face.''

GUTOFF--Judyth, on Thursday, October 7, 2010, Judyth A. Gutoff, beloved wife, mother and sister, passed away after a brief illness. Her family and friends mourn the loss of a beautiful, vivacious and creative woman. Judyth was born on January 25, 1935 to Helen and Ernst Mayer, joining elder brother Donald. She grew up on Central Park West and attended Ethical Culture and Fieldston schools. In 1954 Judyth was the Ohio State University homecoming queen at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena. Judyth was married to Edward Bernstein. They were the parents of Lynn, Neal and Gail. The family lived in Westport, Connecticut for 23 years. In 1981 Judyth married Reuben Gutoff. Together they embarked on a 29-year romance. They traveled the American West, visiting national parks, rafting down the Missouri River on the Lewis & Clark Trail and heli-hiking in Banff Springs National Park. A dislocated hip or a helicopter rescue didn't slow her down a bit. The couple bicycled in Switzerland, Burgundy and Provence. They attended the Summer Olympic Games in Barcelona, Atlanta, Sydney, and Athens, and the Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid, Calgary, Lillehammer, Salt Lake City and Turin. As tennis fans, they often made a June trip to Wimbledon, and were in the stands to witness classic moments such as the 1978 Borg-McEnroe match. Judyth was a natural athlete who excelled at tennis and skiing. She was a competitive ballroom dancer, winning national awards in her specialty, "American Smooth" tango, foxtrot, waltz and quickstep. She founded the Upper East Side exercise studio Judyth B, which she ran for 10 years. Judyth's interest in professional dance led her to support the non-profit organization Career Transition for Dancers. She loved the ballet, especially Swan Lake, and was able to negotiate about a four-to-one ratio of Knicks games to Lincoln Center performances. With her knack for craft and congenital inability to sit still, Judyth always had a project in hand. She was a talented calligrapher and an avid needlepointer, crafting intricate lions and abstract designs. A favorite pillow bore her motto, "This mess is a place," a uniquely Judyth description of the state of her desk. Judyth also loved animals. Her beloved Chihuahas Stretch, Knickie and Tango traveled everywhere with Reuben and Judyth. She volunteered for The Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons. For 28 years, they celebrated their anniversary in Paris. Each year, the theme was "Somewhere And Paris." The "somewheres" included London, Milan and Amsterdam. Paris was always Paris. And theater was always on the bill, whether on Broadway or the West End. Judyth especially loved Stoppard and Sondheim, and could name the songs of most musicals. Reuben and Judyth accumulated a lifetime of travel memories, including five bookshelf feet of Playbills. Judyth is survived by her devoted husband of 28 years, her brother, Donald (Ylain), her children, Lynn (Greg), Neal (Margie) and Gail, her step-daughters Deborah (Jack) and Bija (Daniel) and her grandchildren Matthew Jones (Jamie), Kaylin Jones, Jenson Turner, Walker, Avery and Kendall Stevens, Peter and Alexander Gault, and Nadia Cannon (Sara). Judyth was a sparkly personality who lit up a room. She breezily undertook multiple simultaneous story lines in which enthusiasm trumped linear narrative. "Wait a moment!..." Donations in honor of Judyth may be made to the Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, Weill Cornell Medical Center, Box 123, New York City, 10021, or Career Transition for Dancers (careertransition.org). There will be a gathering for family and friends at the Jewish Community Center, 334 Amsterdam Avenue (76 Street), Tuesday October 12 from 3-6pm.

Before the Alexander McQueen show tonight, Sarah Burton said her main objective with the collection - her first since taking over as creative director - was to impart a strong sense of craft. She also used the word ''tender'' to describe the general feeling of the collection, which was based on a decaying nature. The narrow tailcoats and low-rise trousers certainly follow the McQueen silhouette. The prints and ribbon embroideries were consistent with the style of the last few years. Some of the more sculptural shapes recall his sense of theatre. And Ms. Burton used materials and references associated with him, like feathers, designs that appear to have partially disintegrated, and the hand-painted leather butterflies that clustered on dresses. Although many of the garments are much lighter in construction than they might appear in photographs, some of Ms. Burton's better efforts were conspicuously light and not necessarily embroidered or full of shape.

WEINBERG--Sidney J.,Jr. The board of trustees and staff of the Carnegie Institution for Science are saddened by the loss of our long-time friend, senior trustee Sidney J. Weinberg, Jr. Jim Weinberg was inspired by Andrew Carnegie's vision of giving exceptional scientists the independence to pursue their passions. He joined the Carnegie board in 1983, becoming a senior trustee in 1999. His insights, guidance, and commitment to Carnegie's mission have been unparalleled, and the institution is sincerely grateful for his decades of dedication. We offer our sincerest condolences to Jim's wife Betty, his children, grandchildren, and other family members.

O'CONNOR--Jeremiah, W.,Jr., 68, died peacefully at his home in Bronxville, New York Friday October 8, 2010. He was also a resident of Osterville, MA and Lost Tree Village, North Palm Beach, FL. Jerry was sustained throughout his life by an unfaltering devotion to his faith and family. He was a generous and loving husband, father, brother, friend and colleague. He is survived by his beloved wife of forty-two years, Joan (Bruton), five adoring children, Bill (and Eileen) of Rye, NY, Chris and M.E. of New Canaan, CT, Marjorie (O'Connor) and Nat Furman of New Canaan, CT, Karina (Lagos) O'Connor of Bronxville, NY, Catherine (O'Connor) and Matt Williams of New York, NY, John O'Connor and his fiance, Erin Dougherty of New York, NY. Jerry was predeceased by his son Jeremiah William, III who passed away early last month. He is also survived by fifteen beautiful grandchildren: Jack, Emiliano, Sarah Jane, Erin, Maggie, Will, Cate, Patrick, Margot, Christopher, Jay, Chip, Annie, Connor, and Sophia who loved to play, tease, swim, and spend time with their beloved Grampy. Jerry was born and raised in Newton, MA, the second of eleven children of the late Jeremiah William and Marjorie Quigley. He is also survived by his step-mother, Rose Ann, brothers, William, Peter, Joseph, Michael and Charles and his sisters, Dorothy, Maura, Kathleen and Margaret, and their spouses. He was predeceased by his brothers Paul and Chris. Jerry loved nothing more than to be with his wife, children and siblings to him life was a celebration of family his favorite of which took place often on his beloved Cape Cod. Jerry began his career at Lazard Freres and Co and with their sponsorship he helped found Corporate Property Investors, a private REIT with significant shopping center and office holdings. Jerry was an early pioneer in the development of the regional mall business. He started his own firm, The O'Connor Group, in 1983 and continued to focus much of his efforts in the shopping center industry, investing in and developing many notable properties, among them; The Westchester in White Plains New York, and Menlo Park Mall in Edison, NJ. He enjoyed every detail of development including choosing art for these properties. (In the Menlo Park Mall he placed a sculpture with six children jumping over a puddle, as a memento of his most important achievement, his children.) Jerry was a past president of the International Council of Shopping Centers ("ICSC"). The O'Connor Group, now O'Connor Capital Partners, continued in the mall development and management business and later managed a series of private equity funds that remain active today. In addition to his retail work he was most proud of the rejuvenation of Parkchester, a residential community in the Bronx. Jerry truly believed "to whom much is given, much is expected" and as such was a generous supporter of numerous charities among them: The Papal Foundation, Gregorian University, Catholic Relief Services, Partners in Health, and The Bronxville School Foundation. Jerry also served for many years as a Trustee and Chair of the Investment Committee of The College of the Holy Cross. After a Catholic Relief Service visit to Ethiopia which moved and inspired him, he devoted recent philanthropic efforts to building wells throughout that country. Jerry was a graduate of the College of the Holy Cross 1963, Harvard Business School 1967 and served as a Lieutenant (J.G) in the U.S. Navy. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to Partners in Health, www.pih.org or Catholic Relief Services, www.crs.org. A wake will be held on Monday, October 11th, 4-8pm at Fred McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY and a Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Tuesday, October 12th at 10am at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, NY. A private burial will be held on Cape Cod. It was a wonderful life.

ANN ARBOR, Mich. -- One week after having his return temporarily postponed by a blood clot in his leg, Michigan State Coach Mark Dantonio is expected to resume his duties for Saturday's game between No. 18 Michigan and No. 17 Michigan State (both 5-0, 1-0 Big Ten). Dantonio, 54, had a mild heart attack in the aftermath of Michigan State's overtime victory against Notre Dame on Sept. 18 and missed the Spartans' next two games. He was expected to coach from the Michigan Stadium press box Saturday.

To check out new and traditional indie films from Denmark and elsewhere, plop into a chair in the Danish Film Institute's movie theater, which is known as the Cinematheque. Each month the Cinematheque ( dfi.dk/English.aspx) shows scores of international auteur, avant-garde, experimental and art-house films and showcases one feature film and one documentary. (This month's showcase selections are Jane Campion's ''Bright Star'' and Peter Kerekes's ''Cooking History.'') The institute also holds special theme nights that combine a film with a bar and D.J.-fueled party. ''Friday Late Night'' features a music-based film, and ''Psyched Out'' is for fans of freaky, underground movies. The soundtrack shifts to strings, horns and pianos during the midweek Onsdagskoncerter (onsdagskoncerter.dk), a year-round series of intimate weekly classical music performances (pictured) held every Wednesday at a rotation of Copenhagen's loveliest old buildings. With music provided by students of the Royal Danish Academy of Music, the free shows are a chance to discover centuries-old churches, museums, government halls and foreign embassies that lie off the tourists' normal route.

THE NEWS The state of West Virginia sued to overturn the stricter controls on mountaintop coal mining adopted in 2009 by the Obama administration. BEHIND THE NEWS Gov. Joe Manchin III, a Democrat in a tough race for the state's open Senate seat, said the regulations usurped state rights, were based on inadequate science and harmed the state by preventing new mining projects. The Environmental Protection Agency defended the rules, pointing to damage done by blasting off the tops of hills to reach the coal beneath and dumping the mine rubble in stream valleys.

A picture on Sept. 26 with an article about an economic and cultural revitalization under way in Lodz, Poland, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of the Lodz Arts Center was taken by Katarzyna Dobrzanska, not by Andrzej Rozycki.

Francois Nars's makeup can be described as dramatic, but his limited-edition Bento Box lipstick set takes the concept literally. Inspired by a porcelain pot of lip stain used for kabuki actors that Nars found in Japan 10 years ago, the set of two cups of hand-poured color comes in a handsome wooden box with a wisteria-handled lip brush. ''I've always been fascinated with the concept of kabuki makeup,'' Nars says. ''It's about symbolism and using color to create drama.'' The lipstick application is as seductive as its presentation. ''You dip the brush into the cup, around the perimeter, to pick up product, and simply paint,'' he says. ''It's a beautiful process.'' Unless you want to look like a Japanese theater character, however, Nars recommends using a little restraint: ''It's highly pigmented, so I suggest starting out light and building for desired intensity. It seems intimidating, but the texture is creamy and light and will move easily.'' The set will be available for $125 beginning November 1 at Saks Fifth Avenue and Barneys New York, or go to narscosmetics.com/bento to pre-order. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print

Matisse and Picasso exhibitions will never be in short supply, and you'll never have to go far for them. But a comprehensive survey of one of Italy's greatest 16th-centuryartists, Agnolo Bronzino, is a once-in-a-lifetime affair, and to see it you'll have to travel to Florence, where ''Bronzino, Artist and Poet at the Court ofthe Medici'' appears through Jan. 23. Bronzino (1503-72) was court painter to Cosimo Ide'Medici, and a brilliant multitasker. His aristocratic portraiture, with its chilly hauteur and lacquered perfection, set a fashion for all of Europe, and some of the grandest will be assembled for this occasion.He was also a superlative religious painter, contributing work to Florence's most important churches. Many of those paintings are still in their original locations. And while the show is installed atthe Palazzo Strozzi, Florence itself will function as a kind of Bronzino museum, and a necessary stop on any European art tour. Similarly, Paris will be an extension of ''Mondrian in Paris: 1912-1938'' at the Pompi-dou Center from Dec. 1 to March 31. The Dutch painterspent most of his long careerthere, until World War II forced him to leave for London and then New York. With a re-construction of Mondrian's dazzlingly designed Rue duDépart studio as its centerpiece, this overview will trace his development toward abstraction in pictures shaped by the jazz rhythms and architectural lines of the City of Light.

SCHLOSSBERG--Martin of West Hills passed away on October 6, 2010. He was born in 1936 in Brooklyn, NY and is survived by his wife Estelle, three children, five grandchildren and sister. His long garment center career led to his store Estelle's Dresses in Farmingdale, LI.

Scott Tobias, president and chief operating officer of Village Voice Media, which is experiencing a revenue increase because of ads for medical marijuana.

SCHRENZEL--Bernard, 94. Beloved husband of the late Esther. Father of Naomi (Jesse) Cogan and the late Gloria Sheer. Father-in-law of Rabbi Charles (Judy) Sheer. Grandfather of David (Bonnie), Daniel (Nava), Rachel (Avi), Max and Riva. Great-grandfather of 12. Proud graduate of Yeshiva University and dedicated teacher in the New York City school system. Lover of Jewish life and learning.

MURRAY--Ira. On September 29, 2010, at the age of 105 years and seven months, Ira Murray died in his sleep at the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital, Douglas Gardens, in Miami, Florida. He was the brother and partner of the late Arthur Murray, who founded the famous network of franchised ballroom dancing studios; Ira was the head of the Arthur Murray Studios in Canada. Born on the lower East Side, the youngest of four brothers, he was the son of Abraham Teichman and Sara Shor Teichman. His sister, Dr. Rebecca Roman, was one of the first women doctors in New York City. Ira was the husband of the late Anne Murray; father of Daniel and Edward, now deceased; grandfather of Nadya Murray; uncle of many affectionate nieces and nephews, including Ruth Bart, Jane Heimlich, Wendy Levine, Phyllis McDowell, Matthew Schuss, Judith Walsh, and Naomi Zichlin; father-in-law of Myra Malkin; and long-time friend of Robert (Rocky) Temliak and The Honorable Freda Hertz. In his youth, Ira wrote short stories in Yiddish. He was an accomplished photographer, and in the 1940's was involved with the family real estate business in Manhattan. He remained astute and alert until the end: when he was already over 100, he helped his niece Jane Heimlich with her memoir, "Out of Step," by recalling incidents from the family's past. His generosity of spirit and his concern for family and friends will always be remembered.

HOROWITZ--Dorothy Dall, died on October 6th, 2010. She was predeceased by her beloved husband of 62 years, Harry Mark Horowitz. Dorothy graduated from Hunter College and taught at Bryant High School before becoming a treasured English teacher for Homebound Students on the WNYE High School of the Air. Among her students were talented and renowned young people. Dorothy and Harry were accomplished pianists and were known for their four hand renditions. Their home was a gracious setting for introducing and encouraging young musicians. She was charming, elegant and sensitive to the needs of others. She will be sorely missed by her many dear friends. She was grateful to her physician, Dr. Sharda Ramsaroop of the Wright Center at New York Hospital; her aides and her very dear close friends. As one, Julie Kozich stated, "Harry was the gardener; and Dorothy cultivated friends." The internment will be private. Friends will be received at 45 Sutton Place South on October 17th from 2-7pm. There will be a Memorial Service on the 14th of November at 3:00pm at the Astoria Center of Israel 27-35 Crescent St., Astoria, NY, 11102. If you wish, contributions may be given to the Astoria Center of Israel; Channel 13; or an organization of your choice.

TORNQVIST--Dr. Erik Gustav Markus, January 13, 1924 -- October 1, 2010. Died peacefully at home in Watchung, NJ. Born Lund, Sweden. M.S., Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm. PhD Biochemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison. Chemical engineer Exxon Research, Linden, NJ for 30 years. Over 40 US patents. Started own firm, PolymErik, Inc., consulting in polymer chemistry until 2006. Enjoyed music, skiing, playing/coaching soccer, studying history, stamp collecting. Instrumental in issuance of three US stamps commemorating Swedish-American relations. Involved with numerous Swedish-American organizations. Survived by wife of 41 years, Linnea Lindborg Tornqvist, two daughters, one son, one brother, one sister, one grandchild. In lieu of flowers, please support the American Parkinson Disease Association.

WARWICK--Kathleen Ann, securities law expert, dead at age 76. Kathleen A. Warwick, a long-time Federal Securities law expert, passed away in her home in Manhattan on Sunday, September 26, 2010 after a long illness. A native of Philadelphia, she was a graduate of Vassar College and Columbia University School of Law. Upon graduation her first job as an attorney was at the New York office of the U.S. Securities Exchange Commission. She returned to the SEC twenty years later as the first woman to be appointed Regional Administrator of that office, the SEC's largest regional office. After a brief stay as Regional Administrator, she resumed a solo practice in securities law. During her long career she worked as an associate at Cadwalader, Wickersham and Taft and later as securities counsel at Mobil Oil Corporation. One of the few women who early on practiced Securities law, she was a very active participant in the American Bar Association, Business Law Section, and chaired several committees. She organized and was a speaker in many forums. She is remembered by colleagues and friends for integrity, the high standards she set, and for her dedication to the practice of securities law. She was a supporter of the New York City Ballet and Metropolitan Museum of Art. Ms. Warwick is survived by her cousins, Dr. Ralph Jessar of Gladwyne, PA and Dr. Barry S. Savits of New York City. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Vassar College, 124 Raymond Avenue, Box 14, Poughkeepsie, NY 12604 or to Columbia University School of Law, 435 West 116th Street, Box A-2, New York, New York 10027.

DEUTCH--Murray, died on October 2. Murray, 90 leaves behind his beloved wife, Pamela, his two children Howard and Lisa, devoted father-in-law to Stu and Lea, an adoring grandfather to Hayley, Jordan, Sloane, Maddie and Zoey and a great granddaughter Avery. He was a legendary music publishing icon.

NARVAEZ--Maria, of Manhattan passed away on August 25, 2010. A long-time resident of the Upper East Side, Maria came to this country in the 1940s and embraced it, especially New York, as her own. She will be dearly missed by her daughter, Isabella Zagare, her sister, Myra, her nieces, and her many friends. A memorial service will be held at Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Ave. in Manhattan, on October 16th at 1pm. Memorial donations may be made to: The Art Students League of New York, 215 W. 57 St., New York, NY 10019.

Where culture is concerned, in Madrid variety reigns. With funky new art centers emerging from defunct factories and traditional Spanish musical theater embracing modern themes, there are seemingly endless ways to dive into the arts in Madrid. One of those old industrial spaces is Matadero Madrid (Paseo de la Chopera 14; 34-91-517-7309; mataderomadrid.com), formerly a vast slaughterhouse and now a lively multidisciplinary arts complex with design, technology and art exhibitions, as well as experimental theater like the coming ''Aullidos'' (to Oct. 16), a hard-edged modern fairy tale.

BOBER--Senta, 91, died at 4:40pm on October 7, 2010. No one was more giving, loving and courageous than Senta. She was a tireless worker for Hadassah and for the State of Israel. Her 60 year marriage to her deceased husband Arnold was the highlight of her life demonstrated by deep affection. Her marriage was a pillar of support for her in her later years. Her many, many friends were a testament to her kindness. She was a deep intellectual thinker, a devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She was particularly proud of attending Fordham University when she was 60 years old and earning her bachelors degree, something she wanted all her life but was interrupted by her having to flee Nazi Germany. She is survived by her son Frank, her brother Henry, grandchildren Suzanne, Sarah, Jenia, Bronwen, David and Gabrielle and great-grandchildren Teddy, Sam and Laila. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City at 11:15am Sunday, October 10, 2010.

WEINBERG--Sidney. The family of Sidney J. Weinberg, Jr announce with great sorrow the death of their beloved husband, father and grandfather on October 4, 2010 of prostate cancer, in Marion MA. A longtime partner of Goldman Sachs and a thoughtful and dedicated philanthropist, he will be missed by all who knew him. The family will receive friends and associates at the Knickerbocker Club, 807 5th Avenue at 62nd St., from 4-8pm on Wednesday, October 13, 2010. In lieu of flowers or any gifts, the family asks that contributions be sent to Columbia University Medical Center for the benefit of the Cerebral Palsy Center, 100 Haven Ave, Suite 29D, New York, NY 10032

SPENCER--H. Allen. Marketing and communications executive from Rochester, NY, died on October 8th following a long battle with cancer. Born February 21, 1938 in San Antonio, Texas, to Brig. Gen. Norman C. Spencer and Elizabeth Rudd. Attended The Brooks School in North Andover, Massachusetts, earned a BA and MA from Williams College in 1961 and 1967 respectively, and a Ph.D. in English from the University of Rochester in 1976. Devoted husband, brother, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife of 47 years, Suzanne Moorhead, his siblings Sandra, Sally and John, his sons Upshur and Parke, and his grandchildren Jack, Athena and Teddy. He was a man of letters, known for his honesty, intellectual curiosity and passion for hidden little streams filled with Brook trout. He will be sorely missed.

RUBIN--Cynthia, age 60, died on October 7, 2010 of metastatic melanoma. Cherished twin sister of Corinne, beloved sister of Norma, and the late Janice; dear sister-in-law of Michael, Stanley, Ian, and the late Howard; much adored aunt of Elena and Charlie, Cheryl and Matt, Nicki and Joey, Doug and Kim, Joy, Mindy, Barry and Jackie, and Stewart; doting great-aunt of Jacob, Max, Victoria, Dustin, Tyler, Logan, Alex, Amanda, Harry, Justin, and Hilary. Devoted labor and delivery nurse for 37 years: New York-Presbyterian for 23 years; North Shore-LIJ at Manhasset for the remainder of her career. Lover of Manhattan, movies, Broadway theater, the New York Times, and most of all, her family. Our lives were immeasurably enriched by her love and devotion. Life will not be the same without her. May she finally rest in peace. Private graveside service on Sunday, October 10th, at 10:30am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Shiva will be observed at the home of Corinne and Michael Bronson, Huntington Station, NY through Tuesday evening.

BIG WIN FOR GEORGIA The Bulldogs stopped a four-game losing streak, their longest in two decades, with a 41-14 victory over Tennessee, temporarily easing the pressure on Mark Richt, left. 100 WITH THE BUCKEYES Jim Tressel won his 100th game as Ohio State's coach. ''This is a place that, if they let you stay long enough, you should win 100,'' said Tressel, in his 10th season with the Buckeyes.

WHEN he played the oil tycoon J. R. Ewing Jr., in ''Dallas,'' the long-running, '80s-era nighttime soap opera, Larry Hagman didn't get mad at his adversaries. He got even. Last week, Mr. Hagman, 79, got even once again. This time it was against his broker.

LEIMAN--Saul. The Officers, Directors and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish-Fay J. Lindner Residences extend their heartfelt sympathy to David Leiman, our dedicated Board member, on the loss of his beloved father, Saul. Our sincere condolences to the entire family. Bert E. Brodsky, Chairman Howard Gershowitz, President Herbert H. Friedman, EVP

The Bowlie 2 festival in England will take over the Butlins resort in Minehead, Somerset, Dec. 10 to 12 for a three-day weekend of tasteful, tuneful music curated by the Scottish twee heroes Belle and Sebastian (who also headline). The festival is organized by All Tomorrow's Parties, which is also responsible for the now-annual confab at Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello, N.Y. The packed lineup, which includes Teenage Fanclub, the Southern California beach-poppers Best Coast, the Afro-indie innovators Dirty Projectors (pictured) and 30 or so other bands won't leave much time to explore Exmoor National Park, though you'll at least be able to see the hills crawling up to the sky in the distance. After three days of that, though, something a little tougher might be in order. Nearby Bristol is a city that's been at the center of several movements of forward-thinking electronic music. These days, it's dubstep, the quaking reggae and hip-hop influenced dance music. Rooted Records carries the latest releases, and the blog Don't Panic Bristol has thorough night life listings, including the regular Subloaded and Dubloaded parties. JON CARAMANICA

LEVIN--Pam Schorr. Beloved wife of the late Nathan W. Levin, died peacefully at her home in New York City on Wednesday, September 22, 2010. She was 95. Originally from Michigan, she was a resident of Mt. Kisco and New York City over the past seventy-five years. Pam was the mother of Nina Levin Jalladeau of Paris, France and Joan Kirsch of Portland, Oregon as well as the late Robert Nathan Levin and the late Marion Gottfried, the grandmother of eight children and the great-grandmother of eleven children. She is also survived by her niece, Pam Kraft, and nephew, Cleve Schorr, both of Texas. After graduating from Hunter College in New York City, Pam worked as philanthropic assistant to William Rosenwald. Subsequently, she worked for non-profit organizations dedicated to improving secondary school education, a cause she furthered all her life, notably as Vice-President of the Citizens' Committee for Children. In more recent years, her main focus was as representative at the U.N. for the International Institute of Rural Reconstruction. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club in New York City. Pam had a remarkable talent as a problem solver -- the bigger the problem the more determined she was in finding a solution. She took great pleasure in being helpful to others and was enormously successful at it. She will be missed by the many people who loved and respected her.

AMES--Frances E. (Johnson) 87, of Maplewood NJ, formerly of Glen Ridge and Montclair, NJ on October 1, 2010. Devoted mother of Elizabeth (Betsy) Ames Abramowitz, grandmother of Jack, Paige, Douglas and Carly. Stepmother of Christopher, Sacha and Victoria. Graduate of The Kimberley School, Bryn Mawr College A.B. 1944 and M.A. 1948 in International Economics. First female foreign exchange analyst in Treasurer's Dept. of Standard Oil Co. (N.J.) Listed in Who's Who in Industry and Finance and Int'l Who's Who of Women. Champion Horsewoman and golfer. Memorial Service at First Congregational Church, Montclair October 14 at 11am. Remembrances to First Congregational Church, Montclair, NJ or Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr, PA.

GOLDBERG--Hannah, education innovator and provost emerita of Wheaton College in Norton, MA, died September 24 in Yellow Springs, Ohio. Wheaton provost from 1983 to 1998 (a period of great change, including its transition to co-education), she created the Filene Center for Work and Learning, a new approach to experiential learning that evolved from her earlier work at Antioch College where she served for 26 years as professor of history and later dean of the faculty. She and her late husband, Milton Goldberg, founded the Antioch Centre for British Studies. Hannah was born on January 28, 1933, in the Bronx, the daughter of Charles and Minnie Friedman. Her parents, both immigrants, met while taking English classes at night school. She grew up in a cooperative community built by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers one of three close-knit communities in which she was to spend her life. She was a member of the first coed class at the Bronx High School of Science and graduated magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Brandeis University and earned a doctorate from the Johns Hopkins University. Her scholarly interests included 18th and 19th-century British social and intellectual history. At Johns Hopkins she met Milton Goldberg, a literature professor. They married and moved to Yellow Springs, where both served on the Antioch faculty. Hannah had a great talent for making friends and inspiring their lifelong devotion. She entertained with gusto, enjoyed parties, poker games and world travel and was equally at home in animated discussions of politics, education, cooking or professional basketball. She is survived by her daughter, Lisa, and her sister, Zelda Raider, and many friends and family. Memorial services are scheduled for Sunday, October 24, at 1pm at the Glen Helen Building, Yellow Springs, Ohio, and November 21 at 1pm at Mary Lyon Hall, Wheaton College, Norton, MA. Donations to the Dr. Hannah Goldberg Endowed Scholarship at Community Prep School (126 Somerset Street, Providence, RI 02907) or to the Yellow Springs Community Foundation (Box 55, Yellow Springs 45387).
LEHMAN--Jack H. , Jr. 2/21/1918 - 10/10/2000 Remembered with love. Barbara

President Obama will continue his attempts to engage younger voters this week, holding a rally with a musical guest, the Roots, in Philadelphia on Sunday and a town- hall-style meeting on MTV on Thursday. Younger voters were among the Democrats' strongest supporters in 2008, and they have the highest approval ratings of the president. But in the last two midterm elections, only one in four people under age 30 voted, about half the rate for recent presiden-tial elections. And, according to a poll by the Pew Research Center in September, young Democrats are currently even less engaged than they were in 2006.

HOROWITZ--Dorothy. The Astoria Center of Israel, an historic Synagogue in Astoria, NY, mourns our long-time member and benefactor, Dorothy Dall Horowitz. A skilled musician and patron of the arts, she gave time and resources to our Center. She will be sorely missed.

A few weeks ago, I dropped my younger daughter, Emma, at college to start her freshman year. We hugged long and deeply. ''It's really happening? Now?'' We were more surprised than sad. I got in my rental car, headed for the airport and flew five and a half hours back to New York. Emma will spend the next four years at the University of California at Berkeley, 2,500 miles from home.

Ron Darling won 136 major league games, including 99 for the Mets. He also started seven postseason games, including four in the Mets' 1986 championship season. Last year he wrote ''Complete Game,'' an inside look at pitching in the major leagues. Darling, 50, is an analyst for the Mets during the regular season, and he will be part of TBS's postseason coverage team with Ernie Johnson and John Smoltz for the American League division series between the Yankees and the Twins. He will also cover the A.L. Championship Series.Q.We seem to have really moved past the steroids era. Does it seem that even John McGraw would feel at home if the N.L.C.S. pits the Phillies, with Roy Halladay, Roy Oswalt and Cole Hamels, against the Giants, with Tim Lincecum, Matt Cain and Jonathan Sanchez?A.He certainly would. Never in the past few years have we seen two teams match up like those two with marquee starting pitching.Q.Does the great finish by San Francisco - who were written off in August then roared back in September - give them momentum the way it did with Colorado in 2007? Or does talent win out in the end? A.Talent is always important but if you're in the playoffs you certainly have talent. The emotional impact does count. San Francisco has got some magic in their bag right now. You could see it in Brian Wilson and Buster Posey's reactions; you could see it in the fans. The only way you can pull these things off is with contributions from all 25 guys, and these players believe in each other.Q.What team do you think will win it all?A.Philadelphia has the best team right now. They also have the advantage with the schedule the way the Yankees did last year. They call Halladay, Hamels and Oswalt H2O in Philadelphia and right now they have it lined up so H2O could start 17 of 19 postseason games. And Joe Blanton would start the other two, and he showed in 2008 that he could pitch under pressure.Q.What's your prediction for the American League?A.There's an interesting mix there. Both New York and Tampa are vulnerable. So this is the year for Minnesota or Texas to break through. Tampa and New York have known they were going to be in the postseason almost the entire time. But they are certainly not going into the playoffs as strongly as the Yankees did last year or Tampa did the year before. The Yankees' issue is starting pitching, and Tampa Bay's Achilles' heel is their starting pitching behind David Price. But the difference is that the Yankees can generate some kind of offense. Tampa Bay is a great athletic team - if you put them in a computer it would spit out a championship. But their offense is very sporadic.Q.You pitched on three days' rest in the 1986 World Series. How do you feel about teams starting their aces on three days' rest in the postseason?A.I think they should. C.C. Sabathia has already proven he certainly can do it. It's more a mental thing than a physical thing. And you feel more rejuvenated and more alive in October. I don't know if it's the cool weather or the adrenaline but I felt like I had more on my fastball then I did the whole month of September.Q.As a pitcher, did you prepare differently for postseason games than for regular-season ones?A.Physically you don't do anything differently - you follow your routine in getting to the ballpark, loosening, stretching. But what you want to do is get as quiet as you can - there are all these ticket requests for family and friends, and people coming in who want to meet you for brunch, and you don't want to do it but you don't want to be antisocial, but you have to find as much quiet time as possible. The energy needed to pitch in these games is so intense.Q.Is there any special preparation you need to make for the postseason as a broadcaster after announcing so many less-than-meaningful games for the Mets at the end of this season?A.I've been prepping since the All-Star break, following the teams that were in contention. If I saw Tim Lincecum threw seven scoreless innings I'd want to know more, to know how did he throw. So I might call [Giants announcer] Jon Miller or a reporter out there. But I've announced two Game 163 tie breakers the last two years, one in Chicago and one in Minnesota, and it's the closest an old guy like me can get to having goose bumps. When I announce games like that and postseason games I think, Boy, I wish I could still play. That looks like fun. And that translates into whatever enthusiasm I need for the job.Q.Commissioner Bud Selig recently said he'd like to consider adding another round of playoffs. What do you think of that?A.I don't like it. If you look at this season, you had a horrible race in the American League, where both New York and Tampa knew they were going to make the playoffs. And you had a great race in the National League with San Francisco, San Diego and Atlanta. With the new rules, you'd have two horrible races. This is the first generation with kids where everybody always gets a trophy. I don't think major league baseball needs to give everyone a trophy. Baseball is 162 games long. If you can't figure it out in that time, then maybe it's not going to happen. It's all right to not be in the playoffs. Maybe you don't belong in the playoffs. When you look at teams in the N.H.L. and N.B.A. that make it, many of them don't belong.Q.What happened to the Mets this year?A.In June they were 11 games up [over .500] and they were so good to watch. The fans were really enjoying the team. And then it went away. I don't quite know why. So this year seemed to some like an utter disaster. But in spring training, Gary Cohen, Keith Hernandez and I felt they were a .500 team. If you don't put them under the microscope where they play in this town and try to stay relevant compared to the Yankees, there were some successes.

Karl Lagerfeld, the designer for Chanel, is the Carlos de Beistegui of our era. De Beistegui gave what is considered the party of the last century, the 1951 masked ball in Venice. For his sensational show in Paris last week, Mr. Lagerfeld trellised the 250,000-square-foot Grand Palais and filled it with a black-and-white replica of the gardens in the 1961 film ''Last Year at Marienbad,'' three 20-foot-high fountains, a 90-piece orchestra and 3,000 guests, many in his designs. He showed pretty and wearable clothes most women would kill to own. The airy dresses reflected the spirit of those Chanel herself created for the film. Mr. Lagerfeld took his bow with his former muse, Ines de la Fressange.

As capitals of world cinema, Paris and Rome can make movies feel a little redundant, since you can wander through the streets as if you were being shot by Godard or Fellini. But both cities offer specific, seasonal movie-related pleasures of their own. The Cinémathèque Française in Paris -- always a crucial stop on any cinephile's itinerary -- is presenting a large-scale exhibition (including more than 50 films) called ''Blonde/Brune,'' which will celebrate the tresses of actresses (like Brigitte Bardot, pictured) -- redheads included -- ''long or short, veiled or sensual'' (Oct. 6 to Jan. 16). Rome, meanwhile, will unveil the seventh edition of its international film festival, an event that, while not as venerable or controversial as the one in Venice, pays homage to the glories of Italian and global cinema, old and new (Oct. 28 to Nov. 5). But the cutting-edge festival is to be found in Thessaloniki, Greece, whose 51st festival runs from Dec. 3 to 12. Besides its main competition slate, the festival has programs devoted to new films from Greece and the Balkans, both sites of cinematic resurgence in recent years. A. O. SCOTT
Art Ken Johnson

And to think that Betsy Wetsy shares the same phylum as Kaori the Nurse. Both are dolls, of course, but Kaori is a limited-edition designer toy meant for grown-ups who can afford four figures for a ''cuddly'' five-inch work of art. The scope of these plastic critters, which range from the abstract to the downright lewd (see Cathy Cowgirl, the heifer with big teats), is wonderfully surveyed in ''I Am Plastic, Too'' (Abrams, $45), by Paul Budnitz, the designer and collector behind the art-toy company Kidrobot. What began in 1996 with some handmade toys by two Chinese artists in Hong Kong has now spread west with collectors lining up for hours to buy the latest releases. Globalism strikes again! This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

WERNER--William J.,born January 26, 1933, the only child of Irving and Gussie Werner and husband of the late Maribeth Werner, passed away on October 5, 2010. Bill was a retired tax attorney with a lust for life and an awe inspiring personality. He is survived by his children: Debi Neustadter and her husband Steven, Glenn Werner and his wife Cookie, Cori Neustein and her husband Scott, and Rick Werner and his wife Sabine. He is also survived by his grandchildren: Rori Fox and her husband Jonathan, Joelle Neustadter, Charlotte and Henry Werner, and Erin and Maribeth Neustein. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memorial of Bill may be made to the American Heart Association.

(13, 49) WALLANDER, SERIES II: THE MAN WHO SMILEDKenneth Branagh, left, continues his role as Inspector Kurt Wallander, Henning Mankell's scruffy Swedish sleuth, in this second of three new ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' productions. This episode finds Wallander reeling from having shot a man during his last case and on the verge of resigning from the force. But then his old friend Sten Torstensson (David Sibley) pleads with him to investigate the death of his father, who has just died in a suspicious car crash. Wallander refuses -- until Sten is found hanged. All signs point to murder after both father and son are revealed to have had the same unusual injury. Soon Wallander is back on the job and deep into a conspiracy involving postcards with death threats, a controversial philanthropist working in Africa and a former cop turned chief informant with some demons of his own. 10 A.M. Here are the opening statements made before the Supreme Court on Wednesday in the case of Albert Snyder v. Fred W. Phelps: ''We are talking about a funeral. If context is ever going to matter, it has to matter in the context of a funeral. Mr. Snyder simply wanted to bury his son in a private, dignified manner. When the respondent's behavior made that impossible, Mr. Snyder was entitled to turn to the tort law of the State of Maryland.''

The pre-release of four styles from the Mulberry for Target line sold out within minutes on GiltGroupe.com in August, proving the public's desire for the English luxury house's leather goods. Now, the stellar collaboration is having its official introduction, in Target stores and on target.com, today. Priced from $14.99 for the mobile-phone-friendly Mini Messenger to $49.99 for large satchels and totes, the collection features 18 pieces available in leather and denim, including a winning pink leopard print. Says Emma Hill, Mulberry's creative director, ''Leopards are king this season.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

We're all used to hearing that everything we once thought was good for us is not. But even within that framework, the latest science about antioxidants, free radicals and exercise is telling. As many of us have heard, free radicals are molecules created by the breakdown of oxygen during metabolism. Each of us constantly creates free radicals simply by living and breathing. But these molecules are highly reactive and capricious, sometimes attacking other cells and damaging tissue. Wilding free radicals have been linked with a number of diseases and with aging. Exercise, because it requires increased oxygen consumption, also increases the production of free radicals. So, many experts began urging the fitness-minded to pop large doses of antioxidant vitamin supplements, like vitamins C and E, to counteract the presumed damaging effects of the free radicals. Food alone would not supply sufficient levels of the necessary antioxidants, it was thought. The exercising body needed help from vitamins. But then a few years ago, researchers from the University of Valencia in Spain and the University of Wisconsin in Madison set out to study what would happen if you tried to prevent exercising muscles from creating free radicals. They had laboratory rats run on small treadmills until they were exhausted. Some of the rats had been injected with a powerful, pharmaceutical-grade antioxidant that works in the body to halt the production of most free radicals. After the rats ran, the researchers measured the levels of a number of substances in their leg muscles. Not surprisingly, the injected rats showed almost no free-radical activity. They were virtually immune to what scientists had considered a kind of bodily damage.

SIEGAL--Arthur died peacefully Friday morning, October 8th surrounded by his four loving children, Linda, Jane, Andrew, Julie and son-in-law Mark Florin and dear friend Hal. He is the beloved grandfather to Wyatt, Skylar, Daniella and Sam. Family, friends and associates will remember Arthur for his creative funny mind, kindness and love of life and people. Philippa Foot, a philosopher who argued that moral judgments have a rational basis, and who introduced the renowned ethical thought experiment known as the Trolley Problem, died at her home in Oxford, England, on Oct. 3, her 90th birthday. Her death was announced on the Web site of Somerville College, Oxford, where she earned her academic degrees and taught for many years.

Paul Hindemith's magisterial opera ''Mathis der Maler'' suggests a parallel between the story of the Renaissance painter Matthias Grünewald's struggle for artistic freedom and Hindemith's own dilemma of accommodation and protest during the early years of the Nazi era. An enticing production at the Paris National Opera, opening Nov. 16, presents the compelling (and aptly named) baritone Matthias Goerne in the title role. Christoph Eschenbach conducts. The director Guy Cassiers's new staging of Wagner's ''Ring,'' a co-production of La Scala in Milan and the Staatsoper unter den Linden in Berlin, continues to be unveiled this season. ''Die Walküre,''with René Pape as Wotan and Daniel Barenboim conducting, opens in La Scala on Dec. 7.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

In a bid to compete beyond the microcar segment it helped create, Smart USA announced on Wednesday that it had reached a memorandum of understanding with the Nissan Motor Company to develop a 4-door hatchback for Smart's United States model line. The as-yet-unnamed vehicle is scheduled to go on sale late next year. Smart USA, a subsidiary of the Penske Automotive Group, offers just two body styles in the United States, the Fortwo 2-seat coupe and convertible. The brand's Daimler A.G.-owned European arm previously produced a 4-door hatch for the European market, the Forfour, in conjunction with Mitsubishi.
