An obituary on Sunday about the philosopher Philippa Foot misstated the given name of her mother. It was Esther, not Edith.

The manner in which the 19th-century artist William Bouguereau depicted women - with a combination of ''gentleness, serenity and strength'' - as Demi Moore put it, is what drew the actress to his work. So in 1995, when ''Frere et Soeur,'' an 1887 canvas of a young girl carrying her baby brother, came up for sale at a Christie's auction in New York, she bought it for $178,500. It wasn't all she purchased at that sale. Ms. Moore also snapped up a painting by the Belgian artist Alfred Stevens, from 1883, called ''Mere et Ses Enfants,'' for $200,500. Now Ms. Moore is selling both paintings at a Sotheby's sale of 19th-century European art in New York on Nov. 4. If things go well Ms. Moore stands to make a hefty profit on the Bouguereau as it is expected to fetch $1 million to $1.5 million, but not on the Stevens, which is estimated to bring $150,000 to $200,000.

How did ''The Simpsons'' manage to track down Banksy, the pseudonymous British artist, and get him to create the powerful opening-credit sequence from Sunday's episode, which seems to reveal the torturous sweatshop responsible for the show's creation? And how, after all that mockery, have the producers behind that Fox animated series been able to retain their jobs? Al Jean, an executive producer and the longtime show runner of ''The Simpsons,'' pulled back another layer of the curtain and explained the stunt to ArtsBeat on Monday afternoon.Q.How did you find Banksy to do this, and now that it's done, how much trouble are you in?A.Well, I haven't been fired yet, so that's a good sign. I saw the film Banksy directed, ''Exit Through the Gift Shop,'' and I thought, oh, we should see if he would do a main title for the show, a couch gag. So I asked Bonnie Pietila, our casting director, if she could locate him, because she had previously located people like Thomas Pynchon. And she did it through the producers of that film. We didn't have any agenda. We said, ''We'd like to see if you would do a couch gag.'' So he sent back boards for pretty much what you saw. Q.Were you concerned that what he sent you could get the show into hot water?A.I'd be lying if I said I didn't think about it for a little bit. Certainly, Fox has been very gracious about us biting the hand that feeds us, but I showed it to Matt Groening, and he said, no, we should go for it and try to do it pretty much as close as we can to his original intention. So we did. Like we always do, every show is submitted to broadcast standards, and they had a couple of [changes] which I agreed with, for taste. But 95 percent of it is just the way he wanted.Q.Can you say what got cut out?A.I'll just say, it was even a little sadder. But I would have to say almost all of it stayed in. We were thrilled. It was funny, I watched ''Mad Men'' last night and I wondered if this was my Don Draper letter to The New York Times. I knew just how he felt. But it was great to have a secret.Q.One of the things Banksy is known for is disguising his identity. How can you be sure that you were dealing with the real him?A.The original boards that we got from him were in his style and were certainly by an extremely proficient artist. We were dealing with the person that represented him making the movie. I haven't met him, I don't even know what he looks like, except what the Internet suggests. And he's taken credit for it now so I'm pretty sure it's him. We went through the people that made the movie so I assume they would know how to get to the real him.Q.Even compared to how ''The Simpsons'' has mocked Fox in the past, this seemed to push things to a different level. Are you sure there's no one higher up than you on the corporate ladder who's displeased with this?A.I think that we should always be able to say the holes in our DVDs are poked by unhappy unicorns.Q.Has Banksy's criticism made you reconsider any of the ways you do things at ''The Simpsons'' in terms of producing the show or its merchandise?A.I have to say, it's very fanciful, far-fetched. None of the things he depicts are true. That statement should be self-evident, but I will emphatically state it.Q.A lot of the show's animation is produced in South Korea, but not under those conditions.A.No, absolutely not.Q.And even that closing shot of the 20th Century Fox logo surrounded in barbed wire?A.Approved by them. Obviously, the animation to do this was pricey. I couldn't have just snuck it by Fox. I'll just say it's a place where edgy comedy can really thrive, as long as it's funny, which I think this was. None of it's personal. This is what made ''The Simpsons'' what it is. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Borrowing a marketing ploy from 20th Century Fox and ''Avatar,'' the Walt Disney Company said it would preview more than 20 minutes of its forthcoming ''Tron: Legacy'' free at Imax theaters around the world. Fox and Imax created this model by showing about 15 minutes of ''Avatar'' a few months before that movie's release. The ''Tron'' promotional screenings will take place Oct. 28 as stand-alone events. The language that's the backbone of the Web is changing, and its latest version, HTML 5, is already being used to create new ways of experiencing online content. But HTML 5 is also raising privacy issues. On this week's Tech Talk podcast for The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a media reporter for The Times who has examined the implications of this new technology. Ms. Vega says that while HTML 5 offers benefits, like being able to use Web apps like e-mail when you're offline, it can also collect personal data that it stores on computer hard drives, including Web-browsing histories, blog text, photos and messages. And deleting HTML 5's so-called local storage can be tricky.

Long known for its precision watches, delicious chocolates and soaring mountains, Switzerland also produces an array of white and red wines, although few are exported to the United States. One of the main wine regions is Lavaux, marked by terraced vineyards that hug the slopes overlooking Lake Geneva. (The vineyards, which date to the 11th century, are a designated Unesco World Heritage site.) So it should come as no surprise that a tasting room, multimedia center and shop called Vinorama, which opened in mid-May in the town of Rivaz, is now giving visitors access to the flavors of the area's grapes.

It may be 11 in the morning on a Saturday in Berlin's rough-around-the edges district of Kreuzberg, but Jan-Henrik Scheper-Stuke is decked out in an eye-catching yellow bow tie. A matching silk pocket square tucked into his natty blazer shimmers as he flips on the light switch in the Edsor Kronen factory's showroom. Spinning on his heels, Scheper-Stuke, who is 28, does a little Fred Astaire-style backward kick, then turns back around, brandishing a swath of purple and gold Italian silk. Then he jumps, with practiced agility, right up onto the sample table. "See?" he says, holding a rich, lime-green paisley up to one of the sworls in an antique wool fabric hanging behind glass on the wall. "For this print, this was the inspiration."

Design isn't only about the latest cutting-edge chair or yet another must-have coffee maker. As demonstrated by the winners of two different design awards, it can sometimes make a fundamental difference in the quality of people's lives - and can even make the difference between life and death. It's billed as an horological machine, not a watch. In any case, the Thunderbolt, a tribute to aeronautics, is the newest creation in a series of highly complicated timepieces from the five-year-old Geneva-based company MB&F, founded by Maximillian Büsser, a veteran of the Swiss haute watch world. The Thunderbolt's twin pods, which house a power reserve and hour/minute indicators, was inspired by the 1970s-era A-10 aircraft's two cylindrical jet reactors. More than 200 hours are required to carve, finish and polish the block of titanium and solid sapphire crystal into these sleek "engines." With dials perpendicular to the wearer's wrist, it makes for the perfect pilot's watch - or, for those ground-bound, an on-time driver.

About this time every year, with the fall marathon season at its zenith, racers in training begin to hear the refrain, ''You are going to ruin your knees.'' The idea that distance running inexorably leads to arthritis is deeply entrenched, despite the publication of a number of recent studies (detailed in a Phys Ed column last year) that have found otherwise. In one representative experiment, the knees of experienced marathoners, with multiple races behind them, were scanned with magnetic resonance imaging technology, and then scanned again 10 years later. The runners' knees were and remained robust throughout that time, with few significant cartilage abnormalities. The only truly unhealthy knee in the study belonged to a former marathoner, who had quit the sport. In the years since he stopped running, his joint had deteriorated badly.

WARREN--William Bradford. The Council and membership of The Grolier Club are greatly saddened at the loss of William Bradford Warren. A member of the Grolier since 1988, Mr. Warren sat on the Club's Council from 1991-2000, and served as President of the Club from 1994-1998. His immense knowledge of books and book people, coupled with an expansive and forward-looking interpretation of the Club's mission to foster appreciation of the book and graphic arts, had a positive influence on the Grolier and its activities that is felt to this day, in a larger and more diverse membership, a much-expanded program of activities, and a higher public profile. His guidance and counsel, along with his boundless enthusiasm for everything to do with books and book collecting, will be keenly missed by his many Grolier Club colleagues.

Exhaustion and stress were behind the stomach pains that caused Riccardo Muti to cancel two weeks of concerts at the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the orchestra said on Tuesday. Mr. Muti, who is in his first season as the orchestra's music director, flew to Italy on Oct. 4 to consult with his doctors in Milan and undergo tests. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

HORECKER--Bernard, Ph.D. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. Bernard Horecker, former Dean of the Weill Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences, former Associate Dean for Research and Sponsored Programs, and Professor Emeritus of Biochemistry at Weill Cornell Medical College. An advocate and exemplar of excellence in research and education, Dr. Horecker was instrumental in establishing the tri-institutional M.D.-Ph.D. Program at Weill Cornell, the Sloan-Kettering Institute and Rockefeller University. A distinguished biochemist, microbiologist and molecular biologist, he contributed landmark research that shed light on enzymatic mechanisms involved in metabolizing carbohydrates. Dr. Horecker was a member of the National Academy of Sciences and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and he was revered and beloved for his keen intelligence and personal warmth. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Frances; daughters Doris Colgate, Marilyn Diamond-Schnell and Linda Lally; and the entire Horecker family. Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College David P. Hajjar, Ph.D. Dean Weill Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences Frederick R. Maxfield, Ph.D. Chair Department of Biochemistry Weill Cornell Medical College

An article on Saturday about the performance artist Bill Talen, known as Reverend Billy, misstated the reason that his wife and performance partner, Savitri D, does not use her surname publicly. She says it is because she has mixed feelings about belonging to her father, and also does not want to take her husband's surname. It is not to protect her daughter's privacy.

Eleven employees of Egypt's cultural ministry were sentenced to three years in prison for negligence that led to the theft of a valuable van Gogh painting from a Giza museum in August, Reuters reported. Among those employees whose sentences were announced Tuesday was Mohsen Shaalan, a deputy culture minister who heads the fine arts division of the ministry. The painting, known as ''Poppy Flowers'' or ''Vase and Flowers'' and valued at more than $50 million, was cut from its frame on Aug. 21 at the Mohamed Mahmoud Khalil Museum, where it hung in a room with only some working cameras and no working alarms. The theft led to a review of security at the museum, and some Egyptian officials have said the robbery was probably an inside job, though no suspects have yet been arrested or charged.
SUTHERLAND--Joan. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Joan Sutherland, and send condolences to her family.

SCHWARZ--Richard, passed away at home very peacefully on October 11, 2010, sixteen days short of his 85th birthday. Beloved husband of Ronnie, unbelievably wonderful stepfather to Cory and Scott, father-in-law to Leslie and Debbie, dearest GaGa to Bailey and wonderful grandfather to Samantha, Kiley and Dayne, father of Debbie, Pam and Jeff, grandfather to their eight children and brother to Earl (Marilyn). Graduate of Stuyvesant High School and CCNY, ran his engineering company (Steinharter -Schwarz) for many years and had a wonderful reputation throughout the industry; and worked with the Corp of Engineers, MTA and VA Hospital. Always ready for a martini! Pass the cashews and pretzels! Service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, Thursday, October 14th at 11:15am. Please make donations to Visiting Nurse Hospice, New York Hospital and Sloan Kettering.

This is not what a recovery is supposed to look like. In Atlanta, the Bank of America tower, the tallest in the Southeast, is nearly a fifth vacant, and bank officials just wrestled a rent cut from the developer. In Cherry Hill, N.J., 10 percent of the houses on the market are so-called short sales, in which sellers ask for less than they owe lenders. And in Arizona, in sun-blasted desert subdivisions, owners speak of hours cut, jobs lost and meals at soup kitchens.

SHARE AND SHARE ALIKE Q. I have remarried and live in a family home with my new husband's twin 18-year-old daughters. (They live here part time.) He and I went out to dinner and I did not finish my meal, so I asked to take the items home. I put the leftovers in the refrigerator to enjoy the next day. The next morning one of the girls decided to treat herself to my leftovers without asking. I thought this was rude and disrespectful, to munch on a meal that was not her own. But my husband found nothing wrong with this and thought that leftovers in the fridge were an open invitation to anyone to enjoy. Am I being petty or stingy? Are there any etiquette rules on this? How can I handle this?

DAY--Jocelyne Gilles was born in Haiti in 1994. She was adopted and welcomed into the Day family one week before her eleventh birthday. Within five years of living in the United States, Jocelyne learned English and became a star student and award winning track star. Among so many things, Josie (as she was lovingly nicknamed) played the violin, enjoyed cooking and gardening and raised thousands to support the Greenwich teen chapter of Save the Children's Haiti Earthquake Relief Fund. Despite her challenging childhood in Haiti, Josie managed to love, smile and become an intricate, meaningful part of this community and the Day family. Josie was a good-natured and well-loved daughter, sister, granddaughter, niece and aunt. Josie will be desperately missed by all who loved her. In lieu of flowers, the Day family request that donations be made to Save the Children of Westport Connecticut in honor of Josie Day (1-800-728-3843). Jocelyne is survived by her parents, Emily and Randy Day and her siblings, Greg, Jessica, James and Thomas Day. Calling hours will be on Wednesday, October 13th from 4pm to 8pm at The First Church of Round Hill, 464 Round Hill Road at John Street, Greenwich. The church service will be on Thursday, October 14th at 4pm at The Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich.

An article last Wednesday about Representative Alan Grayson's bid for re-election in Florida misstated the size of Medicare cuts that an opposition group's advertisement said Mr. Grayson had voted for as part of the health care overhaul. Ads by the 60-Plus Association , which bills itself as a conservative alternative to AARP, say he voted for $500 billion in cuts, not $500 million. (The $500 billion figure has been criticized because that amount will not be cut from current spending, but rather will come from reductions projected through 2019.)

Is this a Macbeth which I see before me? No dagger in sight, the spare, streamlined ''Radio Macbeth'' begins with a golden spotlight on a bald man in suspenders who sounds like the famous murderer but isn't him, exactly. Stephen Duff Webber plays an actor performing Macbeth in a radio drama from the 1930s. Often standing in front of old-fashioned microphones, he speaks the famous lines (the script sticks to Shakespeare's words) with great clarity. The cast does its own sound effects and makes silent jokes between lines.

It may not hold as much sway in J. R. R. Tolkien's universe as, say, the the Council of Elrond or the Fellowship of the Ring, but a group of actors in New Zealand is calling on an actors' guild there to drop its opposition to a filmed adaptation of ''The Hobbit'' that Peter Jackson is preparing. The Hollywood Reporter said a group of about 90 actors met in Wellington over the weekend amid a standoff between Mr. Jackson, the producer and potential director of a two-film ''Hobbit'' series, and actors' guilds based in New Zealand and Australia, which say ''The Hobbit'' is a non-union project and are seeking a boycott of the films.

NEW ORLEANS -- Standing on the sidewalk a couple of Sundays ago, outside one of the black churches he was visiting in his district, Anh Cao, the unassuming Vietnamese-American former seminarian who is running for re-election to Congress as a Republican here, considered the day's big news. In just a few hours, in the middle of the Saints game, President Obama would be on television urging the voters of the Second Congressional District to support Mr. Cao's opponent, a 38-year-old state representative named Cedric Richmond.

The major female role in Larry Kramer's ''Normal Heart'' has been filled for the starry Broadway reading that Joel Grey is directing Monday evening at the Walter Kerr Theater. Glenn Close, who has three Tony Awards (''Sunset Boulevard'') and three Emmys (''Damages'') to her name, will play Dr. Emma Brookner, the physician in a wheelchair who anticipates the AIDS epidemic and encourages the central character, Ned Weeks (to be played by Joe Mantello), to warn others of the disease. Asked why she wanted to do the reading, Ms. Close said: ''I remember what it was like. I lost many friends to AIDS. Friends whose names are still in my phone book. I took this on in their memory and to be a part of something that will help keep the issues addressed in this play alive.''

An obituary on Saturday about the gospel singer Albertina Walker misstated a word in the title of a book about gospel music by Anthony Heilbut. It is ''The Gospel Sound: Good News and Bad Times'' (not ''Hard Times'') . The obituary also misstated the name of a song that was a hit for Ms. Walker and her group, the Caravans. It is ''I Won't Be Back (Sweeping Through the City).'' They did not have separate songs called ''I Won't Be Back'' and ''Sweeping Through the City.'' The obituary also referred incorrectly at one point to the singer Inez Andrews as Ms. Anderson.

Adam Lambert said on Tuesday that he would comply with the restrictions placed on a concert he is to perform Thursday in Malaysia, adding that his ''main goal is to keep people entertained - not to make them uncomfortable,'' The Associated Press reported. Mr. Lambert, an ''American Idol'' finalist who is openly gay, drew protests from that country's Pan Malaysian Islamic Party over his plans to play a concert at the Putra Indoor Stadium in Bukit Jalil, near Kuala Lumpur. Representatives for the party have said they believe Mr. Lambert's performances promote ''gay culture'' and contain ''lewd dancing and a gay performance that includes kissing male dancers'' which is ''not good for people in our country.''

President Obama will be on the campaign trail much of the next three weeks, focusing entirely on states that he won two years ago as he tries to help Democrats counter Republican momentum heading into crucial midterm elections. A schedule for the next two weeks released by the White House on Tuesday shows that he will concentrate on the Northeast corridor, West Coast and a couple of Midwest battleground states that he won in 2008, while generally avoiding the South and Mountain regions. All 13 states now on his October campaign schedule voted for Mr. Obama; he is not going to any that went for Senator John McCain, his Republican opponent.

In the Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, Joe Nocera wrote about a lawsuit by Oracle against a division of SAP, claiming theft of intellectual property. Mr. Nocera learned after the column was published that Oracle was represented by the law firm of Boies, Schiller & Flexner, where his fiancée works as director of communications. To avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest, Mr. Nocera would not have written about the case if he had known of the law firm's involvement.

The NBC drama ''Outlaw'' became the third show of the new television season to be canceled. The network announced Monday that the program would be moved from Friday to Saturday night for the remaining four episodes that have been produced. The legal drama, starring Jimmy Smits, had tailed off sharply in the ratings since moving to its regular spot at 10 on Fridays. The cancellation had been expected.

All this talk of newfangled outside groups receiving money from anonymous donors has overshadowed some of the more traditional players. But one of them, the National Rifle Association, is coming in big. All told, the N.R.A. says it plans to spend between $15 million and $20 million this election cycle. As of the end of this week it will have spent $6.7 million so far including mail. So, doing the math, that leaves the last two weeks before Election Day to make up the lion's share of its action, though group officials cautioned their final spending decisions could change with the political environment.

TISHMAN--Robert V. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of one of New York's most respected real estate developers and philanthropists, Robert V. Tishman, at the age of 94. Bob was a member of REBNY for 52 years, serving as Governor from 1966-1979 and as Chairman from 1973-1975. Before co-founding Tishman Speyer in 1978, Bob served as President and CEO of Tishman Realty & Construction Co., which was founded by his grandfather, Julius Tishman in 1898. Bob was a leading advocate in our industry to adopt greater transparency for its practices and transactions and was among the first to incorporate high-speed elevators in Manhattan office buildings. One of the city's first cogeneration power facilities was developed by Bob at 11 West 42nd Street. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Bob's daughters Lynne Handler and Nancy Gonchar, his grandson, REBNY Governor and Executive Committee member Robert Speyer, his colleagues at Tishman Speyer, and the entire Tishman family. Mary Ann Tighe. Chairman Steven Spinola, President

WHAT'S EATING YOU Billed as ''true stories of food, fear and obsession,'' this new six-part series examines a variety of eating disorders and looks at some of the men and women who battle distorted body images with life-threatening food rituals, including Gabby, above. In this premiere episode Adrienne, a successful dancer, tries to overcome anorexia after her career is jeopardized by her startlingly thin appearance. Elsewhere, Danni works to suppress the bulimic tendencies that have already cost her family more than $100,000 in treatment and that threaten to cost Danni her life. The series also offers advice from psychologists, dietitians and physicians, as well as information on organizations that deal with eating disorders. 8 P.M. Chase Stuart contributes to the Pro-Football-Reference.com blog and to Footballguys.com. The San Diego Chargers boast the league's No. 1 offense at 461.8 yards per game. No other team is within 40 yards of the Chargers, and only the Cowboys and the Colts are within 75. But San Diego is hardly one-dimensional: the Chargers also have the league's No. 2-ranked defense, and at 246.2 yards per game allowed, are only 1.6 yards per game behind the league-leading Giants. The Chargers have outgained their five opponents by 1,078 yards, a path of destruction that is rare in league history.

Carl T. Gossett Jr.'s name appeared in agate type beneath photos in The New York Times for about 40 years. He covered the Nuremberg war-crime trials and the 1956 uprising in Hungary. On Jan. 9, 1970, a bitterly cold morning, he emerged from a building in Lower Manhattan after a routine assignment and spotted these creatures huddling to keep warm. They were not strays, necessarily, as the Fulton Fish Market was nearby; this group was most likely taking a break from keeping the rodent population in check. The Times was not accustomed to publishing pictures like this one, but an editor must have found the image irresistible, and ran it two columns wide with the continuation of a front-page article about the cold weather. Letters poured in, which led Gossett to remark, ''If you want to improve circulation, run cat pictures.'' Earlier photographs in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

CLAIRE--Allen B.,October 25, 1933-October 11, 2010: Born, Brooklyn. Attended Lafayette High School and NYU (B.S and M.B.A.) Captain, USAF. Executive Vice President, Gary S. Bell Associates. Survived by loving wife, Arlene; devoted daughters Jacalyn and Lauren; adoring sons in law Brad and Jonathan; cherished grandchildren Brittany, Skylar, Kimi, Griffin and Kendall; and brothers Robert and the late Franklin.

WARREN--William Bradford. 76, of New York City and Sharon, CT. Died peacefully at home in New York City of cancer Friday, October 8. Born in Boston, July 25, 1934, the younger son of Minton Machado Warren and Sarah Ripley Robbins and the step-son of James Hopkins Smith, Jr. He married Arete Bernice Swartz September 20, 1985. Father of John Coolidge Warren (Laura Appell) of Southborough, MA and Sarah Robbins Warren (Michael Walsh) of Jefferson, NH. Grandfather of Ethan and Amanda Warren. Brother of Minton Warren, step-brother of Jane Smith Moody, Dana Smith Poole and Winthrop Noel Smith of Maine. Brother-in-law of James Swartz of London and Riyadh. Survived by his aunt Celina R. Kellogg and uncle Dr. Peter G. Robbins, only Warren cousin Francisca Paine Irwin and many Robbins, Sibley, Kellogg cousins. He was Uncle Bill to many. His two previous marriages to Mary-Elizabeth Coolidge and Elizabeth Bezold ended in divorce. Mr. Warren attended Buckley School '48, Groton School '52, Harvard College '56 and Harvard Law '59. Retired as senior Trust & Estates partner from Dewey Ballantine LLP (now Dewey & LeBoeuf) in 2008, and joined the firm of Morris & McVeigh LLP as Counsel. Mr. Warren was decreed Knight of The Royal Order of Saints Maurice and Lazarus by HRH Crown Prince Vittorio Emanuele, Prince of Naples and Duke of Savoy. Mr. Warren served on many boards throughout his life. At the time of death he was a trustee of St. John's College, Annapolis and Santa Fe, Johns Hopkins University Press, John Carter Brown Library, The Hodson Trust, the Arthur B. and Alice E. Adams Foundation, Association Internationale de Bibliophilie, The New Criterion and The Hudson Review. He was Chair of the Institute for Schools of the Future (New York City), Vice-Chair of the Academy of American Poets, Chair of the Cintas Foundation, and former President of The Grolier Club. He was an Advisory Director of the Metropolitan Opera Assn., American Friends of the British Library, founding member of BLAC- NY Philharmonic, former Regent of the American College of Trust & Estate Counsel and served on the Executive Committee of the International Academy of T&E Law. He was a former Governor and Treasurer of the Knickerbocker Club, former trustee of the Hoosac School and had served on the Council of Fellows of the Morgan Library. In lieu of flowers the family requests that contributions may be made to "The Harvard College Library fund in German History established by William Bradford Warren," Widener Library, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138. A memorial service at St. Thomas' Church will take place this autumn.

Earlier this week, Carl P. Paladino, the Republican candidate for New York governor, defended comments he had made criticizing homosexuality, including some in which he said the city's gay pride parade was not a place for children -- he said the parade featured participants ''grinding at each other and doing these gyrations,'' something he called ''disgusting.'' The response to the City Room post describing his statements was fast and furious: Hundreds of comments flew in, with wide-ranging opinions from far beyond the New York area. Some agreed or disagreed with Mr. Paladino; some addressed larger issues of society and sexuality. A number of comments -- some defending Mr. Paladino, some attacking him -- contained language that is not published on the City Room blog. They were promptly deleted by the moderators.

2:27 p.m. | Updated Sharron Angle, the Republican challenging Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, raised $14 million from July 1 to Sept. 30, a staggering figure that should give her more than enough money for the final weeks of this tight race. The fund-raising figure is the latest evidence of the ability of the Tea Party movement to generate huge waves of cash for a favorite candidate. The fund-raising haul reflects how the effort to remove Mr. Reid, the Senate majority leader, has energized the Tea Party movement, at least nationally. Ms Angle's aides did not immediately release how much of the money came from out of state.

An article on Tuesday about Dr. Abraham Verghese, a Stanford medical professor who emphasizes the importance of physical examinations, referred incorrectly to Kerala, in southern India, where his parents came from, and to the prevalence of Christianity there. Kerala is a state, not a region, and although Christianity is prominent in some parts, the state is not predominantly Christian.
A recipe last Wednesday for quince crumble misstated the amount of butter. It is 14 tablespoons, not 6. The correct recipe can be found at nytimes.com/dining.

SISENWEIN--Irving. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with sorrow the passing of our dear friend and Benefactor. Together with his beloved wife Branna, Irving devoted more than 60 years to supporting medical research. After Irv lost his sight in the year following their marriage, and Branna developed macular degeneration, this extraordinary couple forged a philanthropic partnership to help eradicate blindness and other diseases of the eye. In 2001, they established the Branna and Irving Sisenwein Chair in Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences at Einstein through a gift that represented, at that time, the largest contribution for a named chair in the history of the College of Medicine. In recognition of their exemplary commitment to the medical school and longstanding advocacy of medical research, Yeshiva University honored both Irv and Branna with the degree of Doctor of Humane Letters in 2007. We extend heartfelt condolences to Branna and the family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Albert Einstein College of Medicine Ruth L. Gottesman Chairperson, Board of Overseers

CRAWFORD--David B.,Jr., MD. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center community acknowledges with sadness the passing of our longtime friend and devoted former colleague, David B. Crawford, Jr, MD, from the Department of Obstetrics & Gynecology, who served the patients of St. Luke's-Roosevelt for more than 50 years. He also will be remembered with great fondness for his tireless efforts to help raise funds for the renovation of the Labor & Delivery Unit at Roosevelt Hospital. To his wife Connie, his children Cathy, Sandra, Bradley, Darrel, Brian, Clayton and Nathalie, the entire Crawford family and all who loved him, we extend heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman, Board of Trustees Frank J. Cracolici, President Oscar Garfein, MD, President, Medical Board Oded Langer, MD, Chairman, Dept. of OB/GYN

WARREN--William Bradford. The partners and staff of Morris & McVeigh LLP mourn the loss of their cherished friend, colleague and mentor, William Bradford Warren, who died on October 8, 2010. An esteemed lawyer and academic, we shall greatly miss his friendship, wisdom, enthusiasm, humor and comforting presence. He was a true Renaissance Man. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Arete Swartz Warren, and his children, John Coolidge Warren and Sarah Robbins Warren, and their families.

No wonder Americans are pessimistic and unhappy. The only way we are going to get in gear is to face up to the reality that we are entering a period of austerity. ALLEN L. SINAI, chief global economist at the consulting firm Decision Economics. [A17]

A picture caption on Monday with a dance review of the final Fall for Dance program at City Center, using information from a publicist, misidentified the dancer shown with Maximilian Genov of the Dresden SemperOper Ballett in William Forsythe's ''Vertiginous Thrill of Exactitude.'' She is Leslie Heylmann -- not Chantelle Kerr, another member of the company.

TISHMAN--Robert V. The Board and Staff of JASA (Jewish Association for Services for the Aged) mourn the death of Robert Tishman, founder, longstanding member of our Board of Trustees, generous supporter, and father of our dedicated trustee, Nancy Gonchar. We will miss his wisdom and guidance, and offer sincere condolences to the entire Tishman family. Aileen Gitelson, CEO David Warren, President

ROSNER--Ethel, on October 11, 2010. Adored wife of Bernard. Devoted and loving mother of Valerie and Hillary. Services: Thursday, 5pm, at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made to: Healthcarechaplaincy.com

Steel workers demonstrated in Marseille on Tuesday as protests continued against a French pension overhaul that would raise the retirement age two years,to 62. Some flights and train services were canceled, and the Eiffel Tower was closed. The government said about 1.2million people marched nationwide.French Protest Against Changes in Pension System

A recipe last Wednesday for upside-down caramel-apple muffins misstated the amount of melted butter for the batter in the baking directions. As the ingredients list stated, it is eight tablespoons, or 1/2 cup -- not 1/4 cup. The correct recipe can be found at nytimes.com/dining.

John J. Gotti had been wounded. Not by a gun, but by a crayon. His vanity did not appreciate the thick neck in portraits Marilyn Church drew of him for newscasts of his last trial. So the Dapper Don signaled across the courtroom by slicing his fingers across his neckline, a gesture that she took as, ''Don't you dare draw me like that!''
While the Phillies and the Giants prepared for the start of the N.L.C.S. this weekend, a few hardy surfers hit the waves in Canada.
A bike lesson from Dave Jordan, a New York coach who spent the summer showing Hollywood stars how to ride like messengers.
An error on some electronic voting machines already in use in Illinois identifies Rich Whitney, the Green Party candidate for governor, as Rich Whitey.
In 2010, The Times traveled to the hometown of the Republican House Minority Leader John Boehner to get a sense of how growing up near Cincinnati may have shaped him.
FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - We have a pitchman and three pitchers in today's puzzle. No wonder this tough Friday crossword is no softball. I found it the most challenging Friday in weeks.

Several private equity firms, including the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital, are preparing initial bids for Pfizer's Capsugel unit, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday. These people asked for anonymity because the talks are private and they are not authorized to discuss them.

ARLINGTON, Tex. - Six weeks after the trade that liberated him from a sinking ship in Queens, Texas Rangers outfielder Jeff Francoeur still keeps in touch with his friends on the Mets. He called the former manager Jerry Manuel on Wednesday, and he said he heard from David Wright, Mike Pelfrey and the hitting coach Howard Johnson, among others, during the Rangers' American League division series.

A few blocks east of Detroit's downtown, just across Interstate 375, sits Lafayette Park, an enclave of single- and two-story modernist townhouses set amid a forest of locust trees. Like hundreds of developments nationwide, they were the result of postwar urban renewal; unlike almost all of them, it had a trio of world-class designers behind it: Ludwig Hilbersheimer as urban planner, Alfred Caldwell as landscape designer and Mies van der Rohe as architect.
This is the fifth in a series.
Photos from the debate between Representative Loretta Sanchez and Van Tran for the 47th Congressional District in Orange County, Calif.
What is it like to live in a townhouse designed by Mies van der Rohe?

The conventional wisdom has it that the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission - the bipartisan group of wise men and women charged with uncovering what caused our recent economic meltdown and telling us what should be done to prevent a recurrence - is woefully out-of-touch and out-of-date. A Times article last month suggested that "an exodus of senior employees" from the commission and "internal disagreements" among those remaining could hamper efforts to produce a meaningful and useful report, which is due to be published in December.

GREENBURGH, N.Y. - Mike D'Antoni is highly familiar with Amar'e Stoudemire's offensive prowess and, as if to give a subtle reminder, Stoudemire scored 30 points on a thrifty 13 field goals in his first game as a Knick at Madison Square Garden.

Even the Democrats who supported President Barack Obama's health care legislation last March aren't exactly making the bill the center-piece of their re-election campaigns. Everyone, that is, except Rep. Scott Murphy of New York.

As my colleague Robert Worth reports, a two-day visit to Lebanon by Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, seems to have passed off without major incident -- or minor stone-throwing -- but the presence of Iran's best-known Holocaust-denying, 9/11-truther did have an impact on Beirut's film lovers.

House Democrats, who need every advantage they can get in the midterm elections, say they will have about $10 million more than their Republican counterparts to spend on television advertising in the final three weeks before Election Day.
New York Times reporters and editors discuss President Obama's first two years in office, the weak economic recovery and its impact on the election.

The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 6. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

President Obama was put on the defensive on issues from the economy and Washington partisanship to gay rights and race relations during a televised town hall-style forum on Thursday that captured the disillusionment taking root among younger voters who were a significant force in his election.
By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and PETER LATTMAN
"Paper is upstairs."
Images from a new exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.
Democrats have tried many ways to capture the attention of distracted voters before Election Day.

One of the ten young men accused in the kidnapping, beating and sexual assault of three men in the Bronx was released on bail Thursday, as he and his nine co-defendants appeared before a judge in Bronx Criminal Court.

There's been some excitement this week about Pennsylvania, where two internal polls commissioned by Democrats show a tight Senate race. One of the polls actually puts their candidate, Joe Sestak, ahead by 3 points; the other has him 1 point behind Pat Toomey. Further contributing to the buzz is the disclosure that Republicans are upping their ad buys in the state. On the other hand, Rasmussen Reports provides for a buzzkill of sorts, having released a poll this morning showing Mr. Toomey 10 points ahead -- the largest advantage that Rasmussen has given him all year.
Back on this side of the Pacific, but still not in a position to post.

A New York City Council public hearing on a proposed smoking ban in city parks evolved into an hours-long, occasionally raucous showdown Thursday afternoon, touching on issues such as civil liberties, public health, big government and litter.
Apps highlighted in this week's App Smart column are tailored to medical altruists who might like to help save another person's life.

The New York Times has changed its rating of Connecticut's Senate race from tossup to leaning Democratic, finding that Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has somewhat solidified his position against businesswoman Linda McMahon, the Republican candidate and former wrestling impresario.
Could Philadelphia's loss be New York's gain?

Sidney J. Weinberg Jr. retired as a general partner from Goldman Sachs in 1988, but almost every week afterward until his death, he came into the office. He would meet with staff to give advice about Goldman's culture and values, hoping to leave a little of the firm's past in the present.
Images from the art fair in London.
-Joan Collins bemoans the lack of screen sirens today to Vogue UK. Poor Joan Collins, she doesn't know that Rosie Huntington-Whitely was cast in the next Transformers film.
The viewership for Fox News and CNN more than doubled Wednesday night as the final miner was rescued in Chile.
Photographs from Lebanon, Afghanistan and Greece.

FLORHAM PARK, N.J. - On Thursday, there were positive developments concerning the left hamstring of the injured Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis. That does not mean that Revis will play Sunday at Denver, but the possibility is now higher than earlier this week.
To the clatter, pedestrian obstacle course and store closings created by the Second Avenue subway project, add one more affliction for more than 100 families living on the East Side: no gas.
DVD monitors are just so passé. Mercedes-Benz and BMW have just announced devices - cradles, so to speak - that will house Apple iPads, allow them to swivel and even charge them via a dock connector.
Environmental groups from Appalachia moved Thursday to join the federal government in fighting an industry lawsuit that would weaken oversight of mountaintop coal mining.

The Theaters at 45 Bleecker Street, one of New York's diminishing number of commercial Off Broadway spaces, has closed indefinitely due to litigation between the theater producers and their landlord, the 45 Bleecker theater manager said in an interview on Thursday. Performances have been canceled for Thursday night, including for the two new Off Broadway productions running there, "The Deep Throat Sex Scandal" and "Perfect Harmony."
A new experiment by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority allows riders on the M16 and M34 bus routes to check the real-time location of buses on the Web or a mobile device.
Robert Schwentke, the director of the action comedy "RED," discusses his use of guns and weaponry in the film.

A new study by researchers at Yale University suggests that Americans' knowledge of climate science is limited and scattershot, with some understanding of basic issues like the contribution of fossil fuels to global warming and some singular misconceptions as well.
Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

Bedbugs have made their debut at Lincoln Center. The pests were sighted in the dressing room of the David H. Koch Theater, the New York City Opera confirmed on Wednesday, and at the Metropolitan Opera. City Opera, whose fall season opens Oct. 27, shares the theater with the New York City Ballet, whose season ended on Sunday. The outbreak was reported online on Wednesday by The New York Observer, which quoted from an Oct. 8 e-mail from Mark Heiser, the theater's managing director, who said treatment was under way. "Please understand that this is an epidemic," Mr. Heiser wrote. "Any signs of bedbug activity should not be considered a sign of an untidy house." The pests were also found at the Metropolitan Opera. "Bedbugs were discovered in some isolated locations but not in any public areas," a spokesman for the Met said in a statement, adding that the areas were being treated and monitored.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. -- Got a beef against your broker? Regulators have made it easy for investors to come forward: Call one of their fraud hot lines and tell your story. The Securities and Exchange Commission may even give you cash if your tip pans out.
The buzz Thursday morning was all about reports that AOL and buyout firms might cobble together a complicated bid for Yahoo.

Last year, Tim Wendelboe, a former World Barista Champion (2004) and World Tasting Champion (2005) whose eponymous coffee shop and roaster in Oslo has become a destination for coffee pilgrims on the order of Lourdes or Fallingwater, wrote a book on coffee. It was released in English this summer as "Coffee With Tim Wendelboe." The slim volume is the most complete portrait of this moment in coffee to date.

The former Tavern on the Green will reopen to the public on Friday, reincarnated as a $2.5-million visitor center, food court and retail shop, temporarily replacing the once-glittering landmark restaurant in Central Park, which shuttered on New Year's Day.

It was sent to James Barron, who will incorporate it along with witness accounts and other reporting into his developing City Room post and story for Friday's newspaper. Last year we wrote about how France was subsidizing the ailing newspaper industry. Now it appears the French government has opened its coffers to another sector whose business model has been pummeled by the digital age: the music industry.
Talk about having to eat crow.

The Times's Gardiner Harris writes in an article posted this afternoon that the Food and Drug Administration announced that it would rescind approval for Menaflex, a patch for knee injuries, and acknowledged that had erred. The account notes that approval was granted in 2008 after the agency was pressured by four New Jersey congressmen and its own commissioner.
Is President Obama already thinking about his 2012 re-election campaign?

The mush-mouthed Atlanta rapper Gucci Mane is back with his third studio album, "The Appeal: Georgia's Most Wanted," which features guests like Bun B, Nicki Minaj and Estelle. The artist Andrew Kuo dissects it, track by track.
Two lovers are seen at sunrise on La Promenade des Anglais in Nice, France.
This is the reality of the television news business: when an unexpected event eats into the annual news-gathering budget, at some point there will have to be cutbacks elsewhere.

The decade-long effort to pass comprehensive climate legislation framed around a declining cap and trading for carbon dioxide emissions died an ignominious death. Now new proposals focused on a substantial ramp-up of investments in energy innovation are percolating -- and instantly being attacked. Keith Kloor has nicely woven together links to relevant coverage and commentary in a riff titled "The Post Partisan Power Play."

The tender offer is definitely back. According to Factset Mergermetrics, tender offers were used in 22.95 percent of friendly public deals in 2010. This compares with only 7.59 percent of such deals in 2006. The tender offer has not seen such heights since the 1980s.
Photographs of a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
National Democratic officials have decided that their attacks on undisclosed  corporate money are working, and they have decided to intensify the argument in the final days of the midterm campaign.

Thank goodness for Dashboard, Gene Marks's new blog channel here at "You're the Boss." If not for his efforts to mine the information superhighway for the rest of us, I would have missed a recent Gallup poll declaring that nearly half of small-business owners may never retire.

As part of my business school's program, my classmates and I recently went to China. On our trip home, many of us were carrying or wearing much fancier accessories than we had gone with. Think Rolex watches, Louis Vuitton bags and Gucci sunglasses -- all knockoffs, of course.
David Pogue looks at a wireless speaker for bicycle handle bars, a desk frame for an iPhone, a projector, a PrintStik, a case for an iPad and stickers for wires.

Actors' Equity Association, the union of more than 49,000 theater actors and stage managers, announced on Thursday that Mary McColl would become its new executive director in January 2011. In that role Ms. McColl, currently the executive director of the Cowles Center for Dance and the Performing Arts in Minneapolis, will oversee the collective bargaining process for more than 30 national and regional contracts and act as the union's representative with other labor groups and government officials. Before her position in Minneapolis, Ms. McColl was the director of labor relations for the Broadway League, the trade association of theater owners and producers. She succeeds Carol Waaser, who has served as acting executive director since November 2009, and who plans to retire next year after 26 years on the staff of Actors' Equity.

It's still early in this N.H.L. season but it's impossible to ignore the turnarounds and successes of last year's non-playoff teams so far. They have combined for 19 wins, while losing 12 in regulation and two after regulation, which is 40 of a possible 66 points. Meanwhile, last year's playoff teams have won 22, lost 18 in regulation and nine after regulation, getting only 53 of a possible 98 points.

The Italian designer Mauro Orietti-Carella believes in combining the old and the new. Several years back, he brought fresh life to Zagliani, a venerable but musty manufacturer of crocodile bags, by applying techniques he perfected in his former life in medical school, where he studied skin reconstruction - injecting the material with silicone and resin so that its stiffness gave way to a buttery softness. (The company is preparing to open its first stand-alone store, on Madison Avenue.)
The rumors were rife at the Japanese Grand Prix that Formula One was about to announce a deal to race in Russia.
Here's what's happening on the U.F.O. front Thursday afternoon, a day after silver objects hovered briefly in the skies over western Manhattan.

DealBook loves lists, and Fortune magazine gives us a scrumptious one today with its "40 Under 40" ranking of business's hottest rising stars. (This reporter has about one month until his 40th birthday -- and, alas, has never made this illustrious list -- so our exuberance is somewhat muted this year.)
The Times's Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discussed the debate Wednesday night between the two candidates for Delaware's Senate seat, Chris Coons and Christine O'Donnell.

On Wednesday, Pew Research issued a study suggesting that the failure to include cellphones in a survey sample - and most pollsters don't include them - may bias the results against Democrats. Pew has addressed this subject a number of times before, and in their view, the problem seems to be worsening. Indeed, this is about what you might expect, since the fraction of voters who rely on cellphones is steadily increasing: about 25 percent of the adult population now has no landline phone installed at all.

For its first collaboration with the watchmakers TKO Orlogi, Henri Bendel is turning back the clock to the '90s slap band craze. Like those fun bracelets of yore, the watch's interchangeable straps come in a range of neon colors. At only $50 a pop, the watches are a wallet-friendly alternative to Balenciaga's eye-catching timepieces on the runway for spring.

The Times's Megan Liberman and Frank Bruni discuss how the two Delaware Senate candidates, Chris Coons and Christine O'Donnell, during their debate on Wednesday night, embodied the difficulties each of their political parties is facing this election cycle.

The striking musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra have won a small propaganda coup. A local television station, WADL-TV38, has decided to broadcast one of their concerts, a program on Oct. 24 at a church in the affluent Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. The musicians went on strike on Oct. 4 over wage and benefit cuts and work rule changes at the financially troubled orchestra. They have been playing concerts on their own, to earn publicity and money to support the strike, a common practice in such disputes. The program features Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" and Brahms Symphony No. 2, conducted by Joseph Silverstein.
The Italian actress on working with Sophia Loren, her role in "Baaria" by Giuseppe Tornatore and what she loves about Milan.
Photographs from Lebanon, Afghanistan and Greece.
Shaquille O'Neal still commands the room, even at age 38, even in street clothes, even on nights when he never leaves the bench.

As many as 80 percent of physicians continue to work when they are sick, even though they would have excused patients in the same condition, writes Dr. Pauine Chen in this week's Doctor and Patient column.
A doctor’s decision to keep working while sick may violate the core medical principle of “First, do no harm.”

Dave Itzkoff reports that an interview with the Fox News host Bill O'Reilly on the ABC daytime show "The View" turned heated on Thursday morning, prompting the show's co-hosts Whoopi Goldberg and Joy Behar to walk off the set for a short time.
An occasional assemblage of overheard or underappreciated words - generously emailed by co-vocabularists.

After running underground for two months to preserve his sanity and his body as he awaited rescue along with 32 other miners in the Chilean desert, Edison Peña may have earned himself a unique reward: a seat at the New York City Marathon or, if he desires, an entry.

Updated, 5:47 p.m. | One day after being released from federal prison, a 69-year-old man was shot and wounded by a police officer after trying to hold up a bank branch steps from Penn Station on Thursday afternoon, police officials said.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music has organized a particularly theater-heavy line-up for its spring 2011 season, including a Donmar Warehouse production of "King Lear" starring Derek Jacobi; the Abbey Theater's staging of Ibsen's "John Gabriel Borkman," with Alan Rickman and Fiona Shaw; and an Australian mounting of Gogol's "Diary of a Madman" starring Geoffrey Rush.
Speaking of slow growth, Macroeconomic Advisers, a respected forecasting firm, has just downgraded its estimate for third-quarter annual output growth to a measly 1.2 percent.

Art people have their rituals, especially when it comes to international trade shows. The moment they hit a host town - say, London, where the eighth annual Frieze Art fair opened to V.I.P.'s yesterday - they adopt a pattern of social behavior calculated to produce a buzz. Galleries, museums and auctions houses do their best to whet everyone's appetite for spending money with openings and parties, and visiting dealers, collectors and curators try to be first to spot art that will make the world feel fresh and new.

Steve Fossett, the millionaire businessman and adventurer perhaps best known for circumnavigating the world nonstop in a hot air balloon, was preparing to break the absolute land speed record -- 763 miles per hour -- when he died. He was declared dead after the single-engine plane he was piloting disappeared over the east-central mountains of California in September 2007. (The plane and Mr. Fossett's remains were later discovered near Mammoth Lakes, Calif.)

PASHMUL, Afghanistan - From inside the outpost, the sounds of a gunfight were unmistakable. First the clatter of assault rifles and machine guns, then the sound of rocket-propelled grenades exploding a few hundred yards away. Finally, the report of an 82mm recoilless rifle firing off one big shell, then another, then a third.
Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.
If your laptop happens to be stolen, as mine recently was, it can be a big hassle to protect your data after the fact. That's why it's important to know how to secure your laptop before it's gone.

The Brooklyn district attorney's office impaneled a special grand jury today to look into the death of 4-year-old Marchella Pierce and subpoenaed records from the city's Administration for Children's Services as well as from a city contractor and a hospital that had roles in her care, the office said.

A variety of windfalls - perhaps including book and movie deals and trips to Greece and Graceland- may be on the way for the 33 miners who emerged after being trapped for more than two months beneath the Chilean desert. But already, less than 24 hours after the completion of the globally televised and celebrated rescue, one miner has attracted a singular solicitation: an invitation to the New York City Marathon.

J. K. Rowling, the author of the Harry Potter books, still cannot make a years-old plagiarism charge disappear. A lawsuit in a British court accusing Ms. Rowling of partly copying a 1987 book, "The Adventures of Willy the Wizard," by Adrian Jacobs, may go to trial now that a judge has turned down an application by Ms. Rowling's lawyers to dismiss the case, according to Reuters.

Based on the enticing Travel section article "Tuscany Without the Crowds" (March 7, 2010), my husband and I are planning a week in the Val d'Orcia after Christmas. The problem is: we fly into Milan the week before and don't know where to go over Christmas (we will be in Milan for several days at the end of the trip). We've never been to Venice. Any ideas?

Mozilla, the maker of the open-source Firefox Web browser, said Thursday that it would appoint Gary Kovacs, a veteran software executive, as its new chief executive. The appointment ends a nearly six-month search that began after John Lilly, who has been Mozilla's chief executive for the last three years, announced that he would leave to join Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm.

For more than 50 years, George Vujnovich was a mild-mannered salesman working away at his small business in Queens and living a quiet life on a quiet block in Jackson Heights. He never spoke, even to his closest friends, about his secret role organizing one of the greatest rescue missions of World War II.

For four years, I talked about running the New York City Marathon. But each year I ended up curbside, coffee cup in hand, watching waves of people push themselves to the finish. I would leave the race and say to friends, "I'd really like to run the marathon while I live in New York."

Earlier this year readers who were unhappy with Apple's closed app ecosystem and frustrated with AT&T's spasmodic service asked via e-mail and Twitter if the Android platform could be a real competitor to the iPhone. In a blog post I compared Google's Nexus One phone running the Android operating system to the venerable Apple iPhone.
It's a sad day in techland, writes David Pogue on his blog.

They say you should not judge a book by its cover, but maybe no one told the folks at DC Comics or Quirk Books, who have teamed up for "DC Comics: The 75th Anniversary Poster Book." Inside are 100 covers from the DC archives from three-quarters of a century. The slide show contains some of our favorites from the $40 book.

Yahoo, which is reportedly the target -- or not -- of a potential takeover by AOL and private-equity firms, has been holding meetings with its bankers to prepare itself in the event it receives an offer, people close to the company said.

As my colleagues Michael Powell and Motoko Rich detailed recently, the financial crisis has caused longer-term pain that is expected to last well beyond the confines of the financial panic itself. It has wrought a sort of economic reset, slowing down growth for years to come.

Is the cost of health insurance so out of reach that even when the federal government helps out, many people still can't afford coverage? According to a new analysis by the Employee Benefits Research Institute, the answer may be yes.

Overview | What makes a college essay "work"? How can writers reveal themselves through writing? In this lesson, students explore sample college essays and then consider advice about what separates a great essay from a mediocre or ineffective one as well as essay-writing tips. Finally, they write essays based on the piece of advice that resonated with them.
Do you write about food online or in print, for a magazine or a newspaper? It no longer matters to the James Beard Foundation.

Previously unpublished data from Pfizer shows its antidepressant drug reboxetine is "ineffective and potentially harmful," according to a German research group's report Wednesday, triggering another round of debate about how much information should be publicly disclosed.
Oh, it's a sad day in techland.

Alicia de Larrocha, the great Spanish pianist who died a year ago, will be memorialized in a ceremony at the Manhattan School of Music at 3 p.m. on Oct. 24, the conservatory said. Spain's consulate general is also sponsoring the event. Speakers will include Ms. de Larrocha's daughter, the consul general, the president of the school and record company figures. Performers will include the pianist Joaquin Achucarro, the guitarist Jorge Caballero, the soprano Theresa Santiago and the American String Quartet, the school said.
When I visited college campuses about three decades ago, I put on jeans and sneakers, slung a backpack over my shoulders and rode Amtrak to New Haven, Providence and Boston with a vague schedule.
First came "Couplehood," then came "Babyhood." So where does Paul Reiser go next for the third installment of his best-selling "-hood" book series? "Familyhood," of course.

Anyone who smears raw steak on themselves in public - a gesture of both feral sexuality and absurdity - owes a debt to the Liverpool-born feminist punk artist Linder Sterling. Linder's "menstrual jewelry" (made from absorbent cotton and red nail polish) turned tampons into pretty punk-feminist totems. Her arresting collages from the '70s give girly pop teeth. (See her cover for the Buzzcock's "Orgasm Addict.") And her ethereal wailing, crying and laughter as a member of the British punk band Ludus were the expression of her interest in ritual, religious ecstasy and the torment from her art.
No matter how far the Texas Rangers go in these playoffs, they will have already passed two milestones of sorts when they take the field against the Yankees on Friday night.

This week on Popcast, The Times's music podcast, Melena Ryzik discusses her Arts & Leisure profile of the singer-songwriter Sufjan Stevens, who found indie fame in the middle of the last decade with albums that had lush folk sounds and firm geographical themes ("Michigan," "Illinois"). But for his latest, "The Age of Adz," Mr. Stevens made some big changes, adding layers of electronics and taking inspiration from an obscure outside artist, Royal Robertson.
Apple said Thursday that Verizon Wireless would begin selling the iPad at its stores on Oct. 28.

Training for a marathon is a delicate balancing act for athletes who must push themselves beyond certain limits, but know when to listen to their bodies. Injuries, small and large, can derail the efforts of amateur runners or some of the best in the marathon business. This week, the two-time champion Martin Lel of Kenya and his compatriot Robert Cheruiyot announced they would pull out of New York because of injuries. Lel, who won New York in 2003 and 2007, has a leg injury. Cheruiyot, the four-time Boston Marathon champion who finished second in New York last year, has a groin-muscle injury.

I moved to Milan in 1949, when my parents left Piacenza to take advantage of the opportunities for work and advancement that Milan offered after the war. In spite of the depth of the attachment that I feel to the city in which I have built my career, I am always aware that Milan does have its shortcomings and that it lies at times in thrall to a prevailing mood of melancholy, which has perhaps altered its character and diminished its sense of optimism, its capacity to think big and retain the confidence to accomplish its ambitions. As the Italian capital of financial activity and the world capital of fashion, design and opera, Milan derives its unique strength, I believe, from its capacity to promote a continuous flow of creative ideas and harness them into successful commercial ventures. I love this city most when its sense of discipline is evident, expressed through its citizens' work ethic and ability to plan on a large scale. I also love its rational approach - one driven by passion and generosity. (It's no coincidence that Milan is the center of the nation's charitable sector.) I hope that the optimism and the characteristic determination of the Milanese will provide a much-needed stimulus to the public sector, because the greater one's love for a city, the more one expects from it. From this perspective, Expo 2015 could be the turning point, the opportunity to boost Milan's prestige and provide the perfect arena to reassert our claim to greatness.
Spark Capital, the Boston-based venture capital firm that has investments in Twitter, Tumblr and Boxee, has created a new fund to invest in Web and digital media companies.

This week I travel to Deauville, France, to attend the sixth Women's Forum for the Economy and Society, an annual meeting that brings together influential women -- and men -- from around the world. Described as "Davos for Women," the forum was founded by French entrepreneur Aude de Thuin, who saw a need to give voice to the other half of the population after she failed to receive an invitation to the predominantly male gathering in the Swiss Alps. The 2010 forum will focus on change in politics, the economy, the environment, global health, and the steps necessary to enable progress in all by facilitating full participation by women.

Skepticism runs high on the Clean Development Mechanism, a carbon offset program created by the Kyoto Protocol. The program allows companies in industrialized countries to earn carbon credits by sponsoring greenhouse gas reduction projects in developing countries. Large numbers of credits have been given for the construction of hydroelectric dams in China, however, which experts call an abuse of the system. [The International Herald Tribune]

Milan's annual design week, Salone Internazionale del Mobile, turns 50 next April. As part of the global run-up to the festivities, New York will host ''I Saloni Milano in New York,'' a six-week program starting Nov. 29 that will bring a taste of the design world's reigning extravaganza to Manhattan. It's a mini-Salone, in which 20 Italian furniture showrooms (including B&B Italia, Flos and Poltrona Frau) will host ''Italian Christmas'' exhibitions; the director Peter Greenaway's Milan-centric video installation, ''Leonardo's Last Supper: A Vision'' (above), which was seen at the Salone in 2008, will take over the Park Avenue Armory; and the theater visionary Robert Wilson will create video portraits of Roberto Bolle, who dances at La Scala, interacting with an assortment of iconic design objects (Nov. 30 through Dec. 18 at Center 548). Design has always been close to Wilson's heart. ''When I was 8 years old,'' he says, ''in the middle of the night I took all the plates and glasses out of the kitchen closet and put them back in the shelves in a designed order.'' Perfetto.

Call me naïve. Some years ago -- never mind how long precisely -- having no literary project on the boards, I thought I would open a small fish joint in this watery end of the world. Little did I imagine the sheer volume of human beings with whom I would come into contact on a daily, no, hourly basis. All manner of humans: professional, half-formed and holy humans; newbies and wannabes; multilingual, minimally trained, overqualified, fried, rehabbing, should-be-rehabbing humans; ambitious people, passionate people and degenerate people. They surround you like the ocean. You could drown in them. They keep you afloat. They are exhausting.
